fields.headline: Title is fine - but it's Europe that counts
fields.trailText: A championship hat-trick is still sufficiently rare in English football to be worth a second glance... but the trick on which the success of their season now depends is Europe.
fields.body:
A championship hat-trick is still sufficiently rare in English football to be worth a second glance. Yet such are the changed priorities among top clubs that no sooner have Manchester United joined Huddersfield Town, Arsenal and Liverpool in winning the league for a third successive season than their minds are elsewhere.

For United the reality is that pulling domestic titles out of a hat like the flags of all nations is not the trick on which the success of their season now depends. Unless Sir Alex Ferguson's players can overturn a 1-0 deficit against Bayern Munich at the Olympic stadium on Wednesday to reach the European Cup semi-finals, a seventh Premiership title in nine years will be a matter for consolation, not celebration.

Gary Neville put it rather well after Middlesbrough's unlikely 3-0 win at Highbury on Saturday afternoon - and their own earlier 4-2 victory over Coventry City - had confirmed Manchester United as champions once more. "I think this is the first time a championship has been won but not celebrated," the United defender declared.

"Our minds have got to be totally focused on Wednesday's game in Munich. Our last two league games have been preparation for Bayern. We've got to go there and come away with no regrets."

More than a continued interest in this season's European Cup will depend on Wednesday's result. This match might have greater implications for the future development of the side.

"Wednesday will show whether we are still capable of winning against the best teams in Europe," Ferguson insisted yesterday. "And how we do there will make our minds up on quite a few things."

This sounds like a coded warning that, unless Manchester United do better in the European Cup this season than they did last, changes are on the way. Sublime though a number of United's displays have been this season they played their best football in the Premiership before Christmas, since when their results have been more consistent than their performances.

Away from home in the Champions League, moreover, their record is poor. One victory in six games, with particularly poor performances against PSV Eindhoven, Anderlecht and Panathinaikos, does not bode well for United's chances of beating Bayern, for whom Carsten Jancker must be licking his lips after watching Coventry's John Hartson outjumping Ferguson's defence on Saturday.

Ferguson will put his faith in Manchester United's ability to save their best performances for the least promising circumstances. "My team is always at its best when it's on the edge," he says. Yet already the United manager must be thinking about how he would like the side to evolve next season, at the end of which he is due to retire.

Even when Liverpool were winning the championship with comparable regularity Anfield paid as much attention to the next team as the one getting the medals. So it was with Manchester United after Ferguson had narrowly missed out on a hat-trick in 1995: David Beckham, Paul Scholes, Nicky Butt and Gary and Phil Neville came in as regulars after Paul Ince, Mark Hughes and Andrei Kanchelskis had moved on, with Steve Bruce following a year later.

This has to be the way of it if the kind of success United have achieved since the early 90s is to be maintained and Ferguson is more aware than anybody of the dangers of complacency - Ferguson, that is, and Roy Keane, who has been the team's severest critic this season.

The backbone of the side looks as sound as ever. At £7.8m Fabien Barthez has proved a bargain. But for him United's interest in the Champions League would already be confined to an armchair in front of the TV screen.

It says much for United's ability to improvise that they broke the back of the championship contest largely without the authority at centre-back of Jaap Stam, who was kept out by injury from the end of August to mid-January. The versatility of Gary Neville allied to the early maturity of Wes Brown had much to do with this.

The ease with which one player can fill in for another remains an essential strength of this side. When Dwight Yorke went broody, in stepped Teddy Sheringham to form a prolific partnership with Andy Cole. Sheringham is United's leading scorer with 20 goals and, if, assuming Ruud van Nistelrooy is signed from PSV, Ferguson then sells a striker, Yorke would be favourite to go.

Paul Scholes and Ryan Giggs have had their best seasons to date, Beckham his best half-season. Meanwhile Keane remains the essential driving force, a giant of an all-round footballer who so regularly makes the right choices that it is taken for granted. Old Trafford still wants to see Keane's presence in the side for a few years yet.

The Premiership needs a tighter contest next time and maybe Leeds United will help provide it. A championship which is a foregone conclusion by Christmas and all over by Easter has limited appeal.

Saturday's TV-oriented staggered kick-off times did not help the dramatic effect either. The crown of English football was found under a Middlesbrough mulberry bush while the winners were making their way home from Old Trafford.

The hat-trick heroes

Huddersfield Town (1924-26)

Under Herbert Chapman, Town were the team of the 20s. Chapman joined Arsenal after the second win, but Cecil Potter kept the title in Yorkshire.

Arsenal (1933-35)

Arsenal won their first championship in 1931, before earning a further First Division title in 1933. Chapman again missed out on three in a row, having died from pneumonia in January 1934.

Liverpool (1982-84)

The Anfield club won five titles in nine years before this run. Sadly Bill Shankly died in September '81 and was not around to see it. Bob Paisley retired in 1983 with Joe Fagan becoming manager for the hat-trick season.

Manchester United (1999-2001)

Sir Alex Ferguson became the first manager in England to win three successive league titles.

fields.headline: Ferguson in seventh heaven
fields.standfirst: Champagne corks pop as manager toasts league victory
fields.trailText: In the end it was handed to Manchester United on a plate, their seventh title since the Premiership began in 1992, their third in a row, their 14th in total. Sir Alex Ferguson's side are as dominant now as Liverpool in the 70s and 80s and who is to say that they will not match the Anfield all-comers' record of 18 league championships?
fields.body:
In the end it was handed to Manchester United on a plate, their seventh title since the Premiership began in 1992, their third in a row, their 14th in total. Sir Alex Ferguson's side are as dominant now as Liverpool in the 70s and 80s and who is to say that they will not match the Anfield all-comers' record of 18 league championships?

That it came with a whimper rather than a bang will bother the club not a jot, a noon kick-off and Middlesbrough's later win at Arsenal having relieved United of the ballyhoo that surrounds the achievement. Now they can focus on Wednesday night in Munich and leave the celebrations until May 5 when they will receive the trophy at home to Derby County.

Old Trafford was practically deserted on Saturday when the news came through, although Ferguson had waited around with friends and staff and was photographed popping bottles of champagne. "Somebody told me it was 2-0 up to Middlesbrough and I turned on the telly and I couldn't believe it," he said. "To win the title is a fantastic feeling because it's the true test of the best team in the country."

The captain Roy Keane was not even watching for the result: "I'm not really bothered to be honest - we're just thinking about Wednesday." But Gary Neville had been paying attention and on Radio 5 he took issue with those who dared to suggest that United have profited from a weak Premiership this season.

"We've heard a lot arguments, especially in the last two weeks, about why we didn't perform against Bayern, and that's one of the reasons that's been mentioned - that it's not a competitive league," he said. "But I wonder how Liverpool have got to the semi-final of the Uefa Cup, Arsenal and Leeds are on the brink of the semi-finals of the Champions League, yet we're not in a competitive league."

The suggestion that winning the title while not playing had taken the gloss off was also kicked into touch. After all, United had ended a 26-year title drought when Aston Villa presented them with their first Premiership in 1993 by losing at home to Oldham. "Even though the circumstances are a bit strange it doesn't matter because you know you have achieved something special," said Ferguson.

He now has one championship more than Bob Paisley - who won six with Liverpool - to add to his three with Aberdeen. He is also the only manager to have won three English titles in a row.

Perhaps it was symbolic that Ferguson's former winger at Aberdeen, Gordon Strachan, should be on the opposition bench on Saturday to act as a reminder of the magnitude of his achievements - and also the nerve-shredding nature of his United teams.

Defence has never been United's strong point and a marauding John Hartson caused havoc in their back four, shooting past the debutant Andy Goram to put Coventry City ahead, then heading an equaliser after Dwight Yorke had helped himself to two goals. Typically United left it late, Ryan Giggs's looping header nine minutes from time restoring their advantage and Paul Scholes's long-range special putting the match beyond doubt.

Coventry must now pick themselves up for today's visit by Sunderland. "We need to go for wins all the time," said Strachan. The message from United was more ominous. "We want to keep winning and improving until we are regarded as one of the greatest teams of all time," said David Beckham.

 Coventry's Australia international John Aloisi could be out for a month after tearing a hamstring in Saturday's 2-0 World Cup qualifying win over Fiji.

fields.headline: Fulham reach their Premier goal
fields.trailText: Craven Cottage will be a riot of noise and colour and silly hats today as Fulham fans prepare to call a halt to their weekend-long promotion party to begin another in celebration of the First Division title.
fields.byline: Roy Collins at the McAlpine stadium
fields.body:
Craven Cottage will be a riot of noise and colour and silly hats today as Fulham fans prepare to call a halt to their weekend-long promotion party to begin another in celebration of the First Division title.

But Fulham's players, who did not allow themselves even a sniff of the barmaid's apron after this victory restored them to the top flight after a 33-year wait, are looking far beyond the point required against Sheffield Wednesday to make them champions.

Assuming they manage it - and that is not taking much for granted - it would be easy for them to showboat through the rest of the season, counting down the days to the visits of Liverpool, Arsenal and, of course, Chelsea next season.

But Lee Clark, who helped Sunderland achieve a Nationwide First Division record points haul of 105 two years ago, said: "Our first goal is to win the title and then to beat that record. If we can do that, it will tell us that we should be good enough to compete at the highest level.

"Sunderland went straight back down after winning promotion through the play-offs in 1997 but the side were much more confident after our achievements two years ago."

Clark was also a key player in Newcastle's title romp in 1992-93 under Kevin Keegan, the first season of the new First Division.

Clark says: "Newcastle went on to become a Premiership force after that and now Sunderland have as well; that's what we're aiming for."

He is aware, of course, that his team's performances will have a decisive effect on the other end of the table. Sheffield Wednesday probably consider themselves former relegation candidates after their recent run but the Huddersfield manager Lou Macari, whose team are most definitely not, would not take kindly to below-par Fulham performances against Portsmouth on Saturday and Grimsby in their final game.

Macari has actually steadied the Huddersfield ship, taking them into this game on a five-match unbeaten run including three successive clean sheets.

The chances of another game without conceding a goal, though, looked slim when the Fulham manager Jean Tigana decided that Luis Boa Morte, who was returning from suspension, was ready to resume his striking partnership with Louis Saha. But, for all Fulham's pretty football, which ended in a stream of almost comical missed chances, it was not until the 85th minute that Boa Morte slipped home a delightful winner after the Huddersfield keeper Nico Vaesen's Barthez-style rush outside his area.

The central defender Chris Lucketti, despite his name, found fortune hiding when Boa Morte fell spectacularly following his challenge and Saha scored the penalty for his 29th goal of the season.

Both Huddersfield and Fulham seemed resigned to that 65th-minute effort being enough to settle things until Delroy Facey took advantage of a rare Kit Symons mistake to equalise.

Fulham, although they need only a point today, will be looking to win the title in style and, despite fears that they might prove too fragile for the Premiership, they look more than capable of holding their own. They have, it seems, already secured the services of the giant Czech Jan Koller from Anderlecht. And Tigana has been promised by the club's owner Mohammed Al Fayed that he can have any money he wants to strengthen his team.

webTitle: Councils face financial crisis over foot and mouth

fields.headline: Councils face financial crisis over foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The cost of handling the fallout from the foot and mouth crisis could decimate the budgets of district councils in the worst affected areas, with one authority already facing a "serious" financial crisis.
fields.body:
The cost of handling the fallout from the foot and mouth crisis could decimate the budgets of district councils in the worst affected areas, with one authority already facing a "serious" financial crisis.

Tory councillors at South Lakeland district council claim that, if the crisis comes to an end around the beginning of June, their authority could have used up around £2m of its £11.2m annual budget.

In their response to a survey carried out by the Conservative Party, South Lakeland councillors claimed they were already laying off part-time and seasonal staff. They said: "Unless the government can give the 100% rate relief for the business community, we are looking at a serious financial problem."

Much of the cost will come from providing business rate relief to local businesses affected by the outbreak - authorities must make up between 5% and 25% of the bill.

The Local Government Association (LGA) and the Tories are both calling for the government to meet the full costs, but the Treasury is resistant. It hopes to maintain an incentive for councils to confine the rate break to badly affected businesses.

Tory environment spokesman Damian Green said: "Conservatives have called on the government to introduce a business rate holiday for firms in badly hit areas, with 100% rate relief funded by central government rather than local taxpayers."

Carlisle city council has also been hard hit by the crisis, and Tory councillors claim the costs of rate relief, advice centres and accommodating agriculture ministry officials could reach £250,000 - 5% of the city's council tax income.

Oxfordshire said it has lost £120,000 because it was forced to close educational residential centres, and East Devon district council faces a soaring bill for cleaning beaches, as dog owners switch to the shoreline instead of fields.

The LGA is pushing ministers to provide more emergency funding for councils if this kind of additional cost reaches significant levels.

The Tories claim that the costs, taken together, will force up next year's council tax bills.

webTitle: Top of the NHS is no place for women

fields.headline: Top of the NHS is no place for women
fields.standfirst: The new top management team assembled by NHS chief executive Nigel Crisp is all men. Will women ever have a place at the top of the health service? Patrick Butler investigates
fields.trailText: The new top management team assembled by NHS chief executive Nigel Crisp is all men. WIll women ever have a place at the top of the health service? Patrick Butler investigates.
fields.body:
There is something familiar about the shiny new top management team assembled by NHS chief executive Nigel Crisp to drive forward health service "modernisation" - they are, in time-honoured fashion, all men.

Last week, the latest singularly white middle-aged males to take their seat at the top table were unveiled: David Fillingham, the new head of the NHS modernisation agency; and Andrew Foster, the new director of human resources.

They follow recently recruited finance director Richard Douglas; Hugh Taylor, promoted at Christmas to director of external and corporate affairs; and Neil McKay, promoted to chief operating officer last year.

Women, it would appear, have no place in Mr Crisp's "six-pack" top team - although be fair, he did appoint Barbara Stocking as head of the modernisation agency, only for her to quit, within weeks of taking up the job.

Few would dispute that the big six are not eminently qualified for their jobs. But in an organisation where the majority of staff are female, and which is pledged to overhaul its self-confessed outdated culture and practices, the male domination is a little unfortunate.

"I don't think it's a conspiracy. The pool of candidates that Nigel Crisp can choose from will consist predominantly of men. There are organisational forces at work in the fact that there are so few women in this pool," says Valerie James, a fellow of the King's Fund, the NHS policy think-tank.

This is partly because NHS management careers are "gendered".

Women are good at running so-called "soft" community, mental health and disability trusts, goes the cultural perception, while men tend to handle better the "hard" acute and teaching hospital jobs.

It is the latter post, with the unspoken assumption that only men can deal with the teams of arrogant male medical consultants found in acute trusts, which is traditionally seen as the essential training ground for the top departmental level management positions.

Ms James believes more essential gender differences are also at work: "Women and men operate differently in organisations. Women want to focus on getting the job done as best they can. Men focus on career progression, and have a much greater 'political' awareness."

For years the NHS has been striving to increase the numbers of women in top management positions, but although several high fliers have made it to trust and health authority chief executive status, few have made it to the very top.

Apart from a succession of chief nurses at the Department of Health (DoH) - the most recent of whom, Sarah Mullally, is an ex-trust chief executive - few females have made it through to the upper echelons of management.

The formidable and outspoken Sheila Masters (who came from the private sector to become NHS executive director of finance in the late 1980s) was a brief, if controversial, success in a notoriously masculine world.

Ms Stocking was for years the great female hope, the only non-male NHS regional director. She unsuccessfully applied for the chief executive post which went to Mr Crisp, and despite getting the modernisation agency job, she swiftly leapt at the chance to become the (lower paid) chief executive at Oxfam, the aid charity. . fields.headline: Lauren Laverne
fields.standfirst:
Spitz, London
***
fields.trailText:
Spitz, London
***
fields.body:
After the brazen confidence of childhood comes the tricky growing-up bit. For Lauren Laverne, leaving behind the punk-pop of her teen years spent in Kenickie to perform solo means having to deal with guitars that won't tune properly, strings that break and feedback that dampens a mood of melancholy fuelled by songs of love and heartbreak.

At least Laverne has always been older than her years. Although Kenickie specialised in energetic anthems to lipstick and high heels, it was with a wink and giddy intelligence. Since Kenickie abruptly ended in 1997, Laverne has dabbled in TV presenting before returning to the charts last year with Don't Falter, a collaboration with Mint Royale. Now armed with some new songs, she's back. "You can see by my horizontal stripes that I'm a bit of a risk taker," she says, drawing attention to her Blondie-esque, shocking-pink and black top, "and that applies to all areas of my life."

Including her music. Gone are the shouty singalongs of yesterday - here is Laverne does Dido, with a bit of Saint Etienne and the Cardigans thrown in. Her breathy, ultra-girlie vocals now adorn mellow, waltz-like rhythms. To Have a Home sets the tone, Laverne swaying to her brother Johnny's gentle guitar, her voice seductive yet innocent.

Then the problems start. Her guitar packs up and Laverne turns to a keyboard for a lullaby version of Don't Falter. When a replacement Gibson is found, Jack Klugman's Dream begins, repeating the chilled-out formula. And that's the real problem. Laverne stays in the same groove, straying just once for a bit of bubblegum pop, and after a while it all sounds the same. The only inspired moment comes with a cover of Whitesnake's Is This Love, the crashing chords and posturing stripped away, replaced by confusion and sweetness.

So it's lucky that Laverne is so entertaining. Chatty, cool and compelling, she's too astute to think the transition from indie kid to solo diva is going to be easy. "I don't apologise for any of my mistakes, they're part of my charm," she tells us. The attitude is still there after all.

fields.headline: Buena Vista's spectacular bassist
fields.standfirst:
Orlando Lopez
Royal Festival Hall, London
*****
fields.trailText:
Orlando Lopez
Royal Festival Hall, London
*****
fields.body:
Usually you have to close your eyes and put your imagination into hyperdrive to kid yourself you're in a Havana nightclub when really you're in the sober Royal Festival Hall. But this show, part of the La Linea Latin music festival, went as close as it gets without hallucinating.

Since the rhythm section for bassist Orlando "Cachaito" Lopez's band is the same exhilarating outfit that powers the Buena Vista Social Club, perhaps that isn't surprising. Audiences for these musicians turn up dressed for action, feet itching to pile down to the front as soon as the ushers look the other way. That was the finale for this spectacular concert - about half the packed house clamouring to get close to one of the unexpected musical success stories of the past decade, while the dapper, gleaming Ibrahim Ferrer danced back and forth at the stage edge, grasping outstretched hands.

But this long, varied show wasn't a Buena Vista evening: it was bassist Cachaito's night. Many pieces kicked in with his distinctively un-basslike sound - raised in a percussion culture, Cachaito beats the soundbox as much as he plucks the strings, and phrases in short, unsustained sounds, like a conga player. The programme merged the usual Cuban-dance shuffles with a scratchy DJ, flat-out jazz-sax blasts, dub reggae, and a visit from Rokia Traore's exuberant flautist Magic Malik.

Pee Wee Ellis was scheduled to take care of the tenor-sax sermons, but the second saxophonist, Jimmy Jenks, took his place with a series of free-rolling postbop variations that helped replace the relaxed urbanity of the Buena Vistas with a more rugged directness.

Traditional, loping Cuban pieces shifted into Charles Mingus themes (Cachaito is a Mingus admirer of old), allowing Jenks to hurtle into straight-ahead jazz orbit. The rhythm section of Miguel "Anga" Diaz on congas, Carlos Gonzalez on bongos and the delightfully indolent-looking Amadito Valdes on timbales confirmed that this was a project that started with a rhythm section and worked outwards. Diaz was on devastating form, both solo and in eloquent conversation with everyone who crossed his path, including the choppy Hammond organ sounds of Jamaican Bigga Morrison.

Manuel Galban's strange, skewed 1950s guitar sounds mingled with gracefully intricate, gliding violin arrangements from a string section in evening dress. Trombones curled luxurious lines around each other and, in a sublime moment, combined on a high sustained sound through which the glowing voice of a then-unseen Ibrahim Ferrer suddenly shone, a spectacularly stage-crafted entrance.

The closing episodes involving the turntable soloist DJ Nasty added a streetlife clamour that jacked up the percussion fervour still more, and brought the crowd to its feet. The willowy Magic Malik, delivering an extraordinary flute solo of delicate flutterings, fierce yelping sounds, stuttery speech and runs of sustained grace, could have been the unintended star of the show in other circumstances. But the show itself was the star.

webTitle: Theatre review: Big Trouble in the Little Bedroom

fields.headline: Another Viking invasion in York
fields.standfirst:
Big Trouble in the Little Bedroom
Theatre Royal, York
***
fields.trailText:
Big Trouble in the Little Bedroom
Theatre Royal, York
***
fields.body:
The recent refit of the Jorvik Viking Centre in York cost £5m. John Godber's nonsensical Nordic saga was probably knocked together for about 5p - but it has always been fun to watch Hull Truck making big noises on a little budget.

Big Trouble in the Little Bedroom is a hilarious piece of hokum about a Viking hammer, set to a snappy pop arrangement by John Pattison. It is probably best described as what might happen if Wagner's Ring cycle were serialised in the Beano.

Simple Stan finds his homework project - locating a Viking-styled implement - a great deal easier when the hammer of Thor the thunder god turns up in his bedroom, followed by the deity himself. When Stan relinquishes the tool to the school bully, our puny hero has to prove himself worthy of the hammer while its owner is enslaved by his mum to help around the house.

Godber's idea grew out of his daughter's obsession with Vikings, and a curiosity as to what might happen if one appeared. The result is something all ages can enjoy, though you might need to be under 10 in order to understand it.

The cast of six have a great time behaving like a bunch of kids. Lucy Cullingford's dance sequences are slick and knowingly camp - check out the funky Motown dentists and the Step-tacular line-dance routine. Pip Leckenby's serviceable set offsets the mystery of the fjords with the detritus of a teenage bedroom, so far as such things are possible. Vocals are enthusiastic rather than outstanding, and there's not a live musician in sight - but this is Hull Truck, not the Huddersfield Choral Society.

Of course, if Thor were to suddenly materialise in York, he'd be forced to pose with a group of Japanese tourists. Foreign invasions take quite a different form these days.

 At the Hull Truck Theatre, Hull (01482 323638), from Wednesday until May 5.

fields.headline: One Love
fields.standfirst:
Old Vic, Bristol
**
fields.trailText:
Old Vic, Bristol
**
fields.body:
Really good theatre can sometimes seem like a religious experience, but I've yet to see religion make good theatre. Kwame Dawes's musical play, or dubaretta as it is rather wittily called, is a celebration of Rastafarianism and spirituality. Too often it feels like Sunday school rather than theatre.

Inspired by Roger Mais's early-1950s novel Brotherman, Dawes relocates the story to 1970s Jamaica, where cobbler and healer Brotherman helps the sick and the poor, dreams of building a school to provide education for all and is given a hard time by the local police force and those who think that Rastas are wasters who just sit around smoking weed all day.

In between strong Christ-like motifs, the play interweaves the stories of several characters, all connected with Brotherman. These include his former lover Girlie, who left him for the corrupt Papacita who now beats her; Cordelia, who is driven mad by her sick baby and who eventually does the Judas on Brotherman; and Minnette, the young woman who loves him.

The show really gets moving and is at its most enjoyable in the musical numbers, but the story barely holds together and is sometimes quite confusing. The itsy-bitsiness of the script's short scenes is exacerbated by a set design that slides up and down, this way and that, in a most distracting manner. The script is not in good enough shape for production, and, although director Yvonne Brewster and her cast do their best to paper over the cracks, they can't hide the fact that the foundations of this show are pretty shaky.

It is also a curious mixture of social realism and mysticism. On one hand, it depicts a corrupt society where the police behave as they want, picking on Rastas and planting evidence. On the other, it depicts Brotherman less as a victim of these injustices than as a mystic martyr, who apparently dies and rises from the dead to preach peace and love.

He is not a guy to get excited about and not entirely sympathetic. "Jah give it and Jah take it away," is his laconic comment on Cordelia's infanticide and suicide. Towards the end the play descends into melodrama as the corpses pile up.

The singing is fantastic, Peter Straker as the greasy yet strangely attractive Papacita lights up the stage whenever he appears, and the show is big, bold and colourful. But the script needs a lot more work to cut the mustard.

 Until April 28. Box office: 0117-987 7877.

fields.headline: Pension posers
fields.standfirst:
Rather than taking out a stakeholder pension, you might be better off spending now and relying on means-tested benefits in your old age

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Rather than taking out a stakeholder pension, you might be better off spending now and relying on means-tested benefits in your old age.
fields.body:
The stakeholder pension launched this month signals New Labour's commitment to the privatisation of old-age provision started under Margaret Thatcher. Indeed, Labour says it intends to reverse the current balance between the state and private sector so that in future the private sector makes up 60% of all pension provision, compared to its 40% share now. The Blair government calls this a new partnership. Individuals take greater responsibility for their financial well-being in later life by saving more in private pension schemes.

This privatisation is risky both for the individual considering buying into a stakeholder pension and for society at large.

Choosing the right pension for your circumstances is complex. There are now at least seven distinct vehicles for providing income in later life. Stakeholder pensions increase this choice without making provision for better advice; it is likely more people will end up with the wrong sort. At first sight the 1% cap on charges levied by companies offering stakeholder pensions works in favour of the consumer. But it gives pension companies scant incentive to make advice available at a time when people are in need of more information than ever. They have already begun to lay off their direct-sales teams.

It is difficult to plan for events such as the needs of children or older relatives, unemployment and early retirement. Things happen that may make a stakeholder pension a bad savings vehicle. People might be better off remaining in the state system or putting their money into an ISA, which offers more flexible access to savings.

People may not be able to contribute enough to their stakeholder pensions to make them worthwhile. The table estimates how much you would need to save from a given age in order to secure a weekly income. It assumes a 3% real rate of return and 6% annuity rate. Focus on that £30 a week figure. Gordon Brown has increased the generosity of the minimum income guarantee for older people (MIG) - but by doing so the government has ensured that more and more will find themselves dependent on the state in later life.

Currently, to avoid making a claim on the means-tested MIG would require a stakeholder pension income of at least £30 a week. By 2060, this figure is more likely to be in the region of £100 (in current prices). That means a person who saves continuously from the age of 25 would need to put aside approximately £22 a week to achieve such an income. Delaying this decision is going to be costly - the required amount of savings rises to £62 a week for those who save for only 20 years. Are such levels of saving realistic? Stakeholder pensions are meant for those on low and modest incomes, with the typical case taken to be someone with annual earnings of £12,000. At this level, a 25-year-old would need to contribute 9.5% of gross earnings, the 35-year-old 15%. A 45-year-old would need to contribute more than a quarter (27%) of gross earnings to make a stakeholder pension worthwhile. Spending today and relying on the state tomorrow might be a more attractive choice.

Taking out a stakeholder pension also exposes individuals to risks related to the City's performance. You may be unfortunate in the choice of provider, as Equitable Life policy-holders have found. Pension companies may invest in poorly performing shares or you may retire on a day the stock market takes a downturn.

The fact that those with a stakeholder pension, just like those with other forms of private pension, are obliged to purchase an annuity adds another form of risk. Annuity rates fluctuate widely. In 1990 a pension pot of £100,000 would have purchased an annual income of £11,000. Today the same amount will produce just £6,000. Annuities are calculated according to predicted life expectancy: because women live longer on average, they receive a lower income for their pension pot. The current sex differential in annuity rates means that women need a pension pot between one-fifth and one-sixth higher than men in order to achieve the same income. But interrupted working lives and lower earnings mean women are less able to build up pension savings.

Taken as a whole, these risks will have important consequences for the level of income and welfare enjoyed by the older population. As the basic state pension declines in real value over time, additional pensions will have to work harder to fill the gap. Individual welfare will increasingly depend on the pension pot you personally accumulate. The scope for redistributing between rich and poor, men and women, employed and unemployed is reduced as we shift further towards private provision. As a consequence, inequalities in working life will be perpetuated into later life.

State pension systems were originally conceived of as a mechanism for pooling risk, and spreading its consequences across society as a whole. A pay-as-you-go pension system is effectively a government promise based on the tax money of those not yet born. Privatisation of pensions substitutes this promise for that of returns from the financial markets. Striking the right balance between public and private depends upon how you view the trade-off between the risks of financial bad weather and those of political u-turns. Whether stakeholder pensions and increasing reliance on the private sector turn out right remains to be seen.

 Jane Falkingham and Katherine Rake are at the London School of Economics

The fact that those with a stakeholder pension, just like those with other forms of private pension, are obliged to purchase an annuity adds another form of risk. Annuity rates fluctuate widely. In 1990 a pension pot of £100,000 would have purchased an annual income of £11,000. Today the same amount will produce just £6,000. Annuities are calculated according to predicted life expectancy: because women live longer on average, they receive a lower income for their pension pot. The current sex differential in annuity rates means that women need a pension pot between one-fifth and one-sixth higher than men in order to achieve the same income. But interrupted working lives and lower earnings mean women are less able to build up pension savings. Taken as a whole, these risks will have important consequences for the level of income and welfare enjoyed by the older population. As the basic state pension declines in real value over time, additional pensions will have to work harder to fill the gap. Individual welfare will increasingly depend on the pension pot you personally accumulate. The scope for redistributing between rich and poor, men and women, employed and unemployed is reduced as we shift further towards private provision. As a consequence, inequalities in working life will be perpetuated into later life. State pension systems were originally conceived of as a mechanism for pooling risk, and spreading its consequences across society as a whole. A pay-as-you-go pension system is effectively a government promise based on the tax money of those not yet born. Privatisation of pensions substitutes this promise for that of returns from the financial markets. Striking the right balance between public and private depends upon how you view the trade-off between the risks of financial bad weather and those of political u-turns. Whether stakeholder pensions and increasing reliance on the private sector turn out right remains to be seen.  Jane Falkingham and Katherine Rake are at the London School of Economics Useful link: www.lse.ac.uk

fields.headline: Alina Cojocaru joins ballet's greats
fields.standfirst:
Giselle
Royal Opera House, London
****
fields.trailText:
Giselle
Royal Opera House, London
****
fields.body:
By the time Alina Cojocaru reached the second act of her debut performance of Giselle on Saturday, you felt that history was watching over your shoulder. You sensed the ranks of great ballerinas who have previously performed the role jostling to make space for her. You felt that flukey thrill of being in exactly the right place at the right time. Even if Cojocaru never dances this well again she'll be written into the books as one of the rare talents of the ballet stage.

Describing her performance one might wish there were a sweetie jar of superlatives reserved for the event, except that Cojocaru has a simplicity that resists gaudiness and gush. She doesn't flaunt the dextrous dazzle of Sylvie Guilleme, performing hyperbolic feats of virtuosity that can jigger up a whole audience; nor does she move with the lovely, reckless physicality of Darcey Bussell. Even though she's only 19, she opens herself up to the music and the choreography as if she were their special instrument.

Physically, the qualities that make Cojocaru's Giselle outstanding are ones her fans have already registered. Her tiny body moves with precocious speed, scale and assurance, which allow her to glide over the surface of most technical challenges, while she has an instinct for music that takes her deep inside the logic of a given role. In Act One of Giselle she dances with a peculiar artless intensity - blown about by the lilting energy of her steps. In Act Two she is sustained and exquisite. We don't register individual moves so much as the steady rising arc of her whole interpretation.

For such a junior dancer, this displays a startling maturity; yet it's Cojocaru's youth that clinches her current interpretation. Though she doesn't register as a gifted actress - the way Sarah Wildor does, for instance - she communicates emotion with a shocking lack of guile. Her mad scene features details of mime that might be edited out, except that her body looks so broken with pain you're not even sure she's acting. She conveys Giselle's love for Albrecht with a tenderness that grows into an ache.

Johan Kobborg as Albrecht looks as bemused and entranced as we feel, but he must also take wads of credit for Cojocaru's performance. He is almost as unguarded and hungry as she is and his partnering is so musical it allows her to fly.

Romantic ballet of the 19th century spawned a whole critical poetic - sublime, misty, soft as thistledown - which has become cobwebby with age. Kobborg and Cojocaru blow away the dust.

 In rep until May 16. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

fields.headline: Welcome to prawn hell
fields.trailText: Galatasaray, one step from the European Cup final, are hit by a cash and culture crisis
fields.body:
Life at Galatasaray is one big contradiction. While they are enjoying unparalleled success on the field, they are enduring a crisis on the balance sheet. Their budget is shot to pieces. Capital from business partners that was supposed to fund colossal player salaries never materialised. Inter Milan haven't stumped up a bean of the whopping transfer fee for Hakan Sukur, and the clubs are due to go to Fifa arbitration next month. There is no cash flow. The coach, Mircea Lucescu, hasn't been paid all season.

And yet somehow the Turkish club line up in the Champions League quarter-finals on Wednesday, taking a narrow 3-2 advantage to European Cup holders Real Madrid. They are convinced that the slim lead - given to them by their goal addict Mario Jardel - will be enough to guarantee their place in the last four.

It is just as well for Galatasaray that Jardel has such an unquenchable passion for Champions League football. The Brazilian, who has added another nine goals in the competition this season, including qualifiers, refused to play in the domestic league recently in protest at late payment of players' wages - another symptom of the crisis at the club.

But he cannot resist a humdinger of a European challenge, and scored the winning goal that gives the Uefa Cup holders their advantage in the Bernabeu on Wednesday. Yet so unhappy is he about his club's financial squeeze that he is expected to seek a new employer in the summer. Benfica, Milan, and Olympique Marseille want him.

Money is a source of huge frustration to the Turkish flagbearers, who have seen all their cosmic plans to turn Gala into an international superclub stymied by the economic problems afflicting the country. Last autumn their potential seemed limitless as they sold $20 million of stock to an American company that also owns Vasco de Gama in Brazil, planned to increase their war chest by floating on the stock exchange and were preparing to build a swanky new stadium. Then the Turkish lira collapsed, their investors backed off, and the dreams went on the back burner.

'Nobody knows when we can start again, but I don't see it happening in 2001,' says marketing director Sinan Kalpakcioglu, 'In fact the only good thing in Turkey this year is Galatasaray.' For Kalpakcioglu, a US-certified accountant whose grandfather was one of the club's three founders, the opportunity to revive his club's ambitious vision cannot come quickly enough: 'Our objectives are sufficient to catch Manchester United financially in the short term, within four to five years,' he boasts.

Given that Gala claim to have 16 million supporters worldwide, and to be the only Muslim club performing in a top international arena (their matches are televised in parts of Africa, the former Soviet Union, the Middle East, and even the Far East), they are convinced of their vast potential.

So aggressively do they aim to catch up with the Manchesters, Milans and Madrids that their plans to construct a new home are dominated by finance rather than fervour. For Galatasaray, whose present stadium can, at a squeeze, pack in 30,000, this looks a dangerous gamble. They employed a London firm to make an independent feasibility study, and somehow they came up with the idea that fans in Istanbul would be happy to pay the equivalent of £18 for a match ticket (five times the price of the cheapest admission at the moment), and so decided to build a 40,000 all-seat stadium with premium-priced tickets rather than a 100,000 arena with admission prices affordable to the masses .

It seems the notorious 'Welcome to Hell' mentality that makes the Ali Sami Yen such a hostile place to visit (just ask Leeds United) will be replaced by a wealthy clientele munching prawns in pitta bread. Some clubs who have encountered violent problems with Galatasaray fans will think that is no bad thing.

It will be some time before we discover how much the face of Cimbom, as the faithful call their club, will change. While they wait for the Turkish economy to stabilise, they will be forced to cash in on their most coveted stars. The dazzling homegrown prodigy Emre Belozoglu - described by Italy's sports newspaper Tuttosport as the most sought-after player in Europe - and his best friend and midfield partner Okan Buruk have reportedly struck a deal to join Inter. Typically for Gala, it's not straightforward. The two clubs haven't agreed a fee, so this move, too. will go to Fifa for arbitration.

Jardel's agent may have denied his client will be leaving but his discontent ought to cause a stampede around Europe, and Galatasaray will be hard pressed to say no, given his crippling wages of about £2 million a year. For the benefit of both club and player, a summer move looks certain. Signing him in the first place for £22m was a huge deal by Turkish standards (even if it was bankrolled by the owner of the mobile phone company and club sponsor Telcim). Amazingly, Gala were the only club to come up with a concrete offer, and he has rewarded them by scoring for fun, as you would expect from a marksman who claimed 150 goals from 145 games at his previous club, Porto. Jardel's stock, if anything, has increased through his efforts in difficult circumstances in Istanbul.

'It's a miracle to have achieved the Champions League quarter-finals in these conditions,' remarked Romanian coach Lucescu. The key, according to veteran and volatile playmaker Georghe Hagi, is simply down to the team's quality. Having hoisted the Uefa Cup and European Super Cup in the past year, Hagi expects them to go one better now: 'We're at the peak of our game, we're in great shape, we will play in the final. A year ago we knocked out Milan, this year we'll play the final on their home turf. It's destiny, it's pre-ordained.'

Hagi is due to hang up those mercurial boots and rest that mad temperament at the end of the season, so you can't blame him for envisaging a fantasy finale, however dubious the logic.

That fantasy could yet become a nightmare if Gala do get through_ and face Leeds United. Memories of the murders of two supporters from Leeds in Istanbul are still painfully vivid.

For the moment, the Galatasaray players will not concern themselves with that and Hagi, banned from domestic action for spitting at a referee who dared to disallow one of his goals (an official he later accused of being a thief) should be available.

Meanwhile, money man Kalpakcioglu will be back in Istanbul while the players try to earn a lucrative semi-final place against Bayern Munich or Manchester United. 'I am superstitious and I believe I bring bad luck to my team,' he admitted. 'I watched the Uefa Cup final in my summer house outside Istanbul. I just couldn't take it. And I believe we'll have success in Madrid and make the semi-final. It will be fun.'

It would also be a much needed money-spinner, and a momentous achievement against all the odds.

webTitle: George Burley: how did this happen?

fields.headline: George Burley: how did this happen?
fields.trailText: The Ipswich manager talks to Amy Lawrence.
fields.body:
Where did you think you'd finish?

Most promoted teams get relegated straight away. We wanted to finish seventeenth, and I said before the season if we did that it would be a tremendous achievement.

Who were your key signings?

The main one was Hermann Hreidarsson. I felt we needed more pace at the back, did my homework, and I knew he was a good character. We paid over £4million, a lot of money for Ipswich. Otherwise we just built on what we had. I felt the players could do it, and they have proved me right.

How have they performed?

Better than everybody's expectations. People like Marcus Stewart, John McGreal and Mark Venus were all playing First Division football but have enjoyed the step up. The likes of Jim Magilton and Matt Holland are full internationals, and Jamie Clapham and Jermaine Wright are young players who've really pushed on and proved they are good enough for the Premiership. The players have taken responsibility for their own development. I'm proud of them.

We've played most of our games without fear. We haven't been afraid to go to Elland Road and Anfield; we've won there. We've won eight away games and not even Man United have won more.

What about next season?

It's good knowing we're going to be in the Premiership - the big task is to get better. We're a lovely friendly club, but we like winning. We're loving it at the moment, everything being so rosy, but I know in football that things can change quickly.

fields.headline: How fitting : the anti-climax finalé
fields.trailText: In the end, it was fitting that the Championship should be won anticlimactically and by default. It has been that kind of one-club season, that kind of one-horse title race.
fields.body:
In the end, it was fitting that the Championship should be won anticlimactically and by default. It has been that kind of one-club season, that kind of one-horse title race.

Just as Arsenal were suffering the second of their self -inflicted first-half wounds yesterday, just one United player remained at Old Trafford. Only Roy Keane's silver machine remained in the players' car park, him beside it signing autographs. The rest were long gone, out of the gale and the dank Manchester afternoon.

It was no way to celebrate a Championship even if Manchester United may have become blasé about what has become an annual occurrence. TV's insatiable desire, for which they admittedly pay handsomely, to be in at the moment meant that the game against Coventry had been scheduled to kick off before the Saturday shoppers left home. The decision was always destined to backfire as soon as Arsenal beat Manchester City, as expected, in mid-week.

It didn't even backfire spectacularly; there was no spectacle. More than at any other ground fans loiter in awe and reverence long before and after matches along Sir Matt Busby Way. They were all that was left when the news came through.

Despite the unsatisfactory end game, despite the shortcomings of others, United's achievement of a third successive title, a seventh in nine seasons, remains a towering one, though perhaps less appreciated due to their recent inconsistency, culminating in the home defeat by Bayern Munich in the Championship of late.

The vibrant, expansive football they produced until the turn of the year should not be overlooked, however. At times, at Everton in September or at home to Leeds and Southampton in October they approached the heights of any side ever to grace Old Trafford. It prompted Sir Alex Ferguson to rank them as his best.

He knows best, as he has shown for 15 years now. A personal favourite team remains the 93-94 side that mixed pace, power and panache so thrillingly and might well have gone closer to winning the European Cup had the current relaxed rules about overseas players then been in force.

But Ferguson knows, too, that they have lacked an edge of late. He said last night: 'Considering we won the League by New Year's day, you can perhaps see why we haven't really had that edge this year. I certainly never expected us to lose the nine point lead we had at Christmas. In 1999, the edge was there because the adrenaline and concentration just got better and better. Now, there is no doubt that winning the Champions League again before I retire is uppermost in my mind.'

The crucial area of superiority over their rivals of this United has been in their wide players. Ryan Giggs the dribbler, David Beckham the deliverer give them a cutting edge, even allowing for the latter's recent mild dip in form. Ally this to the drive of Roy Keane, the ingenuity of Scholes, along with the goals of any two from Teddy Sheringham, Andy Cole, Dwight Yorke and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer and it is a mix too potent for any in this country.

They have looked vulnerable in defence, while Wes Brown and Mikael Silvestre accumulate experience and with Jaap Stam injured for much of the season but Fabien Barthez in goal has underpinned them with his insouciant air of authority. Besides, few teams can retain possession for long enough to inflect sustained pressure. But that is down to a work ethic that sets United apart.

Speak to any manager and what they envy most is Ferguson's expertise in getting even the most gifted of players to apply industry to ability. Given some stuttering performances in Europe he may well need to recruit and regroup in the summer for his last season's tilt at the ultimate prize but this crop remains the best in their own country.

The crowning moment domestically was undoubtedly the 6-1 win over Arsenal some seven weeks ago. It was emphatic confirmation of the distance between them and their nearest rivals, in ruthlessness if not necessarily talent, and revenge over the last side to interrupt their title sequence. It may have been a silent moment yesterday but still a sweet one.

Expect it to be rather more raucous next Saturday.

webTitle: Going down? Not till the fat lady sings

fields.headline: Going down? Not till the fat lady sings
fields.standfirst: Coventry's manager is more than familiar with fighting relegation battles - and winning, while down in the Third Halifax can only hope lightning won't strike twice
fields.trailText: The stress of being in relegation trouble can do strange things to a manager. In my case, one of Coventry City's recent defeats - Everton's 3-1 win over us at Highfield Road in January - even caused me to take the first steps towards becoming a long-distance walker.
fields.body:
The stress of being in relegation trouble can do strange things to a manager. In my case, one of Coventry City's recent defeats - Everton's 3-1 win over us at Highfield Road in January - even caused me to take the first steps towards becoming a long-distance walker.

My wife, Lesley, and I were due to be visited by friends the following morning, and in order to ensure that I was reasonable company, I decided to try and get some of the disappointment out of my system by going for a walk. A leisurely Sunday morning stroll it wasn't; I unwittingly ended up walking almost 17 miles (for around three hours) and, as I had not brought any money with me, I had to telephone Lesley to come and pick me up in the car. Needless to say, in training the next day, I was little more than a bystander.

Although all this might suggest otherwise, there is little doubt that, in terms of being able to handle the anxiety of being in a relegation battle, I have been helped by having been in this position before.

One thing it has taught me is the importance of never giving up hope. Throughout my career, I have experienced countless examples of how dramatically fortunes can change in this game; probably the most memorable of these was Coventry's Houdini-like relegation escape in my first season as manager four years ago.

The position looked hopeless for us when we were dumped back into the bottom three through a 2-1 home defeat by Derby in our penultimate match. Publicly, I tried to put a brave face on things, but privately, I kept thinking: 'Where do we go from here?' The following week, of course, Coventry scrambled to safety with that famous 2-1 win at Tottenham.

In those days, because of my inexperience in the job, I tended to blame myself for everything. I tortured myself. Today, while acknowledging the importance of accepting responsibility for your mistakes, I have become much more conscious of the fact that some factors are beyond one's control.

The one problem, of course, is getting this across to the fans, as our chairman, Bryan Richardson, and I discovered through the stick we took the other week when appearing at a special club dinner and open forum before some 200 supporters at Highfield Road.

I cannot say it was a pleasant experience. I knew I was in for a rough ride before the questions, when a supporter who had approached me for my autograph remarked: 'It's brave of you to turn up.' At that point, I turned to Bryan and said: 'I hope the dinner rolls are not hard because I think a lot of them will be heading in our direction.'

The fans, who had previously had some three hours of drinking time to get themselves in the mood to have a go at us, had to submit their questions in written form. Among those posed to me was: 'Have you ever thought of taking up gardening?'

It says much about the general antagonism towards me that, when it came to questions about why Coventry found themselves in a relegation position, it was almost impossible for me to give explanations - such as referring to the top-class players we have had to sell and the delay in signing John Hartson - without the people who had asked them accusing me of making 'excuses'.

The fact that a lot of these people seem to overlook is that I have never been associated with a relegated team, and if Coventry were to go down, it would hurt me me just as much as it will hurt them.

It would be a huge blow for the club, not least because of the financial implications of having players on Premiership contracts in a league in which a club's income is much lower.

Money talks in football, and the reality for small clubs like Coventry is that survival alone is very much an against-the-odds target. Indeed, the problems we face were brought into sharp focus last week, with the report into Premiership players' salaries. It revealed that only five clubs paid less in players' wages than Coventry did last season. Three of them - Wimbledon. Sheffield Wednesday and Watford - ended up in the relegation spots. Of the others, Bradford City were fourth from bottom and Southampton were sixth from bottom.

In our bid to stay up again this time, I think I am fortunate in having a chairman who appreciates our problems and showed no signs of panic or anxiety over our situation. For any club at the bot tom, it is essential for the manager and players not to get too uptight, and the lead for that has to come from the very top.

I think I am also fortunate in being able to put my career as a football manager into its proper perspective.

I have recently been reading a book by the famous American football coach, Vince Lombardi, in which he admits that his obsession with achieving success detracted considerably from the quality of his family life. To me, the way he described it was very sad, but there are a number of people like that in life - and in professional football.

Football managers, in particular, are noted for allowing the pressures of their jobs to change them, which is something that I am determined to avoid. I have always been able to keep my football career separate from my personal life, and like to think that to my family and my friends, I am still the same as I have always been. It is impossible to exaggerate what this means to me.

Once I change, and turn into somebody that I or those close to me do not like, that is the time that I will look for something else to do for a living.

webTitle: How to buy success - and failure

fields.headline: How to buy success - and failure
fields.trailText: Huge wages bills lead to trophies - but also costly calamities
fields.body:
Players' wages are spiralling out of control and football is in danger of going bust; that was the view of some alarmists 40 years ago this spring, with the abolition of the maximum wage. So the game has changed unrecognisably? Indeed it has.

Television and all-seat stadia have seen to that. It is just that the alarmists haven't. A report last week by the analysts Deloitte and Touche showing that the 20 Premiership clubs made a collective loss of £34.5 million last season, with wages the most significant factor and the average player earning £8,000 a week, has been seized upon as a sign that 'football's bubble has burst'.

It seems the English game, like the theatre and the modern novel, is permanently in decline. The burst-bubble comment, incidentally, came from a club chairman, quoted anonymously in the wake of the report. Well he would say that, wouldn't he? Those upstart players, the hired hands, need reminding that they can't hold his club to ransom - unless he is Italian, a bit of a maverick, shifts replica shirts and scores five goals a season. 'Our club are doing all right,' added the chairman, by way of qualification, so we can safely assume that the man being quoted was not Chelsea's Ken Bates.

His debt-riddled club top the wages league, their annual bill having climbed 56 per cent to more than £47m. And Chelsea have not enjoyed the most successful of seasons after sacking Gianluca Vialli. The word Schadenfreude no doubt springs readily to the lips of fans elsewhere. The report's findings, based on last season's figures, make interesting reading, the least of it the confirmation that money does indeed buy success. Below Chelsea came Manchester United, the pair of them the winners of the two main domestic prizes last season. At the other end, relegated Watford increased their salaries by 60 per cent but were still the lowest payers after Bradford City. No longer dispensers of chickenfeed, the desperately offloading Bantams will doubtlessly have their own wage folly revealed in next season's figures.

It also tells us that money does not necessarily buy success. Newcastle United and Middlesbrough are hefty payers, due to the difficulties of attracting foreign signings to the North East. But then London clubs pay well because of property prices and the cost of the Scandinavian iced berries with white chocolate sauce at The Ivy. The middling payers are in the Midlands. What do fans care? Not a lot if the player is genuinely worth it. Manchester United fans will worry not a jot if David Beckham becomes that first £100,000-a-week player. The problem comes in the sums being paid to average imports. For too long, the Premiership has been the soft touch of Europe, some teams packed with players rejected or discarded by the better leagues but still earning huge sums. More likely, the report is a warning shot across the game's bows.

The boom in wages has been down to the effect of the Bosman ruling and the new transfer regulations. With less going in fees and therefore players likely to see more of the available money themselves, wages are likely to continue to rise. In addition, there have been reports that replica shirts are no longer the fashion items they were, with sales decreasing. Then there is sponsorship, with the Premier League having trouble finding the £15m a season it wants, and television. Pay-per-view is stubbornly refusing to provide another pot of gold. And although Sky will next season pay some £25m to each club as part of the new deal, after that, ITV and BBC could well be priced out of the market, leaving Sky free to offer less for the next contract. It is hardly likely to mean the game going bust here, however.

For all their profligacy and complacency at times, the Premiership clubs are some way short of Real Madrid in the debt stakes. And there are few banks brave enough to endure the attendant publicity that comes with foreclosing on a community's football club. It is more likely - you can only hope - that the game will start to re-examine its priorities. Manchester United showed the way a decade ago, when they introduced a clutch of kids from their youth programme and the result has been astonishingly apparent. Their problem now is more that they might need a summer of spending on top overseas players to freshen a squad now in danger of falling behind in European competition, but it remains a mystery why more English clubs have not followed their example.

Ipswich Town and Charlton Athletic have also shown how to play attrac tive, and successful, football by using management and coaching expertise to blend promising young, home-developed players with talents perceptively recruited from the Nationwide League and shrewd, less overpriced overseas signings. How is it that Ipswich saw the Premiership potential in Marcus Stewart at Huddersfield, while Aston Villa had to go to Argentina to pay £9.5 million for the labouring Juan Pablo Angel? Soon, if not already, all the youth academies should be turning out young English players of the required standard.

If the cost of giving them a fling, and also being forced to look again at players in the lower divisions - then taking a chance and turning them into better players with an improved quality of coaching - has been a wages explosion and debt, then it will have been money well spent. In hindsight, none of us believes that the abolition of the maximum wage, even if such clubs as Preston North End and Burnley may disagree, was anything other than justice and meant consequent and subsequent improvement of the game.

By the way, for those history students of the game who believe in its cyclical nature, the 1960s turned into a fascinatingly vibrant period following that wages explosion of 40 years ago. In 1962, Ipswich Town won the league and, a year later, Everton became the 'cheque-book champions' after signing Tony Kay - later banned in a betting scandal - for £60,000 from Sheffield Wednesday. Manchester United also bought big, paying a record £115,000 to bring home Denis Law from Torino. In '64, West Ham won the FA Cup, to be followed a year later by a European trophy with three young men named Moore, Hurst and Peters in the side. Then came '66. It's just a thought.

fields.headline: Gunners shoot themselves
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough were not the only team sent into raptures by this result of spectacular proportions. The corks were popping up in Manchester as well. What blessed relief for City, who are spared the misery of giving United their seventh Premiership crown in nine years next weekend.
fields.body:
Middlesbrough were not the only team sent into raptures by this result of spectacular proportions. The corks were popping up in Manchester as well. What blessed relief for City, who are spared the misery of giving United their seventh Premiership crown in nine years next weekend.

That honour instead falls to Arsenal - already feeling bitter about their inability to have mustered a credible challenge to Old Trafford. Bad enough to hand them the silver. Worse still to do it courtesy of a ludicrous afternoon of mishaps to take the breath away. Two own goals in four shocking first-half minutes destroyed the Premiership's only unbeaten home record.

That is to take nothing away from Boro, for whom three precious and unexpected points should see them well on the way to safety. What a memorable day for one of Old Trafford's favourite sons, Bryan Robson. He could not have done it without Terry Venables, who was right to applaud his team and their ecstatic following at the final whistle. Their application could not be faulted.

Middlesbrough, who earned themselves some Premiership breathing space since hiring Venables, had slipped back into perilously deep relegation waters and knew that a win here- something which has eluded them since before the war - would be priceless. Forced to withstand red pressure for the first half hour, during which Kanu and Thierry Henry went close, they required a touch of inspiration from somewhere to provide them with a glimmer of hope.

It came from South America. Not Colombian striker Hamilton Ricard, but the two Brazilians in Arsenal shirts. What a bizarre contribution from Edu, whose first home start had been eagerly awaited after his arrival was delayed for six months for his passport hold-up to be resolved. With his career in England so ill-fated thus far, Lady Luck grimaced at him once again. Dean Windass's blast of the right foot - which David Seaman appeared to have covered - ricocheted off Edu to produce an unstoppable own goal which squeezed inside the near post.

It was a huge setback for the Patrick Vieira-Edu axis, a partnership Arsène Wenger hopes will emulate the midfield connection Arsenal's Mr Influential enjoyed with his compatriot Emmanuel Petit, and the left-footed playmaker was put out of his misery at half-time, replaced by Sylvain Wiltord.

His compatriot Silvinho must have felt sorry for him but took empathy a step too far. Staggeringly, unbelievably, the left-back replicated his friend's error by lashing Dean Gordon's driven cross past a shellshocked Seaman four minutes later.

The visitors from Teesside tucked into a corner of the Clock End were delirious. It was extraordinary, so ridiculous that even some Arsenal fans could see the funny side. 'It's just like watching Brazil,' was one sarcastic verdict.

Wenger had resisted the temptation to rest key personnel with Tuesday's moment of European truth in Valencia in mind. Six changes were made to the supposedly weakened side which performed so clinically at Manchester City, but he - and indeed the Spanish scouts - could never have expected the full-strength version to self-destruct in such spectacular fashion.

Thirteen minutes into the second half Boro finally scored a goal of their own, and beautifully constructed it was too. Windass knocked the ball towards the irrepressible Alen Boksic, whose stylish back-heel eluded Tony Adams's lunge and fell for the onrushing Ricard. With cool precision he swept the ball past Seaman. 'We want four,' bellowed the Riversiders, who have endured their torrid moments this season. Superbly organised and highly motivated, they thoroughly deserved this momentous result - even if they had significant help along the way.

Arsenal have a job on to lift themselves for a massive European challenge at the Mestalla Stadium. Any more freakish performances like this could jeopardise their current runners-up place, a passport to next season's Champions League. While others celebrate, Arsenal have some serious thinking to do.

fields.headline: Robson's sad return
fields.trailText: The big five have dominated the Premiership so completely of late that you have to go back to the 1996-97 season to find an interloper finishing in the top four. Yet this win takes Ipswich up to third place as they go into a run-in which avoids any confrontations with the flash five - Manchester United, Arsenal, Leeds, Liverpool and Chelsea.
fields.body:
The big five have dominated the Premiership so completely of late that you have to go back to the 1996-97 season to find an interloper finishing in the top four. Yet this win takes Ipswich up to third place as they go into a run-in which avoids any confrontations with the flash five - Manchester United, Arsenal, Leeds, Liverpool and Chelsea.

This victory, secured by a Marcus Stewart penalty 14 minutes from time, pretty much ensures they will be drinking in Europe next season.

By even happier coincidence the points were gained against a team managed by Bobby Robson, the man who last guided them into Europe back in 1982. He was given a standing ovation as he stepped out onto the Portman Road pitch for the first timein 19 years. An emotional moment for an emotional man.

Ipswich dominated the early action with Martijn Reuser, who complained six weeks ago that manager George Burley set his standards too high, causing Warren Barton headaches. First he ran strongly down the right, brushing Barton aside, and crossed dangerously. Second, a cross from Fabian Wilnis skimmed off Barton's head and Reuser's far-post shot was well saved by Shay Given. Next, a vicious cross from Reuser was headed thumpingly against his own bar by Barton.

The Ipswich strategy was simple: give it to Reuser and watch him roast Barton. Newcastle had no answer, no shape, no passion - only Robert Lee giving the ball away in central midfield.

Despite all the Ipswich dominance, it was Newcastle who first put the ball in the net. On the half-hour, Nolberto Solano's corner was headed in by Carl Cort but referee Mike Dunn whistled for an infringement. For a moment, Newcastle came to life, with Lee shooting inches wide of the post.

Then back to the established pattern, with Matt Holland and Jim Magilton bossing the centre of midfield and Reuser buzzing around them. A tidy team playing tidy football against a disorganised outfit barely playing at all. Yet there were no goals to show for the tidy men's superiority.

And there was the feeling that they might have missed their best chance when Newcastle showed greater appetite after half-time and only some alert defending by Chris Makin prevented them from taking an unlikely lead. Ipswich's neat football had been replaced by nerviness. Even Reuser was suddenly off colour.

Showing signs of desperation they took off the impressive Magilton to accommodate a third striker in Scowcroft. A brave move but one that left them unbalanced and for a while Newcastle took advantage of the extra midfield space without creating so much as a half-chance.

Nil-nil looked likely until, on 76 minutes, Ipswich finally took the lead. Hreidarsson's header from a corner was handled on the line by Solano. The Peruvian was sent off and Stewart, the leading scorer in the Premiership, dispatched the penalty. Against such feeble opposition one was always going to be enough.

Second, a cross from Fabian Wilnis skimmed off Barton's head and Reuser's far-post shot was well saved by Shay Given. Next, a vicious cross from Reuser was headed thumpingly against his own bar by Barton. The Ipswich strategy was simple: give it to Reuser and watch him roast Barton. Newcastle had no answer, no shape, no passion - only Robert Lee giving the ball away in central midfield. Despite all the Ipswich dominance, it was Newcastle who first put the ball in the net. On the half-hour, Nolberto Solano's corner was headed in by Carl Cort but referee Mike Dunn whistled for an infringement. For a moment, Newcastle came to life, with Lee shooting inches wide of the post. Then back to the established pattern, with Matt Holland and Jim Magilton bossing the centre of midfield and Reuser buzzing around them. A tidy team playing tidy football against a disorganised outfit barely playing at all. Yet there were no goals to show for the tidy men's superiority. And there was the feeling that they might have missed their best chance when Newcastle showed greater appetite after half-time and only some alert defending by Chris Makin prevented them from taking an unlikely lead. Ipswich's neat football had been replaced by nerviness. Even Reuser was suddenly off colour. Showing signs of desperation they took off the impressive Magilton to accommodate a third striker in Scowcroft. A brave move but one that left them unbalanced and for a while Newcastle took advantage of the extra midfield space without creating so much as a half-chance. Nil-nil looked likely until, on 76 minutes, Ipswich finally took the lead. Hreidarsson's header from a corner was handled on the line by Solano. The Peruvian was sent off and Stewart, the leading scorer in the Premiership, dispatched the penalty. Against such feeble opposition one was always going to be enough.

fields.headline: Doherty makes Spurs' day
fields.trailText: Gary Doherty severely damaged Sunderland's European ambitions with two goals in the final 15 minutes of a game which was transformed in the second half. Tottenham trailed by two goals at the interval - and the margin could have been greater - but staged a remarkable comeback thanks to Doherty.
fields.byline: John Wardle at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
Gary Doherty severely damaged Sunderland's European ambitions with two goals in the final 15 minutes of a game which was transformed in the second half. Tottenham trailed by two goals at the interval - and the margin could have been greater - but staged a remarkable comeback thanks to Doherty.

He may prefer to play in defence, but the Irishman showed he is a major asset in attack with goals which stunned Sunderland as they appeared to be easing to their first league win at home since the start of the year.

Doherty steered in his first goal in the 75th minute after pursuing a clearance from Tim Sherwood and added the winner in the 88th minute.

Goals had been a rare commodity here. Sunderland scored only three in their previous eight home matches, a barren run partly because of a back injury which had hampered Niall Quinn's effectiveness.

Yesterday, he was fully fit, back alongside Kevin Phillips and immediately played a significant part in two goals. After only three minutes, Quinn's towering presence distracted Tottenham and they allowed Patrice Carteron's inswinging cross to reach Kevin Kilbane, who finished decisively at the far post.

Nine minutes later, Quinn added the second himself after keeper Neil Sullivan reacted splendidly to beat away a deflected free-kick by Stefan Schwarz.

Sullivan had a right to question why none of his defenders reacted as alertly as Quinn, but it was only typical of a rearguard which constantly failed to cope with the movement and understanding of Quinn and Phillips.

Quinn in particular provided problems for youngster Anthony Gardner, a 20th-minute substitute for Ledley King, who was concussed in a collision with Kilbane.

There was some consolation for Glenn Hoddle in the way his team, deprived of several regulars through injury, responded to interval talk which must have been harsh.

Spurs scored within eight minutes of the restart and approached their task with resolve and organisation which had been lacking.

The goal was excellent. Simon Davies accepted a pass from Steve Carr and picked out Stephen Clemence with a cross which the midfielder steered into the top corner with a first-time shot.

Sunderland's response was a surging run by Phillips, who set up Julio Arca for a shot which Sullivan turned away at full-stretch.
