fields.headline: Hammers revival hits dogged Derby
fields.trailText: What a bad day for Derby. Their third successive defeat, combined with Middlesbrough's win at Arsenal, sees them just one spot above the relegation places with five games remaining including a run-in against possible top-three finishers Arsenal, Manchester United and Ipswich. Their hope comes from the fact that they are still five points ahead of Manchester City and the final relegation slot.
fields.body:
What a bad day for Derby. Their third successive defeat, combined with Middlesbrough's win at Arsenal, sees them just one spot above the relegation places with five games remaining including a run-in against possible top-three finishers Arsenal, Manchester United and Ipswich. Their hope comes from the fact that they are still five points ahead of Manchester City and the final relegation slot.

After a run of three home defeats without scoring, West Ham made a wonderful start by scoring twice in the opening seven minutes. Their swift passing and competitive edge found Derby badly wanting, resulting in an opening goal in the fourth minute.

The move started with a harmless looking cross from Rigobert Song, but Derby were plunged into danger when Taribo West stuck out a leg and directed the ball into the path of Joe Cole. Mart Poom saved the initial shot, but the ball rebounded off Frédéric Kanouté four yards out and straight back into the net.

Their second, three minutes later, owed more to skill. Another of West Ham's England aspirants, Michael Carrick, threaded through a group of defenders and nudged the ball forward to Frank Lampard, who scored with a low, right-foot shot from the edge of the penalty area.

There were further decent efforts from Carrick and Cole as West Ham tried to have things wrapped up by half- time. Derby were a touch stronger by then, though, and showed a sign that they could get back into the match when Darryl Powell went close to scoring with a 32nd minute attempt from 20 yards. But they lacked the quality of West Ham's attacking.

The home side scored again in the last minute before the break. Di Canio exchanged a one-two with Cole, ran to the byline and pulled the ball back for the young midfielder to finish with a low shot. And it could have been four had Nigel Winterburn been able to follow up Lampard's free-kick moments later.

The Derby manager, Jim Smith, attempted to boost his attack by sending on Malcolm Christie for Stefano Eranio for the start of the second half. They became more positive, and Shaka Hislop made a clever point-blank save from Deon Burton just before Rory Delap headed narrowly wide, but too much damage had already been inflicted for them to play with any real belief and only a brilliant double save by Poom from Di Canio and Kanouté kept the score down midway through the second half.

Derby's efforts were rewarded by an 84th minute goal from substitute Thordur Gudjonsson after a superb piece of finishing.

fields.headline: Poyet the provider
fields.trailText: The millionaires of Chelsea were given a run for their money by the rather less lavishly-paid journeymen of Southampton before winning this battle of Stamford Bridge, which could take the Blues back into Europe.
fields.body:
The millionaires of Chelsea were given a run for their money by the rather less lavishly-paid journeymen of Southampton before winning this battle of Stamford Bridge, which could take the Blues back into Europe.

With both sides going into this game with hopes of qualification for the Uefa Cup, the points were always likely to be hard fought for.

Although Chelsea looked well on their way when Gus Poyet put them ahead shortly before half-time, they had to scrap for the rest of the game as Southampton pushed them close, before falling to a third successive defeat.

Chelsea manager Claudio Ranieri admitted this week that he would love to have more Englishmen in his side, but one has to wonder whether they would be heading for Europe without the foreigners.

Once again Chelsea lined up with just three English players in their 16-man squad, and it was no surprise that it was an overseas player who opened the scoring.

Dennis Wise is Chelsea's top-scoring Englishman, but he is only seventh on their hit list with four goals. Poyet, by contrast, is in double figures and took his total to 11 for the season when he finally broke the deadlock to put his side ahead shortly before half-time.

The Uruguayan midfielder volleyed home with a shot that flew up off the turf and down off the underside of the crossbar in the 43rd minute after Mario Melchiot headed down Graeme Le Saux's deep cross.

It was tough on Southampton, especially as the move had started with a foul throw from Mario Stanic. The Saints had defended stoutly for the opening 40 minutes, with goalkeeper Paul Jones setting the tone in the second minute when he flew out of his goal to save at the feet of Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink after the Dutch striker had been put clean through on goal by Gianfranco Zola.

That was the closest Chelsea came to a goal before Poyet's strike, as Dean Richards led the Saints' defence with a stirring performance.

But Southampton did not offer much in attack, and it took half an hour before they created a real chance, Kevin Davies playing a neat one-two with Jo Tessem before shooting over the bar from the edge of the penalty area.

They were unlucky five minutes into the second half when James Beattie got his head to Jason Dodd's deep cross but watched the ball rebound off the inside of the far post. That came just moments after Dan Petrescu had prevented his former side from increasing their lead, the Romanian midfielder clearing Marcel Desailly's header off the line.

But Petrescu was guilty of a glaring miss later when he ran clear of Chelsea's attempted offside trap but, instead of shooting past Carlo Cudicini or taking the ball round him, attempted a lofted shot from 30 yards which went straight to the Italian keeper.

Cudicini's compatriot Gianfranco Zola looked to be Chelsea's best hope of another goal, having a penalty appeal turned down when he seemed to be tripped and then having a shot headed away by Richards and a trademark free-kick deflected for a corner.

But Southampton always looked dangerous on the break, and as Chelsea began to look more nervous in defence the visitors went for an equaliser, with caretaker manager Stuart Gray sending on Hassan Kachloul, Tahar El Khalej and Uwe Rosler as substitutes.

That left Saints exposed in defence, and Jones came to the rescue twice in a minute in the closing stages before his opposite number was again tested.

Southampton broke quickly from defence and Cudicini raced out of his area to try to clear from Rosler, but the German striker won the ball before being fouled by Melchiot. Beattie took the free-kick, his shot flying off the defensive wall and just wide of the post.

Both sides had chances in a frantic finale, but Chelsea held on to move closer to a European place next season.

fields.headline: Glory days for classy Fulham
fields.trailText: The last time Fulham embraced the top flight of English football, Yorkshire were winning the county championship under Brian Close and The Beatles were sounding better than Liam Gallagher ever would.
fields.byline: Kevin Mitchell at the McAlpine Stadium
fields.body:
The last time Fulham embraced the top flight of English football, Yorkshire were winning the county championship under Brian Close and The Beatles were sounding better than Liam Gallagher ever would.

But as the stylish Londoners prepare now for their reincarnation as a serious team, there will be more than nostalgia to sustain their debut in the Premiership next season.

They needed only a draw to ensure promotion, so dominant are they in the First Division with six matches left, but they rounded out their campaign with a win of nervous brilliance.

As a Fulham fan of 60 years' standing remarked during this classy performance: 'There is not a single player of ours out there who has played better than he is playing now for Jean Tigana. In fact, this has to be our most talented team of them all.'

It would be a delight for all impartial admirers of the passing game if Fulham were able to embrace that talent under pressure against the likes of Manchester United, Liverpool and Leeds.

This is the sort of football that Arthur Rowe would have been proud of at White Hart Lane several decades ago - yet Tigana has brought a French flair to Fulham's play that is just as wonderful to watch.

He has obviously given them free rein to express themselves as they see fit and they did just that with a flurry of nutmegs, backheeled flicks, dummy runs and intuitive running off the ball.

There was little in the first 45 minutes to suggest we had gathered to witness anything more than an exhibition, although, playing into a driving wind and drizzle in the second half, Fulham had one or two uncomfortable moments.

Overall, though, Fulham were quicker, smarter and more composed than Huddersfield, whose anxiety for points was probably more urgent given their parlous position near the bottom of the table. They had come to this match unbeaten in five games yet were so clearly outclassed it was hard to believe these teams were in the same division.

One of the first to recognise Fulham's superiority was the sharp-eyed Town manager Lou Macari, who said: 'On the opening weekend of the season I went to watch Birmingham play Fulham at St Andrews. When I came back into the McAlpine on the Monday morning, I told the rest of our coaching staff that I had just seen the champions-elect of Division One.'

These were two teams going in decidedly opposite directions, a disparity made cruelly obvious through the class of Boa Morte and Saha up front and the masterful defending of Melville at the back, leaving few areas in which Huddersfield competed on level terms.

Nevertheless the first goal was a long time coming, as Fulham played with almost arrogant ease. In the 65th minute Lucketti brought Boa Morte down in the area and, from the spot, Saha did what he does best and blasted the ball home. Within 12 minutes, however, Facey robbed Symons in midfield, held off Melville and placed the equaliser neatly under Taylor.

Even though they needed only a point, Fulham now regathered their senses and pressed forward again after this hiccup in search of a win. Boa Morte, yet again, picked up Finnan's chipped pass, rounded the keeper Vaesen and languidly stroked in the winner.

While Fulham had the majority of possession and chances - 11 shots on goal to Huddersfield's five - there were a few moments in the second half when the machine looked a little creaky. Fulham missed chance after chance.

For Huddersfield, Lucketti was competitive throughout, bringing down Saha and Boa Morte in separate challenges; Heary and Facey also provided odd moments of encouragement and their Dutch international Gorre might have scored in the second half if he'd had an extra moment on the ball.

For Fulham, Clark, despite missing a late chance, was all smooth control in the middle of the field. Generally, the players around him had all the time and space they needed in which to create a succession of eye-pleasing attacks.

The several thousand who travelled to Huddersfield to witness Fulham's elevation stayed behind for 20 minutes celebrating near the golf range-end goalmouth. Next season they will have one more winter at Craven Cottage, before the builders move in. Overall they can hardly care where they play - this time five years ago they were losing 2-1 to Torquay at the bottom end of the Third Division. It's been some journey.

webTitle: Well, at least it's low on calories

fields.headline: Well, at least it's low on calories
fields.standfirst: If you loved Four Weddings and swooned over Notting Hill, you'll like Bridget Jones's Diary. If, on the other hand...
fields.trailText: If you loved Four Weddings and swooned over Notting Hill, you'll like Bridget Jones's Diary. If, on the other hand...
fields.body:
Bridget Jones's Diary (105 mins, 15) Directed by Sharon Maguire; starring Renée Zellweger, Hugh Grant, Colin Firth

Are men especially attracted to stupid, pretty women? This is the view of popular culture since the introduction of universal female suffrage. First, there was the dizzy blonde in pursuit of a millionaire husband, who reached her apogee in Marilyn Monroe. She was succeeded by the ditzy brunette, a rather smarter type, but less orderly and ruthless, generically known as 'kooks', played by Shirley MacLaine, Audrey Hepburn, and Liza Minnelli, reaching an apotheosis in Diane Keaton's Annie Hall.

Now we have the airhead heroine, usually a natural blonde, vulnerable, a terrible worrier, riven by doubts in a post-feminist manner, still looking for a rich Mr Right and best exemplified by Lisa Kudrow's Phoebe in Friends and the heroine of Helen Fielding's newspaper column, novel and now film, Bridget Jones's Diary.

From the same production team as Four Weddings and a Funeral and Notting Hill, this is a moderately amusing film in conventional sitcom fashion, and is a form of flattire, the genre in which flattery poses as satire. It appears to be sending up the trendy metropolitan media world in which the unmarried thirtysomething Bridget works, the affluent, Home Counties, middle-class circle of her parents and their grotesque friends, and the insecure, man-chasing Bridget herself. But the filmmakers are uncritically in love with their heroine and her milieux and have romanticised them to an almost laughable degree.

The office cad, Daniel Cleaver (Hugh Grant), Bridget's Mr Wrong, flirts with her by computer and seduces her, drives a Mercedes convertible and lives in a Thamesside apartment of breathtaking luxury. Her Mr Right, the strong, silent Mark Darcy (Colin Firth), is a celebrated civil rights lawyer of impeccable probity whose parents live in a country house that could give Castle Howard a run for its tourist dollar. The film's London is a clean, sparkling place out of a tourist brochure and the idyllic opening and closing Yuletide scenes in the snow are like Dickens at his most celebratory.

As appealingly played by Renée Zellweger, the film's Bridget is doubly affected in that we have an American affecting a plausible British accent, but the Sloaney drawl she uses is itself an affectation. She is also inconsistent in her naivety. In the book, she knowingly talks of herself as a 'child of Cosmopolitan culture', yet doesn't know the sporting phrase 'throwing a match'. In the film, despite having a degree in English and working as a publicist for a smart publisher, she thinks F.R. Leavis is still alive and when being interviewed for a TV job professes to believe that El Niño is a Latin American dance.

These are the things we laughed at in Monroe and Judy Holliday. They are also what appeal to both the sly suave Daniel, and the decent, kindly Darcy. In Daniel's case, they make her easier to seduce and cast aside; in Darcy's, they're the perfect attributes of the submissive, admiring partner he requires.

The co-writers - Helen Fielding, Andrew Davies (in whose TV adaptation of Sense and Sensibility Colin Firth became a star) and Richard Curtis (author of Four Weddings and a Funeral and Notting Hill ) - have largely dropped the diary format after the opening few minutes, though the diary itself is used as a plot device in the swooningly romantic climax.

We thus see Bridget more objectively than in the book, though whether this makes her narcissism and comic whingeing less tiresome is another matter. In both novel and film, we are clearly intended to find her not merely funny but also sympathetic, moving and exemplary of our age - as Owen might have said (Deborah Owen, the literary agent, that is, not Wilfred Owen), the poetry is in the self-pity.

Of the film's three authors, Richard Curtis seems the dominant influence. What one might regard as his Hugh Grant Trilogy (Four Weddings, Notting Hill and Bridget Jones) resembles Howard Hawks's John Wayne Trilogy ( Rio Bravo, El Dorado and Rio Lobo) which, despite having different literary sources, are versions of the same story with similar characters and settings. 'I'm not a damn bit interested in whether somebody thinks this is a copy,' said Hawks, 'because the copy made more money than the original, and I was pleased with it.'

So almost everything appears familiar, from the character who obsessively uses the word 'fuck' (as if laughter would flow exponentially from the repetition) through the climactic car chase to the calculatedly embarrassing scenes in which the heroes and heroines make idiots of themselves in public.

The most excruciating of the latter comes when Bridget delivers a disastrous speech at a book launch attended by some leading figures in the London literary world, among them Salman Rushdie, who makes the most wincing personal appearance since Graham Hill congratulated Yves Montand on his success on the Monaco circuit in Grand Prix. This sequence should have been one of the film's best, because it could have enabled Sharon Maguire, making her feature debut here, to draw on her experience making documentaries.

Another Curtis device, which may well have influenced Fielding's book, is to have the heroine surrounded by a devoted group of colourfully eccentric friends, one of them the gay confidant that's mandatory for every movie heroine nowadays.

fields.bodyText: Bridget Jones's Diary (105 mins, 15) Directed by Sharon Maguire; starring Renée Zellweger, Hugh Grant, Colin Firth Are men especially attracted to stupid, pretty women? This is the view of popular culture since the introduction of universal female suffrage. First, there was the dizzy blonde in pursuit of a millionaire husband, who reached her apogee in Marilyn Monroe. She was succeeded by the ditzy brunette, a rather smarter type, but less orderly and ruthless, generically known as 'kooks', played by Shirley MacLaine, Audrey Hepburn, and Liza Minnelli, reaching an apotheosis in Diane Keaton's Annie Hall. Now we have the airhead heroine, usually a natural blonde, vulnerable, a terrible worrier, riven by doubts in a post-feminist manner, still looking for a rich Mr Right and best exemplified by Lisa Kudrow's Phoebe in Friends and the heroine of Helen Fielding's newspaper column, novel and now film, Bridget Jones's Diary. From the same production team as Four Weddings and a Funeral and Notting Hill, this is a moderately amusing film in conventional sitcom fashion, and is a form of flattire, the genre in which flattery poses as satire. It appears to be sending up the trendy metropolitan media world in which the unmarried thirtysomething Bridget works, the affluent, Home Counties, middle-class circle of her parents and their grotesque friends, and the insecure, man-chasing Bridget herself. But the filmmakers are uncritically in love with their heroine and her milieux and have romanticised them to an almost laughable degree. The office cad, Daniel Cleaver (Hugh Grant), Bridget's Mr Wrong, flirts with her by computer and seduces her, drives a Mercedes convertible and lives in a Thamesside apartment of breathtaking luxury. Her Mr Right, the strong, silent Mark Darcy (Colin Firth), is a celebrated civil rights lawyer of impeccable probity whose parents live in a country house that could give Castle Howard a run for its tourist dollar. The film's London is a clean, sparkling place out of a tourist brochure and the idyllic opening and closing Yuletide scenes in the snow are like Dickens at his most celebratory. As appealingly played by Renée Zellweger, the film's Bridget is doubly affected in that we have an American affecting a plausible British accent, but the Sloaney drawl she uses is itself an affectation. She is also inconsistent in her naivety. In the book, she knowingly talks of herself as a 'child of Cosmopolitan culture', yet doesn't know the sporting phrase 'throwing a match'. In the film, despite having a degree in English and working as a publicist for a smart publisher, she thinks F.R. Leavis is still alive and when being interviewed for a TV job professes to believe that El Niño is a Latin American dance. These are the things we laughed at in Monroe and Judy Holliday. They are also what appeal to both the sly suave Daniel, and the decent, kindly Darcy. In Daniel's case, they make her easier to seduce and cast aside; in Darcy's, they're the perfect attributes of the submissive, admiring partner he requires. The co-writers - Helen Fielding, Andrew Davies (in whose TV adaptation of Sense and Sensibility Colin Firth became a star) and Richard Curtis (author of Four Weddings and a Funeral and Notting Hill ) - have largely dropped the diary format after the opening few minutes, though the diary itself is used as a plot device in the swooningly romantic climax. We thus see Bridget more objectively than in the book, though whether this makes her narcissism and comic whingeing less tiresome is another matter. In both novel and film, we are clearly intended to find her not merely funny but also sympathetic, moving and exemplary of our age - as Owen might have said (Deborah Owen, the literary agent, that is, not Wilfred Owen), the poetry is in the self-pity. Of the film's three authors, Richard Curtis seems the dominant influence. What one might regard as his Hugh Grant Trilogy (Four Weddings, Notting Hill and Bridget Jones) resembles Howard Hawks's John Wayne Trilogy ( Rio Bravo, El Dorado and Rio Lobo) which, despite having different literary sources, are versions of the same story with similar characters and settings. 'I'm not a damn bit interested in whether somebody thinks this is a copy,' said Hawks, 'because the copy made more money than the original, and I was pleased with it.' So almost everything appears familiar, from the character who obsessively uses the word 'fuck' (as if laughter would flow exponentially from the repetition) through the climactic car chase to the calculatedly embarrassing scenes in which the heroes and heroines make idiots of themselves in public. The most excruciating of the latter comes when Bridget delivers a disastrous speech at a book launch attended by some leading figures in the London literary world, among them Salman Rushdie, who makes the most wincing personal appearance since Graham Hill congratulated Yves Montand on his success on the Monaco circuit in Grand Prix. They're always there to bring her comfort and advice (and to help her with the wine and vodka), though if there were many such people at large in real life there would be queues a mile long at the admission gate of every Trappist monastery in Europe.

fields.headline: Waiting for Vidia...
fields.standfirst: V.S. Naipaul said good riddance to Trinidad 50 years ago. Now Merchant-Ivory is filming one of his books there and, as  Quentin  Falk finds, the island is holding its breath to see if the prodigal son will return
fields.trailText: V.S. Naipaul said good riddance to Trinidad 50 years ago. Now Merchant-Ivory is filming one of his books there and, as Quentin Falk finds, the island is holding its breath to see if the prodigal son will return
fields.body:
Rather like Godot, the spectre of V.S. Naipaul hovers over the Merchant-Ivory production filming in a tropically dense corner of the Booker Prize-winning author's native Trinidad.

It is only a fortnight until the end of shooting of The Mystic Masseur, the first film adaptation of a Naipaul novel, and the famously reclusive - or should that be elusive - writer is expected to visit the set shortly before the film 'wraps' on the eve of Carnival.

Cast and crew, not to mention the producers, some prominent local financiers and even the Trinidad and Tobago government, are in varying degrees of excitement, anticipation and sheer muck-sweat about the promised return of one of the island's most famous sons. Now 68, Naipaul, son of a hard-working local journalist and writer, left for Oxford University in 1950 and has rarely returned since.

According to Letters Between a Father And Son, a volume of revealing correspondence compiled and edited by Naipaul's UK literary agent, Gillon Aitken, as a young exile of 22, Naipaul declared: 'I think I shall die if I had to spend the rest of my life in Trinidad. The place is too small, the values are all wrong and the people are petty.'

Now, according to Aitken, Naipaul probably holds pretty much the same view, 'though perhaps not with the same young man's contempt. He does not have much time for the place'. Instead, he has, for the most part, remained in England.

Like some literary tennis master, he has amassed a cupboardful of trophies including the Booker Prize (In a Free State), the Hawthornden (Mr Stone and the Knights Companion), Somerset Maugham Award (Miguel Street), W.H. Smith Award (The Mimic Men) and the John Llewellyn Rhys Memorial Prize (The Mystic Masseur). Curiously, A House For Mr Biswas, loosely based on the life of his late father and still his most popular work, missed out on the prizes.

On location in Trinidad, everyone seems to have his or her own theory about the man - from 'tetchy' and 'temperamental' to 'funny' and even 'playful'. Will he or won't he turn up? The shooting is taking place in Santa Cruz, doubling as the novel's invented Fuente Grove, which is about an hour west of the capital, Port of Spain. A bargain-basement production, even by Merchant-Ivory's own cost-conscious standards, there are no trailers, so cast and extended crew muck in together each day under temporary awnings. A cocoa tree drops its solid fruit like grenades over the set and some stunt cockerels are tethered to the roof to add local colour.

It was the comedy that originally attracted Ismail Merchant to The Mystic Masseur, published in 1957 when Naipaul was 25. Set during the Forties and Fifties in and around the island's Indo-Trinidadian community (from which the Naipaul family hails), the story concerns the rise and rise of bookish young Ganesh Ramsumair from failed schoolteacher, aspiring author and struggling masseur (a sort of spiritual healer in local terms) to revered mystic, member of the legislative council and MBE.

'When I read it again,' Merchant recalls, 'I was in stitches of laughter, very amused by it and extremely taken with the characters.' It would, he agreed along with James Ivory and Ruth Prawer Jhabvala, his partners in Merchant-Ivory Productions (now celebrating its fortieth anniversary of filmmaking) 'make a good film'.

That was six years ago. After being 'strung along' by Naipaul's American agent for a year, Merchant then approached Aitken to learn that 'Naipaul doesn't want his books turned into films because of bad experiences when people have inquired but nothing ever happened'. After some further discussion, and despite a declaration by Merchant that 'in 99 per cent of the cases when we're "interested" the film gets made', the answer was still no.

So he finally wrote directly to Naipaul, whom he had met some years earlier, told him he'd just finished directing an adaptation of Anita Desai's In Custody and would love to show it to him. And, by the way, ' The Mystic Masseur would make a fantastic film'. Merchant says he received a letter from the author apparently saying: 'Please don't come to see me. I know your powers of persuasion are legendary - and you can have the rights.'

Merchant signed up Caribbean writer Caryl Phillips - on Jhabvala's recommendation - to pen the screenplay and, after several drafts, the pair made their first recce to the islands two years ago. There were subsequent meetings with everyone from the Prime Minister (Basdeo Panday, the country's first Indo-Trinidadian PM and sometime actor) and island magnates to discuss co-operation and cash.

With the veiled threat that the whole production could just as easily be relocated to southern India, the locals succumbed to the filmmakers' charms and cajoling even to the extent of part-funding the $2.5 million (£1.7m) production.

For their thirty-ninth film - following in the book-to-screen footsteps of, among many others, E.M. Forster (Room With A View, Howards End) and Henry James (The Europeans, The Golden Bowl) - Merchant, on his fourth assignment as director, cast his net wide for a talented if comparatively inexpensive Asian cast.

To play the charismatic Ganesh, he chose Aasif Mandvi, an award-winning New York stage actor who had first arrived in the States as a teenager from his native India via Bradford and the Brighouse Children's Theatre. Better known, to British audiences at least, are Bombay legend Om Puri and one-time EastEnder Jimi Mistry, who were last together as warring father and son in East Is East. Then there's Madhur Jaffrey's daughter, Sakina, Ayesha Dharker, who'll be seen in the next Star Wars episode, and 88-year-old trouper Zohra Segal playing one of Naipaul's most memorable characters, an ageing auntie with wind assistance known justifiably as the Great Belcher.

Finally, in a timely casting 'coup', Merchant went for Sanjeev Bhaskar, of Goodness Gracious Me fame and recent front man for a droll Channel 4 odyssey through the Kama Sutra, to play Beharry, Ganesh's amiable and endlessly supportive sidekick, indeed the man who dubs him 'Mystic Masseur'.

Settled into a lush clearing, Merchant and co are indulging what some observers acclaim as 'the Prozac school of filmmaking'. The mood is extremely relaxed as the director actively encourages collaboration. But as Merchant is quick to point out, he rarely does more than three takes on any scene with the result that the no-frills production is already four days ahead of schedule. When he does occasionally snap, it's because Bhaskar, ever the stand-up comic, has reduced co-stars like Dharker to uncontrollable giggling.

Though he's the director, Merchant can never - despite the presence of his ebullient nephew, Nayim, as producer - quite forget his own diehard producer roots. So when he has just finished saying 'Cut', he hardly draws breath before ordering an assistant to 'make sure there are fresh sheets on the bed and the room's properly aired', pending the imminent arrival of a new artist. Also on his mind is the company's film for later this year, an adaptation of Diane Johnson's bestseller, Le Divorce, to be directed by Ivory.

Nothing is impossible, even mustering a string quartet at the last minute. 'It was five o'clock on a Sunday,' sighs Nayim, 'and we were due to start shooting at seven. Most people were out "liming" [partying] and I had to make at least 50 calls but from three different groups we finally managed to put a quartet together in time.'

With the production galloping to an early end - with scenes still to be shot in Oxford and Kidderminster - it's clear that Naipaul would be a 'no show'.

Back in England, Sir Vidia is unavailable for comment because he's deeply into a new book. According to his second wife, Nadira, there was never ever a question of his travelling to Trinidad: 'The timing was very bad, he was involved in other things and he's not the kind of man who would just get up and go, as I told Ismail.'

Aitken adds helpfully if cryptically that Naipaul, 'who never saw the script nor wanted to anyway', would 'probably prefer to let the film speak for itself'. There are, it has been said, ways of making films and ways of making Merchant-Ivory films. 'Bang on,' agrees Lady Naipaul, with a hint of reproof.

The Mystic Masseur opens later in the year

fields.headline: He's so like his father...
fields.standfirst: Tweeny special agents are better value than cheerleaders
fields.trailText: Tweeny special agents are better value than cheerleaders
fields.body:
Spy Kids (90 mins, U) Directed by Robert Rodriguez; starring Antonio Banderas, Carla Gugino, Alan Cumming
Valentine (96 mins, 15) Directed by Jamie Blanks; starring Denise Richards, Jessica Capshaw, Marley Shelton
But I'm a Cheerleader (89 mins, 15) Directed by James Babbit; starring Natasha Lyonne, Cathy Moriarty, Bud Cort

Back in the 1980s, Arthur Penn made an underrated thriller, Targets, in which a discontented Texas teenager suddenly discovers that his despised father, an apparently conformist timber merchant (Gene Hackman), is in reality a retired CIA agent of formidable accomplishments and lethal talents. The movie was something of an attack on family life, real and surrogate.

Robert Rodriguez, best known hitherto for extremely violent action pictures such as El Mariachi and Desperado, has taken the same plot and turned it into Spy Kids. His affirmative comedy-thriller is a more family-friendly version of Austin Powers.

Deftly, Rodriguez shows top agents Gregorio (Antonio Banderas) and Ingrid Cortez (Carla Gugino) meeting on opposite sides in the Cold War, marrying and retiring to raise a daughter (Alexa Vega) and son (Daryl Sabara) in a quiet suburb. When mom and pop are called back to action to defeat the schemes of a nefarious megalomaniac toy manufacturer (Alan Cumming) the two kids come to their rescue, drawing on their new-found personal courage and using a succession of devices the prototypes of which were invented by (or would not be disowned by) 'Q' in the Bond movies.

The design influences range from Antoni Gaudi to Ken Adam and there are no winking jokes directed at adults over the heads of children. Kids will love it, parents will find it more than tolerable, and in a very salutary manner the good guys are mostly Hispanics, and the bad guys mostly American Wasps.

Jamie Blanks's new slasher flick Valentine is a throwback to the late 1970s when every week there was a picture about a high school outsider taking a bloody revenge in early adulthood for slights and humiliations suffered a decade or so before. The killings here take place on the anniversary of a grade school Valentine's Day dance in Southern California and each is preceded by the receipt of a menacing Valentine's Day card. Unlike the Scream trilogy and other horror flicks of the past decade, there isn't a single reference to slasher films, which makes it post-postmodern. In the film's most horrific scene, the water is cut off while one potential victim is shampooing her hair and she has to rinse it in the lavatory bowl.

Jamie Babbit's feeble comedy But I'm A Cheerleader stars the fetching Natasha Lyonne (so good in Slums of Beverly Hills) as a high school senior suspected by her petit bourgeois parents of being a lesbian and sent to Cathy Moriarty's True Directions rehabilitation camp to be sexually reoriented. The film wastes a gifted cast on a clumsy, sub-satirical tale that deals solely in sexual stereotypes while condemning sexual stereotyping.

fields.headline: John, Paul, George, Ringo (and Joan)
fields.standfirst: Philip French takes pleasure in two revived black and white classics
fields.trailText: Philip French takes pleasure in two revived black and white classics
fields.body:
A Hard Day's Night (87 mins, U) Directed by Richard Lester; starring the Beatles, Wilfrid Brambell
Mildred Pierce (110 mins, PG) Directed by Michael Curtiz, starring Joan Crawford, Zachary Scott, Jack Carson, Ann Blyth

The most striking feature of both this week's re-issues - something brought out in excellent new prints - is their black-and-white photography. They're a pleasure to look at. The veteran Ernest Haller's images in Michael Curtiz's Mildred Pierce (1945) - the pools of light in fields of darkness, the shadows, silhouettes, reflections, the expressionist distortions - make this one of the great films noirs. Five years earlier, Haller had shared an Oscar for his colour photography on Gone With the Wind , and he later lit Rebel Without a Cause and Anthony Mann's Man of the West , but Mildred Pierce is his finest achievement. Gilbert Taylor shot Richard Lester's A Hard Day's Night (1964) in hand-held cinéma-vérité style, with the grainy high-contrast black-and-white favoured by the smart magazines of the time, and it gives the picture an enormous immediacy and vitality. He'd come straight from shooting Kubrick's Dr Strangelove and went straight on to working with Polanski on the low-budget Repulsion and Cul-de-Sac . He later shot Polanski's Macbeth and Hitchcock's Frenzy before photographing Star Wars .

Alun Owen's screenplay for A Hard Day's Night defined the public personas of the Beatles, but his 'day in the life' script has worn badly, as has the central notion of the Beatles as the only authentic beings in Britain. There's scarcely a decent line in the picture, and the role of Wilfrid Brambell as Paul's grandfather is pure embarrassment. Lester's best films (most notably The Knack and Petulia ) were still to come, but the pace and sheer exuberance he brought to the picture (you can glimpse him beaming cheerfully on stage in the finale), the charismatic presence of the Fab Four and the dozen vintage songs have kept it from being a mere time capsule.

I never walk along Tottenham Street (just off Tottenham Court Road north of Goodge Street station) and pass Charlotte Mews without releasing a nostalgic sigh. Charlotte Mews is the arched alleyway from which the quartet emerge running, to cross the road and enter the stage door of the now defunct Scala Theatre for the film's climactic concert. Incidentally, the word 'Beatles' is never spoken in the picture, and is only spelt out on Ringo's drums, by a final flashing sign on the rear wall as their set ends, and in a pun when the letters BEA on the helicopter bearing them away to Wolverhampton have had TLES added to it.

MGM dumped the 41-year-old Joan Crawford and she went straight to Warner Brothers and won an Oscar with her greatest performance as Mildred Pierce, the Los Angeles career woman who sacrificed everything, nearly including her life, for the daughter (Ann Blyth) she's spoilt rotten. Like many noir melodramas of the time (eg Double Indemnity , Farewell My Lovely ), the movie unfolds in flashback as a doomed narrator explains his or her downfall to the authorities. In this case, the murder suspect Mildred tells the police how she fought her way up from waitress in gingham uniform to rich restaurateur in fur coat. webTitle: Will I love my baby, even if it's a horrid little boy?

fields.headline: Will I love my baby, even if it's a horrid little boy?
fields.trailText:
After five years of marriage, my husband and I have decided to try for a baby. It's something we have been thinking about for a while. However, I have terrible reservations. I want to have a baby, but I can only contemplate having a girl. When I see little boys playing, they look so rough and unappealing. If I feel like this, am I really ready to have a child and will my feelings change when I see my baby, whatever its sex?
C.D. of Oxon
fields.body:
After five years of marriage, my husband and I have decided to try for a baby. It's something we have been thinking about for a while. However, I have terrible reservations. I want to have a baby, but I can only contemplate having a girl. When I see little boys playing, they look so rough and unappealing. If I feel like this, am I really ready to have a child and will my feelings change when I see my baby, whatever its sex?
C.D. of Oxon

If you carry your reservations to their logical conclusion you might not want to beget a human at all, of either sex. Boys turn into lager louts, football hooligans, drug barons; girls into sex-mad, spicy ravers, Yuppies, neurotic singletons. It's so easy to put people into categories and there always seem to be more types that you don't like than ones you do.

Though technically possible, it is not legal in Britain selectively to abort a baby on grounds of sex, and rightly so. It happens illegally in other parts of the world where boys are deeemed more desirable than girls.

Your ambivalence is irrelevant because your baby, whoever he or she may be, will be in a unique, front-row position in your perspective; the most wonderful child ever begotten. Infancy is the only time in our lives when we receive unadulterated, unselfish love. That love is not controlled by any con scious part of your mind and you will find how instinctive it is if a child of yours is ever threatened.

Your aversion to rough little boys is perceived in a very different part of your mind, one of more modern evolutionary provenance. You will never look at your own son through that perspective; indeed once you have a child you will always see other youngsters through a mother's indulgent eye. You will doubtless look back to your present uninitiated state with the superior amusement of the newly enlightened.

When I was a junior doctor, communicating with young patients could be as challenging as making rapport with someone of a different culture speaking an unknown language. Once I had my own family the mists cleared. It was as if they pressed my recall button and I was suddenly able to recon nect with the juvenile world.

If you are by nature neat, nice and particular, as your letter suggests, you may have some adjusting to do when your family begins to grow in size and numbers. Children of both sexes can be rowdy, rumbustious, loud and chaotic.

As a parent you must learn to raise your threshold of tolerance for noise and mess; for other things too. Your own survival demands it.

Readers' Replies

Yes your feelings will change, but give it at least six weeks. I wanted my third child to be a third daughter. He wasn't. Initially I felt disappointed and disorientated. (He wasn't as delicate and pretty as the girls.) The love affair only started six weeks later and has never dwindled. I now understand the irrational devotion mothers can feel for their sons; it is almost frightening. All mothers I know with experience say how much more affectionate are little boys. My son is no exception and is far less aggressive than his eldest sister.
K.R. via email

Many women, when pregnant for the first time, are convinced they are carrying a girl, as the thought of having a boy is so impossible to comprehend if you've never actually been one yourself.

This was true for me. I had a list of girls' names but couldn't think of a single boy's name I liked - so, not surprisingly, I was stunned when the midwives told me I had given birth to a son!

My little boy, who is nearly three, is sweet, affectionate, eager to please and enchanting. Whatever the sex of your child, you'll fall in love with him or her the moment you meet.
L.W. of London

Next week's problem

My mother-in-law has recently revealed to us that she and her husband have entered a scheme whereby she has taken the equity on the house to use it in their retirement. This means the house will belong to the company when they die, not be passed down to my husband and his two sisters.

We are horrified and very upset by this action. It means that we will have no opportunity to inherit a significant amount of money and improve our lifestyle.

Am I justified in my anger or should I be glad my parents-in-law will be able to have a worry-free retirement? My husband is 36 and his parents are 70 and 72.
D.C. of London

Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk Views on problems must reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal

fields.headline: The earth moved. Not...
fields.standfirst: The BBC has wheeled out its big guns to tell us that works such as Ulysses, Figaro and Battleship Potemkin changed the course of history. But few of them did - and rarely for the better
fields.trailText: The BBC has wheeled out its big guns to tell us that works such as Ulysses, Figaro and Battleship Potemkin changed the course of history. But few of them did - and rarely for the better
fields.body:
The depressing and also the reassuring thing about history is that it is continuous. Time ticks on, unstoppably. The present instantaneously turns into the past, and the future - despite promises and prophesies - never arrives. We long for time to have a stop, so that we can start it up again. Why else do we celebrate Easter and the pagan rites of spring from which the festivity of rebirth derived? The millennium allowed us to contemplate a row of zeroes, as if history had suddenly been erased. In politics, revolutions offer the illusory chance of a breach with precedent and custom, and a clear road ahead with the New Jerusalem on the horizon - until the cycle completes itself and counter-revolution restores the old order.

In the history of art as well, we are desperate to believe that traditions can suddenly be expunged and reality revised overnight. This mistaken faith lies behind Art That Shook The World , a new BBC2 series about innovation. The title echoes a report on Bolshevism by the American left-winger John Reed, who described the upsets in St Petersburg in 1917 as '10 days that shook the world'; we are asked to imagine the world trembling and tottering all over again as it is affronted by Mozart's Marriage of Figaro, Monet's Sunrise , Joyce's Ulysses, Eisenstein's Battleship Potemkin and the biblical Psalms.

The excitable presenters do their share of shaking and shuddering, to calibrate the seismic wallop of these novelties. Andrew Graham-Dixon, jumping up and down before Monet's impression of bleary dawn in Le Havre harbour, says that this painting 'truly did change the world', though he omits to say how, since by his own account Le Havre is as much of a dump now as it was in Monet's day. Nevertheless, Graham-Dixon gives the metaphor an additional charge of violence by contending that the picture set off 'an avant-garde earthquake'. T5om Paulin, explicating Ulysses, gives a more lurid variant of the cliché: the novel, he says, 'shocked and shook the world'. All this seems to mean is that it made Paulin's twitchy teenage member quiver when he first read it, since for him its primary claim to revolutionary status is that it contains farts, knickers and is 'wonderfully obscene'. Renny Bartlett, vaulting down the Odessa steps in the programme about Potemkin, shouts that Eisenstein 'literally changed history'. No he didn't, he merely fictionalised it: the massacre on that stairway never happened.

Sensational exaggeration replaces sober critical assessment. Barbara Bonney - an opera singer who, interestingly, is the least hyper and histrionic of the presenters - feels obliged to call Figaro 'the greatest opera ever written' and Paulin inevitably acclaims Ulysses as 'the greatest novel ever written'. These are flagrantly and uselessly personal enthusiasms. The Belfast earth may have moved when Paulin first panted his way through Molly Bloom's randy monologue at 17, but did our steady, reliable old globe pause in its rotation? Sunrise, Monet's subject, is something that happens every day. It's a habit the sun has, and its recurrence does not necessarily betoken a messianic New Dawn, like the one which Madame Blavatsky and the Theosophists prated about at the start of the twentieth century.

The shaking in question was a local occurrence and soon subsided, like a tremor which hardly agitates the instruments monitoring the San Andreas fault. The first production of Figaro was seen a mere nine times in Vienna in 1781. Even in Bolshevik Moscow, Potemkin played only in a few half-empty cinemas, overtaken in popularity by Douglas Fairbanks's Robin Hood; in Britain, where the censors were nervous after the General Strike of 1926, it was withheld from public exhibition until 1954. The men of power, ultimately, had nothing to fear from the artists who challenged them. Emperor Joseph II's decision to license Figaro for performance was, as Bonney acknowledges, a gesture of patronising, permissive tolerance. Ten years later Mozart, the victim of Joseph's legislation about burial practices and urban hygiene, was dumped in a pauper's grave. Eisenstein worked and indeed lived only so long as Stalin permitted him to. If he hadn't danced himself to death on the set of Ivan the Terrible, the dictator would no doubt have dispatched him to the gulag.

Popularity, when it eventually came, lessened the force of these supposedly radical works, sedating them by repetition, defusing them through parody and pastiche. Monet, as Graham-Dixon says, was 'mugged by his own celebrity': he illustrates the point by brandishing a coffee mug with Sunrise imprinted on it. Arias from Figaro are sold as 'easy listening', and recommended for their soothing influence on unborn babies. The editorial cuts and clashes of the Odessa steps sequence from Potemkin are mimicked in a television commercial for ketchup: a dowager orders her limo to bump down the steps so she can jerk the sauce out of her bottle. Innovation is soon enough absorbed into a commercial system which appreciates novelty because it is fashionable and therefore potentially profitable.

Would the movers and shakers in question have minded if they'd known how little the world actually changed? I doubt it. Only hucksters bother about creating scandals and sensations, and only egomaniacs think that their own originality makes all pre-existing works of art redundant. Ulysses is, among other things, an anthology of previous literature, from Homeric epic to late-romantic lyricism; T.S. Eliot approved of it because he saw that it wanted to grow back into the classical past rather than ejecting itself into an experimental future. For the same reason Monet, not content with anecdotes about the industrial city like Sunrise, went on to paint Rouen cathedral, training his own molten, deliquescent light on the ancestral heritage of European imagery. He may have changed the way we see the world, deflecting it through a luminous haze, but objects are not altered by our subjective whimsies. Graham-Dixon calls him one of the first 'architects of modern perception'. Again it's a wistful metaphor: perceptions are too fickle and unverifiable to be called architectonic.

Some dissident good sense about the ambitions of artists is talked by Jonathan Miller in the programme on Figaro. The opera moves him, he says, because it's so elegiac and backward-looking. It meticulously recreates a busy social world that has been defunct for more than 200 years; to stage it is an act of resurrection, evoking 'the fragility and mortality of being us'. The Beaumarchais play which Mozart adapted may have been 'the revolution in action', as Napoleon said, but the opera is not concerned with class war, vengeance and restitution. It is about lost happiness and a forfeited harmony, briefly recovered when, at the very end, all the disputatious characters finally sing together for the first time.

Does this mean that art is impotent? Auden thought so, and believed this was its safeguard. He posthumously rebuked Yeats - who thought of his verses as a goad to ideological combat - by declaring 'Poetry makes nothing happen'. Whenever poetry or any other art does make things happen, what happens is generally deplorable. Goebbels admired Potemkin and commissioned Leni Riefenstahl to copy it. In her Triumph of the Will , the Cossack troops goose-stepping down\the steps become the heroes, since Eisenstein's choreographic style can be applied to whatever political content you choose. Hitler's regime was uniquely and disturbingly dependent on such imagery: fascism, as Walter Benjamin argued, is politics aestheticised. The same can be said today about consumer capitalism, which - as the Monet mug and the Eisenstein sauce bottle prove - exploits art to boost sales. We are all the dupes of an aestheticised economy. Art, rather than shaking the world, helps it keep commodities circulating.

Throughout western history, consciousness and even conduct have been modified by poems, plays, pieces of music. But those changes have occurred slowly and stealthily, rather than with the explosive éclat dramatised by the BBC's presenters. We fall in love, expressing gratuitous emotions according to a ritualised series of rules, because Provençal troubadours in the twelfth century invented a newly reverent way of sublimating sexual feeling. Romanticism demonstrates how assiduously life imitated art. When Goethe's hero Werther shot himself, dozens of actual wannabes did the same, expressing their contempt for a drably unsatisfactory reality. The example of Hamlet was equally baleful: the Russian film director Grigori Kozintsev believed that the nineteenth century suffered from a malady he called 'Hamletism' - a surfeit of moody thought, which undermined the capacity for political action.

The motor of history, on those intermittent occasions when it does start up, is intellectual not artistic. Jean Cocteau called art 'science given flesh', and the scientific conjectures of the early twentieth century irrevocably altered the physical substance of the world and our feelings about it. Nuclear physics devised a formula for destroying the earth; if the ground seems tremulous underfoot, blame Einstein not Joyce. Artists did go on to describe the psychological consequences of this instability: the hero of Patricia Highsmith's Strangers on a Train commiserates with the split atom, and reflects on a moral quandary by pondering the electron theory, which has broken 'the universal law of oneness'.

The one programme in the series that makes the thesis work is Germaine Greer's investigation of the Psalms. She treats them as poetry (and gives some notably actressy readings of them, in one case striding up the aisle of an empty cathedral and shaking her fist at a crucifix while she demands why father has deserted her). But of course they are much more than verse. Because they purport to be the words of God, anyone who quotes them - whether unctuously mumbling them like the Anglican clerics she interviews, jazzily rapping through them like Rastafarians, or pentecostally babbling them in unknown tongues - purports to be a divine or perhaps demonic ventriloquist. The Psalms, Greer points out, empower people and also make them crazy: the argument is more impressive than the spectacle of Paulin stomping through a maze which represents the complexities of Ulysses and bellowing 'It's driving me mad!' Heretics were set alight during the Reformation because they ventured to make slight changes in approved translations of the Psalms. David, the singer of these songs, lends his star to the Zionist flag, and his name to the cultist David Koresh, incinerated at Waco in Texas with his loyal Davidian acolytes.

Here is a genuine case - even more frightening than the revelation of art's complicity with totalitarianism in the Potemkin programme - of art provoking change, and doing so for the worst. Otherwise we should be grateful that the earth revolves without being revolutionary, and is beyond being redeemed (or annihilated) by art. I apologise for breaking the news on Easter Sunday, when the world is indeed being shaken by something more precious than art: the pressure of growth, tunnelling through the soil and making the ground crack open.

Art That Shook the World is on Saturdays on BBC2. Figaro is shown on 21 April; Potemkin on 28 April and Psalms on 5 May.

Did any work of artchange the world? Some people think so

Richard Eyre

In The Cherry Orchard (1904), Chekhov showed how to write about private lives and public ideas in the contemporary world in an unprecedented way: realistic, humane, spare, poetic, unsentimental and prescient.

Philip French

As important as the coming of sound, Orson Welles's Citizen Kane (1941) opened up new directions for the movies and created more cinematic vocations than any other film. It announced the possibility of a serious, ironic, playful cinema, at once personal and public, popular and avant-garde. It challenged the rules and orthodoxies. It showed that anyone (who happened to be a genius experienced in theatre and radio) could occupy a Hollywood sound stage and, with the help of veteran technicians, direct a masterpiece. It shook the world. Satyajit Ray, India's greatest filmmaker, said the major regret of his life was his absence from Calcutta during its brief 1941 run. Jorge Luis Borges, Latin America's greatest writer, wrote the only persuasively unfavourable review, and went blind before he could revise it. There is Cinema BK and Cinema AK. It's that much of a landmark.

Ronan Bennett

The King James Version of the Bible (1611). Who'd have thought that a book put together by a committee of dusty old academics and theologians working under state supervision would produce one of the most sublime works in the English language, and at the same time inspire ordinary Englishmen and women first to resist and eventually to behead the son of the very man who authorised its creation? With its dramatic and hypnotic cadences and its unsettling imagery, it contains writing of the greatest invention and beauty.

Jonathan Kent

For the first time in our civilisation, Euripides in Medea created a protagonist confronting a force and a passion which was no longer an alien being from without - 'a god' - but inescapably part of her own psychology. Medea's struggle is an internal one, and what had been the gods now become psychological archetypes. In this sense it is the first modern play.

Jude Kelly

Athol Fugard's Sizwe Bansi Is Dead was produced by the Market Theatre Company in South Africa during apartheid. It toured Europe and America and any other part of the world it could get to. It was one of the most vital, artistic and political experiences. It was art illuminating what apartheid meant emotionally. It had an enormous effect on how people shifted that political situation.

Paul Morley

Marcel Duchamp's The Bride Stripped Bare By Her Bachelors, Even because it was a work that changed art.

Innovation is soon enough absorbed into a commercial system which appreciates novelty because it is fashionable and therefore potentially profitable. Would the movers and shakers in question have minded if they'd known how little the world actually changed? I doubt it. Only hucksters bother about creating scandals and sensations, and only egomaniacs think that their own originality makes all pre-existing works of art redundant. Ulysses is, among other things, an anthology of previous literature, from Homeric epic to late-romantic lyricism; T.S. Eliot approved of it because he saw that it wanted to grow back into the classical past rather than ejecting itself into an experimental future. For the same reason Monet, not content with anecdotes about the industrial city like Sunrise, went on to paint Rouen cathedral, training his own molten, deliquescent light on the ancestral heritage of European imagery. He may have changed the way we see the world, deflecting it through a luminous haze, but objects are not altered by our subjective whimsies. Graham-Dixon calls him one of the first 'architects of modern perception'. Again it's a wistful metaphor: perceptions are too fickle and unverifiable to be called architectonic. Some dissident good sense about the ambitions of artists is talked by Jonathan Miller in the programme on Figaro. The opera moves him, he says, because it's so elegiac and backward-looking. It meticulously recreates a busy social world that has been defunct for more than 200 years; to stage it is an act of resurrection, evoking 'the fragility and mortality of being us'. The Beaumarchais play which Mozart adapted may have been 'the revolution in action', as Napoleon said, but the opera is not concerned with class war, vengeance and restitution. It is about lost happiness and a forfeited harmony, briefly recovered when, at the very end, all the disputatious characters finally sing together for the first time. Does this mean that art is impotent? Auden thought so, and believed this was its safeguard. He posthumously rebuked Yeats - who thought of his verses as a goad to ideological combat - by declaring 'Poetry makes nothing happen'. Whenever poetry or any other art does make things happen, what happens is generally deplorable. Goebbels admired Potemkin and commissioned Leni Riefenstahl to copy it. In her Triumph of the Will , the Cossack troops goose-stepping down\the steps become the heroes, since Eisenstein's choreographic style can be applied to whatever political content you choose. Hitler's regime was uniquely and disturbingly dependent on such imagery: fascism, as Walter Benjamin argued, is politics aestheticised. The same can be said today about consumer capitalism, which - as the Monet mug and the Eisenstein sauce bottle prove - exploits art to boost sales. We are all the dupes of an aestheticised economy. fields.headline: What keeps Roddy rooted
fields.standfirst: Roddy Doyle always looks forward to a spell in prison - well visiting anyway. And with a new film comedy in progress, it's one way of keeping in touch with the often less than charmed lives of working-class Dubliners
fields.trailText: Roddy Doyle always looks forward to a spell in prison - well visiting anyway. And with a new film comedy in progress, it's one way of keeping in touch with the often less than charmed lives of working-class Dubliners
fields.body:
Roddy Doyle, the Irish novelist loved by millions, lies back in an easy chair with his legs outstretched and his arms comfortably behind his head, and says that nowadays 'happiness is a pretty usual state of mind'. But he's also said said that unhappiness is harder to avoid as you get older.

Certainly, his own novels have darkened over the years, shifting from exuberant optimism to something bleaker and sadder and not so convinced of people's innate goodness. In his earlier fiction, like his self-published The Commitments or The Van, the tone is one of lovely, poignant optimism and comic survivalism. But this gives way to the bleaker world of Paddy Clarke Ha Ha Ha - where a boy watches his parents' marriage disintegrating - or the shocking, touching narrative of an abused wife, The Woman Who Walked Into Doors.

The Doyle landscape darkened further with the publication, two years ago, of A Star Called Henry. A first novel in a planned trilogy about Ireland's bloody twentieth century, it was a movement away from contemporary domestic sadness, loneliness, friendship and joy into the savage epic, the recent history where fact is stranger than fiction and where it's not so easy to forgive, to be optimistic, to make jokes (though he tries).

Doyle seemed to have left behind Barrytown and the Rabittes, demotic fluency and psychological finesse, for a more savage land. It is as if he has created a dark looking-glass reflection of his own successful and self-avowedly contented life. Where he is happy, his characters suffer.

They fail where he succeeds. They remind him of worlds he is lucky enough not to inhabit. Well, you could have said all that - drawn a neat, downwards-plunging graph of Doyle's progress, summed up his 'phases' - but not if you'd just seen his latest venture, the quirky, slightly surreal romantic comedy, When Brendan Met Trudy. This is Doyle's first original film script (he has of course adapted the Barrytown Trilogy, The Commitments, The Snapper and The Van, before), and it is light-footed, warm-hearted, full of a sense of its own fun - and full, too, of homages and film-buff nods to other films, from the title (When Harry Met Sally), through the opening sequence (a man lies face downwards on a street, in the rain, a reference to Sunset Boulevard), and on for the rest of the film, actual fragments of classic movies intercut with the action.

When I meet Doyle and his director, Kieron Walsh, they try and list them all for me. They sit back in their chairs, both dressed in black, legs outstretched, grinning at each other.

'The Quiet Man,' says Doyle.

'Once Upon a Time in the West,' adds Walsh.

'The African Queen.'

'The Producers.'

Even a snatch of a film which they made up because they couldn't get permission to use La Strada.

Urgently chasing their schedule and with an eye on their limited budget, they found a skinny Italian man who looked as if he'd been chiselled out of granite in 1947, and a big, good-looking woman, and gave him a bike and her a basket of food and put them in front of a pile of old bricks.

'Hair-raising,' says Walsh fondly.

'Actually the whole thing was the most even-tempered and level-headed experience,' says Doyle. 'Kieron's pretty even-tempered.'

'Yes, I had a temper every day.'

'Although directors are supposed to wear jodhpurs and carry whips and stomp around, aren't they? Just as well we didn't do that. It was fun,' says Doyle. 'And writing is such a lonely business.'

When Brendan met Trudy began with a single, cinematic image - and it was always going to be a film, never a written story; 'it was to be seen and heard'. Roddy Doyle was listening to an old John McCormack song, 'Three O'Clock in the Morning', which had been recorded in 1917 and had a crackle over it that reminded Doyle of the sound of rain falling ('To another man', interposes Walsh, 'it might remind them of an egg frying, mind'). And he found himself imagining a man lying face down in the street, at three in the morning.

'It was a stark image, so I turned it on its face, to reflect my own state of mind at the time. I was happy. It's not an unusual state of mind for me.' The subsequent story is also a melancholy one turned inside out. Brendan is an unenthusiastic teacher, unmarried and dysfunctional and lonely; he sings baritone in a church choir and watches old movies in his drab flat; he hides behind heroic characters like John Wayne, and lives life through them. Trudy is blonde and wacky and earns her money by stealing. She barges her way into Brendan's life and capsizes him utterly. They don't rightly belong together, but the film railroads them into romance anyway, insisting on the possibility of happiness and a happy ending against the odds.

'Well', protests Doyle, 'you're always seeing people together who don't seem to fit. Stunning women with men from the Smurfs. It's like that song: "Is she really going out with him?"

'You see women dropping off Charles Haughey and he's an ugly little dwarf. Nobody suggests that Annie Hall wouldn't fall for Woody Allen. And look at Dawn French - she's not conventionally attractive, but she's so funny that she's just great. Then there are gorgeous people and you meet them and, well, there's not a lot going on there, and the attraction just slips away. You've just got to be happy to be yourself. Anyway, Brendan sings like a bird and he's prepared to make a fool of himself for Trudy. That's important.'

'She's charmed by him,' adds Walsh, and for some reason the two men find this rather funny and giggle nicely at each other once more, like little boys. One of the last scenes of the film is shot in Dublin's Mountjoy prison, a prison for men that is so overcrowded, says Walsh, that its inmates (solidly working-class) can only have showers once every two weeks.

'They're just wandering round the corridors like zombies. Eighty per cent of them are heroin addicts; if they're not before they come in, they are by the time they get out again.

Doyle nods. 'I used to teach some of them,' he says. 'And some of the prison officers. I was in the prison, and I'd be saying hello to the POs and look over my shoulder and see an inmate I knew too. I came away with my feathers a bit ruffled.'

Doyle was a teacher until eight years ago. He stopped when Paddy Clarke was short-listed for the Booker Prize in 1993 - when it won, Doyle was only in his early thirties, suddenly rich, famous, one of Ireland's sons. His fear in giving up was that he would be severed from the world that he wrote about - his characters aren't usually successful, they are working- or lower-middle class; they struggle and often survive and sometimes fail.

'I was determined not to cut myself off from all of that. I had to make sure I kept an eye on the real world. It came up to my desks when I was a teacher. If you are a writer you're at home, which means you're out of touch. You have to make excuses to get out there and look at how the world is changing. For instance, in Brendan Met Trudy I had to make a big effort to get Dublin the way it is now. It's changed so much in the last decade, and I wanted to get that - the Nigerian character who gets deported, that wouldn't have happened before. But I love learning; it is engrossing and part of the job. With the second in the Irish history trilogy, I have to find out about America before the war - a vanished world, and I must try to get closer and closer to it: jazz, skyscrapers being built. As my character moves through it all, I have to move with him.

'It's true that it is harder now than 10 years ago for me to know how a teenager would talk, say. I don't come into regular contact with 14- to 16-year-olds any more - and my children aren't old enough yet. I try and listen to people. I heard these two young women the other day, and one of them was telling the other about dumping this one poor guy and going out with someone else. "He was a bit full-on," she said. I really liked that somehow. Full-on.'

Walsh responds with a story about a screening to an audience of young people of the newly filmed Beckett plays (one of which, Rough for Theatre One, he directed). At the end, the teenagers were asked what they thought. 'They yawned widely and they said the plays were shite.' He and Doyle laugh, hugely pleased.

'Or heroin addicts,' says Doyle. 'I've met heroin addicts and I'm trying to understand the language around heroin - not that I'm intending to write about it, but I want to understand. I sometimes arrange sessions with kids, say; go into schools or something - they love it; people are really keen to talk about things, you know. And I jump at the chance to go into prisons. If I was in jail and I heard that Maeve Binchy was coming in, that'd keep me going. I think they look forward to my visits; I know I do.'

Doyle has steered clear of fame's trappings. He doesn't look like a star or a rich man; he remains modest and funny and unpretentious. 'I'm a well-known face in Dublin, of course. But when The Commitments was released 10 years ago, I made sure I used the same pubs, the same trains, went to the same places. I never allowed myself to become a celebrity or to let that state of mind interfere with my life. And at school I had been teaching 12 years before that film - I was just part of the furniture. They just knew me as their teacher.' Punk Doyle, he was called, because of his earring - though apparently, for all his laid-back manner, he was quite a disciplinarian.

'When Snapper was released,' he goes on, 'there was a special screening, and the kids had a half day off and we bussed them all there for it. It was brilliant.' He turns to Kieron Walsh: 'You know, the day afterwards, three lads came up to me and said, "That film was great." They hovered for a while and then added, "Will you write a song for our band?" I said, "But lads, I didn't write 'Mustang Sally', you know." Touching, though. They thought I could write music too. Sweet.'

Doyle has three children of his own now, of 10 and under. He takes them to their school (a non-denominational state school) in the morning and spends time with them when they return at the end of their day. Because of them, he has started writing children's books. 'I've always told them stories at night, but I'm not very good at making stories up on the spur of the moment. Kids are easily satisfied, but I was never happy with the tales I told them out of my head, so at the end of each working day I'd write a couple of pages for them and read it to them after school and get their reactions. They had some great ideas for how it should go - well, some of them were off the wall as well. And it also gave them a solid sense of what it is that I do every day.'

Roddy Doyle knows he is lucky - it's perhaps that knowledge that keeps him normal, focused on the lives of ordinary people, surrounded by close friendships. 'I have worked very hard for it, but I'm very lucky, yes. It could not have happened. I don't work to any commissions. I do what I want to do. My novels come from within me; they are things I feel I want to do.' His success has given him the time and the freedom to do answer to no one but himself. He says that it would be boring to keep on doing just more of the same (as some of his readers want him to, preferring the Barrytown Doyle to the Easter Rising one). But what characterises all of Doyle's work, light and dark, is a certain sweetness of tone; an unsentimental lovability. He has faith in his characters. He listens to their voices and with a beautiful lack of ego he disappears, letting them be heard instead.

When Brendan Met Trudy opens in May

fields.standfirst: In a week of sugary award shows and surf stars, Positive Women shone out like a beacon
fields.trailText: In a week of sugary award shows and surf stars, Positive Women shone out like a beacon

'I was gobsmacked. She doesn't appear to have much contact with her family now because they didn't take the news very well. Now 25 and on a cocktail of drugs that appear to be working (the virus is currently 'undetectable'), Sarah enjoys the support of her mother and a lovely nurse: 'They're all special to us,' said Jenny of her HIV-positive patients, 'but Sarah could have been my daughter.'

Blithely, she remarked: 'A few boyfriends have taken a few days off work after I've told them [about the virus]. I don't know if it's a coincidence...' Probably not.

Five years later, she met Karl ('I just wasn't fazed in any way at all') and they practised safe sex until their condom broke, too (this programme wasn't great PR for the barrier method). Though Karl didn't catch the virus, Nicki discovered she was pregnant. 'It was better to think positive,' she recalled without irony. She had a daughter, Ellen, who was diagnosed HIV-positive at 15 months.

In a heartbreaking scene, Nicki recalled her daughter's death. After an 'amazing vision', in which a 'beautiful' Ellen was being led away from her, she decided that her sick daughter 'might need to hear from us that's it's OK to go. And as I said those words she took her last breath and it felt so right... she'd opened my heart to a love that I'd never known existed until I'd had a child.' Karl and Nicki have now split and Nicki is 'not in a relationship and I don't intend to be', but she treats herself to a lot of massages because 'it's important to be touched'.

I have given all three of the Positive Women so much space because they deserve it. These days, when the format often looks tired and debased, this was a perfect documentary that simply and seriously tackled a highly emotive subject without squeezing from it a drop of sentimentality.

In a week that also saw ITV's Pride of Britain Awards, a syrupy gong show for an arbitrary selection of the extraordinarily ordinary, in which the likes of Ulrika Jonsson 'honoured' the architects of the London Eye alongside a woman who ran a hospice for children, a little girl with cancer and another woman who saves swans, Positive Women highlighted how desperately important it is to be touched by dignified and moving factual television, rather than bludgeoned into crocodile tears in the name of ratings.

But just to reassure readers that I'm still in touch with my shallow side, the second best documentary of the week was about surfing. Like all the finest sports, surfing is beautiful, terrifying and pointless in equal measure, so while C4's Ride the Wild Surf might have been shallow it was shallow in a really deep kinda way. Or at least as deep as rudely healthy American men called Laird Hamilton, Darrick Doerner, Brett Lickle and Rush Randle (yes, really. Only Boogie Nights' Dirk Diggler was missing from the surf-porn all-stars line-up), with their bull-necks, David Coulthard jawlines and the kind of blank expressions that hint either at a great spiritual peace or an enormous stupidity, can be when talking really heavy shit about big waves.

'Fear gives you intelligence' (though not obviously manifest here) or, after a fun day out avoiding death on a small tsunami : 'That was pretty gnarly!', and my favourite, when faced with an imminent wipe-out: 'It's balls to the wall! Suck, tuck and duck!' The titans of the tides, kings of the crests - the so-called 'Watermen' - are mad, but my god it makes for great pictures.

They ride only the biggest and most fearsome waves in the world, like Maui's Jaws, a wall of water that has been known to roll in at 70ft, though usually hovers at around a manageable - for the merely mildly certifiable - 30ft. Given that the watermen face death regularly, their claim that the experience offers quite a lot in the way of 'spiritual growth' probably isn't to be laughed at, though it's fabulous for one's muscle tone, too.

All the men interviewed (thirty- and fortysomethings, mostly - this is a sport you grow into, not out of) are sponsored professional surfers, so when they're not tracking waves and weather formations on the web, they're inventing real neat new surf stuff, like the snowboard-style surfboard (an 'airboard') with a hydrofoil that literally allows the surfer to fly above the water! The airboard experience looked so mind-blowingly thrilling that had I known such a thing might one day exist, the teenage me would have got straight off that sofa and delayed losing her virginity indefinitely. Suck, tuck and... well, never mind.

And there was pathos, too, beyond the hard body swagger, notably when Laird mused on the possibility of encountering 'surf so big and so perfect that I might not see it again in my lifetime'. Wow, that would be sad, wouldn't it? Not perhaps quite as sad as the possibility of dying of Aids before your fortieth birthday, but pretty poignant, none the less.
