fields.headline: Don't bleat about the bush
fields.standfirst: Some Australian comics whinge, but others can take on the world. And they'll be over here soon
fields.trailText: Some Australian comics whinge, but others can take on the world. And they'll be over here soon
fields.body:
Melbourne Comedy Festival

Australians are so much better than everyone else at everything you can think of that it hardly comes as a surprise to discover that the Melbourne Comedy Festival, the third largest in the world, is also the most fun. Perfect weather, beautiful venues, cheap beer, and a choice selection of the best international and domestic live comedy: you can see why most comedians rate it more highly than Edinburgh and Montreal.

I was fully expecting the event to follow the pattern of the Sydney Olympics - bronzed and muscular Australian comics whupping their foreign counterparts with superior wit, delivery and observational perspicuity - until I discovered that there is, after all, a downside to the general marvellousness of life down under. Having watched 16 Aussie comics performing five-minute slots at the opening-night gala, I felt like I understood the essence of the nation's humour: the Poms are negative and uptight, the Yanks are ignorant and bizarre... we are positive, relaxed, clued-up and down-to-earth, so let's laugh at them. The result is a kind of patriotic smugness, which does not make for great humour.

When I mentioned this theory to some Aussies, they became annoyed and defensive. More to the point, they didn't believe me. Our comics are the best, they yelled, waving their pints of Carlton Premium in my face. So I issued a challenge: their top eight comics against a random selection of talent from the rest of the world. An evil, smirking gleam appeared in the Australians' eyes: it was a competition . They like competitions here!

Battle commenced with Wil Anderson (Aus) against Chris Addison (UK). Physically, they are similar types - young, skinny, tall, handsome - but with the natural tendencies of their respective nations... so Anderson is sinewy and tanned, like he's grown up playing beach volleyball, while Addison has pasty pipecleaner limbs of a kind only produced by English boys' schools. This contrast is misleading, however, as the weakling Brit easily overpowers his Aussie counterpart. Addison's penetrating and impassioned examination of Englishness, Cakes and Ale, has been hardened over eight months' touring and comprises enough material to fill two hours. Meanwhile, all Anderson's charm and skill cannot conceal the paucity of his material, which is lightweight, forgettable men-and-women stuff. Australia 0, Rest of the World 1

The next round involves two comedians who have written shows about their parents. Rich Fulcher (US) performs Mom, I'm Not A Lawyer , based on the true story of a whopping great lie. Greg Fleet (Aus) performs I Wish You Were D(e)ad, an hour of real-life anecdotes about his father - a small-time movie actor and bigamist who abandoned him at the age of 10 by faking his suicide. Both are strong concepts, but Fleet's is by far the more entertaining show, partly because he is 100 times more relaxed on stage and partly because he has thought at every stage of the writing process, 'How can I make this funny?' rather than just elegant and interesting. Australia 1, Rest of the World 1

Now we come to the musical section. Max Sharam is a former pop star in Australia - a one-album wonder who went to LA to make her fortune and has now returned as a sort of deranged cabaret comedienne. Her show, Mad'moselle Max, is billed as a work-in-progress. There are, accordingly, plenty of failed experiments, but Sharam has Factor X in such abundance that you can forgive her almost anything. Dressed as a slutty cleaning lady, she sings about boob jobs ('I've Got Two Under My Skin') and unrequited lust ('Shame He's Gay') in a voice that is part sex-kitten, part opera diva. Remorselessy quirky, she reminds me above all of Cyndi Lauper, and she would surely have won her homeland their second point had not she been paired with Otis Lee Crenshaw (US), ex-con country singer and the greatest live comedian on the face of the earth. Tough draw, Max. Australia 1, Rest of the World 2

Sensing that they are losing control of the match, Australia send out their brightest young hope, Sarah Kendall, a 24-year-old who looks like a supermodel and manages to produce a show without any hint of patriotism nor one single reference to the travails of 'being a woman'. War is an intelligent, witty discussion of two world wars, the Third Reich, Vietnam and the power of television. All this in 60 minutes, with no boring bits and lots of laughs. Amazing. Unfortunately for Australia, she was drawn against Arj Barker (Can). Halfway between Prince and Eddie Izzard, Barker has always been hugely talented and charming, but a year or two ago he seemed to be losing his way in terms of material. His new show, 2001: A Spaced Odyssey , boasts a magnificently weird image change (silver chainmail vest and inconceivably tight pants) and lots of fresh, sweet jokes. A glorious return to form, and enough to secure a valuable half-point. Australia 1 1/2, Rest of the World 2 1/2.

Like Sharam, Judith Lucy (Aus) moved to LA in search of fame; unlike Sharam, she has neither charm nor musical ability, so she has to scrape together 90 minutes of relentlessly sarcastic observations about Hollywood celebrities. Her voice may grate (think Clive James crossed with Dame Edna) and her views on other nations may be predictably Oz-aggrandising ('Frankly, I'd rather shove a three-pronged fork up my arse than live in England'), but her brash, crude humour inevitably yields a few laughs. Lucky for Lucy, she is up against another 'clapped-out old slapper', Jenny Eclair (UK), whose latest effort lacks the thrilling conviction of her 1995 Perrier-winning show, Prozac and Tantrums . The result is stalemate. Australia 2, Rest of the World 3

Miss Itchy (Aus) is a comic legend in Australia, which suggests that the nation's self-image as a straightforward, laidback, no-probs bunch of guys is a little misleading. Because Miss Itchy (aka rotund, foulmouthed Linda Haggar and Faehy Younger) is one of the most disturbing, least straightforward things I've ever seen. The show I saw was a rerun of 1996's I Can't Stop Burrowing, a prison play that lay somewhere between Benny Hill, Kafka, The Young Ones and Prisoner: Cell Block H . Profane, disorienting and oddly serious, it gave me nightmares. I can only be thankful I didn't see The Crème de Menthe Breakfast Show , featuring the 'cunt in the cage', which sounds horribly Freudian. Poor Jeff Green (UK), then, who looks bland and hackneyed next to Des O'Connor, never mind something this strange and dangerous. Australia 3, Rest of the World 3.

So the decider is between Adam Hills (Aus), a comic so clean-cut, positive and relaxed he could be a national symbol, and Dave Gorman (UK), so understated, eccentric and original, he too could be a national symbol, were he not competing on behalf of the Rest of the World.

Beneath that boyish visage, Hills is a tough competitor - his shows are hugely energetic, technically flawless and ruthlessly crowd-pleasing. He could easily have made it as a demagogic politician, a revivalist preacher or a door-to-door salesman. However, he is queasily patriotic ('maybe that's why Australians are doing so well, kicking ass all over the world') and cloyingly upbeat. Gorman, bless 'im, would never be so crass; his show - a quest to find all the other Dave Gormans on the planet - is a quiet exploration of human nature; the universe inside an anorak. Sorry, Australia, but there can only be one winner. Australia 3, Rest of the World 4.

fields.headline: What's it all about, Albee?
fields.standfirst: His plays may be full of sparring vitriol and dysfunctional lives, but Edward Albee is rather sweet, thinks  Simon Fanshawe
fields.trailText: His plays may be full of sparring vitriol and dysfunctional lives, but Edward Albee is rather sweet, thinks  Simon Fanshawe
fields.body:
Edward Albee reminds me of an airline experiment that happened some years ago. The hostesses served passengers with raspberry-flavoured ice-cream. But it was coloured banana yellow. And no one could make out exactly what it tasted of. Albee's most famous work is still Who's Afraid Of Virginia Woolf? Premiered in New York in 1962, it won the first of his three Pulitzer Prizes and in 1966 was filmed by Mike Nichols. Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton played George and Martha, a pair of veteran marrieds armed to the teeth with intellectual savagery, emotionally stripping each other in front of a younger couple. The razor slashes of wit and extended alcoholic bouts of recrimination painted a husband and wife seemingly bent on mutual destruction. A-ha, the dull people thought, life imitating art. Albee the bitter chronicler of arid marriage.

But revived three years ago in London with Diana Rigg and David Suchet in the title roles, you saw two people flexing their wit and intelligence in a heroic effort to make sense of being together and in the world. Theirs was a marriage that worked in its own terms, despite the collateral damage. And while certainly raw and emotionally naked, it emerged as a very funny play. In fact a love story. That is what Albee thinks too. Banana ice-cream tasting of raspberries.

'No,' he says with an acknowledging grin, 'the servants did that.'

Yet for all his rejection of these people and their values - he is a fervent Democrat, describing Bush as 'a heartbeat away from being President' - he embraces them in his plays and is himself something of the gentle patrician. He is a Wasp in both senses of the word, turning his stinging intelligence on his own people. Three Tall Women he readily admits was about his domineering mother. And although it's an excoriating portrait of the old girl, it feels not so much a revenge but a reconciliation after her death and with death itself.

The physical territory of Finding the Sun is similar. Two young upper class women are married to two rich young men who were previously lovers. They have buried their sexuality in convention. Endlessly weary about being asked to expand on what he is saying in any of his plays, Albee sighs and eventually acknowledges that this one is 'about the responsibilities of being alive, of living fully and being your own person. What happens to poor Daniel and Benjamin is that they are trapped by social pressure.'

It is bleak. Yet there is optimism. There is Fergus, a 16-year-old, oh-so-good-looking and preternaturally intelligent boy who wanders in and out of the play, which is set - conveniently for those who like to watch young men in swimwear - on a beach. 'He is a quizzical, sweet boy,' says Albee, entranced by his own creation. 'I like Fergus a lot. He's like all those boys I went to prep school with... my first loves. The skin of those kids...'

Inevitably Fergus leaves the play after hearing a wistful speech by his mother saying that she doesn't want to around when, as Albee puts it, 'he will discover that all things are not possible.' In as much as one can pin Albee down, this illustrates one of the great atmospheres of his work. It's not bitterness or disillusion so much as that we live in danger of getting to the end of our lives and being disappointed. 'What could be worse,' he says, 'than getting to the end of your life and realising that you haven't fully participated?'

Or, as he says about Marriage Play, in which more bitterly but more quietly than in Virginia Woolf, a couple - played in this new production by Sheila Gish and Bill Paterson - battle it out on the matrimonial turf: 'I suppose the conclusion of that play is that they have got to the stage where they realise that the final relationship in one's life is a form of dying.'

Death is a great annoyance to Albee. 'I enjoy participating,' he says and continues in a typical quotable riff, 'and I disapprove of death. The only two things you can write about are life and death. The dread of reaching a certain age is that it will be interrupted and that one may not finish life.' It happens to the couple in A Delicate Balance who arrive at their friends' house gripped by an inchoate fear, which is little more than mortality. Yet despite his age and being in what he presumes will be his last relationship, Albee rejects the strictly autobiographical take on this.

He fends it off sarcastically when you ask him why he doesn't want to die. 'Probably because I enjoy being alive.' Thanks for that. It's in a fairly long line of staccato put-downs that are only rescued by a sardonic smile, and which mask his warmth in the same way that first impressions of bitterness can overshadow the humanity of his work.

The marriage in Marriage Play is not a bad marriage, he says, 'except for what's happening'. Ha, ha. 'They've had a good relationship, they enjoy each other's company, they make jokes together. It's better than a lot of marriages. They've just got to the stage where he has realised that in your last relationship maybe nothing has to be enough.' Ow.

Does he see bitterness in everything? 'Yes I guess I do. Except when the sun comes out.' So are you sad and bitter? 'Oh, no. Not at all.' Edward Albee, raspberry and bananas.

Finding the Sun/Marriage Play open at the National Theatre's Cottesloe on 8 May

webTitle: The race to be a Capital of Culture is a non-starter

fields.headline: The race to be a Capital of Culture is a non-starter
fields.trailText: When cities start talking about how European they are, it's time to start worrying. Cardiff, for example, is claiming to be Europe's fastest-growing capital city. What about Dublin, Lisbon or Ljubljana? And Newcastle and Gateshead, an invisibly hyphenated urban entity that's new to me, has taken to issuing press releases suggesting that it has 'Europe's largest temporary arts space'.
fields.body:
When cities start talking about how European they are, it's time to start worrying. Cardiff, for example, is claiming to be Europe's fastest-growing capital city. What about Dublin, Lisbon or Ljubljana? And Newcastle and Gateshead, an invisibly hyphenated urban entity that's new to me, has taken to issuing press releases suggesting that it has 'Europe's largest temporary arts space'.

How do they know? Where is the statistical authority that records such information, and are they sure that they have got the word temporary in the right place in the sentence?

Every city struggling to make it out of the third division and into the second, latches on to the word Europe sooner or later. It is invariably emblazoned on the 'welcome to' signs at airports: 'Leeds: a European City'. Of course, it's meant to imply steely-eyed vision, matched with cultural achievement, rather than geography. As if to underscore the awkward mix of social unease and vainglory on which such claims are based, they are always delivered in the same triumphant tone: 'We have the tallest high-rise flats, the longest wall, the largest community of artists, the greatest social deprivation in Europe.' It doesn't matter if it's good or bad news, at least we have put ourselves on the map seems to be the line.

Which is why ambitious cities are so keen on collaring a European title that looks so good on the municipal letterhead. None comes more sought after than the European Capital of Culture logo. It wasn't always this way. The days when culture was seen as decadence on the rates are not so long gone.

The big difference since then has been the Glasgow effect. No doubt about it, Glasgow is a different place since it was European Capital of Culture. Ten years ago, it was still stuck with the razor gangs in the badlands stereotype. Now, despite the best efforts of the Daily Record to remind everybody about the city's heroin-soaked housing estates, Glasgow is better off, and more confident about itself than it has been for half a century.

No wonder that Birmingham and Newcastle, Liverpool and Bristol and all the rest are lining up to repeat the trick in 2008, the next time Britain gets a shot at the title. But if they are looking to pull off the same regenera tion-through-culture trick as Glasgow, the title is not worth having. It has become meaningless by dint of sheer repetition.

The idea of a capital of anything runs counter to Chris Smith's line on partnership and ethnic quotas in museums. In its nature, it's élitist. It's setting out to make one place get the limelight and it runs against a lot of ingrained ideology about the arts. But in this particular case, élitism works. When I found myself in Glasgow trying to run a year of architecture in 1999, in the wake of the Capital of Culture programme, the first thing people started saying was: 'Let's be nice to the losers. Let's do the year in partnership with Liverpool and Edinburgh.' But what on earth is the point of having a capital of anything if you are going to dilute its impact by spreading it thinly all over everything?

But this is exactly what the European Union has done with the Capitals of Culture programme. It declared no less than seven cities of culture for 2000. This year is equally dotty: there are two capitals of culture - Rotterdam and Porto.

There will only be one Glasgow; the British cities lining up to follow in its footsteps will have to make do with culture for culture's sake. But I don't think that is what Councillor Bore, leader of Birmingham City Council, will have in mind when he unveils Birmingham's bid for the title this week. He has his eyes on jobs and investment.

And there is nothing wrong with that, but if we are really looking for means of economic renewal through cultural regeneration, it's time to put the old cultural capital warhorse out of its misery and start again with something fresher.

fields.headline: One Nil to Neil
fields.standfirst: Mix Pearl Jam, Crowded House, the Smiths and Radiohead and you get a bona-fide supergroup
fields.trailText: Mix Pearl Jam, Crowded House, the Smiths and Radiohead and you get a bona-fide supergroup
fields.body:
Neil Finn St James Theatre, Auckland, New Zealand

It's like stumbling into your own birthday party - you don't know where to look first. Centre stage is Neil Finn, hair greying but still a hint of that haphazard Crowded House quiff, a wisecracking ringleader for the musical circus around him. On his right, the almost impossibly tall Ed O'Brien from Radiohead. To his left, the long-lost British guitar hero Johnny Marr, wearing a shaggy Liam Gallagher haircut. Ponytailed bass player Sebastian Steinberg, from New York avant-garde rock group Soul Coughing, alternates between upright and electric bass. Occasionally, Eddie Vedder from Pearl Jam takes to the stage, throwing himself at the microphone. At the rear, multi-instrumentalist Lisa Germano and Radiohead's drummer Phil Selway lurk in the shadows.

Welcome to Neil Finn's 'Seven Worlds Collide', a five-night run in New Zealand's recently renovated St James Theatre. It's much more than a launch for the former Crowded House leader's solo album, One Nil, his second since the band's demise. Here, for one week only, is a catch-them-while-you-can supergroup.

The five shows have been preceded by four days of 12-hour rehearsals in a barn at Karekare, the wave-swept west Auckland village where Jane Campion's The Piano was filmed. It's a rushed itinerary - Johnny Marr only managed to make it for a day of rehearsals and there were 40 songs to learn, from Crowded House classics to songs on One Nil to dusty old Split Enz tunes.

But any rough edges have been smoothed out by the time the band hits the stage for this fifth gig after Finn's solo opening gesture of Crowded House's plaintive anthem, 'When You Come'. What follows is three-and-a-half hours of the stuff that makes you fall in love with your record collection all over again.

Sometimes, it's almost too much. On 'Suffer Never', the gritty highlight from 1995's Finn brothers album, Finn, Ed O'Brien turns the song into a slice of apocalyptic guitar meltdown. And Vedder's rush through Pearl Jam's own live favourite, 'Better Man', sees Phil Selway pounding the drumkit in a manner he hasn't needed to do in Radiohead for a long time.

When Marr starts into the Smiths' classic 'There Is a Light', with Neil Finn managing a sweeter approximation of Morrissey's drone, the excitement is intense. Two hours later, the impossible happens; after mumbling that he's hasn't played the song for a while, Marr begins the pulsating opening to 'How Soon Is Now'. O'Brien, who'll later drunkenly gush in a backroom bar that Marr is one of the reasons he picked up a guitar, adds the spine-tingling distortion. And when Neil's son, Liam, takes to the stage with his band, Betchadupa, for the Split Enz classics 'I Got You', 'History Never Repeats' and 'I See Red', it's with Vedder singing them, careering around the stage to songs that have become staples at every beach barbecue and Saturday night party in New Zealand for the last 20 years. A few days after the gig, Finn says the moment he saw Liam playing 'I Got You' was the highlight of the week, especially as he'd had to calm his son's nerves before he hit the stage. 'It was magic for me - here's a song I'd written before Liam was born, and there's his band playing it, rocking up a storm.'

Finn's plan for the extravaganza came late last year: he and O'Brien had been longtime friends since meeting at a festival in the Crowded House days, Germano and Steinberg had played on One Nil and Johnny Marr and Finn had met at Linda McCartney's memorial concert in 1998. Vedder has gone on record as saying Split Enz made his life bearable as a mixed-up kid in California.

Finn says: 'We all felt really moved by the week, because we proved that with a really strong will you can become a band. The fact that it was five nights was a great thing because it meant that we could develop - it wasn't a one-off all-star occasion.'

It's not often you can find seven such strong personalities playing on a stage and giving each other room, and that's not lost on the man behind it all. It was, he says, fondly, five nights of 'charms and delights'.

'Ed was just expressing that what he liked about this was that it had a certain joyfulness about it.' He's not joking. A few hours after the last gig ends, Ed O'Brien is what you could adequately describe as emotional at the after-show party, still coming down to earth after the week. 'When Neil played that last note, we were all sat on the edge of the stage,' he says, 'and we thought, "Oh no, it's over".'

One Nil is out now. Finn's two-week tour starts at the Belfast Waterfront on Saturday

fields.headline: We sure have lift-off
fields.standfirst: As one new play soars into outer space, another breaks up on re-entry
fields.trailText: As one new play soars into outer space, another breaks up on re-entry
fields.body:
The Far Side of the Moon Newcastle Playhouse
Underworld Nordoon Arts Centre, Maidenhead
The Ramayana Olivier, London SE1

It is full of marvels. The Far Side of the Moon is a comedy of brotherly love and estrangement which is also a metaphysical investigation. Here's a kaleidoscope of imagery which invites you to look at the world as if you were a lunar guest. Here's one of the most vivid events currently visiting the British stage. It truly lives up to its name.

The French-Canadian filmmaker and theatre director Robert Lepage is the sole writer, director and performer. On the fortieth anniversary of Yuri Gagarin's journey into space, he's set himself to examine what it is that human beings regard as alien, which means that he ends up looking at what we think of as normal.

While Laurie Anderson's aptly eerie music seethes and pings like the current in a faulty element, Lepage takes on the parts of two cosmically conscious brothers. One's a TV weatherman - loud, confident, prosperous, often pictured importantly in front of a globe; the other's a timid, constantly defeated 'cultural philosopher', bent on examining the effect of science and, particularly, the space race on popular culture.

They're attached to and wary of each other. Each is the other's far side of the moon, as distant as Russians were from Americans in the Sixties. And each is a version of the director. In a canny, critically pre-emptive move, Lepage has put on stage the extremes of his theatrical personality - the showman and the hippy free-associator.

The droll precision of the sibling scenes, in which both sides are as ridiculous as they are touching, is a sur prise from the not pernickertly realistic Lepage. But they're only half his point. At the back of the action, a sequence of images peels back layers from everyday life, making unsuspected, dashing connections; domestic tasks take on an extraterrestrial tinge.

While you watch a man entering a launderette, you see black-and-white film of the Soviet space programme; gradually, you notice the similarity between the round doors of the washing-machines, the portholes of a cabin and the helmets of cosmonauts. You look at the slow tumble of clothes inside the machines and recognise the weightless drifting of spacemen.

An infant-sized puppet, swaddled like a spaceman, swims out of one of those portholes. As he does so, you hear childish gurgles, listen to a news announcement about man's first walk in space and realise once again how much those early cosmonauts looked like babies, bouncing along with their outsize globular heads and trailing umbilical cords.

A man calls for a lift - the bleep of the button sounds like the chirrup of Sputnik circling Earth. A man gets trapped in a lift, as sealed off from his world as if he were in a space capsule. What, Lepage asks, without ever clumpingly putting the important question into words, is so strange about strange? The show moves to Glasgow's Tramway this week and to the National in July.

Energy cracks like a whip across the stage in the scary, smouldering, breakthrough piece from Frantic Assembly. Frantic call themselves a 'physical theatre' group, and though this is usually an irritating term (how could a theatre piece not be physical?), it's not hard to make out its meaning in Underworld. Gesture is used here not simply to colour or inflect the dialogue, but to tell a different kind of story.

In the opening moments of Underworld , all you see on the almost bare stage, hung with long banners, glowing with deep contrasts of warm light and dark shadow, dominated by a huge wardrobe, resounding to a thumping beat, are disjointed gestures. Unidentified feet poke up from the end of a bath, then slither down; an unknown body slides downwards across a bed. Everything is strobed.

When talk breaks in, it's at first so desultory that it sounds like improvisation. In the past, members of the audience have complained on discovering that what they'd thought of as confessional material was in fact made up. But then things tighten. What unfolds - and this is the breakthrough - is an old-fashioned (that's to say, tight and exciting) horror story given wings by a supple gymnastic technique. In the absence of words, there is never silence.

Four young women, two of them sisters, gather together in an isolated house. A murder has taken place and one of them suffers from nightmares. The others cluster around, apparently protectively, but the seance they have is creepy, gloriously so for the audience, when the candlelit table starts to revolve in the twilight. They have a frightening excursion; even their v Bridget Jones, v funny exchanges take on a threatening edge. The night ends in bloodshed and in a fight, danced with terrific, sinister muscularity.

The sheer physical agility of the all-female cast allows an all-encompassing weirdness: a figure can loll in the bottom of the wardrobe with her limbs rucked up like those of an abandoned puppet; a character will chat away while standing on the top of that cliff-like wardrobe and then jump from its heights, as if walking over a doorstep. But they can rein it in too, executing dances of silent collaboration and exclusion, moving in dreamy concert, like synchronised swimmers. The distin guished result can be seen at the Lyric Hammersmith on 23 April, after which it tours.

Some Frantic dynamism would be welcome in Indu Rubasingham's production of The Ramayana, which has come to the Olivier from Birmingham. A mistake is committed before the show even begins: 'Try to feel at home,' an anxious warmer-up merchant begs the audience, immediately frightening them to death. But it is impossible to relax when a piece is as ill at ease as this.

Peter Oswald's version of the epic Hindu poem, a tale of love and war, in which the divine Rama fights for the love of his wife, Sita, against a cunning devil, should provide ideal material for the stage. Everything is always, in the manner of the theatre, turning into something else: monkeys become gods, eagles lose their wings and sprout them again, devils shift their shapes. As one character points out here, immediately creating a stick with which to beat the play, you can resist what you see, but not what you imagine.

Imagination isn't allowed space here. The fact that everything takes place in front of a shower curtain wouldn't matter if the actors were given a chance to breathe, but they're just plonked down and required to declaim. As Rama, Ramon Tikaram (Ferdy from This Life) has been got up to look like the Green Lady who used to smirk over restaurants: his locks tumble around a bright blue face out of which he pronounces adequately but without animation. His demon antagonist wears a crimson helmet that makes him look like a dancing fire-extinguisher; his followers bulge their eyes and poke out their tongues to promote fiendishness. The monkey god has an embarrassing pants-and-truss costume.

If you're given, as some of the audience are, a banana, you might raise a grin, but you couldn't ever think any of it mattered.

fields.headline: Seductive - with a marrow
fields.trailText: Rokia Traoré Barbican, London EC2
fields.body:
Rokia Traoré Barbican, London EC2

Rokia Traore's gig last Thursday night clashed with Omara Portuondo - of Buena Vista Social Club fame - at the Royal Festival Hall. When I met Traoré the day before, she was quietly hoping the odd punter would turn up. 'Even if there are only 10 people, I will be happy to perform,' she says, in the soft husk of a voice that everyone remembered from last year's Womad (she arrived late, lost her main-stage billing, had to go on against veteran show-off Papa Wemba, and still got great reviews). After that, Traoré left Emmylou Harris, Rubén González, Norma Waterson and Youssou N'Dour trailing in her mellifluous wake to win best roots album of 2000 in a national critics poll with Wanita (Indigo).

In the event, the Barbican was packed (though, to be fair, some had come along to witness the astonishing first-half antics of Kimmo Pohjonen, Finland's answer to Jimi Hendrix, only on the accordion). Traoré is already hailed as the new queen of African music, a title that usually denotes 'venerable' and 'large', except that Mali's latest export is a reed-like 27-year-old who lives near Paris and did Later With Jools Holland two nights earlier (between Frank Skinner and the Black Crowes) in a see-through skirt.

Traoré deploys more vocal force live than on either the seductive Wanita or her acclaimed 1998 debut, Mouneissa: long, plaintive notes thrown out; a bit of lisp and warble; bridled feeling. Things began quietly, Traoré alone on stage with her guitar before being joined by two guys on n'goni (half banjo, half marrow); balafon (big, buzzy xylophone); two backing singers; one clattering, hard-bellied calabash; plus flute player Malik Mezzadri, who added a spacey new dimension to the stand-out 'Wanita'.

The daughter of a diplomat, Traoré grew up in Algeria, Saudi Arabia and Belgium as well as Mali, and was inspired as much by Tina Turner on video as Mali's griot singers. She gave up a sociology degree in Brussels to return to Mali and music. Her lyrics are about respecting ancestors and women's rights; she has also written a lullaby for children of divorced parents. Back in Mali, they're proud that she's taking their culture abroad, but tell her they can't understand why she doesn't use 'modern instruments' (like compatriots Oumou Sangare and Baaba Maal), 'why I sing in Bamanan [her first language], with a village accent'.

In English, Traoré dedicates 'Laidu' to old lovers ('I admire you') and young lovers ('I wish you good luck'). The pace is whipped up with a talking drum, Finally, the shoes come off, she lets loose those long graceful limbs, kicks up her skirt with a huge smile; everybody's out of their seat.

Traoré parents had hoped she'd get an office job: 'They said to me, it's true that when you sing for us at home it's sweet, but we're not sure other people will like it.'

fields.headline: Behind the lines
fields.standfirst: Sebastiao Salgado brings us face to face with the world's 100 million migrants and gives them back their humanity
fields.trailText: Sebastiao Salgado brings us face to face with the world's 100 million migrants and gives them back their humanity
fields.body:
Migrations The New Art Gallery Walsall, until 10 June

Sebastiao Salgado worked for a doctorate in political economics in Brazil and Paris as a young man and, in a way, he has stayed true to that vocation. His extraordinary journalism deals in what auditors of nations call 'macro': he is the first truly global photographer. His last major project, Workers, depicted desperate, distant tribes of labourers united on the margins of world capitalism. His latest project, Migrations, is no less ambitious. It is a profound survey of the mass movement of refugees in our time, which has seen the displacement of people on a scale unprecedented in history. Salgado attempts to take full account of this wandering nation of 100 million migrants, and to measure the balance of payments it exacts on the collective human spirit.

In the seven years he has been taking these photographs he has turned himself into something of a multinational, too. Having left the photographers' co-operative Magnum in 1994 ('if I stay,' Salgado observed melodramatically at the time, 'I die'), he established a worldwide agency, Amazonas, to deal with only his own work. The franchise is proving effective. The new gallery in Walsall is one of 16 venues in which this appropriately itinerant exhibition will be seen across the globe. There are two vast volumes of photographs in book form to accompany the touring show - 100,000 copies of each have been published in six languages - as well as a multilingual website (www.sebastiaosalgado.com.br).

No other person on the planet, you guess, has come as close to the world's restless upheaval in the past decade, and none has been so resourceful in bringing its reality to the attention of the 'stable' nations.

What strikes you most immediately about Salgado's work, then, is the sheer scale of the endeavour: he has travelled to 35 countries, most of them in extremis, to create this portrait of a stateless people. The surprise, perhaps, is the fact that looking at the compendious drama that has resulted is not simply overwhelming. Though he seeks to delineate the kind of population movements that might be indi cated by broad arrows in a text book, Salgado never fails to give his contemporary history paintings a complex, immediate human face. One effect of his pictures is to place the viewer intimately within ethnic groups - Kurds, Palestinians, Bosnians - whose names have become easy journalistic shorthand for displacement and return to them some of their individual humanity.

The constant companion to most of the people photographed, the event they all have in common, is the road itself. It acts as a metaphor for both despair and hope, and mostly it seems to go on for ever. From Mozambique there is a photograph of a woman scaling a vast road bridge, her bed-roll on her head, her child on her back. When Salgado asked how far she had left to go, she replied quietly that she was walking to Maputo, 750 miles away.

Sometimes it is enough that the road leads anywhere but here - 800,000 people have left Vietnam by boat since 1975, desperate enough to let winds and currents decide their destination - and, in some cases, it becomes the closest approximation to home. In 1995, for example, Salgado photographed hundreds of Muslim refugees in Croatia who had been forced to construct a life for themselves on a train without a destination: 'not victims of rape, torture or ethnic cleansing,' his caption explains, 'they had fled their homes before the atrocities reached them, so they had not earned the right to migrate...'; instead they sat for weeks and months in a siding, watching the world, with its timetable, rumble by.

Salgado's camera recognises no boundaries so in the midst of this project, not surprisingly, he recalled: 'At times I wasn't sure if I was in Mexico City or Manila.' But for the people he depicts, the world's borders could hardly be more defined, or more arbitrary. At some point in each of the narratives of escape every one comes up against the barbed wire that defends our world against the desperation they represent. In a featureless scrub desert outside Tijuana two men peer through a huge metal fence at a possible future in the featureless scrub desert on the other side: America. In Morocco, refugees from famine and civil war in the Sudan, who have travelled much of the way on foot, find themselves living in the shells of cars in a portside wrecker's yard, losing hope daily of a passage to Spain.

Interviewed about his project soon after it was completed, Salgado said: 'I once had political beliefs, I thought there were answers. I am no longer sure.' The pictures bear out this doubt. At times they seem to search in vain for a proper sense of scale, for a way of containing the subject. However far the photographer steps back from the problem, looking for context, further and further into the mountains or across the plain, the random geometries of the aimless and stateless still fill his frame.

Life and death both become problems of logistics in this global no man's land: bulldozers struggle to bury the mounds of corpses of Rwandan refugees in Zaire while aid workers attempt to get food to a million starving survivors. When Salgado closes in again, however, there seem to be more hopeless stories than the world could contain: a sharp-eyed money lender with a fat wad of dollars is picked out among the dead and dying; mothers observe a morning ritual of strapping false limbs on to sons and daughters.

As an extended footnote to his reporting, Salgado collected a gallery of portraits of children from each place he visited. The pictures were taken as a necessity - 'When I was with refugees from Mozambique,' he explained, 'there were children everywhere, stopping me from working. So I said: "If you want to be photographed, line up here. Then you let me work, OK."' - but still they have a restless intensity. This singularity is heightened by proximity to the photographs of some of the 4,000 orphan toddlers who compete for space at a single SOS shelter in Zaire, or the battalion of abandoned babies tumbling over one another on the roof of a makeshift care home in São Paolo.

In Paris, where photojournalists are revered as semi-mythical beings, these pictures created a furore when published. In Le Monde Salgado stood accused of 'sentimental voyeurism' and 'exploitation of compassion'. There are always problems, of course, in finding beauty in suffering, but even in his portraits Salgado never comes close to crossing a line into manipulation or sentimentality. The photographs are hard won from places most of us would never want to see at first hand, and they let us begin to imagine, for an instant, what it might be like to be on broken railway tracks and in pathless forests and adrift on swollen rivers - anywhere going nowhere fast. His own argument for his work, in the face of this criticism, was a simple one: 'I take photographs the way I see them, with the light I have known, with the life I have had.' It is a light and a life that recasts the world.

In Le Monde Salgado stood accused of 'sentimental voyeurism' and 'exploitation of compassion'. There are always problems, of course, in finding beauty in suffering, but even in his portraits Salgado never comes close to crossing a line into manipulation or sentimentality. The photographs are hard won from places most of us would never want to see at first hand, and they let us begin to imagine, for an instant, what it might be like to be on broken railway tracks and in pathless forests and adrift on swollen rivers - anywhere going nowhere fast. His own argument for his work, in the face of this criticism, was a simple one: 'I take photographs the way I see them, with the light I have known, with the life I have had.' It is a light and a life that recasts the world.

webTitle: She was blonde or black. Divine or an ogre. And as for those asps...

fields.headline: She was blonde or black. Divine or an ogre. And as for those asps...
fields.standfirst: Cleopatra's image is ever-changing. Forty years ago, it was defined by Liz Taylor. Now it's Tracey Emin's turn
fields.trailText: Cleopatra's image is ever-changing. Forty years ago, it was defined by Liz Taylor. Now it's Tracey Emin's turn
fields.body:
Cleopatra of Egypt British Museum, London WC1, until 26 August

Interpretation - as this exhibition makes clear - is a nice excuse for indulging pet prejudices. We know little enough for certain about Cleopatra, which frees us to think whatever we please.

As a mythical character, she is the sum total of all the contradictory stories told about her. A racial outsider, stigmatised by Augustan Rome, or a triumphant feminist, ensnaring Caesar and bullying Mark Antony? An irresistible enchantress, as for romantic painters like Delacroix, or simply 'the wickedest woman in history' as Cecil B. de Mille salaciously called her? Shakespeare's play perhaps gets closest to the mercurial muddle that surrounds her: his Cleopatra has a different persona - siren, shrew, tomboy, high priestess - in every scene.

At the British Museum, the iconographic puzzle begins with a series of choices about what she looked like. There is no firm evidence. Despite her sensual reputa tion, Plutarch reported that her chief charm was her conversation, and contemporary coins lumber her with an unprepossessingly beaky nose. The exhibition lines up a row of statuesque images of this absent being, and asks you to select a white goddess or a black beauty. A head in marble makes her look wise, calm, classically reasonable; a full-length figure in basalt, wearing a peekaboo sheath and clutching a cornucopia, is an emblem of baleful, savage erotic power.

If the contrast between white marble and black basalt seems too schematic, there is also a head in porous yellow limestone: an earth mother with luscious, gobbling lips. Another head from Delos reverts to the official numismatic profile, emphasising the high cheekbones and sniffing, suspicious nose of a martinet and closing down the lush mouth into a mean, strict line. Caricatures depict the orgiastic afterlife of the love goddess. In a Roman terracotta lamp, she squats to impale herself on a columnar penis which has conveniently sprouted from the tail of a crocodile.

Shakespeare's Cleopatra declares herself a deity, purged of all 'baser elements'. Divinities of course can misbehave with impunity, and don't need to be democratically accountable: playing Cleopatra in Joseph Mankiewicz's film, a rampaging Elizabeth Taylor tells Richard Burton's Antony to ignore the senate, and shrills 'Gods are not elected!' The exhibition follows this passage from history to myth, and documents Cleopatra's posthumous conquest of the entire world. As ruler of Mauretania, she wears an elephant scalp. Returning to Egypt after Caesar's assassination, she is gradually Africanised, even though she was a Hellenistic monarch who never saw a sphinx or a pyramid.

Because every society has its own ideas about her, she is claimed by cultures in which she did not belong and reconceived by historical periods which have new ideas about the eternal female. Fifteenth-century illustrations to Boccaccio concentrate on her sinfulness and the self-imposed penalty of suicide: in one of these, she attaches two leathery pythons - not thin, flickering asps - to her breasts, and has them gorge on the nipples. In the 1740s Tiepolo, painting the banquet she laid on for Antony, saw her as a rococo aristocrat, unacquainted with the dark continent, and gave her blonde hair and milky skin. This might be the Cleopatra of Handel's opera about Caesar's Egyptian campaign, first performed in 1724: a frivolously alluring coloratura soprano, no longer liable to Boccaccio's accusations of lechery and greed.

A little later, Angelica Kaufmann painted a more romantic Cleopatra, an implausible model of connubial loyalty who visits Antony's tomb with a memorial garland of flowers. By the end of the nineteenth century she had changed again, and was now represented as a devouring ogre. Théophile Gautier wrote a feverish account of her gaudy nights, and the painter Alexandre Cabanel showed her listlessly petting a leopard while watching as the slaves on whom she is trying out poison contort in agony at her feet.

Aptly, the first Cleopatra on film was vampily played by Theda Bara, whose name was an anagram for Arab Death.

Cleopatra astutely marketed her own image, associating herself with the worship of Isis. Among the titles she gave herself was Philadelphia, which means brother-loving: there was a certain justice to this boast, since she married two of her own brothers.

Because she controlled her own propaganda and publicity, it's not surprising to find her being merchandised all over again in 1934, when Cecil B. de Mille's film about her - with Claudette Colbert as a giggling hoyden who belches during the banquet with Antony - went on release. A press book alerted cinema managers to the range of Cleopatra-branded trophies they could tout: belts, make-up compacts, cigarette cases. Advertisements invited women to 'frame your face with lovely curls' in imitation of Colbert's skittish queen.

Three decades later, when Elizabeth Taylor became the new face of Cleopatra, the coiffure being sold changed once more: Taylor's black hair, ironed flat, defined the new look of the 1960s. A pity that Twentieth Century Fox cut short this history by refusing to allow the museum any images from the Taylor film.

The American artist and poet Barbara Chase-Reboud has created a Cleopatra for our own mercenary times, fabricating a contract for her third marriage: a maze of hieroglyphic legalese scribbled in a volume of hand-made parchment, from which dangle an onerous fringe of waxen seals, talismans and good-luck charms. Snakes coil across the paper, and marginal sketches of pyramids fill out the catalogue of marital assets. This is a Cleopatra who clearly drove a hard bargain during discussions of the pre-nuptial agreement.

And the BM has recruited an even more modish and slangily local Cleopatra, who will be bringing the archetype up to date at a lecture on 19 May: our own version of the fatal woman is Tracey Emin, fresh from the Cairo Biennale and a cruise down the Nile. Will she, I wonder, be adorned with dung-beetles and have adders wriggling out of her cleavage?

If you want to know the answer, tickets for her performance cost £5. Carrying on as Cleopatra continues to be good business.

webTitle: This paint is killing me; one of us must go

fields.headline: This paint is killing me; one of us must go
fields.standfirst: Little wonder that Leonora expired in Il Trovatore. The interior design would finish anyone off
fields.trailText: Little wonder that Leonora expired in Il Trovatore. The interior design would finish anyone off
fields.body:
Il Trovatore ENO, Coliseum, London WC2
Concerts for Holy Week Concordia, Temple Church, London EC4/Radio 3
Parsifal Live from the Met, New York/Radio 3

For reasons I have not managed to fathom (like much else about this occluded opera), Il Trovatore has been called an 'Italian St Matthew Passion'. With effort, a tenuous link might be identified: it contains grand choruses, plenty of death and, in certain respects, sacrifice. Any more profound connections between Verdi's rousing four-act tale of a gypsy, a troubadour and his lover and Bach's sublimely cogent account of the crucifixion are not easy to unearth.

I'm clutching at straws here, but, nevertheless, it may be one reason why English National Opera music director Paul Daniel and general director Nicholas Payne chose to mount their production at the start of Holy Week - they have more understanding of the work than I. According to press interviews last week, their special affinity with the piece is what persuaded them to put in abeyance their normal duties and assume the director's mantle themselves.

Yet I have paused for some time before deciding how to write about this bewildering venture. The singing, mostly by company principles, is often admirable, and that should be said at the outset. It is a dismal national trait that we mistrust those who show skill in more than one cultural field. Instead of applauding boldness and adventure, we succumb to envy and prejudice. 'Jack of all trades' springs too readily to scornful English lips. Such a blinkered attitude is easy to refute when the efforts which prompt it are successful - hardly the case here.

Trovatore is notoriously difficult to stage. Apparently, Payne and Daniel could not identify an available producer equipped for the task. This seems improbable. Some might say it insults the many gifted figures currently working in opera. Perhaps money was a reason; this must certainly have been a low-cost enterprise. With the exception of a few wooden rifles, there were no props. The production was also unencumbered by ideas and scene endings were especially problematic. Often characters just froze and waited for the lights to go off. Leonora's death was unusual - she leant against the wall and expired. The abstract set, by Conor Murphy, has few identifying features of time or place and much orange paint.

Surging emotion is symbolised - symbols otherwise being in frugal supply, which will relieve some operagoers - by a large screen on which an image of eddying water is projected. The lovers, Manrico (the troubadour hero of the title) and Leonora, (a sympathetic Sandra Ford), poured their hearts out against this watery turbulence. The lighting often created most peculiar effects. When they sang kneeling, there were no shadows. When one or other stood up, their shades bobbed awkwardly in the swell, as if drowning.

Indeed, shadow play was quite a feature. It is not clear whether this was intentional - having little or no lighting rehearsal also helps keep down costs. At one moment, the hero (a potent Julian Gavin, in soaring voice) was grotesquely parodied by his own priapically distorted shadow. This certainly enhanced his manliness while also, unfairly, distracting from his singing. Had anyone looked? Theatres create their own tricks of illusion that can inadvertently make performers look foolish. Producers need eyes for every eventuality.

David Kempster, who was outstanding as Chou En-lai in Nixon in China, here sang expressively but sorely lacked direction. He is capable of more than fist-clenching and silent-film eye-rolling. Like the rest of the cast (and the audience), he was persistently left stranded. After some uncertain ensemble work, both chorus and orchestra played with spirit, especially in the dramatic climaxes. Yet for such a hot and impassioned opera, the effect was surprisingly tepid. Rarely has the case for the professional opera producer been more strongly made.

Death of a quieter, devotional variety, was the focus of the concert by Concordia at Temple Church, part of a series of BBC Radio 3 Concerts for Holy Week (the last is today). This consort of viols performed Dowland's cycle of Lachrimae Antiquae or Seaven Teares (1604), written shortly after the death of Queen Elizabeth I and here interspersed with lute songs sung by James Bowman.

Dowland is often named, with Purcell and Britten, as one of the greatest English songwriters. In his day, the Lachrimae achieved virtual pop status across Europe. According to the title page, when Dowland wrote them he lived just opposite Temple 'in Fetter Lane neare Fleete street' and must have known the church in which this glorious concert was given.

Viols, early bowstring instruments which are played downward rather than up like a violin, produce a quiet, almost ghostly sibilant sound. 'Is it not strange that sheeps' guts should hale souls out of men's bodies?' asks Shakespeare's Benedick. Indeed, Dowland's highly chromatic harmonies in his Seaven Teares emerge as if through a shroud. Bowman's pure, bright voice offered perfect contrast. When he created the role of Oberon for Britten's A Midsummer Night's Dream as long ago as 1967, he awakened a new enthusiasm for the counter-tenor voice. He still holds sway, in repertoire old or new.

Bowman's exact contemporary, Placido Domingo, was also in formidable voice this week. In a compelling relay of Parsifal live from the Met, he sang the title role. Wagner's 'sacred festival opera' is highly seasonal, with its Good Friday music and themes of sin and redemption. For Domingo, it demonstrated his own hard-won musical transformation. Like Pavarotti, he began his career with Il Trovatore et al . Then, a decade ago, he sang his last Manrico and turned his attentions to German fare. Wagner's Pure Fool and Verdi's Troubadour stand at either end of the nineteenth- century operatic spectrum. Domingo spans both. He can also, as he has proved, conduct and direct.

Such a full command of theatre, as we have so disastrously learned last week, is rare indeed.

fields.headline: Children's choice
fields.trailText: Stephen wakes to find himself in a monastery. He remembers nothing at all except his name.
fields.body:
Out of Nowhere
Gerard Whelan
O'Brien Press £4.99, pp240
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Stephen wakes to find himself in a monastery. He remembers nothing at all except his name. He soon discovers from the monks that he is not the only one. Six other people have turned up in the last few days - and four of them have gone mad. The monks report that all the local houses are empty - the human occupants have vanished, and there is no electricity and no working telephones.

When Stephen, the other amnesiac, Kirsten, and the strangely unsettling Brother Philip visit a nearby town, unease turns to fear when they are set upon by maddened youths.

Meanwhile, the outside world is trying to understand what is going on behind the strange purple barrier that has cut the area off. 'It soon became clear that in a corner of Ireland, something terribly, terribly odd had taken place.'

Stephen finds himself in the middle of a terrifying adventure. Who are the strangers who appear to be able to control the feral 'hunters'? The answers are far from predictable in this enthralling thriller with a great twist at the end. For 10-ups.

webTitle: So good they make you vomit

fields.headline: So good they make you vomit
fields.standfirst: Sigur Ros have the oddest effects on their fans, says  Andrew Smith
fields.trailText: Sigur Ros have the oddest effects on their fans, says  Andrew Smith
fields.body:
On the other side of the door is a sprawling south London estate gathered round an old factory turned business park, as oppressive an environment as you'll find anywhere in the city. To enter the airy, top-floor studio where Sigur Ros ready themselves for a European tour, though, is to be transported.

The elements of their sound are becoming familiar. A glacial falsetto voice floats across a slow cycle of descending notes, pursued by a swarm of ethereal, violin-bowed guitar and a warm wash of real strings. There's the shuffling beat, some distant, echoed radar-like blip, a feeling of light and space that fleetingly conjures artists ranging from Spiritualized and the Cocteau Twins to Bach and the insane but brilliant Gesualdo.

The last time I saw them playing this song, 'Svefn-G-Englar', the Icelandic four-piece were supporting Radiohead in Paris, commanding the wildest applause I've ever seen an unknown band get. Bassist Georg Holm remembers that night, admitting that, 'when I walked offstage, my legs were shaking'. Before long, Rolling Stone would be naming his group's second album as one of last year's 10 best, despite the fact that it is still only available on import in the US.

Still all 25 or under, Sigur Ros have been together for seven years, variously working in child-care centres, TV studios, steel works and homes for severely disabled people, or studying politics at university, to survive along the way. They've spent the past few years as their country's most popular home-grown band, thanks in particular to that second album, Agaetis Byrjun - which, despite being sporadically inspired, still gets nowhere near capturing their live magic.

The alien quality of their sound owes more than a little to vocalist Jonsi Birgisson's penchant for singing in a mixture of Icelandic and a tongue of his own invention, which he likes to call 'Hopelandish'. The key to Sigur Ros's post-rock rapture is that while you can't understand what he's saying, you always feel you know what he means.

That one of the freshest bands to have emerged in a while should come from Iceland doesn't surprise us anymore, not since Björk and the Sugarcubes and various contemporaries like GusGus first established the nation's talent for vivid, non-conformist pop. Nevertheless, the present crop looks to be particularly promising, with Sigur Ros being closely followed by the brilliant Blake, Mum, Kanada and old Blur favourites, Lhooq. All are helped by an active but compact music business, whose infrastructure they control. Record company accountants and the stifling short-termism they bring hold no sway over what goes on.

Hilmar Hilmarsson, a doyen of the Reykjavik scene, cites the country's long domination by Denmark as a factor in the delight his people seem to take in creativity and invention.

Sigur Ros's articulate bass player, Georg Holm, will add that there are no surviving folk instruments. Indigenous music is vocal and you wonder whether the characteristically Icelandic willingness to make mischief with genres and stylistic conven tion owes something to this. The tiny 250,000 population is perhaps equally important. 'It's a small place, so things get jumbled up and having clearly defined boundaries is difficult,' is how he puts it. Ergo, the kind of tribal purism that always defined our culture is not possible in theirs. For instance, Birgisson, who carries the disarming expression of a naughty child caught with his hand in the biscuit tin, will tell you that his favourite vocalists are Leonard Cohen and the jazz trumpeter Chet Baker.

Holm will mention Cohen, too, explaining: 'I never considered him depressing or sad; I always thought of him as uplifting.' (This is a very Scandanavian sentiment; for one Icelandic reviewer, Sigur Ros were so beautiful in concert that she had to run to the lavatory to throw up.)

But if you inquire as to whether he listened to classical music as well, he looks at you as if you've just asked whether it ever gets chilly in Reykjavik. Eventually, he replies: 'Yeah, yeah.'

Sigur Ros play Brighton, St George's Church, 21 April; Leeds, City Varieties, 23 April; London's Sheperd's Bush Empire, 24 April

There's the shuffling beat, some distant, echoed radar-like blip, a feeling of light and space that fleetingly conjures artists ranging from Spiritualized and the Cocteau Twins to Bach and the insane but brilliant Gesualdo. The last time I saw them playing this song, 'Svefn-G-Englar', the Icelandic four-piece were supporting Radiohead in Paris, commanding the wildest applause I've ever seen an unknown band get. Bassist Georg Holm remembers that night, admitting that, 'when I walked offstage, my legs were shaking'. Before long, Rolling Stone would be naming his group's second album as one of last year's 10 best, despite the fact that it is still only available on import in the US. Still all 25 or under, Sigur Ros have been together for seven years, variously working in child-care centres, TV studios, steel works and homes for severely disabled people, or studying politics at university, to survive along the way. They've spent the past few years as their country's most popular home-grown band, thanks in particular to that second album, Agaetis Byrjun - which, despite being sporadically inspired, still gets nowhere near capturing their live magic. The alien quality of their sound owes more than a little to vocalist Jonsi Birgisson's penchant for singing in a mixture of Icelandic and a tongue of his own invention, which he likes to call 'Hopelandish'. The key to Sigur Ros's post-rock rapture is that while you can't understand what he's saying, you always feel you know what he means. That one of the freshest bands to have emerged in a while should come from Iceland doesn't surprise us anymore, not since Björk and the Sugarcubes and various contemporaries like GusGus first established the nation's talent for vivid, non-conformist pop. Nevertheless, the present crop looks to be particularly promising, with Sigur Ros being closely followed by the brilliant Blake, Mum, Kanada and old Blur favourites, Lhooq. All are helped by an active but compact music business, whose infrastructure they control. Record company accountants and the stifling short-termism they bring hold no sway over what goes on. Hilmar Hilmarsson, a doyen of the Reykjavik scene, cites the country's long domination by Denmark as a factor in the delight his people seem to take in creativity and invention. Sigur Ros's articulate bass player, Georg Holm, will add that there are no surviving folk instruments. Indigenous music is vocal and you wonder whether the characteristically Icelandic willingness to make mischief with genres and stylistic conven tion owes something to this. The tiny 250,000 population is perhaps equally important. 'It's a small place, so things get jumbled up and having clearly defined boundaries is difficult,' is how he puts it. Ergo, the kind of tribal purism that always defined our culture is not possible in theirs. For instance, Birgisson, who carries the disarming expression of a naughty child caught with his hand in the biscuit tin, will tell you that his favourite vocalists are Leonard Cohen and the jazz trumpeter Chet Baker. Holm will mention Cohen, too, explaining: 'I never considered him depressing or sad; I always thought of him as uplifting.' (This is a very Scandanavian sentiment; for one Icelandic reviewer, Sigur Ros were so beautiful in concert that she had to run to the lavatory to throw up.) But if you inquire as to whether he listened to classical music as well, he looks at you as if you've just asked whether it ever gets chilly in Reykjavik. Eventually, he replies: 'Yeah, yeah.' Sigur Ros play Brighton, St George's Church, 21 April; Leeds, City Varieties, 23 April; London's Sheperd's Bush Empire, 24 April

webTitle: Paperback of the week: The Journals of Sylvia Plath 1950-1962

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: For the first time, then, we have a complete collection of Plath's diaries from the age of 17, through to the two years she spent teaching and writing in New England.
fields.body:
The Journals of Sylvia Plath 1950-1962
Edited by Karen V. Kukil
Faber £17.50, pp732
Buy it at a discount at BOL

This unabridged edition of Plath's journals includes the two volumes written between 1957 and 1959 which had remained sealed and were released by Ted Hughes shortly before his death in 1998. For the first time, then, we have a complete collection of Plath's diaries from the age of 17, through her college years and her stay in Cambridge, her marriage to Ted Hughes and the two years she spent teaching and writing in New England.

Sadly, the two volumes any Plath scholar and enthusiast would most desire to read, those covering the last three years of her life, have disappeared for good. One was destroyed by Hughes after his wife's suicide and the other is 'missing'.

But Kukil's edition is invaluable for anyone who is fascinated as much by Plath's life as her art and who believes that the two were inextricable. Even in the early entries, among the predictable teenage fulminations, you glimpse an acute awareness of her own troubled psyche, now easy to identify with the benefit of hindsight.

Much of the attention when the book was first published was inevitably directed to Plath's relationships with men, and Hughes in particular, but perhaps the most intriguing insights into her mind are in the many sections where she struggles to understand her relationship with her writing. 'How much should I sacrifice to writing anyway, before I find out if I'm any good?' she writes at the age of 18. 'Above all, CAN A SELFISH EGOCENTRIC JEALOUS AND UNIMAGITIVE [sic] FEMALE WRITE A DAMN THING WORTH WHILE?'

The greatest delight of the Journals, however, is encountering Sylvia Plath entirely exposed, without the many filters of interpretation imposed on her by critics and biographers and by her own carefully-wrought poems.

She and Hughes appear here as their youthful, hungry, anxious selves, troubled and human, before history lionised and demonised them respectively.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.standfirst: A riveting black comedy from John le Carré, plus Shakespeare's Language, A New World, After You'd Gone and Night Train
fields.trailText: A riveting black comedy from John le Carré, plus Shakespeare's Language, A New World, After You'd Gone and Night Train
fields.body:
The Tailor of Panama
John le Carré
Coronet £6.99, pp460
Buy it at a discount at BOL

This riveting black comedy is set in the months leading up to the handover by the Americans of the Panama Canal to the Panamanians on 31 December 1999, and fizzes and sparks as the labyrinthine conspiracy is revealed.

Duplicitous but loveable Harry Pendel, a British expatriate tailor drawn into a world of spying, is a character of genius. He is our centre of consciousness as we are led all over this distorted world, while his relationship with Andy Osnard, the Old Etonian spy, is gripping.

Le Carré is a master of shifting narrative focus - close-ups of characters, Panamanian politics, family backgrounds, English hypocrisy - and then interweaving everything so atmospherically that the whole story seems to grow organically in the reader's mind. The ending is convincingly dark.

The Tailor of Panama was first published in 1996 and has been reissued to coincide with the launch this week of the film of the book.

Shakespeare's Language
Frank Kermode
Penguin £7.99, pp324
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Frank Kermode is an elder statesman of literary criticism and theory. In this provocative study, he casts aside contemporary political interpretations of Shakespeare, which label him as a lynchpin of imperialist English culture, and instead reinstates Shakespeare as a linguistic genius.

Kermode unfashionably concentrates on the development of Shakespeare the dramatic poet. He argues that it was his unique mastery in the use of the rhetorical devices that enabled him to create worlds of such multi-layered complexity, and traces this to a key turning point in Shakespeare's mid-career. The reader is re-connected to the sophisticated linguistic brilliance of the playwright.

Part Two, electric and challenging, examines the plays performed at the Globe from 1599, when Shakespeare was working at the height of his powers. The chapters on Coriolanus and Hamlet are especially powerful.

Savour Shakespeare's Language. I doubt there will be a better book on the Bard for a long time.

A New World
Amit Chaudhuri
Picador £6.99, pp200
Buy it at a discount at BOL

This novel is a precise and delicate evocation of claustrophobic family life in the sweltering heat of well-to-do suburban Calcutta. After his failed marriage in the States, Jayojit, a writer and lecturer, returns with his seven-year-old Americanised son to spend two months with his parents.

The three generations gently wrestle towards understanding and the healing strength of family ties. From their apartment, wider worlds ripple outwards - Indian politics, poverty, neighbours, life in America - to absorb and charm the reader. Best of all, we see the West from the other side, and our perspective subtly shifts as we are pulled into the heart of another world. The novel is a kind of parable about change, and the integration of different cultures with each other.

This is a quietly wonderful book that avoids all gimmickry. The brilliance radiates from beneath the narrative surface to illuminate A New World. Deeply enjoyable.

After You'd Gone
Maggie O'Farrell
Review £6.99, pp372
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Maggie O'Farrell's confident first novel flashes back and forth across three generations of a family as the heroine, Alice Raikes, lies in a coma after an accident in London. The narrative moves between her various levels of imagined consciousness as her past life is recounted, and her love story is strangely tied up with a dark family secret.

Her trendy London life is well drawn, and the build-up to her relationship with arts editor and future husband John Friedmann is good. Their love is premised on the notion of passion over reason. But John is as Byronic as a shop dummy. The real passion, and anger, is between mother and daughter and this drives After You'd Gone. Details of Alice's childhood in North Berwick, its landscape and the well-observed objects that texture everyday life are convincingly done. The cleverly constructed plot and great ending almost overcome some of the weakness of characterisation.

Night Train
Nick Tosches
Penguin, £6.99, pp266
Buy it at a discount at BOL

American writer Nick Tosches's penetrating biography uncovers the dangerous world of Charles 'Sonny' Liston, heavyweight champion of the world from 1962 to 1965, who died in mysterious circumstances in Los Angeles in 1971, at the age of 38.

The author explores the forces that partly moulded Liston: birth in a shack in the South, an unstable family, prison and corrupt managers. But the main focus is the man himself, 'the ultimate outlaw' who fought with such extreme violence. His 'other big sport' was women, often prostitutes, though he remained married to his wife throughout.

The strength of this study is the flesh-raw immediacy of the author's style, combined with meticulously researched social and historical details. Liston's Mafia connections are chillingly conveyed, and the world of boxing oozes corruption.

Liston's flawed nature is brought vividly to life by Tosches. This is grit lit at its grittiest.

fields.headline: No escape from reality
fields.trailText: Does the gritty realism of today's teenage fiction appeal more to adults than its target audience?
fields.body:
I'm not sure I go for all the 'reality' entertainment which is overwhelming our teenagers. Big Brother, Kevin and Perry and American Pie are a small, unappetising sampling of film and television. Not a lot is left to the imagination and surely fantasy is a tool for growing up?

As I grew up, my father taught me to use my imagination. When I was older, he moulded me to have 'sparky' thoughts and when I wrote my first children's books, he tutored me on intertwining reality with creativity. Never too much information, allow young minds to smoulder with vision and ideas. But then the internet came along. Information became highly accessible, an awful lot of information. It was less acceptable to have subtlety and no longer is less more. Yet it seems the teenage novel is embracing this medium and has far greater appeal than the offerings of the Nineties. Teasing your reader is a tool of the past.

Luckily, the pre-teens of the Nineties were fortunate enough to be weaned on C.S. Lewis, Anne Fine, Dahl and then J.K. Rowling, so at least they learnt slowly to scale reality with a knapsack full of imagination. The lowest ebb of children's novels (or books for young adults) was at the end of the twentieth century. Then the average sale of a hardback novel was about 800 copies; today, it is at least double that. Harry Potter was the catalyst for this and J.K. Rowling is by far the cleverest of our new authors, as she interprets real-life sagas and interweaves them with fantasy. The Harry Potter books take elements from C.S Lewis, E. Nesbit, Dahl and even Enid Blyton's Far Away Tree. Each of these authors overemphasise the injustices of our world through wildly imaginative fantasy.

Are we are now witnessing the aftershock of the reality genre, the internet and other 'in your face' raw messages? It seems suspicious to me that Scholastic, Rowling's publishers in the US, reports that 40 per cent of its readers are adults and the majority of them are single. Philip Pullman's books are being followed by David Almond and Jacqueline Wills in seeming equally popular with adults, despite the claim that they are written for the less mature reader. So are these books really an accurate representation of what a teenage novel is or, indeed, what teenagers want?

In the past few weeks, I have read four books which were written for 'young adults'. It 's been an exhausting process, with no escape. In Shylock's Daughter (Macmillan £4.99, pp272), I felt discomfited by the clear message of Jewish victimisation by Christian society. Mirjam Pressler, the author, is shameless in her telling of Jessica's story from the ghettos to 'marrying out' into the Venetian nobility. This novel, though based on the Shakespeare play, presents the unhappy lot which befell Shylock's family at the hands of Antonio and Lorenzo's anti-Semitism. In the summing up by Brian Murdoch, the translator, the young reader is given little choice but to conclude that Jessica will reap only unhappiness through her Christian marriage: 'I did it of my own free will and I will have to take the consequences.'

Family dysfunction and obsession overwhelmed me in Jan Mark's The Lady with Iron Bones (Walker Books £9.99, pp159). The sadness of Casey's home life (her mother has postnatal depression, her father has left home, her brother has disappeared to find her father while her baby brother is allegedly 'backward') causes her to pray to a statue, the Lady with Iron Bones, which, in reality, is a birdbath in a neighbour's garden.

Once her prayers are seem to be answered, she becomes obsessed, worshipping the statue and rewarding it with her few precious gifts. Ultimately, Casey becomes caught in the spiral of power she has handed over, terrified when the statue appears to respond to her bad as well as good wishes - not much of a story for a £9.99 hardback.

Denial is the unhealthy problem in Sharon Creech's The Wanderer (Macmillan £4.99, pp240) as Sophie sails across the Atlantic with 'her family'. Through her diary and the diary of her cousin, we discover that Sophie has blocked her terrible past - dead parents, dead grandfather, fostering, confusion and drowning only revealed through her nightmares.

I found no humour at all, except by accident. 'Today my father told me I'd been a good son and he'd been a bad father, and he was sorry about that. But he was wrong: I haven't been a good son.'

Even though I didn't understand some of Milo's Wolves (Mammoth £4.99, pp244), I loved it. The technology - computers, cloning, freezing of dead children - whirled past my understanding. However, Jenny Nimmo's balance between raw truth and familial cosiness provided the novel with the new reality requirements but softened with a fantastic emotive story. I realised the secret here - reality is fine, but only when interwoven with humour and a good plot.

Perhaps our young teenagers will be less open to disappointment in later life. For without magic and mystery, happy families and fairyland, their expectations will be not be based on the imaginary perfection which was the launching pad we blasted off from.
