fields.headline: Cat killing and other pastimes
fields.trailText: Children need as much poetry as possible to graze on. Variety is essential. Kate Kellaway rounds up some of the most exciting new anthologies
fields.body:
According to Ogden Nash: 'In the world of mules/ There are no rules.' In the world of The New Faber Book of Children's Verse (Faber £16.99, pp280), a wonderful new anthology edited by Matthew Sweeney, there are no rules either. This is a wild selection and the first thing to celebrate is that it takes children to unsafe places: it does not patronise or pussyfoot around.

Yet even its wildness is not unvarying or dependable. It begins with a quaintly arresting poem by Elizabeth Bishop about good manners in which a child, in 1918, is required by her grandfather to greet strangers whenever she passes them. This is a long, calm distance from the 'stranger danger' that is hammered into the children at my son's primary school.

The sense of distance, of getting away from the known, is one of the great pleasures here. Instead of staple anthology fare (a nice poem by Eleanor Farjeon about a cat or the classic overkill of Blake's 'Tiger'), we have a show-stopping poem, new to me, by Vernon Scannell, about a boy who finds himself murdering a cat; close by is a poem by James Reeves, at once comic and slightly sinister, about a girl called little Fan who, slowly but surely, turns into a mermaid.

In between the poems come anonymous rhymes such as: 'Don't care - he didn't care/ Don't care was wild./ Don't care stole plum and pear/ Like any beggar's child.' But these are thrown in sparingly, like a judicious handful of salt into a zesty soup.

There are some excellent poems, too, that subvert old forms, such as Geoffrey Grigson's offering about a false leg with a mind of its own (is such a thing possible?) that strolls into the sea and Christopher Reid's lovely 'Old Ballad', in which a daughter is advised not to marry a man who might feed her only on dog biscuits and rainwater: 'But marry that wild young man she did,/ glad that he could support her/ on the best dog biscuits money could buy/ and the freshest of fresh rainwater.'

I was delighted, too, to see favourites of mine such as Yeats's 'The Song of Wandering Aengus', Robert Frost's 'Birches' and 'Harold's Leap' by Stevie Smith: 'Harold, are you asleep?/ Harold I remember your leap,/ It may have killed you/ But it was a brave thing to do.' I have always loved Smith's deadpan commentary on the sportively suicidal Harold.

Many poems signal to each other, as if trying to fix up a meeting. Auden's 'O what is that sound which so thrills the air?' picks up on the bewildered question in Charles Causley's 'What has happened to Lulu?' Benjamin Zephaniah and Spike Milligan each write about 'nothing' and show how it is possible to make something of it (King Lear, eat your heart out). I also found Matthew Sweeney's own contribution 'A Boy', about his escape into books, disarming. (Faber publishes more of the buoyant Sweeney in Up on the Roof, his new and selected poems.)

No single anthology of poetry could ever be definitive, but this anthology does what poetry anthologies so often fail to do - it made me hungry for more. It made me realise, suddenly, that children need as much poetry as possible to graze on and that variety is essential. Sweeney's Faber anthology is too sophisticated for young children, but it is a must for anyone from a poetically inclined nine-year-old to a lyrical 99-year-old. I am aghast at the thought that childless adults may miss it.

In his introduction, Sweeney writes about poems that did not make the final selection because of 'shortcomings in craft and technique'. Too much of what passes for 'children's poetry' does not deserve that description. However, there is a place for unchallenging 'poetry' as a way in. Gervase Phinn's It Takes One to Know One (Puffin £3.99, pp96) captivates Leo, my nine-year-old, just as anything by Michael Rosen infallibly does. It is unambitiously focused on familiar experience (plenty of poems about school) and aims to be amusing. Phinn's offerings seem like damp squibs to me but they make Leo's face light up and the funny poems make him double up.

I have also been reading T.S. Eliot's Old Possum's Book of Practical Cats (Faber Children's Classics £4.99, pp56) to him at the same time. Some of the vocabulary is unlikely to be understood by most children, but there is nothing to beat the cunning ebullience of the rhythms, the joy of the rhymes. Leo judges them 'weird' but listens spellbound.

After all, there is no one like Macavity - or T.S. Eliot, come to that.

fields.bodyText: According to Ogden Nash: 'In the world of mules/ There are no rules.' In the world of The New Faber Book of Children's Verse (Faber £16.99, pp280), a wonderful new anthology edited by Matthew Sweeney, there are no rules either. This is a wild selection and the first thing to celebrate is that it takes children to unsafe places: it does not patronise or pussyfoot around. Yet even its wildness is not unvarying or dependable. It begins with a quaintly arresting poem by Elizabeth Bishop about good manners in which a child, in 1918, is required by her grandfather to greet strangers whenever she passes them. This is a long, calm distance from the 'stranger danger' that is hammered into the children at my son's primary school. The sense of distance, of getting away from the known, is one of the great pleasures here. Instead of staple anthology fare (a nice poem by Eleanor Farjeon about a cat or the classic overkill of Blake's 'Tiger'), we have a show-stopping poem, new to me, by Vernon Scannell, about a boy who finds himself murdering a cat; close by is a poem by James Reeves, at once comic and slightly sinister, about a girl called little Fan who, slowly but surely, turns into a mermaid. In between the poems come anonymous rhymes such as: 'Don't care - he didn't care/ Don't care was wild./ Don't care stole plum and pear/ Like any beggar's child.' But these are thrown in sparingly, like a judicious handful of salt into a zesty soup. There are some excellent poems, too, that subvert old forms, such as Geoffrey Grigson's offering about a false leg with a mind of its own (is such a thing possible?) that strolls into the sea and Christopher Reid's lovely 'Old Ballad', in which a daughter is advised not to marry a man who might feed her only on dog biscuits and rainwater: 'But marry that wild young man she did,/ glad that he could support her/ on the best dog biscuits money could buy/ and the freshest of fresh rainwater.' I was delighted, too, to see favourites of mine such as Yeats's 'The Song of Wandering Aengus', Robert Frost's 'Birches' and 'Harold's Leap' by Stevie Smith: 'Harold, are you asleep?/ Harold I remember your leap,/ It may have killed you/ But it was a brave thing to do.' I have always loved Smith's deadpan commentary on the sportively suicidal Harold. Many poems signal to each other, as if trying to fix up a meeting. Auden's 'O what is that sound which so thrills the air?' picks up on the bewildered question in Charles Causley's 'What has happened to Lulu?' Benjamin Zephaniah and Spike Milligan each write about 'nothing' and show how it is possible to make something of it (King Lear, eat your heart out). I also found Matthew Sweeney's own contribution 'A Boy', about his escape into books, disarming. (Faber publishes more of the buoyant Sweeney in Up on the Roof, his new and selected poems.) No single anthology of poetry could ever be definitive, but this anthology does what poetry anthologies so often fail to do - it made me hungry for more. It made me realise, suddenly, that children need as much poetry as possible to graze on and that variety is essential. Sweeney's Faber anthology is too sophisticated for young children, but it is a must for anyone from a poetically inclined nine-year-old to a lyrical 99-year-old. I am aghast at the thought that childless adults may miss it. In his introduction, Sweeney writes about poems that did not make the final selection because of 'shortcomings in craft and technique'. fields.headline: Hard-hitting feelgood
fields.standfirst: Smack, child abuse, teenage pregnancy... and now, that boy who wants to be a ballet dancer
fields.trailText: Smack, child abuse, teenage pregnancy... and now, that boy who wants to be a ballet dancer
fields.body:
Melvin Burgess still groans with embarrassment and buries his head in his hands at the memory of the day he received the Carnegie Medal for his controversial and highly acclaimed novel Junk. Full of pride and conscious of the honour, he set off for the ceremony from his home in Manchester. It was only when he was on the train that he realised he hadn't packed his medal, which authors are allowed to have beforehand to stroke and gloat over. A panicky succession of phone calls, involving retrieving house keys from neighbours and use of express delivery ensued. But the medal didn't turn up in time - and the ceremony had to go ahead with a makeshift medal stand-in.

The story - and his reaction - reveals another side to the author whose books have raised eyebrows (at the very least) because of their unflinching narratives, which deal head on with sex, death, love, fear, drugs - all the things that teenagers want to read about, but which set the establishment twitching.

Although his picture on the children's literature website, Achuka, makes him look like an evil overlord from an early Dr Who episode, in person he's slight and self-deprecating with a gap-toothed grin. He is committed to pushing the boundaries back in order to give adolescents and young adults the kind of books that they can really get involved with.

Given his reputation as a man who deals in difficult subjects, it was an interesting decision to choose Burgess to write the book of the Oscar-nominated film, Billy Elliot - which, despite its strong language and grimly realistic setting, is a feelgood story of the first order.

'I don't have a bad view of life,' laughs Burgess. 'I'm certainly not pessimistic. And I enjoyed writing this.'

Turning a book into a film is not unusual - though it can rouse high feelings in devotees of the original. The retrospective novelisation of a popular film is less usual.

'I used as much dialogue as possible from the script. The interesting thing was to get inside the characters' heads because you see it all from a third person's point of view in a film. I spoke to Lee Hall (the scriptwriter) about his thinking behind the script,' says Burgess.

As he chose one of his preferred methods of writing, which is to use a multiple first-person narrative, the contrast between a visual art which 'shows' and a written one which 'tells' is highlighted in the novel. His achievement is to have done this in a way which means the novel stands alone as a compelling and moving story, but also complements the film and will enhance it for those who have already seen it.

All of the main characters have a voice - except the dance teacher, (Julie Walters in the film). Burgess explains: 'I was fascinated by this family of men. With his wife dead, Jackie Elliot is trying to be a mother to the boys. They're all having to learn how to live together and there is some ambivalence about Billy's sexuality, and Jackie is trying to incorporate everything. It's a male environment - that's what impressed me about the film. And that's why the dance teacher doesn't have a voice.'

Burgess was approached to write the novelisation at the beginning of December with the aim of getting it out to coincide with the video release of the film this month. He finished it after three weeks of intensive writing. One major problem was getting the accents right in his head, and on the page. (He was born 46 years ago in Sussex and was brought up in the South.)

Fortunately, his friend David Almond, award-winning author of Skellig and Kit's Wilderness, whose novels are all set in the North East, was on hand. 'I kept turning the dialect and accent into Yorkshire or Lancashire, so I would ring David to check and he'd put me right.'

With the Billy novel finished, Burgess has been working on his next book, Lady: My Life as a Bitch, which is due to be published in the autumn. This book sees a return to the sort of controversial work which his readers and critics love, and others love to hate. 'Well,' he says carefully, 'it's the story of a teenage girl who gets turned into a dog - a sniffy, licky, shaggy bitch.' The parents who think teenagers should read self-improving tracts are really going to adore this one, Melvin.

webTitle: Observer review: Electric Light by Seamus Heaney

fields.headline: A haunting he will go
fields.standfirst: Seamus Heaney delves into his past - with detours through Virgil and Kosovo - in his new collection Electric Light
fields.trailText: Seamus Heaney delves into his past - with detours through Virgil and Kosovo - in his new collection Electric Light
fields.body:
Electric Light
Seamus Heaney
Faber £14.99; £8.99 paperback, pp81
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The jacket of Seamus Heaney's new book is vibrant red with no illustrations, just his name and the book's title in bold, large type - reminiscent of an earlier time of elegant typographical Faber jackets. And the book itself begins as if it too is going to be a referring back - the opening poem touches on the Troubles and Irish history, and ends with an image reclaimed from his first collection, Death of a Naturalist: 'The slime and silver of the fattened eel.' But this is no simple revisiting of old concerns. What is being set up here is the past, in all its evocativeness, and this is a past-haunted book if there ever was one.

Inevitably, scenes from Heaney's earlier life feature largely. There are several childhood poems. This is nothing new, but here they are nudged towards the marvellous. 'Out of the Bag', for example, goes back to his origins, or what he, as a child, believed they were:

All of us came in Doctor Kerlin's bag.

Yes. That, or something like it, was what many of us were led to believe. But what makes this poem - and it's a poem that works superbly - is the adult writer staying true to the child's perspective, and allowing this to let him back into an imaginative world where the doctor's eyes were:

Two peepholes to the locked room I saw into

Every time his name was mentioned, skimmed

Milk and ice, swabbed porcelain, the white

And chill of tiles, steel hooks, chrome surgery tools

And blood dreeps in the sawdust where it thickened

At the foot of each cold wall. And overhead

The little pendent, teat-hued infant parts

Strung neatly from a line up near the ceiling -

A toe, a foot and shin, an arm, a cock

A bit like the rosebud in his buttonhole.

I love this big-eyed, Frankenstein-like imagining, and the shiver of remembered fear it brings with it. Similarly, in the title-poem that ends the book, an elderly relative's toughened, mangled thumbnail so terrified the child who used to stay with her that the adult writer imagines it must still be intact:

Among beads and vertebrae in the Derry ground.

Other poems revisit his life at later stages. The mischievously titled, 'Red, White and Blue', for example, is not a reference to a particular flag, but to the colours of garments he remembers his wife wearing at different times in their marriage or courtship. Here is a cheery image from 'Red':

Later that night, as you jived with me hell for leather

In the Students Union, the cleared floor like a paddock

Where we gave each other rope and scope and snaffle.

Given Heaney's admiration for Birthday Letters, one might see this poem as as a discreet homage to Ted Hughes's book. There are plenty of directrefer ences elsewhere to writers he has loved and admired - the second section of the collection is given over, almost entirely, to elegies, mainly of writer/ friends, including Hughes.

One of the most winning poems is 'The Bookcase', where the initial picturing of his old bookcase ('Ashwood or oakwood?') allows him to slyly slip in the authors who were his touchstones - something that any Heaney fan will be interested in. It's a device so simple that many poets will be irritated they hadn't thought of it, but few poets could have taken this simple idea as far, or to such a graceful, resonant conclusion:

In Riders to the Sea Synge specifies

In the opening stage directions 'some new boards

Standing by the wall,' and in Maurya's speech

'White boards' are like storm-gleams on the flood

At the very end, or the salt salvaged makings

Of a raft for books, a bier to be borne.

I imagine us bracing ourselves for the first lift,

Then staggering for balance, it has grown so light.

But, then, Heaney is no ordinary poet. Especially since being awarded the Nobel Prize in 1995, there is a weight of expectation on him that must be hard to cope with. His first collection after that, The Spirit Level (1996), would have been the pressure equivalent of a penalty shoot-out in the World Cup. He scored with aplomb, and the display here is arguably even more relaxed and confident. Again, there is the need at times to take on the big public subject. In this he wisely uses the personal as a launching pad. Take 'Known World', which begins with a recollection of a boozy poetry festival in the former Yugoslavia in 1978 and proceeds - by way of a remembered flypaper from childhood - to focus on the refugees streaming out of Kosovo in 1999.

The poem's title refers to the familiar world he comes from, which helps him make sense of the unfamiliar places he travels to - 1978 Belgrade, for example, reminded him of the West of Ireland. Similarly, in another poem, waving Spanish peasants in the fields as he drives by remind him of the Irish Gaeltacht in the Fifties. It's as if there's a safety in connecting everything with what you know. But the flip side of that is that you also then admit what is theirs - so the Kosovo tragedy becomes yours.

The Gaeltacht makes another appearance in a lovely, simple sonnet of that name, one written 'in imitation of Dante'. And elsewhere a polished version of a Virgil eclogue - a form he is totally at home in - sparks off two other eclogues of his own.

I'd like to end, though, by turning to my favourite of the elegies, 'Late in the Day', written in memory of his friend, the historian/ writer David Thompson, whose recently reissued book dealing with seal lore in Scotland and the West of Ireland, The People of the Sea, Heaney has written an introduction to, a man:

Never more at home than when on the road,

Led by amazement as if it were a seal

Walking ahead of him up the Aran shingle

In a clawhammer coat and top hat, dressed to kill,

About to enter a public house or kitchen

The way he would himself, like Arion

Arriving in off the waves, off the dolphin's back,

Oblivious-seeming, but taking it all in

And glad of another chance to believe his luck.

webTitle: Observer review: Losing It by Ranjit Bolt

fields.headline: Onward the virgin soldiers
fields.standfirst: Ranjit Bolt manages to avoid offence as Lucy romps through a fairytale Hampstead in pusuit of a first time in his verse novel, Losing It
fields.trailText: Ranjit Bolt manages to avoid offence as Lucy romps through a fairytale Hampstead in pusuit of a first time in his verse novel, Losing It
fields.body:
Losing It
Ranjit Bolt
John Murray £9.99, pp155
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The 'it' in Losing It is the virginity of an attractive 19-year-old named Lucy, and Ranjit Bolt has chosen to relate her story in verse. Iambic tetrametric couplets, to be precise, although Bolt gives himself plenty of poetic licence with the form. The subtitle of the book - 'An adult fairytale for those/ Who've tired of fairytales in prose' - makes it sound like a rhythmic 'Reader's Wives' involving witch outfits and rubber toads, which isn't far from the truth.

Lucy, a sweet young thing from the provinces, is fed up with her long-preserved virginity, and goes to live with her Great Aunt Alicia (hooked nose, pointy hat, broomstick) in London. The capital, she reasons, must be well stocked with potential cherry-pickers. Alicia lives in a Gothic manse just off Hampstead Heath, replete with gargoyles, barn-owls, nightjars, a sepulchral butler and a black cat. She has no issues with Lucy using her house as a base for her campaign:

I give you leave - no, I 'demand'
That you secure your cherry's loss,
Shake off the stupid albatross
That's hanging round your nubile neck.

Over the course of the novel our heroine tries out six beaux, but with each one something goes amiss at the eleventh hour. Richard, a middle-aged depressive, turns out to be an ex- of Great Aunt Alicia, who takes swift and belated revenge by turning him into a hare and releasing him onto Hampstead Heath. The egregiously erudite Algernon falls for Lucy when she plays a nimble tune on a virginal, but then misplaces his condoms at the crucial moment. Mungo, a Wildean dandy who wears a milk-white kimono of Kyoto silk, is wedded to art and bats for neither side.

Then there are the three famous lovers. Alicia's magic broomstick allows Lucy to travel in time in her search for Mr Right. Dick Turpin, who turns out to be a jolly nice chap and not the ruffian that history has constructed him as, is the most considerate of Lucy's almost-lovers:

Is it yer first time, wench?' he said,
'Ah, well, tis nothin' ye need dread'.

But an excess of wine, consumed in the Spaniard's Inn, means Dick's dick won't stand and deliver.

'Me cursed yard-arm, damn its eyes!
Damn the Madeira! Damn it all!"

Julius Caesar is stabbed by Brutus before he has time to veni-vidi-vici Lucy. By far the funniest of her clinches involves Casanova:

He must be good; he's Casanova -
He's famed for it the whole world over

He convinces Lucy to attempt The Scorpion With Two Backs, a fiendishly complicated sexual position from a Sanskrit treatise on the art of love. The pair end up locked in a concupiscent cat's-cradle of legs, arms and other things, and have to be lubricated apart by 12 pats of melted butter.

The verse novel is a rare beast in today's publishing jungle. It is the Procrustean bed of narrative forms: novelistic qualities such as plot and character tend to get stretched or lopped to fit the demands of the poetic form. The most successful recent example is Vikram Seth's virtuosic The Golden Gate (1986), 690 tetrametric Shakespearean sonnets about Californian twentysomethings and their imaginatively named pets: a genuinely impressive feat of verbal dexterity. Losing It doesn't bear comparison, but then it doesn't have any particularly literary aspirations.

It's just splendidly silly stuff, in which the gags are kept coming by the rhythm and rhyme (couplets being the correct form for a story about coupling). North Londoners will enjoy Bolt's transformation of Hampstead Heath into a Wuthering-Heightsesque stretch of moonlit wilderness, though his 'satiric' swipes at London life can be toe-curlingly ham-fisted:

While the crowds passing to and fro
In almost a cloacal flow
Disgust one as they mill along,
With bad manners, and their pong.

There's a discreet lack of anatomical detail, and asterisks act as fig-leafs for the very few naughty words. It's not quite the sort of book you'd let your children read, but not far off. Bolt's achievement is to write a lubricious romp about a virgin on the offensive, without ever verging on the offensive.

Richard, a middle-aged depressive, turns out to be an ex- of Great Aunt Alicia, who takes swift and belated revenge by turning him into a hare and releasing him onto Hampstead Heath. The egregiously erudite Algernon falls for Lucy when she plays a nimble tune on a virginal, but then misplaces his condoms at the crucial moment. Mungo, a Wildean dandy who wears a milk-white kimono of Kyoto silk, is wedded to art and bats for neither side. Then there are the three famous lovers. Alicia's magic broomstick allows Lucy to travel in time in her search for Mr Right. Dick Turpin, who turns out to be a jolly nice chap and not the ruffian that history has constructed him as, is the most considerate of Lucy's almost-lovers: Is it yer first time, wench?' he said, 'Ah, well, tis nothin' ye need dread'. But an excess of wine, consumed in the Spaniard's Inn, means Dick's dick won't stand and deliver. 'Me cursed yard-arm, damn its eyes! Damn the Madeira! Damn it all!" Julius Caesar is stabbed by Brutus before he has time to veni-vidi-vici Lucy. By far the funniest of her clinches involves Casanova: He must be good; he's Casanova - He's famed for it the whole world over He convinces Lucy to attempt The Scorpion With Two Backs, a fiendishly complicated sexual position from a Sanskrit treatise on the art of love. The pair end up locked in a concupiscent cat's-cradle of legs, arms and other things, and have to be lubricated apart by 12 pats of melted butter. The verse novel is a rare beast in today's publishing jungle. It is the Procrustean bed of narrative forms: novelistic qualities such as plot and character tend to get stretched or lopped to fit the demands of the poetic form. The most successful recent example is Vikram Seth's virtuosic The Golden Gate (1986), 690 tetrametric Shakespearean sonnets about Californian twentysomethings and their imaginatively named pets: a genuinely impressive feat of verbal dexterity. Losing It doesn't bear comparison, but then it doesn't have any particularly literary aspirations. It's just splendidly silly stuff, in which the gags are kept coming by the rhythm and rhyme (couplets being the correct form for a story about coupling). North Londoners will enjoy Bolt's transformation of Hampstead Heath into a Wuthering-Heightsesque stretch of moonlit wilderness, though his 'satiric' swipes at London life can be toe-curlingly ham-fisted: While the crowds passing to and fro In almost a cloacal flow Disgust one as they mill along, With bad manners, and their pong. There's a discreet lack of anatomical detail, and asterisks act as fig-leafs for the very few naughty words. It's not quite the sort of book you'd let your children read, but not far off. Bolt's achievement is to write a lubricious romp about a virgin on the offensive, without ever verging on the offensive.

webTitle: Teachers jeer as Blunkett hints he's off

fields.headline: Teachers jeer as Blunkett hints he's off
fields.trailText: Education Secretary David Blunkett yesterday made it clear that he would not be returning to the job after the General Election.
fields.body:
Education Secretary David Blunkett yesterday made it clear that he would not be returning to the job after the General Election.

In a much-heckled speech to the Easter conference of Britain's largest teaching union, the National Union of Teachers, Blunkett echoed Tony Blair's commitment to continue increasing public spending on education - and added, 'whoever takes over from me'.

He later told The Observer that he would miss the job 'terribly'. He is widely expected to become Home Secretary in Tony Blair's post election cabinet reshuffle.

Blunkett was constantly barracked during his speech in Cardiff as he sought to praise teachers' efforts in achieving a rise in classroom standards. 'Hell's bells, if we can't celebrate our achievements then we might as well go home,' he said, decrying the jeers as 'absolute silliness'.

The strongest attack on the Minister came in an unprecedented rebuke from the platform when NUT president John Illingworth told Blunkett he had put 'relentless pressure' on teachers ever since taking office. This had 'led to some of the serious difficulties which we now face in the shortages of teachers,' said Illingworth.

To applause, he told Blunkett: 'We know we're doing a good job - we don't need you to tell us that. What we need you to do is to start listening to us.'

Illingworth is thought to be one of the 42-strong NUT executive who voted against suspension of industrial action when a last-minute, closed doors decision was taken late on Thursday. The narrowly won vote of 23 to 19 was in response to Blunkett's announcement that an immediate review would take place of teachers' workload.

The review will look at NUT demands for a 35-hour working week contract, but yesterday efforts were being made by a militant minority to challenge the executive's decision during today's conference sessions. Any clash between the executive and the left-wingers was looking less likely last night as a deadline passed with only one challenge to the executive being tabled.

Yesterday Blunkett told the conference it was crucial that unions and Government sat down together. 'Otherwise we have the dialogue of the deaf,' he said.

'Of course, we have a long way to go. I welcome the decision to suspend industrial action and in so doing responding positively to our proposals.

'We have to sit down with the unions and look at ways of tackling workload.'

He added: 'There is a hell of a long way still to go, but there's a joint offer on the table to see if we can get this right.'

webTitle: Police better off under the Tories

fields.headline: Police better off under the Tories
fields.trailText: Police budgets are being slashed under Labour, with a study showing that Tony Blair has halved the annual increase to forces across England. Constabularies got twice as big a rise each year under John Major.
fields.body:
Police budgets are being slashed under Labour, with a study showing that Tony Blair has halved the annual increase to forces across England. Constabularies got twice as big a rise each year under John Major.

'During John Major's government police spending underwent an average annual increase of 3.2 per cent,' said Christine Frayne, of the Institute for Fiscal Studies. 'For the first four years of this Parliament, spending on the police increased every year by an average of 1.4 per cent. And in their first two years in office Labour increased police spending by an average of 0.4 per cent each year.'

The figures reveal the police budget would be almost £796 million greater if Labour had raised spending at the average rate Major did. The fight against crime was a key issue in the 1997 election, with Blair pledging to be 'tough on crime and tough on the causes of crime'.

The findings - which take inflation into account - will outrage campaigners and police who have long protested at shrinking numbers of officers, poor recruitment levels and falling morale.

Violent and urban crime rose last year, with assaults up 8 per cent, while police recruitment reached a seven-year low between April 1999 and March 2000.

The study, based on figures revealed by Ministers last week, also shows that Scotland Yard's budget has been slashed this year by £33m. Staffordshire Constabulary, where a 13 per cent rise in crime was recorded last year, has had its budget cut by £2.1m. Cleveland and Cheshire constabularies have also had their budgets cut.

In December, Sir John Stevens, the Metropolitan Police Commissioner, said the police service was 'moving towards the edge of crisis'. He blamed falling numbers and the branding of the Metropolitan Police as 'institutionally racist' after the Macpherson report.

Home Office figures show that funds given from Whitehall to police forces have dropped since 1997. Police forces are funded by central government and top up their budgets with local authority contributions. Between 1990 and 1997, funds from central government to the police rose on average by 3 per cent a year. After 1997, the increase each year dropped to a fifth of that level.

Simon Hughes MP, Liberal Democrat spokesman on home affairs, said 'Police funds have fallen behind since the Major administration. Police are now having to say that there simply are some things they can no longer do and turning to private sponsors for extra money.'

Robin Corbett MP, chairman of the Home Office Select Committee, expressed concern at the figures, adding that police were under pressure to buy new equipment. 'There is an urgent need to upgrade IT resources,' he said. 'I would be very worried if funds are being diverted from recruitment to pay for these projects.'

A Home Office spokesman stressed that police forces controlled their own spending. 'Police services will enjoy £8.5 billion in funds next year - 10 per cent more in cash terms,' he said, conceding that the Home Office 'has responsibility for the police and has a major part to play in ensuring that they are properly funded'.

A Labour Party spokesman said that funding was 'purely a departmental matter' and declined to comment.

Last week, the Metropolitan Police came under severe criticism from an audit of their finances by accountants KPMG which concluded that tens of millions of pounds were wasted every year through poor management.

fields.headline: Genetic tests clampdown
fields.standfirst: Milburn acts over insurers' use of DNA profiles to predict illness
fields.trailText: Milburn acts over insurers' use of DNA profiles to predict illness.
fields.body:
The exploitation of genetic testing by insurers is set to be outlawed by the government amid fears of creating an uninsurable 'genetic underclass'.

Health Secretary Alan Milburn will signal this week that the use of so-called genetic profiling tests, which could predict who will die prematurely or suffer chronic disease, to deny people essentials such as mortgage cover should be banned. He is still awaiting final recommendations from the ethical watchdog, the Human Genetics Commission, next month before taking a final decision, but is known to favour at least a partial moratorium. One option considered by the commission is to regulate against 'genetic discrimination' by insurers in the same way as racial prejudice.

Milburn will also pledge legislation to ban human reproductive cloning - likely to be highlighted in Labour's manifesto - to allay public fears about scientists playing God. The practice is already outlawed by watchdog, the Human Fertility and Embryology Authority, but he wants to ensure that this ban could not be reversed in future.

Milburn will use a speech on Thursday to highlight potential benefits of genetic testing, such as new screening programmes for those found to have inherited a risk of serious treatable disease, and promise NHS funding for developing accurate tests. But he will warn discoveries must not be used to divide patients into a 'genetic underclass' likely to become ill and a healthy 'genetic superclass'.

'The NHS over the next decade and beyond can put Britain at the leading edge of this new frontier, not just in advances on genetic testing but to develop for Britain modern genetic health services unrivalled anywhere in the world,' he will tell his audience at the International Centre for Life in Newcastle. Milburn will stop short of announcing an outright ban on insurers using any genetic test results, pending commission reports. But the commission is understood to favour a moratorium of at least two years - and has not ruled out a ban, backed by 78 per cent of the public in Mori polls.

Ministers may make a regulatory distinction between 'essentials' such as life insurance needed for mortgage cover, where genetic discrimination could have disastrous consequences, and 'luxuries' such as extensive private health insurance, where patients could rely on the NHS instead.

Milburn knows discussing such a sensitive issue close to an election is risky. But he fears that unless patients are sure test results will not be used against them, scientific progress will be hampered as they refuse to take tests.

'There are huge potential health gains to be had from genetic advances, but until we address these public concerns we can't create the necessary space,' said one source close to Milburn. 'We want to make sure these advances are to the benefit of all, not the cost of a few.'

The Department of Health has approved only one genetic test, for the rare and fatal Huntington's chorea, as reliable. Others are in the pipeline for approval, but already being used by insurers. So far the industry has handled fewer than 100 cases involving genetic testing. But numbers will soar over the next decade as researchers develop susceptibility tests for more common illnesses such as cancers, Alzheimer's or heart disease. Britain is well placed to lead research because of its role in the Human Genome Project, which mapped l the genes in DNA.

Insurers argue using genetic testing to calculate premiums is little different from asking about family medical histories and helps spread risk. They agreed not to use results in applications for life insurance linked to mortgages of under £100,000, but a recent survey found this widely flouted.

The Commons science and technology committee has condemned the voluntary code as 'inadequate' and warned insurers were placing a significance on tests 'that cannot at present be justified'.

But the committee said an outright ban could disadvantage those with a family history of disease whose own tests were negative.

fields.headline: UK at 'high risk' of recession
fields.standfirst: Shock report will show the economy on the brink as Chancellor urges caution and international co-operation. Exclusive interview with Gordon Brown
fields.trailText: Shock report will show the economy on the brink as Chancellor urges caution and international co-operation.
fields.body:
Britain is facing an economic downturn far more significant than previously thought, according to an analysis of the government's own figures.

A report to be released next weekend by accountants Ernst & Young says growth will fall below the psychologically significant 2 per cent mark by the autumn, as the country struggles to buck the international crisis in manufacturing and high-tech industries.

Gordon Brown, in an exclusive interview with The Observer, admitted this weekend that there were 'downside risks' in the economy but said that reforms brought in since 1997 left Britain 'better placed to cope with the ups and downs of the economic cycle'.

The Chancellor, who refused to return to the language of 'no more boom and bust', said there was now a need for increased vigilance over the economy and that he would be 'very cautious on how we approach these events'.

The Ernst & Young analysis, which uses the Treasury's own economic modelling technique, will increase government fears of tens of thousands of job losses as problems in the American economy race across the Atlantic. 'We are in a precarious position,' said Professor Peter Spencer, author of the report. 'The UK is most obviously following the problems of the US - we are in a high-risk situation which contains a lot of practical worries.'

News of the report, which will call for more interest rate cuts to help companies and the housing market, comes after a week of gloomy economic tidings. On Wednesday the Birkenhead-based shipyard Cammell Laird, which employs 3,500 people, went into receivership with debts of £125 million. The following day Motorola, the mobile phone company, announced its first operating deficit for 16 years, putting a question mark over the future of its plant in Bathgate, central Scotland, which employs 3,500 people.

And then General Motors announced that the car market was still depressed as figures revealed that new car registrations fell by 8.25 per cent last month.

'Clearly the US has had to experience a slowing,' the Chancellor said. 'Obviously there are downside risks. No economy, particularly our own which is a trading economy, could be isolated from these. But I have said that because of the changes made in our monetary and fiscal policy over these last few years we are better placed to cope with the ups and downs of the economic cycle.'

Brown said he wanted to see a stronger signal from continental Europe that the dangers of an economic downturn were being seriously addressed.

Last week Wim Duisenberg, the president of the European Central Bank, was criticised when he refused to bow to pressure from governments and manufacturing industry and agree to an interest rate cut across the euro-zone.

'You might say I hear but I don't listen,' Duisenberg said as he announced that interest rates would remain at 4.75 per cent.

Brown said that there was a need for quicker action on economic reform and that Japan and America must act on the 'international stage' to ensure that the downturn did not become a full recession.

'I will be expecting a signal that Europe, Japan and America all play their part in maintaining growth in the world economy,' Brown said. 'I think people now look to Europe to perform a leadership role in restoring world growth. I think Europe has got to send a message that it is reforming.'

Brown's comments came as government officials revealed their increasing concern at the state of Britain's economy.

The Financial Times reported yesterday that the Government believed the outlook for the world economy over the next 18 months was 'pretty rough'. 'Things could get quite sticky,' one official is quoted as saying.

'We are in as good a state as anyone, but by next year I would expect the climate to look volatile.'

Last week Andrew Smith, the Chief Secretary to the Treasury, said the US slowdown 'would be a matter of concern'.

The Confederation of British Industry also said in a report that up to 50,000 British jobs could be at risk, with particular problems in tourism and farming because of the current foot and mouth crisis.

webTitle: Labour declares war on the BBC

fields.headline: Labour declares war on the BBC
fields.trailText: Labour is to launch 'a war of attrition' against the BBC during the general election campaign after losing patience with the coverage given to political stories.
fields.body:
Labour is to launch 'a war of attrition' against the BBC during the general election campaign after losing patience with the coverage given to political stories.

Senior party figures have told The Observer that the BBC trivialises politics and concentrates on the 'tittle-tattle of the Westminster village' rather than serious policy issues such as education, health and the economy.

The party is now planning a series of complaints to senior figures in the BBC, including the new head of news, Richard Sambrook. The moves will be spearheaded by David Hill, the party's former chief media spokesman, who will be brought back to a senior campaigning role during the election.

Hill was involved in a series of high-profile spats between the party and the BBC in the run-up to the 1997 election. He regularly rowed with the editors of BBC Radio 4's the Today programme and the World at One. One official said Hill would be checking the BBC 'with a stop-watch' to ensure Labour policies received fair coverage.'

Senior BBC figures said they 'were ready for a fight'. 'What they [the Labour Party] don't seem to understand is that the more they complain the more we realise we are doing a good job,' said one editor. 'Trying to bully us into covering politics the way they want will not work. The public will see them for what they really are.'

Last week Downing Street directly criticised the BBC over the prominent coverage it gave a newspaper story saying that Alastair Campbell, the Prime Minister's official spokesman, was to take a 'behind-the-scenes' role after the election. 'It's typical of the media obsession with process and personality, rather than the serious issues facing the country, that a newspaper article about Alastair Campbell should feature on the BBC TV news ahead of an important speech by the Prime Minister about the future of our country's schools,' a Downing Street spokesman said.

fields.headline: Loafer's guide
fields.standfirst: Oxygen
fields.trailText: Oxygen.
fields.body:
What, that colourless, odourless and tasteless gas that sits at number 8 in the periodic table? No, well, yes - but not as you know it. The oxygen in question is called 02Live oxygen and it's special, not the common or garden stuff you can breathe anywhere, any time. webTitle: May Day activists to surrender to police

fields.headline: May Day activists to surrender to police
fields.trailText: The ringleaders of this year's May Day anti-capitalist demonstration in London plan to hand themselves over to the police in protest at alleged harassment of activists.
fields.body:
The ringleaders of this year's May Day anti-capitalist demonstration in London plan to hand themselves over to the police in protest at alleged harassment of activists.

Organisers of the loose alliance of anti-globalisation, environmental and animal rights groups will turn themselves in on 30 April and challenge police to arrest them.

If enough people take part in the Spartacus-style action, they could clog up London's police stations on the eve of one of the most important operations of the year. The anti-capitalists believe the police will be forced to release them without charge.

The stunt has been conceived by the so-called 'Wombles' - identified by the police as the driving force behind this year's events.

The White Overall Movement Building Libertarian Effective Struggles is a direct action group inspired by European anarchists who wear boiler suits padded with bubble wrap and polystyrene to protect them from police batons. The mass arrest is designed to cause maximum embarrassment to the Metropolitan Police, who have so far failed to seize any of the demonstration's organisers.

One Mayday Monopoly organiser said many people in the alliance believed they would have to go public to rebuff police claims that this year's demonstrations are organised by a 'hard core' of 1,000 activists bent on an orgy of violence. 'It is very provocative for the police to warn anyone peaceful not to turn up,' he said.

Activists said last night that members of the anti-capitalist movement had been approached by police officers to act as agents and that activists had also been visited at home and threatened with arrest. A group of anti-capitalists who were stopped and searched by officers at Stansted airport in March after a demonstration in Milan have begun legal action against the police. The Met last night refused to confirm reports that it would be sending uniformed police to monitor and film a key bi-weekly meeting of activists in the King's Cross area of London planned for today.

This year's event has been named 'Mayday Monopoly' after the property-buying board game. Targets on streets around the Monopoly board such as Pall Mall and Mayfair have been identified on a website and a glossily produced 'game guide.' Police have have not identified the producers of the Mayday Monopoly material

This week the organisers will print a leaflet outlining actions to take place on 1 May. A group of animal rights protesters dressed as Mary Poppins will feed the birds in Trafalgar Square to protest against the ban imposed by Mayor Ken Livingstone, while in Mayfair campaigners will build a cardboard hotel to protest at the plight of the homeless.

Allegations have also emerged that police have targeted freelance journalists with close links to the activists. Roddy Mansfield, a producer working for Channel 4, was last week refused entry to a Scotland Yard press conference held by Metropolitan Police Assistant Commissioner Mike Todd.

fields.headline: The cost of...
fields.standfirst: ... being a spy
fields.trailText: ... being a spy.
fields.body:
It looks like the good old days are back for the espionage community. Spies were out of the news for much of the 90s, but recent arrests in China, Russia and the US have brought them, so to speak, out of the cold.

Although most MI5 and MI6 operatives are recruited by their Oxbridge tutors, budding spies can easily become private eyes. So what do you put in that innocuous briefcase?

Surveillance is all about information gathering, or eavesdropping. At a basic level, this requires a transmitter (or bug) which can be disguised in any number of ways: a calculator bug costs £644, a credit card-shaped bug, with 20 hours of battery power, costs £668. Or you can get a £652 pen bug.

Bugging a telephone line is a little more complicated - a transmitter capable of tapping networked office telephones costs £850. A receiver will pick up signals from your transmitter: a standard pocket-sized model is £620, while serious surveillance will necessitate a £1,030 radio-controlled recorder. For your telephone tap, you will require a £995 receiver. If you have to work with your targets in person, use a body-worn recording system costing £895 - you may wish to team this with a disguise to enhance the subterfuge.

As an agent, you won't be immune to bugging, either. Sweep the room with a RFD-Pro bug detector, which is worth every penny of its £2,750 price. As the catalogue says: 'Ideal if your potential adversary is sophisticated, well-funded and highly motivated.'

Further defensive precautions include a voice changer, with eight voice-masking settings, for just £69. To scan the airwaves, invest in a DJX-10 scanner costing £249 and capable of scanning frequencies from 100KHz to 2000MHz. Another piece of kit, of the kind that Q might entrust to 007, is a wireless, pinhole spy camera. The tiny device can be hidden in clocks, mobile phones and smoke detectors, and is just £345.

Move into the big league, international espionage, and you will need rather more expensive spying kit - something like an EP-3 ARIES II spy plane, for example. Manufactured by Lockheed Martin and retailing for at least £25m, it can monitor electronic signals from deep within another country. But the superspy is the US's Echelon network of satellite listening stations (including one based at Menwith Hill, Yorkshire). Annual budget estimates stretch from £0.5bn to £3bn.

Bug detector £2,750

fields.headline: Pleasure dome
fields.standfirst: It's 50 years since the Festival of Britain opened its doors to a disbelieving and enchanted public. Lesley Gillilan conjures up the excitement of the time and speaks to seven people who'll never forget the first and greatest South Bank show
fields.trailText: It's 50 years since the Festival of Britain opened its doors to a disbelieving and enchanted public. Lesley Gillilan conjures up the excitement of the time and speaks to seven people who'll never forget the first and greatest South Bank show.
fields.body:
Almost 50 years after the Festival of Britain, I make a pilgrimage to its erstwhile epicentre, the Thames embankment site of the South Bank Exhibition. It doesn't take long. Other than pacing the length of the site, between Waterloo Bridge and the old County Hall, all it entails is a disappointing inspection of the vacant ground now known as Jubilee Gardens.

It's a struggle to equate this scruffy patch of grass with the post-war pageant that saw 8m people tramping in and out of gaudy show pavilions, under garlands of patriotic bunting, twinkling lights and fountains fizzing with gas flames. Armed with an original Festival map, it's still impossible to place the ghosts of the Skylon (slender, luminous rocket of steel and aluminium) or the Dome of Discovery (flying-saucer lookalike, four times the size of the Albert Hall).

The spaces once devoted to a maze of themed Festival pavilions (Sea and Ships, Homes and Gardens, Power and Production, etc) are now buried beneath the soulless concrete towers of the Shell Centre. The Festival's Fairway, once a fairy-lit piazza, has been swallowed by the Hungerford carpark. Even the Royal Festival Hall, the only exhibition structure to survive intact, has been subjugated by a ring of brutalist concrete wrapped like a motorway flyover around its lower regions. All other evidence of the state-run arts fest, which Dylan Thomas described as 'a palace in thunderland, sizzling with scientific witches' brews', has been erased without so much as a commemorative plaque.

So was the South Bank Exhibition just a giant garden fête? Not if you talk to the generations of designers whose work is still inspired by it. Indeed, in the prologue to A Tonic to the Nation (a collection of essays published in 1976 to mark its 25th anniversary), Sir Roy Strong, former director of the V&A, went as far as to say that the Festival of Britain was 'the last really great stylistic statement this country made'.

The Festival could also be said to be the pinnacle of Old Labour achievement: a tonic to the nation, expressed in welfare-state architecture, public art and enterprise and free of commercial sponsorship. There would, perhaps, be an irony here, had Tony Blair decided to call an election on 3 May - the day was the Festival's official opening, exactly 50 years ago. But although the Festival of Britain is often remembered as an apotheosis of dreary authoritarian socialism, it was truly popular; and it certainly looks much more fun than the late, unlamented Millennium Dome.

First mooted by the Royal Society of Arts in 1943, the Festival of Britain was originally intended to commemorate the centenary of the first world fair - the Great Exhibition of 1851. By the time Clement Attlee's newly elected Labour government appointed Home Secretary Herbert Morrison (Peter Mandelson's grandfather) as Lord President of a Festival Cabinet in 1947, the emphasis had shifted away from international trade to a British celebration of identity and national industry. It was, as Morrison said, a 'madness... but the sort of madness that would put Britain on the map'.

In his role as Lord Festival, he appointed a council of eminent advisors (including TS Eliot and John Gielgud); he made Gerald Barry (former editor of the News Chronicle ) his director general; and Hugh Casson his architectural director. And together with armies of artists, designers and 'theme convenors', their task was to transform 27 acres of what Casson described as 'a grimy and battered film set of a place' into a place of 'gaiety, colour and enchantment' in just 22 months.

Like the Dome, it was lambasted by the press as a profligate waste of money (£11m in all). And Morrison's struggle to justify frivolous public expenditure, at a time of meat rationing, petrol shortages and the Korean war, now looks much more tricky than his grandson's. The administration was also beset by Dome-like problems (resignations, strikes, wet weather). But, in the end, its lighthearted tone and innovative democratic design won the hearts of the public.

'It was a marvellous uplifting experience,' remembers photographer Jane Bown, who documented the event for The Observer. 'We were young, the war was over, and there we were, full of hope, dancing on the South Bank. The breathtaking shapes and colours evoked a wonderful feeling of freedom.'

The main attractions were the Dome of Discovery - a huge inverted saucer of aluminium, designed by 39-year-old Ralph Tubbs, featuring a planetarium (reached by an 'Escalator to Outer Space'), a Polar Theatre (complete with huskies) and a life-sized repro of Captain Cook's Endeavour. There was the 300ft Skylon, the result of an architectural competition for a 'vertical feature', won by architects Powell and Moya; a television pavilion designed by Wells Coates (including a 'Telecinema' in which audiences wore goggles to watch new-fangled stereoscopic films).

The communal spaces, laid out as a miniature city, were decorated with sculptures by Henry Moore, Barbara Hepworth, Lynn Chadwick and others. In the Homes and Gardens pavilion, Robin Day experimented with ideas on the theme of 'home entertainment'. In the Minerals Pavilion, there was a simulated coal mine. In the Countryside Pavilion, a variety of tractors whooshed up and down on hydraulic columns. A herd of Jersey cows attended the opening.

And if you think this sounds like a heaven of kitsch, then you wouldn't have been able to resist taking a shuttle boat from one of the two piers, either side of the Hungerford Bridge, to 'lovely Battersea Park'. Here, were the Festival pleasure gardens - Alice in Wonderland meets Eurotrash - complete with Water-Splash ride, the Oyster Creek and Far Tottering railway, a hideous pneumatic giant and a wedding-cake of a café designed by Patrick Gwynne.

The food, everyone recalls, was awful. But then there was no decent food; one of the adverts in the souvenir programme was for canned processed peas ('Oh! how tender, how delicious; sweet and plump and so nutritious'). But the restaurants were visual feasts. Not least the iconographic Regatta Restaurant designed by Misha Black, which featured murals by Ben Nicholson and 'a novel system of decorative pattern... derived from the diagrams made when scientists map the arrangements of atoms in crystals studied by X-ray methods'.

This injection of colourful crystallography, cybernetics, aeronautics and moon-gazing optimism into Britain's drab, bomb-shattered landscape was what really captured the imagination. People complained, of course; about the queues, the shabby British tourists, the rubbish floating in the Thames, even the smell of the huskies. 'It was all bread, circuses and socialism,' remembers one disenchanted visitor. But even the most cynical factions of the press were forced to admit that the Festival of Britain was a success.

After five months, and an estimated 250 miles of sucked Festival rock, the South Bank Exhibition closed, as was always intended, in September 1951. A general election followed in October. And in what now seems a churlish act of vandalism, Winston Churchill's succeeding Conservative government removed all trace of the exhibition pavilions. The 208 white plaster doves that fluttered above the exhibits in the ultra-kitsch Lion and Unicorn pavilion were auctioned for a guinea each; the beautiful Skylon was sold for scrap, ditto the Dome of Discovery. The site lay derelict for more than a decade before redevelopment as offices and carparks.

Since then, the whimsical Festival style has been dismissed by the architectural cognoscenti as too decorative and, indeed, derivative (a little bit of Mies van der Rohe here, a touch of New York World Fair there). Even Misha Black was to admit: 'It released a flood of the worst kind of bastardised modern architecture the country had ever seen.' Alan Powers, of the Twentieth Century Society, disagrees. Disaffection, he argues, is symptomatic of old-school architects trying to keep in with the young. Now, the Festival of Britain is more widely recognised as the catalyst of a post-war design renaissance, as a parent of the Arts Council, and, as Hugh Casson put it, as 'a pattern book for our new urban landscapes'.

But will it provide a pattern for the programme of renewal planned by the South Bank Centre? I doubt it. Under master planner Rick Mather, there will be a new concert hall, a film centre and a multiplex cinema. There is some semblance of Festival of Britain spirit in the eight-strong shortlist of architects for the scheme, but there is no suggestion of a memorial. Does it need one? 'No one who lived through this period will ever forget it [the Festival of Britain],' wrote Roy Strong. I just wish I'd been there.

 An illustrated book on the Festival of Britain, edited by Alan Powers, will be published next month by the Twentieth Century Society, £19.95. The Society is also releasing a video, Brief City, a 20-minute black-and-white film shot in 1951 by Hugh Massingham for The Observer, £9.95. For details, call 020 7250 3857. The exhibition Festival of Britain - 50 Years On is now at the Church Farmhouse Museum, Greyhound Hill, Hendon, London NW4 (020 8203 0130).

fields.headline: Go buy
fields.standfirst: Art on the net
fields.trailText: Art on the net.
fields.body:
So you've finally chucked out the chintz and got the pared-down minimal pad you've always yearned for. Lots of natural wood, chunky furniture, clever ways to store clutter_ and yawning expanses of white walls crying out for a bit of art to bring them to life. But what to choose? Mass-produced posters are too cheesy; one-off artworks can be seriously expensive. And even if the mortgage and those trips to Habitat and Ikea haven't left you broke, galleries can be intimidating places to the uninitiated.

fields.headline: Children of a lesser god
fields.standfirst: The moral maze
fields.trailText: The moral maze.
fields.body:
Computer games and the people who play them have invaded our space. But a new game threatens to penetrate our inner lives and reveal who we truly are. In Black & White, you play a god summoned by prayers to a pristine Eden. The object of the game is to become, through divine intervention, the one true god accepted by all. In between lie hundreds of moral dilemmas. One comes when a farmer prays to you to take action against the children who are stealing his cows. Closer inspection reveals that the kids are starving. What do you do? Kill the thieves, or the hard-working farmer? Or both? Or neither.

Every action you take in the game is weighted 'good' or 'evil'. In this case, killing the children is the most 'evil' thing you can do. A series of such acts will gradually be reflected in the physical appearance of your world. The sky will grow darker, everything will be tinged with red, the landscape will become threatening. Be a 'good' god and you'll eventually engender a My Little Pony world of unbearably cute radiance.

The most eye-catching element of Black & White, however, is 'the creature' - an artificial intelligence so sophisticated it makes a Furby look like a Pet Rock. Early on, you pass through a giant gate. Three creatures emerge from the forest - a turtle, a tiger and an ape. You choose one.

This creature is unformed. It learns from copying what you do, from specific things that you teach it, and from what it experiences by itself. As a baby you can feed it anything - trees, rocks, people - and it will make up its own mind what it thinks of them. Rocks make it sick, people are very tasty. Discipline it with a slap, however, and it'll leave off snacking on the villagers.

You can never be sure what the creature will do. Leave it alone for a while and you may return to find it uprooting trees. It eventually grows into a giant capable of crushing a village with a single footstep. And like the world that surrounds it, it takes on the appearance of the god it serves.

Black & White's creator, Peter Molyneux, is convinced that the creature which results from any sustained period of play is you. The game reflects decisions made over a long period of time. 'After two hours of play, people begin to revert to type,' he says. 'After 10 hours, what emerges is a creature and a world that reflect your personality.'

Molyneux claims that the principle holds true for the hundreds of people who tested the game. 'The timid ones invariably make a creature in their own image, while those who don't give a damn are instantly recognisable.' His own game-playing, he says, results in a world that is slightly on the evil side. 'The sunsets are better,' he claims.

In real life, Molyneux has a demeanour somewhere between a kindly vicar and a burning-eyed revolutionary. As a nine-year-old, he and his sister stole a baby kangaroo from Windsor Safari Park - until their parents noticed a knocking coming from the boot. Although his original input in Black & White was written on just two sheets of paper, he's since invested everything he has: three years of his life, a family that fell apart under the pressure, and millions of pounds of his own money. It's make or break. 'Of the 2,500 games that appeared at the biggest trade show last year, five will make an awful lot of money, 15 to 20 will make a reasonable amount, and perhaps only 50 will make back their original investment,' he says. But if you make it big, you make it 'very, very big indeed'.

Already it is possible to describe Black & White as a phenomenon. After five days on sale in the US, the PC version of the game had generated $60m. That's before it went on sale in Europe and Japan on 6 April, and before the GameBoy, PlayStation and X-Box release dates have even been announced.

The process of delineating between good and evil was also a tricky one. Molyneux discussed these issues with Richard Evans, a philosopher who specialises in artificial intelligence. Between them they created the moral universe of Black & White and the mind of the creature. Other decisions were painfully obvious. There are 11 types of creature in the game, but in the earliest versions, these were people. 'It became apparent that the discipline element was not acceptable,' says Molyneux. Even as animals, some are uncomfortable with the slapping. He played the game with his five-year-old nephew. 'He chose a turtle and loved it. But he never punished it. The results were quite embarrassing. It was crapping against the side of the temple by the end.'

Toilet-trained or not, the creature you nurture can be downloaded into multi-player games on the net. Others will be able to make instant judgments about you from its appearance. The prospect of corporate employers abandoning psychometric testing for an interview spent playing a computer game is not impossibly far-fetched. Don't say you haven't been warned.

fields.headline: The perfect lunch
fields.standfirst: Keith Waterhouse, author of Soho
fields.trailText: Keith Waterhouse, author of Soho.
fields.body:
I'm a luncher rather than an eater, which is a very different breed. Food isn't in the least important, but neither party should be on a diet because I don't want people fussing about it. I always leave most of my food, but the ritual is very important. I don't eat bread in a restaurant, but I want bread on the table and I like to be able to crumble a bit on the tablecloth.

The perfect lunch has more to do with atmosphere than food, and the company you are in creates atmosphere. Ideally, it should be someone of the opposite sex. It gets a little buzz going, even if nothing is going to happen, because lunch is essentially a flirtatious event. It feels like stolen time because you have a sense that you're playing hooky and you should be at work or doing something constructive. I believe that no one should go back to work after lunch, but for some unfortunate people it's in the middle of the working day. You haven't knocked off for the day, so you feel that you're not entitled to this time and should be back at your desk. Do not try to compromise by having a business lunch. You may talk a little bit of business, but not much. Anything to do with work you can do on the telephone.

Lunch is for generalities and gossip. It's a great chance for dissemination, another reason it should take place between two people of the opposite sex. Men on their own don't gossip a lot, but men and women together do.

The restaurant should be busy, but not so busy that you can't get the attention of the waiter. The Ivy and my local canteen, Langan's, create the best ambience. The person running it must have a sense of theatre and know how to look after people who are there for a treat.

 Soho by Keith Waterhouse (£16.99, Sceptre) is published on 19 April

fields.headline: American beauty
fields.standfirst: In the furore about Mena Suvari and the roses, it was easy to miss the understated yet incandescent screen presence of Thora Birch as Kevin Spacey's daughter. Now audiences are realising what insiders have known since she was six - that Thora Birch is Hollywood's brightest young star (just ask her mum)
fields.trailText: In the furore about Mena Suvari and the roses, it was easy to miss the understated yet incandescent screen presence of Thora Birch as Kevin Spacey's daughter. Now audiences are realising what insiders have known since she was six - that Thora Birch is Hollywood's brightest young star (just ask her mum).
fields.body:
Thora Birch and her mother arrive together as a kind of package, though I am not supposed to write about the mother, Carol, a middle-aged woman with long hair and a face free of the maquillage that usually camouflages the skins of the Beverly Hills animal kingdom. 'Please don't write about me,' says Carol. 'I always talk too much.' She is still angry about an article written about her daughter which suggested that the 19-year-old, whose parents manage her career, was not being allowed to break free of them. 'I could kill that writer,' says Carol vehemently. 'I really could.'

They do have a problem, the Birches. Jack and Carol. The shadow of Macaulay Culkin rests uneasily and the showbiz parent attracts bad press in a town where embarrassing mothers hog borrowed spotlight and spew inanities at the gawpers and stalkers.

The history of Hollywood relates that it is more sensible for an actress to employ her father than her husband. One cannot imagine that it is easy doing business with a person who is also the actress's father, but the trajectory of many a career would be very different if the woman had employed a person as concerned with her personal welfare as with her ability to make money.

The Birches are keen to keep a low profile, and Carol points out that she is not a stage mother - 'I hate that accusation!' She was not the one who noticed Birch's potential. A babysitter took her, aged four, to an audition for a commercial. 'It was like a fish to water,' Carol says.

The little girl was a success right away, appearing in television advertisements for California Raisins and Quaker Oats. At the age of six, she won an award for her appearance in Purple People Eater. By her third film, All I Want for Christmas, in 1991, she was being compared to Shirley Temple and giving interviews of uncanny self-possession.

The Evening Standard 's Angus McGill, finding her in a suite at the London Athenaeum Hotel, could not believe his eyes. 'How old are you?' He asked. 'Nine,' she replied. 'How old are you?' Birch was in town to work on Patriot Games, in which she played Harrison Ford's daughter. McGill asked her if she liked the business. 'Like it?' She exclaimed. 'I love it. My father said I could give it up any time. It was up to me. I didn't have to go to auditions if I didn't want to. I told him no, I want to stay in the business - and here I am. It's amazing.' Then she asked him if he thought God was a man or a girl.

Self-possessed she was then, and self-possessed she is now. One cannot imagine anyone being able to bully Birch, now 19, for she is intelligent and determined and seems to know exactly what she is doing. She reads all the scripts that are sent to her and, while knowing what she likes, finds it more difficult to articulate why she does not like something. 'It would sound pretentious and nasty so I won't vocalise it.' Her parents tend to agree with her on things, though not always on 'how to handle them'.

We are in Le Conversation on Doheny Drive, on the outskirts of Beverly Hills. She has chosen it because it is near the West Hollywood apartment which also doubles as her office, and because it is funny. She is right. It is funny, a 'café society' tea salon with striped wallpaper, pier gilt mirrors, faux-marble floor, several youngish directors eating scones, and a huge oil painting of two rabbits. Understated in jeans and jersey, Birch has a flawless complexion supervised by her mother, who has just discovered products made by Dr Hauschka.

She has talent, as was apparent to anyone who saw the Oscar-winning American Beauty, in which she played troubled teenager Jane Burnham. She was one of the first to audition for the part. 'I knew the script was good,' she says. 'And I knew the process would be amazing - how could working with Kevin Spacey not be brilliant? - but I didn't know what people would think of it, and I still don't really know if the audience actually liked it. I mean, they all saw it because it made a lot of money - I think they recognised it as being a brilliant film - but I don't think they were very comfortable with it.'

The success of American Beauty opened doors and she proceeded to corner a niche in nubile young women. The Smokers is about three teenage girls who rape their boyfriends at gunpoint; Ghost World saw her as Enid, a geeky outsider in thick-framed specs and Doc Martens. Dungeons and Dragons , a fantasy adventure, provided a departure. As heroic Empress Savina, she is involved in a difficult struggle with Jeremy Irons who, as the Mage Profion, employs various elves to help him take over the Empire of Izmer.

Now she has made The Hole, a sinister British thriller set in an upmarket boarding school (Downside was used as a location), which tells the story of a group of teenagers for whom a practical joke goes very badly wrong. As Liz, she plays a complex person summed up in the synopsis as a 'damaged and dangerous mind'.

She wears it well, the duplicitous psycho. Sometimes sweet and innocent, sometimes deranged with maniacal obsession, she provides the story with the layers required to give it depth and deflect the usual clichés of horror. It is a good movie, genuinely unnerving, and filmed imaginatively by first-time director Nick Hamm. It is also reflective of a dark cultural truth where, to a lot of schoolchildren, particularly in America, the high school has become a genuinely dangerous place to be.

Birch shrugs at 'damaged and dangerous'. It was hard work, she says. There was a lot of crying. She has never felt an emotional pain like that before in her life. But she is good at tapping into her hidden fury. 'Liz was about five different characters,' she says. 'She is totally sick, yes, but it was about love...'

She hopes people will see the character's point of view; it was a difficult role to shrug off, and she feels protective of her, as actors often do with the characters they have created. It is about obsession and, in particular obsessive love, a dark place experienced by many that can drive an individual to ruin. She understands that, has felt it, and thinks that once you have felt it, it effects your life and never entirely leaves you.

Is there a boyfriend, I wonder. 'I'm in between at the moment,' she says. She is used to the press, so she probably would not tell anyway, if she did not want to.

She lives at home with her parents and younger brother on their ranch in the Californian desert. She doesn't spend much, drives a 1998 Mustang, buys the occasional CD by Radiohead, the occasional book by Tom Wolfe, watches a lot of DVDs. Gary Oldman is a hero and she is desperate to work with Anthony Hopkins because he doesn't seem to, 'give a damn' about all that Hollywood stuff. She would be more excited by the idea of meeting Moby than some big-name actor. She has met most of them, after all, and worked with a lot of them. The only question she really wants to ask is: 'Have you got any good scripts for me?'

She went to school in West Hollywood where there are not many children, as it is a gay community, so pupils were 'bussed in ' from east LA. Older brothers were armed; younger ones would talk about joining gangs. Birch thought they were insane. She was usually off doing a commercial, anyway.

Her parents were involved in the music business; her father was a road manager and toured with struggling rock bands before going into property and making money from selling land. They had a sophisticated sound system that piped music through the house. Birch grew up listening to Lenny Bruce. 'Part of me would like to be Lenny Bruce for some reason. I would love to hear what he would say about Eminem and Clinton now.'

Pink Floyd also echoed through the family ranch. 'You listen to Dark Side of the Moon and you might think it is boring at first, then, after several times, it's like Oh my God, the genius of it. That is very English, I think.'

She likes the English and feels comfortable with them, unlike in Los Angeles, where she does not really feel a part of things. She enjoyed London from a tourist's eye - appreciating things like Sock Shop and Hyde Park and the pubs.

She visited Benenden, the girls' public school, to research her part for The Hole, and was surprised to discover how much they cared about what adults thought. 'I spent the night in a dorm. We had a midnight feast and everything. But even the kids who think they are really bad couldn't last five minutes on one of our urban streets...'

Nick Hamm's own experience, at a boarding school in Belfast, had not been enjoyable - though he insists his film is not an act of revenge. He thinks the British public-school system leaves a lot to be desired and was keen to reflect its dark side by keeping the film based in England and very British in its tone. To this end he tried, and failed, to find a British actress. After six months, he took the search to Hollywood. He wanted the film to be about teenagers and for the actors to be the right age - 20 would have been too old. A lot of actresses read for the part of Liz, but Birch, according to Hamm, 'had the Bette Davis quality of being able to lie and tell the truth at the same time'.

Young people, says Hamm, are capable of 'huge surliness one minute and massive love the next'. He made sure that all this was channelled into the work; everyone went to bed early. There was no time for emotional explosions.

To Birch, I repeat Hamm's observation that 'teenagers look down on all adults because adults don't understand them... and never will'.

'Most teens think that adults don't understand them,' she replies. 'And I think a lot of adults tell themselves they don't understand teens. But that is not true. All they have to do is remember being one, but the reason they don't is that it is an awful time and who wants to remember it?

'A lot of parents have this tendency to treat their kids like they're not people. It is not a malicious thing, it is more that this is my child and it is not really a person, it is a "beautiful alien" - a precious gift that cannot be treated like anything else on the planet - so everything gets muddled up.'

Her two most high-profile projects have seen her as short brunette playing against a tall blonde - Mena Suvari - in American Beauty, Keira Knightley in The Hole. I wonder if she has ever been aggrieved by the high-school diktat that says all teenagers must be thin and look like Hitler Youth in order to be popular.

'Everyone thinks that,' she says. 'But I think that it is the personality that is important. If you are gorgeous you are going to get attention - but it is about attitude. If there is fear you invoke fear, if you are a party person you are invited to parties. It is about your personal energy. Do you have an outgoing energy or the kind of energy that makes people want to hit you? Most people have a normal energy which means that no one pays them attention - then they say they are not popular because they do not have this or that, but, in fact it is because they are not opening up.'

'Jesus,' I say. 'I wish I had known all that when I was 18.'

 The Hole goes on general release on 20 April.
