It is a good movie, genuinely unnerving, and filmed imaginatively by first-time director Nick Hamm. It is also reflective of a dark cultural truth where, to a lot of schoolchildren, particularly in America, the high school has become a genuinely dangerous place to be. Birch shrugs at 'damaged and dangerous'. It was hard work, she says. There was a lot of crying. She has never felt an emotional pain like that before in her life. But she is good at tapping into her hidden fury. 'Liz was about five different characters,' she says. 'She is totally sick, yes, but it was about love...' She hopes people will see the character's point of view; it was a difficult role to shrug off, and she feels protective of her, as actors often do with the characters they have created. It is about obsession and, in particular obsessive love, a dark place experienced by many that can drive an individual to ruin. She understands that, has felt it, and thinks that once you have felt it, it effects your life and never entirely leaves you. Is there a boyfriend, I wonder. 'I'm in between at the moment,' she says. She is used to the press, so she probably would not tell anyway, if she did not want to. She lives at home with her parents and younger brother on their ranch in the Californian desert. She doesn't spend much, drives a 1998 Mustang, buys the occasional CD by Radiohead, the occasional book by Tom Wolfe, watches a lot of DVDs. Gary Oldman is a hero and she is desperate to work with Anthony Hopkins because he doesn't seem to, 'give a damn' about all that Hollywood stuff. She would be more excited by the idea of meeting Moby than some big-name actor. She has met most of them, after all, and worked with a lot of them. The only question she really wants to ask is: 'Have you got any good scripts for me?' She went to school in West Hollywood where there are not many children, as it is a gay community, so pupils were 'bussed in ' from east LA. Older brothers were armed; younger ones would talk about joining gangs. Birch thought they were insane. She was usually off doing a commercial, anyway. Her parents were involved in the music business; her father was a road manager and toured with struggling rock bands before going into property and making money from selling land. They had a sophisticated sound system that piped music through the house. Birch grew up listening to Lenny Bruce. 'Part of me would like to be Lenny Bruce for some reason. I would love to hear what he would say about Eminem and Clinton now.' Pink Floyd also echoed through the family ranch. 'You listen to Dark Side of the Moon and you might think it is boring at first, then, after several times, it's like Oh my God, the genius of it. That is very English, I think.' She likes the English and feels comfortable with them, unlike in Los Angeles, where she does not really feel a part of things. She enjoyed London from a tourist's eye - appreciating things like Sock Shop and Hyde Park and the pubs. She visited Benenden, the girls' public school, to research her part for The Hole, and was surprised to discover how much they cared about what adults thought. 'I spent the night in a dorm. We had a midnight feast and everything. But even the kids who think they are really bad couldn't last five minutes on one of our urban streets...' Nick Hamm's own experience, at a boarding school in Belfast, had not been enjoyable - though he insists his film is not an act of revenge. He thinks the British public-school system leaves a lot to be desired and was keen to reflect its dark side by keeping the film based in England and very British in its tone. To this end he tried, and failed, to find a British actress. After six months, he took the search to Hollywood. He wanted the film to be about teenagers and for the actors to be the right age - 20 would have been too old. A lot of actresses read for the part of Liz, but Birch, according to Hamm, 'had the Bette Davis quality of being able to lie and tell the truth at the same time'. Young people, says Hamm, are capable of 'huge surliness one minute and massive love the next'. He made sure that all this was channelled into the work; everyone went to bed early. There was no time for emotional explosions. To Birch, I repeat Hamm's observation that 'teenagers look down on all adults because adults don't understand them... and never will'. 'Most teens think that adults don't understand them,' she replies. 'And I think a lot of adults tell themselves they don't understand teens. But that is not true. All they have to do is remember being one, but the reason they don't is that it is an awful time and who wants to remember it? 'A lot of parents have this tendency to treat their kids like they're not people. It is not a malicious thing, it is more that this is my child and it is not really a person, it is a "beautiful alien" - a precious gift that cannot be treated like anything else on the planet - so everything gets muddled up.' Her two most high-profile projects have seen her as short brunette playing against a tall blonde - Mena Suvari - in American Beauty, Keira Knightley in The Hole. I wonder if she has ever been aggrieved by the high-school diktat that says all teenagers must be thin and look like Hitler Youth in order to be popular. 'Everyone thinks that,' she says. 'But I think that it is the personality that is important. If you are gorgeous you are going to get attention - but it is about attitude. If there is fear you invoke fear, if you are a party person you are invited to parties. It is about your personal energy. Do you have an outgoing energy or the kind of energy that makes people want to hit you? Most people have a normal energy which means that no one pays them attention - then they say they are not popular because they do not have this or that, but, in fact it is because they are not opening up.' 'Jesus,' I say. 'I wish I had known all that when I was 18.'  The Hole goes on general release on 20 April.

webTitle: Festival of Britain: Sir Terence Conran

fields.headline: Festival of Britain: Sir Terence Conran
fields.standfirst: Helping to design some of the Festival's exhibits gave Sir Terence Conran an insight into a bright new world. But it was a decade before people could afford to bring that colour into their own homes
fields.trailText: There was a whole feeling of making it happen, and it was very difficult to make things happen at that time. It was a grey and damaged land and it was a challenge to buy simple things like screws. You would want to make cushions for something, but you couldn't find any textiles, so I'd spend my time going down to Petticoat Lane where you'd find some that had fallen off the back of a lorry. In a sense you would design for the materials you could get your hands on.
fields.body:
There was a whole feeling of making it happen, and it was very difficult to make things happen at that time. It was a grey and damaged land and it was a challenge to buy simple things like screws. You would want to make cushions for something, but you couldn't find any textiles, so I'd spend my time going down to Petticoat Lane where you'd find some that had fallen off the back of a lorry. In a sense you would design for the materials you could get your hands on.

But when we went back a few months later, we thought it had been terrifically worthwhile, because you actually saw the reaction of ordinary people. They were still carrying their sandwiches in their gas-mask cases and wearing long raincoats, but the Festival showed them a different sort of world. You could see it on their faces. It was quite romantic.

The great disappointment after the Festival finished was that we thought our lives were made, only to find there was no work. It had offered the nation something different and they were amazed and excited. So I knew there was a dormant audience for the kind of design I believed in.

But it wasn't until the end of the 50s that the economy expanded sufficiently and young people had money to spend. You begin to see the effects of the Festival of Britain in the early 60s when I opened Habitat. Young people were offered things they hadn't seen before and they were able to indulge in something different from their parents.

I'm sure the Festival was the beginning of a great revolution in this country where we are perceived as the most creative nation in the world. We're thought of as the great happening place in the world, and the Festival of Britain lit that touchpaper.

fields.headline: Festival of Britain: George Simner
fields.standfirst: From postcards to mugs and badges to plates, the paraphernalia of the Festival of Britain is not not only collectable, it's surprisingly valuable. George Simner, a retired plasterer and founding member of the Festival of Britain Society, explains the appeal
fields.trailText: I was looking for an alternative to stamp collecting, when my mother reminded me that we still had some old Festival of Britain postcards in the attic. I thought, there's a nice thing - surely nobody else collects Festival of Britain? And it went on from there.
fields.body:
I was looking for an alternative to stamp collecting, when my mother reminded me that we still had some old Festival of Britain postcards in the attic. I thought, there's a nice thing - surely nobody else collects Festival of Britain? And it went on from there.

I did go to the South Bank Exhibition. I was 17 and waiting to get my call-up papers to do my national service. My most striking memory was standing underneath the Skylon. It's always stayed in my mind, as have the vibrant colours, and the huge queues. The capacity of the Dome of Discovery was 4,000, but the queue to get in was two miles long. In my collection, I've got old snaps of the Festival - with people, like ants, everywhere.

At first, I just collected postcards, but through going to fairs, I met other like-minded people. One of them invited me down to a talk with Abram Games (the designer who created the famous Festival symbol) at the Portsmouth philatelic society. Afterwards, I was having a cup of tea and a chat, with some of the people there, and we hit on this idea to form a Festival of Britain society.

That was over 10 years ago, and now we've got 150 members. Some joined just because they were born in 1951, or worked at the Festival, but about half of us are serious collectors. My main interest is in ephemera: the books, the guides, the postcards, but I collect anything I can find with a Festival of Britain connection. The most unusual items are a beer sign, advertising special Festival beers, and a beautiful bit of wrapping paper. The most precious is a signed Abram Games poster.

I've also got two tablecloths, nine headscarves and 40 badges with the Festival symbol on. I think I'm up to 40 powder compacts. I've got the Skylon Biro pen, the classic Wedgwood mug (they are worth about £300, now), the Poole pottery plate with Festival of Britain 1951 written on it - a very collectable piece. I'd like more posters, but they are way out of my league, now. When I bought mine, I paid £14 for it, Christie's recently sold one for £700. I like the personal mementos, as well as the collectables, like people's personal photographs. We didn't own a camera then - in the war years, it just wasn't on, you had to have a licence. At the Festival they superimposed a picture of yourself on to one of four or five different views of the exhibition. They put it in a little cardboard frame decorated with the Games symbol. I wish I'd done one now.

fields.headline: Sexual appetites
fields.standfirst: How the contents of your kitchen can help in the bedroom. Plus, beating breast cancer and taking the swelling out of arthritis
fields.trailText: How the contents of your kitchen can help in the bedroom. Plus, beating breast cancer and taking the swelling out of arthritis.
fields.body:
Forget Sex and the City - 'no sex in the city' might be a more accurate description of what's going on in many bedrooms: a major survey published by the Journal of American Medicine has found that 30 per cent of men and more than 40 per cent of women have no interest in sex. It's 'Not tonight, thanks' in many British homes, too - often a result of today's stressful work and home environments. Low libido is now a real problem for many people.

A lack of sexual desire can have many causes. But a contributing factor can be nutritional imbalances. While I'm not claiming that the correct diet can cure a low libido, the synthesis of the hormones involved in regulating sex drive, including oestrogen, progesterone and testosterone (which also affects women's libidos), requires niacin (vitamin B3), vitamin B5, vitamin A or beta carotene and zinc, which means that boosting your intake of these nutrients could transform your sex life.

To glean the B vitamins, try to eat milk, yogurt, cheese, fish, meat, green, leafy vegetables, nuts and dried fruits. Beta carotene is found in carrots, dark-green, leafy vegetables, peppers, apricots and peaches, as well as other fresh yellow, orange and red fruits. And although the traditional aphrodisiacs oysters, lobsters and other types of seafood contain zinc, it is also found in hard, crumbly cheeses, brown rice and offal. As to quantity, not only is it difficult to set rigid rules, but getting het up about whether you've consumed 15 or 20mg of zinc during the day won't do your libido any favours either.

Another libido-boosting tip is to seek out foods that contain the amino acids tyrosine and arginine, which help to produce neurotransmitters that stimulate alertness and arousal. They are found in protein- rich foods, as well as in such high-grade microalgae supplements as spirulina or chorella (available from health-food stores).

Finally, eating well will make you feel healthier and energetic, which in turn should stimulate your interest in having an early night for reasons other than sleeping.

Nutrition news: Curbing breast cancer

Eating less could help to decrease women's chances of developing breast cancer, according to recently published research in the British Medical Journal . Polish researchers have discovered that calorie intake can affect the concentrations of oestrogen and progesterone which are produced during the menstrual cycle. This has important implications because high levels of ovarian-produced progesterone are linked with an increased risk of breast cancer.

Following a diet low in animal fat, high in fibre and with lots of fruit and vegetables has also been shown to lower the risk of developing breast cancer.

Your questions

I have just been diagnosed as having rheumatoid arthritis. Is there anything I can do to get rid of the incredibly painful inflammation that I feel in my joints?
Moira Visser, Walthamstow

A Oily fish, such as sardines, tuna, herrings, kippers, anchovies, mackerel and salmon, are rich in omega-3 fatty acids, which can reduce arthritic inflammation. Try to eat oily fish once or twice a week and ensure that your diet is healthy. The question of levels of polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB) and dioxins that oily fish, particularly salmon, may contain remains confusing, and I have yet to receive a satisfactory answer from the Food Standards Authority, which only recommends eating a portion of oily fish once a week. I'd personally recommend that you opt for freshwater, rather than farmed, salmon for the time being. Meanwhile, eat lots of fruits (apart from citrus fruits, which could aggravate your symptoms) and vegetables, as they contain antioxidants that help your body to deal with the residues in oily fish.

Many exclusion diets offer relief from rheumatoid arthritis and advocate cutting out wheat, dairy and cooked foods, but the scientific evidence for this is not conclusive. However, having kept a food diary in which they noted what they ate and how they felt for a few weeks, some of my patients have found that specific foods make their symptoms worse. If this applies to you, either experiment with reducing the amount of the culprit food or avoid it for several weeks. If this relieves your stiffness and pain, seek the advice of a dietician, who will help you to plan a diet that excludes the trigger food. On no account cut out important food groups without replacing them with sufficiently nutritious substitutes, because this could burden your body with even more health problems.

A final warning word about anaemia, a common side effect of restricted diets and taking strong anti-inflammatory drugs, which can result in gastrointestinal bleeding (this is why you should eat before taking them), thereby causing your body to become deficient in iron. If you're feeling very tired, ask your GP for a blood test.

 Jane Clarke is a state-registered dietician. Please note that Jane Clarke cannot enter into any personal correspondence.

fields.headline: Brighter later
fields.standfirst: Not everyone chooses to live surrounded by flocks of garish plastic flamingoes and Formica, but for some the 50s have never gone out of fashion. Lesley Gillilan enters a suburban shrine
fields.trailText: Not everyone chooses to live surrounded by flocks of garish plastic flamingoes and Formica, but for some the 50s have never gone out of fashion. Lesley Gillilan enters a suburban shrine.
fields.body:
Lucie Smailes sometimes has trouble finding a babysitter. Her two young children, Billy and Lily, are not the problem, she explains; it's the wall-to-wall 50s decor. Some of her mates simply can't stomach another evening on her authentic post-war sofa, leaning against poodle-stitched antimacassars, surrounded by green-tinted Tretchikoff babes and crowds of small plastic señoritas doing the Fandango across coloured Formica.

The house is an ordinary two-up-two-down in suburban Bristol, except that its interior appears to have got lost in time somewhere around 1955. The look is post-modern retro, but more at the Woolworths end of the style spectrum (think Only Fools and Horses meets The Simpsons ). The basic colour palette is custard, bubblegum and candy floss. Kitchen furnishings include a yellow dinette table and matching metal-leg chairs; one of those tallboy (or Del Boy) cabinets with a fold-down work surface; and a original retro fridge (in spray-on lipstick pink).

Accessories include a canoe-shaped dish of fake fruit, a carousel of frilly cotton pinnies, coloured pegs, pink flamingos, Festival of Britain wire ware (with knobs on) and illuminated posies of Lucie's favourite plastic roses ('I love roses,' she says). She also loves leopard print, red Perspex and diaphanous vinyl. She wears them when she gets a chance (a wardrobe of ruched swimming costumes, frothy frocks, hats and handbags, is displayed on her bedroom wall). Lucie's idea of a snack? A handful of jelly beans dispensed from a slot machine ('It only takes French francs'), served on red-and-white spotted picnic ware.

In her front room, there's a ship-shaped cocktail cabinet clad in wood-look Fablon and a glitzy mirror-glass cupboard stuffed with plastic-flower paperweights. There's a plastic budgie in a chrome cage, a shiny red-vinyl settee, festoons of paper lanterns and light-up tropical birds, but no television, no stereo - just a mind-bending display of 50s kitsch.

'To my mother's generation, it's all tacky, working-class crap,' says Lucie. And even to us 50s-friendly baby boomers, it evokes mixed feelings, ranging from a vague, uncomfortable sense of familiarity to plain distaste. 'Most of my friends don't like all my 50s stuff,' says Lucie. 'They think I should clear it all out and make the place more homely for the children.' And she has tried to give it up. But therein lies a problem: she can't live without it. 'To me, it's a form of antidepressant - it makes me smile.'

In a sense, her sentiments reflect the mood of the time in which her 'stuff' was born - when cheap, cheerful chain-store goods, big hair, big frocks and imported Americanisms provided an antidote to years of war-time gloom. Imagine the joy of escaping dreary Utility plywood for chrome and vivid Formica, swapping khaki serge for brushed Bri-Nylon, or replacing blackout curtains with the window-wear equivalent of Hawaiian shirts.

The years that followed the Festival of Britain saw the birth of Terylene, tea bags and TV dinners, the first jet-airline service, the Pill, the Pop Parade, molecules, microchips, Miss World and the Chevrolet Corvette. Yet at the beginning of the decade, nearly half of British homes had no bathroom or indoor lavatory. The whimsical mass-market consumer goods of the time suggested cocktail hours and exotic package holidays, but for most people, it was all scrubbing brushes, boiled cabbage and Spam.

'My interpretation of the 50s is a fantasy,' admits Lucie, who wasn't born until 1968. 'In my 50s, everyone had bright melamine kitchens and new-fangled gadgets, and went to rock'n'roll concerts every night, but I know it wasn't really like that. In fact, I'd hate to have been a 50s housewife. Life was still very hard. It wasn't until 1959 to 1960 that things started to pick up.' And nobody, working class or otherwise, would have had quite the concentration of frivolous knick-knacks that have been squeezed into Lucie's house. Her collection must have come from literally hundreds of households (and that's just the Spanish dolls).

Her habit started with a Pat Boone record case, circa 1955, bought at a jumble sale 10 years ago. 'When I first started collecting, I wasn't aware I was buying 50s things - I just liked what I saw and bought it.' Throughout her twenties (as London Contemporary dancer, Citroën 2CV mechanic and tequila slammer girl), Lucie continued to buy, but it only became an obsession when she was studying interior design at art college. 'I did a project on Molecular 50s and Festival of Britain furnishings, and I got completely hooked,' she says.

She succumbs to the occasional extravagance, such as the pink retro fridge at £250 ('It was worth it, especially when you think of the price of a Smeg'), but the challenge is in finding things at a bargain price. Most of Lucie's treasures were bought at jumble sales and car boots.

Favourites include a Hula-girl table fountain which sprinkles water into a small, lurid-green pond of plastic lilies; a cylindrical, red Perspex cocktail cabinet with matching red-rose lampshade; plus Lucie's collection of 'Tinas', or framed glamour-girl prints by Siberian-born Vladimir Tretchikoff, JH Lynch and other masters of low-brow populist art. Tretchikoff's The Green Lady , painted in 1952, was the most reproduced work of the 20th century. It is now achieving status as an icon of post-modern irony, but Lucie doesn't see her like that.

'I don't care about dates, origins or how much anything is worth; my choices are purely aesthetic,' she says. But she has, nonetheless, picked up some 'classic' pieces of collectable kitsch. A spike- legged coffee table featuring a scene from Swan Lake , for example, is a relic of the 'Balletomania' era, when Margot Fonteyn was the teen-heroine equivalent of Posh Spice. The boat-shaped cocktail bar is not particularly rare (factory-made in the early 50s by Barget), but Lucie's is in pristine condition and includes a porthole, anchor and fake-wood laminate deck.

She has a small collection of Homemaker - Ridgway Potteries' tableware, designed by Enid Seeney for Woolworths (in which an abstraction of Robin Day-esque chairs and boomerang tables float around in monochrome space). She has at least two Miss Tissue Heads (plastic dolls' heads from which Kleenex is dispensed from a mane of pink-nylon hair), and dozens of examples of wire-ware products (zigzag wall tidies, magazine racks, plant holders) with the classic Festival of Britain-style 'cocktail cherry' feet.

According to Collecting the 1950s (£15.99, Mitchell Beazley), a Miller's Collectable Price Guide, many of these things now fetch reasonable prices (Tretchikoff print about £30; Barget bar, £150; American dinette table, £750). In fact, Lucie often sells pieces she's grown tired of or can't fit into her house - though she still has a wish list of things she would always find room for. 'I've always wanted a Miss Mixer Martini shaker,' she says. 'She wobbles her boobs around while shaking the drink.' Sounds ghastly? Well, yes, but this battery-operated Barbie lookalike is worth up to £150. London retro specialist Flying Duck Enterprises reports a waiting list.

fields.bodyText: Lucie Smailes sometimes has trouble finding a babysitter. Her two young children, Billy and Lily, are not the problem, she explains; it's the wall-to-wall 50s decor. Some of her mates simply can't stomach another evening on her authentic post-war sofa, leaning against poodle-stitched antimacassars, surrounded by green-tinted Tretchikoff babes and crowds of small plastic señoritas doing the Fandango across coloured Formica. The house is an ordinary two-up-two-down in suburban Bristol, except that its interior appears to have got lost in time somewhere around 1955. The look is post-modern retro, but more at the Woolworths end of the style spectrum (think Only Fools and Horses meets The Simpsons ). The basic colour palette is custard, bubblegum and candy floss. Kitchen furnishings include a yellow dinette table and matching metal-leg chairs; one of those tallboy (or Del Boy) cabinets with a fold-down work surface; and a original retro fridge (in spray-on lipstick pink). Accessories include a canoe-shaped dish of fake fruit, a carousel of frilly cotton pinnies, coloured pegs, pink flamingos, Festival of Britain wire ware (with knobs on) and illuminated posies of Lucie's favourite plastic roses ('I love roses,' she says). She also loves leopard print, red Perspex and diaphanous vinyl. She wears them when she gets a chance (a wardrobe of ruched swimming costumes, frothy frocks, hats and handbags, is displayed on her bedroom wall). Lucie's idea of a snack? A handful of jelly beans dispensed from a slot machine ('It only takes French francs'), served on red-and-white spotted picnic ware. In her front room, there's a ship-shaped cocktail cabinet clad in wood-look Fablon and a glitzy mirror-glass cupboard stuffed with plastic-flower paperweights. There's a plastic budgie in a chrome cage, a shiny red-vinyl settee, festoons of paper lanterns and light-up tropical birds, but no television, no stereo - just a mind-bending display of 50s kitsch. 'To my mother's generation, it's all tacky, working-class crap,' says Lucie. And even to us 50s-friendly baby boomers, it evokes mixed feelings, ranging from a vague, uncomfortable sense of familiarity to plain distaste. 'Most of my friends don't like all my 50s stuff,' says Lucie. 'They think I should clear it all out and make the place more homely for the children.' And she has tried to give it up. But therein lies a problem: she can't live without it. 'To me, it's a form of antidepressant - it makes me smile.' In a sense, her sentiments reflect the mood of the time in which her 'stuff' was born - when cheap, cheerful chain-store goods, big hair, big frocks and imported Americanisms provided an antidote to years of war-time gloom. Imagine the joy of escaping dreary Utility plywood for chrome and vivid Formica, swapping khaki serge for brushed Bri-Nylon, or replacing blackout curtains with the window-wear equivalent of Hawaiian shirts. The years that followed the Festival of Britain saw the birth of Terylene, tea bags and TV dinners, the first jet-airline service, the Pill, the Pop Parade, molecules, microchips, Miss World and the Chevrolet Corvette. Yet at the beginning of the decade, nearly half of British homes had no bathroom or indoor lavatory. The whimsical mass-market consumer goods of the time suggested cocktail hours and exotic package holidays, but for most people, it was all scrubbing brushes, boiled cabbage and Spam. 'My interpretation of the 50s is a fantasy,' admits Lucie, who wasn't born until 1968. 'In my 50s, everyone had bright melamine kitchens and new-fangled gadgets, and went to rock'n'roll concerts every night, but I know it wasn't really like that. In fact, I'd hate to have been a 50s housewife. Life was still very hard. It wasn't until 1959 to 1960 that things started to pick up.' And nobody, working class or otherwise, would have had quite the concentration of frivolous knick-knacks that have been squeezed into Lucie's house. Her collection must have come from literally hundreds of households (and that's just the Spanish dolls). Her habit started with a Pat Boone record case, circa 1955, bought at a jumble sale 10 years ago. 'When I first started collecting, I wasn't aware I was buying 50s things - I just liked what I saw and bought it.' Throughout her twenties (as London Contemporary dancer, Citroën 2CV mechanic and tequila slammer girl), Lucie continued to buy, but it only became an obsession when she was studying interior design at art college. 'I did a project on Molecular 50s and Festival of Britain furnishings, and I got completely hooked,' she says. Most of Lucie's treasures were bought at jumble sales and car boots. 'I don't care about dates, origins or how much anything is worth; my choices are purely aesthetic,' she says. But she has, nonetheless, picked up some 'classic' pieces of collectable kitsch. fields.headline: Designer drugs
fields.standfirst: In less than a decade, tailor-made medication could make fatal side effects a thing of the past
fields.trailText: In less than a decade, tailor-made medication could make fatal side effects a thing of the past.
fields.body:
Take a peek inside the bathroom cabinet of just about any home and the chances are you will find a collection of half-used, long-forgotten medicine bottles, tablets and tonics. As a nation, we spend more than £6bn on prescription drugs and another £1.5bn on over-the-counter medicines every year, yet vast quantities are regularly flushed down the loo or left to gather dust in cupboards.

The fact is that all too frequently the medication we optimistically pick up at the chemist is then abandoned - either because it didn't work at all or because it made us feel a whole lot worse. The reason for this is simply that we are all different. Just as some of us have blue eyes and blond hair while others have big noses and freckles, our genetic make-up means we all react differently to different medicines, which makes taking them a bit of a lottery.

Fast forward to 2010. You visit your GP with, say, asthma, or migraine, or high blood pressure. After a simple test from a mouth swab, your doctor then prescribes the exact dose of a medicine tailor made to work for you with minimal side effects. This is not science fiction. Opinions may vary about the date, but scientists agree that before long we will all be taking designer drugs - in the nicest possible sense.

This breakthrough will revolutionise health care. Personalised medicine should make clinical treatment safer and more effective, saving money and lives. It will mean medicines can be created which are custom made to suit particular genetic types. The technology already exists. The knowledge - gained through the efforts of the human genome project to map our genetic make-up - is rapidly emerging. And clinical trials are already taking place in which patients are genetically selected for the drugs that will work best for them. Indeed, of all areas of genetic research, scientists believe personalised medicine - properly called pharmacogenetics - is likely to have the greatest effect soonest.

'I think it is a very exciting time,' says Professor Tony Moffat, chief scientist at the Royal Pharmaceutical Society. 'Some time in the near future we're going to have diagnostic tests made available that will allow us to choose the right drug at the right dose for the right patient.'

It will, he says, be a huge advance on existing practice. Currently, prescribing medicines is often a game of trial and error. Visit a doctor with a particular complaint and you will be prescribed the standard medicine at the standard dose. Yet the human genome project has shown that while we are all 99.9 per cent identical, we are each also significantly different and these variations in genetic makeup apply to our responses to drugs. We all vary in the way our bodies absorb, transport and process different medicines, so the same drug may work perfectly in one person, not at all in another and cause toxic effects in a third.

Research in the US has shown that side effects of medicines are the fourth commonest reason people end up in hospital and the fifth leading cause of death. There is no reason, says Professor Moffat, to believe the situation is any different here. Indeed, the Medicines Control Agency (MCA), which records adverse drug reactions in the UK, received 32,666 reports last year, including 309 deaths - although this may not have been due to the drug reactions in all cases.

The risks are already well understood. People process different medicines at vastly different rates. When drugs are metabolised slowly, they stay in people's systems too long with potentially fatal results. Poor metabolisers of succinylcholine, an injection given to relax muscles before operations for example, may remain paralysed for many hours after their surgery and even die. Figures from the MCA show 356 people have suffered adverse reactions to succinylcholine since 1967, and 47 have died. Other drugs can have similarly disastrous effects. Slow metabolisers of warfarin, used to treat thrombosis and prevent strokes, may bleed to death. MCA figures show that there have been 1,156 suspected adverse reactions to warfarin since 1964, including 168 deaths.

At the same time, Professor Moffat explains, genetic variations mean many common drugs just don't work for some people. Beta-blockers, used to treat heart conditions, are ineffective for one in five people. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as Prozac, fail to work for a quarter of people. Drugs prescribed for schizophrenia are ineffective in a colossal 94 per cent of people. Effectively, each schizophrenia drug has a one in 20 chance of working.

Frequently this hit-and-miss affair means patients have to return to their doctor several times to try different drugs at different doses, says Professor Moffat. Since some drugs, like the SSRIs, take several weeks to work at all, the process can be slow as well as wasteful. It is not surprising many patients give up.

In future, genetic tests will predict how well a certain drug will work for a particular patient. Using this information, the doctor or pharmacist can then alter the dose or prescribe a different drug. The test, which is different to the controversial genetic tests used to screen for predisposition to inherited diseases, is already available. Pharmaceutical companies now use such tests in the trials of new medicines to eliminate patients who would either not respond or would respond badly to the drug. This not only makes the results look better - trials only include patients on which companies know the drug will work - but may give them the edge over competitors if they can assure doctors a new pill will work for a given group of patients.

Existing medicines are also being analysed to determine who they will best work for. UK-based company Bristol-Myers Squibb is studying genetic variations in patients with cancer, to assess who will respond best to its oncology medicines. Novartis is undertaking research in Britain to determine which patients respond best to its asthma drugs.

Allen Roses, an expert in genetic diseases with British-based GlaxoSmithKline, says: 'Potentially, this could save enormous numbers of lives and cost.' Instead of selling a drug which is only effective in 60 per cent of people, companies will be able to offer medicines that are 100 per cent effective in a smaller band of patients, he explains. He also believes that this advance may even give a new lease of life to medicines previously banned due to harmful side effects, which could be reintroduced with a licence only for certain, safe, genetic types.

Currently pharmacogenetic tests are too expensive for general use. But costs are expected to fall rapidly so that eventually all of us will have the test carried out - possibly at birth - with the results kept centrally on computer or on a personal smart card.

A handful of people, however, have already undergone tests privately through a laboratory service, LGC, which performs tests for the pharmaceutical industry. After taking the test himself, Dr Paul Debenham, head of life sciences at LGC, found that he was a poor metaboliser for certain drugs. Like eight per cent of Caucasian people - metabolism rates vary among ethnic groups - he has a deficiency in the enzyme CYP2D6. This makes him slow to process about a quarter of common drugs, including beta-blockers and pain relievers; they stay in his system too long so are potentially too powerful.

'If I am prescribed a medicine, I would certainly now go to the drugs manuals and see whether it is affected by CYP2D6,' he says. He predicts many more people will soon start demanding the tests once they realise their relevance. Theoretically, he believes, patients may even have a legal case against doctors who prescribe a drug with a predictably toxic effect when a reliable test is available.

Patients' groups are rapidly realising the potential benefits of pharmacogenetics. Alastair Kent, director of the Genetic Interest Group, which represents 130 patients' organisations, sees personalised medicine as the least controversial offshoot of genetics. 'It should lead to better outcomes, fewer harmful effects for patients and therefore better compliance,' he says.

Meanwhile, the NHS is watching developments keenly. 'It should be a win-win situation,' says Dr Ron Zimmern, director of the Public Health Genetics Unit, which monitors genetics advances for the NHS. 'Safer, more effective drugs should reduce costs to the NHS, by avoiding wasted medicines and treatment of adverse side effects'. But question marks remain, he cautions, over funding, timing and logistics.

Nobody knows the likely cost of testing the population, nor who will pick up the bill. Drugs manufacturers may bump up their prices if they have to limit certain drugs to smaller groups of people. Eventually, says Dr Zimmern, if certain drugs are known not to work or to cause toxic effects in some people, they might only be licensed to treat particular genetic types.

And the pace of change towards this medicine nirvana is anyone's guess. Expert predictions vary from five to 30 years, according to Dr Zimmern. But however long it takes, he adds, one thing is certain: 'There is no doubt that pharmacogenetics is going to change the way we prescribe and practise medicine.'

Letting the genie out of the bottle

Everyone responds very differently to different drugs. Reasons include our diet, other medicines being taken at the same time, and our genetic make-up.

It has been known since the 1960s that genetic variations affect how we respond to drugs. Common examples include:

 Codeine: the painkiller is activated by an enzyme which converts some of the drug into morphine which then tackles the pain. In the minority of people who lack this enzyme, codeine fails to work.

 Debrisoquine: the rate at which people process or metabolise this drug, which is used to treat high blood pressure, varies 20-fold.

 Ecstasy: about 8 per cent of Caucasians lack the enzyme needed to metabolise ecstasy. Doctors suggest this may explain why some people die after a single tablet.

 Statins: these drugs used to treat heart disease are ineffective in between 30 per cent and 70 per cent of people.

The Genetic Interest Group

fields.headline: Well being
fields.standfirst: An alternative look at health issues. This week: following the path of least resistance with Tao, how to dispel dizziness and to cut or not to cut
fields.trailText: An alternative look at health issues. This week: following the path of least resistance with Tao, how to dispel dizziness and to cut or not to cut.
fields.body:
'Trust in the Tao and it'll all work out somehow,' goes the ancient song of the itinerant barefoot doctor, meaning be confident, trust yourself and trust in the innate benevolence of life, as it unwinds through its unbroken sequential process of cause and effect, and your personal fairy tale will have a happy ending (if you don't mind dying, that is).

Predating Buddhism and Confucianism, Taoism evolved in the ancient Orient as a philosophy, code and way of life at least 5,000 years ago (some believe 12,000). It was said to have been passed down by the so-called 'sons of reflected light'. Taoist folklore has it that these beings were 7ft tall, wore unusual clothing, lived in the mountains between Tibet and China and one day disappeared without trace. But not without first sharing their secrets with the locals.

They taught how energy and consciousness flows and works - both microcosmically in the human body and macrocosmically through time and space - and how to take command of that process in order to reach your optimum potential.

Taoism is not actually an 'ism' at all and is definitely not a religion, though in more recent centuries, its practice has been mildly subverted by some who have managed to twist it into a neo-religious form.

The art in sampling or exploring this rich yet simple seam of metaphysical gold lies in identifying with the minds of the original Taoist practitioners. I say 'practitioners' because Taoism consists merely of a series of mind-body-spirit practices designed to maintain in harmony all aspects of your life and how it stands in relation to others and to your environment. These practices include t'ai chi, chi-kung, feng shui and acupuncture, as well as many other lesser-known arts.

Using Taoist methods to your advantage would not run counter to any religious or nonreligious belief you may or may not hold, but would rather augment it. The Tao is not an alternative to God, the Buddha, or any other manner of label we attach to the unlableable. It's just a big, friendly, all-encompassing idea that can help make sense of the nonsense of life.

And it's got a clean history. No one, to my knowledge, has ever fought, killed, conquered, savaged, raped, plundered, or has had done to them likewise in its name. As far as I know, no other concept of the inconceivable has managed to thrive through 5,000 years with such a spotless record.

This may be because a fundamental tenet of Taoism is not to arouse contention in your fellow humans. This is not to suggest giving way and getting trampled on in the jungle of postmodern life. Indeed, t'ai chi and its older Taoist sister arts, hsing i and pa kua, are the three most respected boxing (and self-defence) systems in the Orient. The ideal to aspire to is the round-based wobbly doll, which, no matter how how hard you push it, always circles and returns upright without ever losing its equilibrium or dignity.

This implies always following the path of least resistance while remaining centred and collected internally. Done with a particular intention in mind, you flow like water, easily, effortlessly and, when necessary, powerfully from your centre towards your goal, never expending wasteful energy in worry or giving way to frustration, self-pity or panic.

This requires a trusting willingness to surrender to the flow, letting go of the fruits of your labours, deriving all your satisfaction from the action of doing itself, rather than the results. The Taoists call this phenomenon of effortless achieving wu wei .

To become adept at practising wu wei you first have to teach yourself to relax. First, tense the muscles of your scalp for a brief instant, gently without straining, then release. Repeat likewise through your neck and shoulder girdle and so on, progressively downwards through your body in lateral 'chunks', until you've tensed and released more or less every muscle group. Finally, remembering to breathe in and out smoothly throughout and to maintain effortlessness, tense your entire muscular network at once from head to toe and release. Now spend a 'quality' instant luxuriating in this brief interlude of inner peace and basking in awareness of your intrinsic virtue. Virtuousness, the quality Taoists call te , also means authenticity, or being in the flow of what actually is.

This means being willing to accept the conditions of your life as they present themselves and to let go of trying to change them with your metaphorical remote control. But even following these strictures diligently will prove to be a dry affair without the wilful exercise of compassion - your inbuilt faculty for feeling into the pain and suffering of self and others, knowing you can't help everyone, yet helping rather than hindering whoever you can. In this way we will feel a little comfort every now and then as we wander along this often ferocious but quite magnificent boulevard of broken dreams.

Your questions

Dear Barefoot, I have vertigo and been prescribed Betahistine. I would prefer to use an alternative medication from my health store, but my friend says I shouldn't use this as it would not have been scientifically tested. Is this true? I'm also taking Phytodolor for stabbing pains in my head. Please help.
Concerned, County Down

Forgive me if I sidestep your question to suggest that you may possibly be barking up the wrong tree by relying on 'taking things', whether allopathic or otherwise. Vertigo, in oriental body mechanics, arises from deficient liver energy causing weakness in the gall bladder meridian. When working normally, this meridian is responsible for conducting enough inner strength to the brain to stop dizziness. Deficient liver energy can also cause stabbing pains in the head. Both conditions can be successfully treated with acupressure, thus precluding your need for concern as to the efficacy of medicines.

Dear Barefoot Doc, My daughter injured her ankle while doing Highland dancing. The ligament has come away from the bone and she has been told the only way to mend it is by surgery. We are concerned about this operation. Do you think it could be successful in getting her ankle back to normal? We were hoping to mend it without an operation, but have been told this is not possible. Please help us.
B Mathers, Ilford, Essex

From my experience with these things, though obviously everything depends on the individual in question, a good hands-on healer, capable of generating the 'heat', or a well-trained cranio-sacral therapist or cranial osteopath, can often work wonders with so-called unmendable conditions, so it would be well worth hunting one down for a few seesions before considering the surgery. On the other hand, the ankle seems to heal up well enough after surgery and can be helped along by gentle connective-tissue massage as soon as the scars have healed.

Predating Buddhism and Confucianism, Taoism evolved in the ancient Orient as a philosophy, code and way of life at least 5,000 years ago (some believe 12,000). It was said to have been passed down by the so-called 'sons of reflected light'. fields.headline: A taste of France
fields.standfirst: Four French fancies
fields.trailText: Four French fancies.
fields.body:
Hibiscus 17 Corve Street, Ludlow, Shropshire (01584 872 325). Ten months ago, the richly accented Claude Bosi left the nearby Overton Grange to take over Oaks as chef-proprietor - renaming it after his favourite flower. The décor is plain enough, but Bosi's cooking is restlessly inventive. Daily-changing menus have modern twists, such as pan-fried foie gras with liquorice. Seven-course dinners are not uncommon, but four are enough for most people, especially with the many little French extras - such as sorbet flavoured with hibiscus.

Fleur de Sel Manleys Hill, Storrington, West Sussex (01903 742 331). As the many enthusiastic supporters of Bernadette and Michel Perraud's restaurant know, Fleur de Sel is a rarefied French table salt, harvested on the island of Noirmoutier. M Perraud grew up there, where his father was chef. Now his own culinary genius has brought a Michelin star to Manleys Hill. Yet, despite a wide appreciation of classical French cuisine locally, there is just one dish the Perrauds have never been able to take off the menu: slow-roasted Gressingham duck basted with honey and fresh ginger.

Le Cassoulet 5 Romilly Crescent, Canton, Cardiff (02920 221 905). This family-owned restaurant is practically the only outpost of Gallic cuisine worth mentioning in Wales. In the 13 years it has been trading, the cooking has evolved from bistro-style to modern provincial. The eponymous cassoulet from Toulouse has been much praised, but there is more delicate fare, too, such as yellow-pepper soup, and vanilla and aubergine gteau with goat's cheese. It has a great value lunch (three courses for £13.50); in the evenings, classical music and a more reverential atmosphere accompanies dining à la carte.

Monsieur Max 133 High Street, Hampton Hill (020 8979 5546). If The Square can be voted Best French Restaurant in the London Restaurant Awards despite having an English chef, then Monsieur Max can and does cultivate the same French charm in the burbs under an English chef (Alex Bentley) and owner (Max Renzland.) Bentley says he knows how to shout in French, anyway - essential with 12 sous-chefs all from across the Channel. Regulars love the food, the Art Deco, Parisian décor and the gentle irony of greeting Essex-born Renzland as 'Monsieur Max'. *

fields.headline: Party time
fields.standfirst: How to be healthy and still keep kids' food fun
fields.trailText: How to be healthy and still keep kids' food fun.
fields.body:
Although not designed specifically for parties, the Blue Parrot Café range from Sainsbury's might be just the thing. It was developed in an effort to bridge the gap between pester power and parent preference. If you could make fresh fruit more fun, and reduce the salt and saturated fats in kids' favourite foods, then theory says that everybody should be happy. The 250 products in the range, from macaroni cheese to Jaffa squares, are aimed at five-to-11-year-olds, and restrict the use of colours and preservatives, as well as eschewing flavour enhancers: the Hyperactive Children's Support Group seems happy with the results, although cured meat and sausages contain additives that Sainsbury's considers 'essential to food safety' (how did previous generations ever survive without these?). Easy-to-peel satsumas, small apples and kiwi fruit with a special scoop all aim to make fresh fruit more attractive, and if the assurances are accepted, then parents should be able to watch their kids eat jumbo crunchy cod fish fingers, chicken dippers, cheeseburger snacks and strawberry fizz wafers with equanimity.

There is more to a party than just eating, at least when you are that age. There are hats, balloons, games, dressing up, little presents, badges and so on. To leave yourself free to concentrate on the food, and on the party-goers themselves, it is worth seeking help with all the extras. Party Pieces (Freepost RG910, Childs Court Farm, Ashampstead Common, Berkshire, 01635 201 844) operates a mail-order service supplying all the above plus invitations, disposable plates and cups, outfits for fairies, princesses, pirates, cowboys and knights in armour, and colourful themed packs from Bob the Builder to Barbie. Items can be ordered individually (a cup with a lid and straw, 20p; a glow-in-the-dark skeleton, 70p), but a full package of accessories (including anything from a pink Cadillac to a jungle jeep in which to present your sandwiches, chips, burgers and fruit) for an average-sized party should work out at around £25.

If you want to do kiddy things with kids, consider spending a 'Funday Sunday' at Smollensky's (105 The Strand, London WC2, 020 7497 2101; and 255 Finchley Road, London NW3, 020 7431 5007) between 12 noon and 4pm. There is a clown and a magician - as well as the waiter and chef - plus activity sheets, 3-D 'wikki stix' and screenings of various children's films. Kids can eat anything from Caesar salad, via penne with tomato sauce, to chocolate mousse or banana split.

For a more serious approach to eating out, consider the proposition that children are small adults, and that if they are treated as grown-ups they will behave in an appropriately sophisticated way. To test the theory, put yourself in the hands of child-friendly restauranteurs such as Giorgio Locatelli at Zafferano (15 Lowndes Street, London SW1, 020 7235 5800), Bill and Sukie Barber at Old Pines (Spean Bridge, Fort William, 01397 712 324), Michael and Lucy Hjort at Melton's (7 Scarcroft Road, York, 01904 634 341) or Raymond Blanc at Le Manoir aux Quat' Saisons (Great Milton, Oxon; 01844 278 881).

 Jim Ainsworth is editor of The Good Food Guide.

fields.headline: Festival of Britain: Jean Symons
fields.standfirst: Jean Symons worked for a year as an architecture student on the Royal Festival Hall building site and has recently published her memoirs, Concert Hall Notebook (A Record of Fifteen Months in the Site) from that time
fields.trailText: I was due to qualify at the end of 1950 when I realised that I'd seen lots of buildings being bombed but none being built, so I got work on the Royal Festival Hall site. They had just laid the foundation stone the week before I arrived and by the time I left it was nearly finished. I was initially just interested in learning about building, but I became more fond of it and began to realise its importance. I used to love wandering around the site. My best friend there was Hugh Casson, and I had a whole range of responsibilities: I acted as runner between the site and County Hall; I did a lot of chivying for the designers and other strange things like looking after the tree growing near the entrance. The builders used to throw all sorts of rubbish on it and I had to clear it all away.
fields.body:
I was due to qualify at the end of 1950 when I realised that I'd seen lots of buildings being bombed but none being built, so I got work on the Royal Festival Hall site. They had just laid the foundation stone the week before I arrived and by the time I left it was nearly finished. I was initially just interested in learning about building, but I became more fond of it and began to realise its importance. I used to love wandering around the site. My best friend there was Hugh Casson, and I had a whole range of responsibilities: I acted as runner between the site and County Hall; I did a lot of chivying for the designers and other strange things like looking after the tree growing near the entrance. The builders used to throw all sorts of rubbish on it and I had to clear it all away.

I was the only woman working on the site, but I have no memory of feeling I was pioneering in any way. I think there was slight resentment among some of the men. Some of my male friends used to say, 'You should have heard what they called you', but they were too embarrassed to tell me. It was my job to write a weekly progress report and one of my methods of finding a new gang on the site was by following the wolf whistles. When I heard them, I knew the new gang had arrived and went to find out what they were doing because it was a good way of updating my report.

Otherwise, there was a marvellous atmosphere and it was very exciting. We had access to all these materials that had been so scarce for ages, like glass and lightweight concrete, and we were lucky because the Festival Hall was to be permanent. I remember sitting on the roof of the hall and imagining a conversation between St Paul's and Big Ben about this interloper, where they were saying, 'It may be the biggest dome in the world, but it's only temporary.' And, of course, the government changed and they whipped it away so fast. The Skylon was marvellous and they just dumped all these things in the Thames.

When I saw what was proposed for the Millennium Dome, I thought, 'Oh my God, they don't understand what they're trying to do, they have no vision'. The Dome was all to do with fashion and when you compare it to the dome of 1951, you can see it's totally derivative. It didn't have any of our feeling of looking to the future.

fields.headline: Festival of Britain: Michael Frayn
fields.standfirst: As a suburban schoolboy, novelist and playwright Michael Frayn remembers the Festival of Britain as being the post-war party the country deserved but had never had. Here, he recalls travelling up to the capital to a 'wonderful paradise' where people danced in the rain
fields.trailText: In 1951, I was a sixth former in a suburban grammar school in Kingston upon Thames. There was all this excitement going on about the Festival of Britain, but it took a while before I finally condescended to see what the fuss was about. I took a very lordly view of life at the time, but I was absolutely bowled over. I only intended to look in for half an hour, but I stayed all day. It was absolutely ravishing.
fields.body:
In 1951, I was a sixth former in a suburban grammar school in Kingston upon Thames. There was all this excitement going on about the Festival of Britain, but it took a while before I finally condescended to see what the fuss was about. I took a very lordly view of life at the time, but I was absolutely bowled over. I only intended to look in for half an hour, but I stayed all day. It was absolutely ravishing.

It's difficult to imagine now, but London was still very run-down from the war. It was very poor, very grey and dirty, with bomb sites everywhere - there hadn't been the time or the money to rebuild or repaint. But, suddenly, there was this wonderful paradise, full of bright colours and stylish, elegant forms. Afterwards, the designs came to seem rather silly - too spindly, too bright - but they were the first new fashions since the1930s, so they did seem very striking at the time.

The Lion and Unicorn pavilion really sticks in my mind. It was supposed to show the whimsical glories of the British character and sense of humour. There was a statue of the White Knight from Alice in Wonderland , and recordings of supposedly typical English conversations - all highly middle class, needless to say.

The Dome of Discovery was another exhibit that made an impression on me (which looked remarkably like a smaller version of the Dome of late and not so blessed memory), a wonderful water sculpture that represented the sequence of larger and smaller waves on a beach, and a great open space called the Fairway, which had lights set in the ground. These days everyone has lights set in the ground, but nobody, as far as I can remember, had seen them before. It all seemed terribly sophisticated to me. There was open-air dancing there every Saturday night. Often it rained, so people wore raincoats and put up umbrellas as they danced.

A lot of people protested that they didn't know what the Festival was for. But the reasons were a bit more self-evident than they were for the Millennium Dome. There was a sense that we'd won the war and hadn't got much out of it, because the austerity of life still continued, and that here at last was a reward - the celebratory party we still hadn't had. There was a certain logic about this that captured most people's fancy.

The problem with all exhibitions is what to put in them. It's always things you've seen a million times before in the permanent museums - dinosaur skeletons, or telescopes, or examples of rural crafts. It was true of the Festival of Britain, but it was the packaging of the thing that counted; the packaging and the air of surprise and excitement it gave to the content. The best thing of all about the South Bank was just being there.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: John Kamara met officer Mark Smout in 1998, 17 years into a life sentence for a murder he didn't commit. Having supported him through his appeals procedure, John and Mark are now becoming friends outside prison
fields.trailText: John Kamara met officer Mark Smout in 1998, 17 years into a life sentence for a murder he didn't commit. Having supported him through his appeals procedure, John and Mark are now becoming friends outside prison.
fields.body:
John Kamara: When I was given a life sentence it was as though time just stopped. It was December 1981 - I still had 19 years in prison ahead of me. I had been framed for the murder of a betting-shop manager in Liverpool. The parole reports said I'd shown no remorse, but I used to tell them I can't show any remorse because I wasn't at the betting shop.

I started writing letters the day after I was sentenced. I cut myself off from other people. I'd request solitary confinement, 23 hours a day in a cell on my own, so I could concentrate on fighting my case. After a while I told my family not to visit, because if you don't have visits you can transfer them for stamps and I needed them for letters. I'd write to MPs, EU ministers, the House of Lords, anyone who might help. I'd write 30 letters a day at times.

I was moved to Parkhurst prison on the Isle of Wight in January 1998.

That's where I met Mark Smout. I had encountered dozens of prison officers over the years, but he was the one who really seemed to take an interest. He made the time to listen. At that point my case was before the Criminal Cases Disputes Commission, the third time it had been looked at by the authorities.

I was more angry with the system than anything else. When I was depressed, Mr Smout used to come into my cell, talk to me, explain the letters I would be sent by the Commission. He'd post my letters, talk to my solicitor. Even on his days off, if he heard I had gone into segregation, he'd come in from home and talk to me and the governor and take me back on the wing.

I was mostly depressed because of the uncertainty hanging over me about the outcome. Mr Smout would try to keep my mind occupied. He got me on to computers, arts and crafts, and classes such as English. That really helped because I was always worried about how the case was going to go. I knew there were other members of staff saying to him: 'Don't get too involved.' But he was different. Others would just open and shut your door. He would go out of his way to help.

Mark Smout: John was quite difficult and stubborn. He couldn't see other people's points of view because of his frustration with the case, the appeals he'd fought and lost. Fourteen months went by and he felt that the commission, which investigates alleged miscarriages of justice, was taking too long. I had to remind him daily that Rome wasn't built in a day. I tried to keep him focused on the positive, while also preparing him in case he wasn't released. When he found that I was legally aid trained, he used me as a sounding board. I began to assist him, too, on other sides of his personality. He could be quite abrupt and I'd try and smooth out the rough edges.

Finally, in March 2000 his conviction was quashed after witness statements were uncovered which weren't produced at the trial. I can't describe the relief.

I have been a prison officer for 11 years. It is a tough job. You live on a knife edge and you have to have your wits about you. When the alarm rings your pulse quickens - you don't know what you'll find. But my biggest nightmare would have been picking up the pieces if John hadn't been released.

John has adjusted to life outside prison well. I was frightened for him in case he went out and blew all his money, like other wrongly convicted people have done. The compensation he'll get is likely to have to last him the rest of his life. We're realistic enough to say, at 45, we can't see John being a labourer on a building site. He hasn't worked for 19 years. The thing he can do well is talk and explain his point of view and he has said he wants to give talks for the Miscarriage of Justice Organisation.

I'm no longer his personal officer, but I still give him advice. He visits me, and he's been formal and nervous, lapsing into calling me Mr Smout. It will take time for him to see beyond the uniform. Above all, he needs to relax and enjoy life. I'm pleased for him that he's met Bettina and they have invited me to their wedding. She's very level-headed and it seems she's going to look after him now.

 Life After Life, a Rough Justice special, will be shown on BBC1 on 17 April.

fields.headline: Festival of Britain: Lucienne Day
fields.standfirst: As an ambitious young designer, Lucienne Day persuaded Heal's to print a fabric she'd created. The shop agreed, despite the fact it was sure none of it would sell. But when the fabric featured in the Festival's Homes pavilion it became an instant hit.
fields.trailText: I wanted to design some wallpapers, but I didn't want to do anything speculatively. I rang Hugh Casson, the director of architecture for the Festival. It was very forward of me, but being a young designer I didn't think there was anything unusual about it. I asked him if he thought some of my designs could go into the Festival and did he have any suggestions for getting them produced. He gave me some advice, and in the end I designed three and they all went into the Festival.
fields.body:
I wanted to design some wallpapers, but I didn't want to do anything speculatively. I rang Hugh Casson, the director of architecture for the Festival. It was very forward of me, but being a young designer I didn't think there was anything unusual about it. I asked him if he thought some of my designs could go into the Festival and did he have any suggestions for getting them produced. He gave me some advice, and in the end I designed three and they all went into the Festival.

Robin was designing the interior part of the Homes and Gardens pavilion and wanted a textile that would reflect the low cost of that section. At the time, there were some very beautiful fabrics on the market, but they were mainly commissioned from painters and were very expensive. So Robin said to me, 'Why don't you design one?', but I didn't have a client and someone had to fund the production. I had already designed a couple of things for Heal's, so I took the design for Calyx along to them. Tom Worthington said he would produce it for me but would only pay me half the usual fee of 20 guineas, because he was certain they wouldn't sell a yard of it.

Robin used it in his section and it was so popular that Heal's entered it for an award in New York that year. Calyx won, so the Festival of Britain was the beginning of my career. Suddenly one could produce designs and firms would be able to produce them because their looms would no longer be dedicated to making blackout material. They were set up again for producing things designers wanted to make. There was a feeling that the years of the war were behind us and that it would be a rosy future. The opening was an extraordinary moment. You felt that this great exhibition which had been in fact looked down on was really going to happen. The newspapers were rather down on it; it was mooted a couple of years previously, but they thought we didn't have anything to show and it was too soon after the war. But then it got underway and they thought it was wonderful. We had to be in our positions in the pavilions near the things we had designed in case the Queen or somebody came and talked to us. I don't remember that she did, but it was a wonderful event.

fields.headline: Festival of Britain: Dinah Casson
fields.standfirst: Sir Hugh Casson was the architectural director of the Festival of Britain. His daughter, Dinah Casson, was only four years old at the time, but she can clearly remember the sense of excitement - not to mention new clothes - that the Festival brought
fields.trailText: My strongest memory is of my father being out a lot. There was a sort of change of gear after the Festival, and the nature of his life altered. We moved to a bigger house and I suppose it made him famous. One of the family legends is that he came home one day and told my older sister that he was going to be a Sir and she said, 'Does that mean we can have a butler?'
fields.body:
My strongest memory is of my father being out a lot. There was a sort of change of gear after the Festival, and the nature of his life altered. We moved to a bigger house and I suppose it made him famous. One of the family legends is that he came home one day and told my older sister that he was going to be a Sir and she said, 'Does that mean we can have a butler?'

We had new outfits for the Festival, and I think that had serious significance. New clothes were an event then, unlike now, and I had a sense that they were marking something special. We had long white socks, black patent shoes, dark green pleated skirts, dark green box jackets and white blouses. When we got there, it was something on a scale I hadn't experienced before. I can still feel the atmosphere of expectation and optimism.

It was said at the time that the Festival was built by a bunch of herbivores who were rather gentle grass-eating chaps in suede shoes, like my father, who had a socialist agenda of some sort. The housing schemes built at the time were all part of that. Post-war architecture was full of optimism about building a new society and cities were going to be wonderful, with places for children to play, and the Festival seemed to embody that spirit.

If you were being mean, you would say that my father was editorially too pluralist, that he didn't have a strong enough vision, but he wasn't part of that serious, dogged group of architects. He was much more in favour of encouraging people to express their own voice and took enormous enjoyment from watching that happen.

The people who should get credit are the ones who thought of him to do the job because it was quite a risky appointment. He hadn't done very much but he showed the potential to pull this thing together; to start with London in a state of rubble and misery and to make something that's somehow a kind of celebration of survival.

There was a long time when no one was interested in the Festival. Many years went by when no one asked me about it. I think it was regarded as naive and twee. People thought that it was an expression of a side of England that we didn't want to know about. But there's been a reappraisal and that's the natural evolution of fashion.

 Dinah Casson is in partnership at design company Casson Mann and is currently involved in a five-year project to redesign the British galleries in the Victoria & Albert Museum.

fields.headline: Festival of Britain: Robin Day
fields.standfirst: Despite never having designed any production furniture before, Robin Day's first commission was for 3,000 seats for the Royal Festival Hall. It was a turning point in his career and he went on to become one of the country's foremost furniture designers
fields.trailText: It was a fantastic commission for a young designer. I was really awed. I had never designed any production furniture before, and suddenly there was a huge contract for 3,000 tip-up auditorium seats and seating for the restaurant and foyer. I knew it was a big exhibition, but no one had any idea of its future importance. It was a very exciting time. There was a general feeling of enlightenment and opportunity to get some design work, but it was as much to do with a feeling of euphoria at the end of the war when we lived in some degree of danger. We lived in London during the bombing, so one saw a lot of destruction and death, and there was a lot of rebuilding to be done afterwards. But the Festival gave designers an opportunity to let their hair down.
fields.body:
It was a fantastic commission for a young designer. I was really awed. I had never designed any production furniture before, and suddenly there was a huge contract for 3,000 tip-up auditorium seats and seating for the restaurant and foyer. I knew it was a big exhibition, but no one had any idea of its future importance. It was a very exciting time. There was a general feeling of enlightenment and opportunity to get some design work, but it was as much to do with a feeling of euphoria at the end of the war when we lived in some degree of danger. We lived in London during the bombing, so one saw a lot of destruction and death, and there was a lot of rebuilding to be done afterwards. But the Festival gave designers an opportunity to let their hair down.

I had a great sense of hope that we would improve the quality of people's lives by designing a more colourful and uplifting world, something that was also a concern of town-planning and architecture at the time. I was fairly keen on designing furniture that was at a price acceptable to a lot of people and all the designers were influenced by the government's introduction of social security and a greater awareness of people's needs.

It was a shot in the arm for design generally and alerted high-street retailers and customers to the fact that there was something other than their usual dreary furniture. Although I do remember standing by my section of the Homes and Gardens pavilion as two women looked at the interior. One said to the other, 'Just look at those chairs. Can you imagine anyone ever being able to live with them in their home?' Now, of course, there's a resurgence of interest in the period generally. Habitat are producing designs of mine from the time.

Collaborating with the architects on the Festival Hall was super. They were working with great enthusiasm on one of the finest buildings in London. It was so totally different from the process behind the Millennium Dome. People like Hugh Casson who were making decisions about the Festival were themselves designers. The whole thing was in the hands of designers, not committees, from the beginning.

fields.headline: A pinch of salt
fields.trailText: Peter Silverton (Life, last week), must be quite young if he thinks that the presenting at table of salt in little bowls is an affectation going back a mere five years.
fields.body:
Peter Silverton (Life, last week), must be quite young if he thinks that the presenting at table of salt in little bowls is an affectation going back a mere five years. I well remember my grandparents' house, as a child in Manchester in the late Forties, where salt was always presented in a small, cut-glass bowl, the etiquette being using the tip of a clean knife to place a small heap of salt on the edge of your plate at the start of the meal, to be distributed over your food as needed.
Ron Graves
Prenton Wirral

fields.headline: Shallow satire
fields.trailText: To claim 'satire is serious comment masquerading as humour' (Letters, last week) hardly denies the charge that satire is distanced and shallow.
fields.body:
To claim 'satire is serious comment masquerading as humour' (Letters, last week) hardly denies the charge that satire is distanced and shallow. Rory Bremner said his programme was a good outlet for material Labour could not release. Now it is the 'true opposition'. I detect a sales pitch.
Michael Brooks
Tamworth
Staffs

fields.headline: Energy remedy
fields.trailText: How can anyone take the 'Barefoot Doctor' seriously when he recommends (Life, last week) rotation of the arm in an anti-clockwise direction to dispose of negative energy?
fields.body:
How can anyone take the 'Barefoot Doctor' seriously when he recommends (Life, last week) rotation of the arm in an anti-clockwise direction to dispose of negative energy? Anyone knows it is clockwise.
Gary Williams
London N17

fields.headline: Layers of faith
fields.trailText: I think Mary Riddell (Comment, 1 April) is harsh when she says no one wants to be part of a faith community. I believe it is like the layers of an onion.
fields.body:
I think Mary Riddell (Comment, 1 April) is harsh when she says no one wants to be part of a faith community. I believe it is like the layers of an onion. At the centre are the highly committed. Then the regular congregation, families who consider themselves part of the church, occasional visitors, people we meet in pubs and schools. Many will never attend church, but know they can talk to my husband, a clergyman, unconditionally, at any time.
Mary Bolster
Luton Beds

 The Reverend Norman Bird (Letters, last week) suggests his faith in God can be supported by rational argument and evidence. Will he call on Christians to refrain from indoctrinating children until their powers of reason are fully developed?
Stephen Park
Devon

fields.headline: Killing countries
fields.trailText: The most salient cases [of bloodshed] in the last three decades are certainly not Chile, Poland or Indonesia, as Ariel Dorfman suggests (Comment, last week). It is China, Afghanistan and Vietnam.
fields.body:
The most salient cases [of bloodshed] in the last three decades are certainly not Chile, Poland or Indonesia, as Ariel Dorfman suggests (Comment, last week). It is China, Afghanistan and Vietnam.

The 'cultural revolution' in China which went on there until 1976, led to arrest, barbaric torture and execution of the country's best intellectuals, academics and media people.

In 1979 the USSR invaded Afghanistan. The following war resulted in one million Afghan dead and five million refugees. The USSR lost about 20,000 soldiers.

In 1975, North Vietnamese troops, in contravention of the Paris Treaty, entered Saigon. Within weeks they killed at least 80,000 people: they were democrats, liberals, members of political parties and the parliament, Catholics, Buddhists, civil servants, journalists, friends of the British and other Western embassies.
Oleg Gordievsky
London WC2

fields.headline: Sophie's bad PR
fields.trailText: A minor member of the royal family putting her foot in it with some rather dim remarks (News, last week) is hardly new.
fields.body:
A minor member of the royal family putting her foot in it with some rather dim remarks (News, last week) is hardly new. What is novel this time is that her day job is a PR consultant to others. If this is how she looks after her own public relations, I wonder what horrible fates have befallen those who paid her for advice?
Mark Pack
London N19

fields.headline: Ostrich politics
fields.trailText: Congratulations on your foot and mouth articles, particularly to Barbara Ellen (Life, last week) and Nick Cohen (Comment, last week).
fields.body:
Congratulations on your foot and mouth articles, particularly to Barbara Ellen (Life, last week) and Nick Cohen (Comment, last week). I shall find it difficult to campaign for the elections given that the Government allowed the ostriches in Maff and the NFU to dictate a medieval policy in the twenty-first century.
Rosemary Bradley
Chepstow
Monmouthshire

Brussels
