fields.trailText: Noreena Hertz (Comment Extra, last week) counsels against idealising anti-corporate protest but her Manichaean perspective generates equally simplistic polarities of corporate power v democracy, protest v passivity.
fields.body:
Noreena Hertz (Comment Extra, last week) counsels against idealising anti-corporate protest but her Manichaean perspective generates equally simplistic polarities of corporate power v democracy, protest v passivity. And however eye-catching or laudable the individual protests of José Bové or Bolivian water consumers, they do not amount to 'a global uprising' even bracketed alongside the self-indulgent stunts of May Day anti-capitalist protesters let out of public school for the day.

Innovative efforts to develop a civil dimension to globalisation are less dramatic and media-driven but none the less important. In contrast to the sterility of sporadic protest and the conscience-salving tokenism of individual consumer boycotts, a serious engagement with corporate interests is a precondition of addressing such problems as child labour, sweatshop conditions and environmental degradation. The Global Alliance www.theglobalalliance.org, a consortium comprising global firms, the World Bank, NGOs and universities, gives a direct voice to workers in the global supply chains of such companies as Nike and The Gap. Through surveys and focus groups, and working in partnership with unions, managers and public agencies, the Alliance designs and delivers programmes - from training to health clinics - that meet workers' needs and aspirations expressed through plant-level surveys and focus groups.
Michael Allen
Cranfield School of Management
Beds

Noreena Hertz should be congratulated on her analysis of the corporate takeover. However, it was wrong to state that there is little for voters to do but stay away from the polls and protest. Of course Labour, the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats between them nowadays only offer three versions of the same neoliberalism - and are equally committed to facilitating the corporate takeover. But the Green Party is offering a strong challenge to the neoliberal 'consensus', with policies for both rejuvenating democracy and delivering fair and sustainable economics.

It's always ironic when a mainstream newspaper or TV channel takes this line that politics has ended because there are no choices any more. It's the media itself which has the power to report refreshing alternatives, but confines itself largely to publicising only three big parties squabbling over their respective versions of neoliberalism.

It's especially ironic that Channel 4 will launch its general election season with a film on this imaginary 'end of politics', when C4 is refusing to screen the England and Wales Green Party's general election broadcast.

Journalists can't even say the Green Party is marginal any more. Public opinion has come round to our way of thinking on issues ranging from roadbuilding to GM foods. And many millions agree with Green policies on asylum seekers, renationalising the railways and taking radical action to stop climate change.

We challenge The Observer and the rest of the media to rescue the public from the boredom of the neoliberal 'consensus' by fully reporting the alternatives on offer at the general election.
Spencer Fitz-Gibbon
Green Party of England & Wales

As a political scientist, I must say that Noreena Hertz offers little that is new. The role of corporate power has been documented by, among many others, the sociologist C. Wright Mills in the 1950s, in a book called The Power Elite, and by Charles Lindblom in the 1980s. Even as far back as the eighteenth century German philosopher Hegel was suggesting that only the state can provide the social unity which corporations cannot.
Dr Robert Garner
University of Leicester

Although I was pleased to see Noreena Hertz take on globalisation in her essay, I do believe she is not giving the United States enough credit.

In her essay Hertz implies that the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge has already been opened for oil exploration. This is not entirely correct. Although legislation has been introduced in the Senate, no official action has been taken thus far on this issue.

Many environmentalists, both in government and out, are working hard to making sure that this disastrous legislation never crosses President George W. Bush's desk. And these activists, according to polls, have nearly two out of three Americans behind them. Please let it be known that there is hope for us yet here in the States!
Jim Dallas
University of Texas, Austin
United States

fields.headline: Paying our way
fields.trailText: Your article 'BA ready to foot householders' bill for Heathrow runway' (1 April) is unfounded. The UK aviation industry can and does pay its own way in funding investment in infrastructure.
fields.body:
Your article 'BA ready to foot householders' bill for Heathrow runway' (1 April) is unfounded. The UK aviation industry can and does pay its own way in funding investment in infrastructure. For specific local impacts, the airport developer would normally pay such costs. To suggest it would be bankrolled by any one airline is wrong.
Paul Ellis
Manager, Airport Policy
British Airways
Harmondsworth
Middx

fields.headline: They're fair cops
fields.trailText: The City of London Police Commissioner and his Deputy were not 'carpeted by Jack Straw' (News, last week).
fields.body:
The City of London Police Commissioner and his Deputy were not 'carpeted by Jack Straw' (News, last week). Instead, the Home Secretary gave a statement to the House of Commons in which he placed on record his appreciation for the way in which the City police, supported by other police forces, had dealt with the violence in 1999.
Judith Mayhew
Chair, Policy and Resources Committee
Corporation of London
London EC2

webTitle: Bid to arrest crew as child slave ship heads for port

fields.headline: Bid to arrest crew as child slave ship heads for port
fields.trailText: The authorities in the West African state of Benin, working with Unesco officials, have laid plans to arrest the operators of a slave ship, carrying an estimated 250 children, that has been trying in vain to unload its human cargo in Gabon and Cameroon over the past fortnight.
fields.body:
The authorities in the West African state of Benin, working with Unesco officials, have laid plans to arrest the operators of a slave ship, carrying an estimated 250 children, that has been trying in vain to unload its human cargo in Gabon and Cameroon over the past fortnight.

Like everything in the horrible business of child slavery, the origins of the slave boat are shrouded in mystery. It is referred to in Benin as l'Etireno. But in Gabon, it is called l'Itinero. The French newspaper Libération says it is registered in Nigeria.

Did it first sail from Lome, Togo, before picking up additional cargo in Benin? Is the financier a Benin national, as alleged? No one will know for sure until the boat docks in Benin today - if it does.

What is certain is that the boat attempted to discharge the slaves in the Gabonese port of Owendo, near Libreville, to go to work on plantations or to take other menial jobs in Gabon. But it was refused permission by the port authorities after Interpol had alerted them.

It then sailed to Douala, in Cameroon, but was again rebuffed. It is now heading back to Benin but the two attempts to discharge its cargo suggest that there are excellent slave trade links in both countries into which the boat's passengers would have been easily disgorged.

Indeed, the boat's return to Cotonou is not certain, for the Benin authorities have threatened, publicly, to arrest the captain and his crew. Yet these are men who could be desperate enough to endanger the lives of their young charges. Children as young as four are reported to be among the slaves.

The nouveaux riches in West African societies employ - and abuse - servants in a way that recalls pre-Victorian England. But being a servant is nothing compared to the black market version.

Middle men (usually women) go into the interior of each country and try to woo the poorest of the parents of young children to allow them to take their kids into the towns to offer them 'employment'. In countries where £10 counts for a great deal of money, a down payment weakens the resistance of parents. Usually, the first payment is also the last.

They may never see 'contractor' or child again. The child may be 'given' (sold) to diplomats going to serve abroad or be taken to work on a cocoa or coffee plantation in the Ivory Coast or as a miner.

Yet many African countries have signed the conventions against child labour and slavery enacted by the UN and the Organisation of African Unity. These conventions are a dead letter, because the middle classes who should enforce them benefit from the evil practices the conventions seek to ban. The saga of l'Itinero - if it ceases to be an itinerant vessel - could thus blow open a festering social sore.

webTitle: Kremlin's men seize last free TV outpost

fields.headline: Kremlin's men seize last free TV outpost
fields.standfirst: Journalists resign and set up a rival newsroom after 3am raid on Moscow studios by private security guards
fields.trailText: Journalists resign and set up a rival newsroom after 3am raid on Moscow studios by private security guards.
fields.body:
Russia's state-controlled gas giant, Gazprom, finally seized control of the country's leading independent television network yesterday during a nocturnal raid on NTV's television studios - sacking all journalists who refused to sign allegiance to the new regime.

Dissident staff members fled to the headquarters of a smaller television station, also owned by the exiled media magnate who founded NTV, where they swiftly set up a newsroom and continued defiant broadcasts. Two rival versions of NTV news were aired on two different channels throughout the day, as both halves of the splintered editorial team struggled to continue their work.

A large team of private security guards, hired by Gazprom, swarmed into the Ostankino television complex at 3am, catching rebellious staff off guard at a time when the NTV studios were almost deserted. The team was under instruction to refuse entry to those journalists who had fought hardest against the takeover.

Shortly before dawn, the station's new editor-in-chief arrived with the American businessman Boris Jordan, who was named director of the station in a controversial boardroom coup 12 days ago. The timing of their arrival was carefully chosen; until their unannounced night-time appearance both men had been denied access to the television studios by staff members who refused to recognise their appointments.

The ousted station director, Yevgeny Kiselyov, was not there to fight for his job; he had left the country briefly for urgent meetings with the beleaguered founder of the station, Vladimir Gusinsky, at the villa in southern Spain where he is under house arrest fighting extradition proceedings on fraud charges, which he denies.

The moment when control effectively passed from the old guard to the new regime was witnessed on live television shortly after 8am when one of the protesting newscasters, Andrei Norkin, was cut off in mid-sentence as he tried to explain what was happening inside the studios. The screen cut to coloured intermission stripes.

Norkin later continued to broadcast his version of the news from the relatively primitive TNT television studios, under an NTV protest logo. Official NTV news dispatches were put together by the channel's new regime and focused primarily on uncontroversial subjects - devoting five minutes at the start of one bulletin to preparations in Russia for Easter.

The events marked an emotional climax to a fight for control over NTV that has lasted for a year, ever since the offices of the Media-Most company that created the station were raided by masked police and Gusinsky was imprisoned in a Moscow jail last spring.

During their extensive coverage of the crisis unfolding within their organisation, NTV journalists have insisted that they are the victims of Kremlin oppression, artfully wielded using the tool of Gazprom, the gas monopoly which is 38 per cent owned by the government. They have argued that their critical reporting of the problems besetting President Vladimir Putin's government - the prolonged war in Chechnya, the Kursk nuclear submarine catastrophe, the heating disasters which left hundreds of thousands of Russians battling the cold this winter - has prompted the government to act to stamp out their dissenting voice.

Opponents have pointed out the dispute between NTV and Gazprom is more complex than simply a fight for freedom of speech in the face of government repression, not least because Gazprom is owed $200m (£140m) in unpaid loans by NTV.

The true independence of Gusinsky's media holding has been called into question by those who remember how NTV abandoned its editorial objectivity in the run-up to the 1996 presidential election campaign, making a pact with powerful Russian business figures to ensure victory for Boris Yeltsin.

But liberal politicians, like the leader of the Yabloko party, Grigory Yavlinksy, who has been campaigning on behalf of NTV's former management, insist that the complexities of the situation deflect from the single crucial point at the heart of the crisis: that once NTV falls into state hands all Russia's national television channels will be loyal to the Kremlin.

'It looks like a clampdown on the journalists,' Yavlinksy said yesterday.

Jordan emerged, looking weary, from his newly occupied directors' offices in the early afternoon to declare that the channel would not become a Kremlin mouthpiece. 'Today is the start of a new era for NTV. I hope that it will be possible to build the first truly independent television station,' he said.

His pledge was undercut by another announcement that the influential current affairs programme, Itogi , which has been the vehicle for some of the fiercest attacks on the government, would no longer be broadcast - apparently because of the resignations of the reporters who created it.

There were contradictory reports about how many of the NTV staff had been sacked or had resigned from the channel. The former editor-in-chief claimed that 85 per cent of journalists had submitted their resignations early yesterday, but Jordan said the figure was closer to 20 per cent. More resignations were expected and it was not clear how the high standard of reporting would be maintained after so many of the station's senior staff had left. Staff from a popular Crimewatch-style programme were being given a crash course in news broadcasting in the NTV canteen.

Political reporter Alim Yusupov was one of the first to resign. 'I am convinced there is no future for NTV as I know it under the new management,' he said.

Despite accusations he is behind the Gazprom decision to call in its overdue debts, President Putin has tried to appear uninvolved in the protracted NTV crisis; he stated last week that he was committed to upholding press freedoms but said he saw NTV's problems as simply a dispute over property.

The President made an unexpected and unannounced visit to Chechnya yesterday, accompanied, somewhat unusually, by Media Minister Mikhail Lesin, who has played a crucial and highly controversial role in orchestrating the handover of NTV to Gazprom.

webTitle: Leader: Give us a break, we need more holidays

fields.headline: Give us a break
fields.standfirst: We need more Roman holidays
fields.trailText: We need more Roman holidays.
fields.body:
So what's it to be tomorrow? Queuing for the water chute at Alton Towers; a bit of wenching, quaffing and jousting at Myddleton Hall in Staffordshire; decorating the loft; painting eggs at Norton Priory in Cheshire or an afternoon in watching The Great Escape on telly?

The British, with their passion for arcane traditions and their penchant for creating new ones (the DIY calamity, the Bank Holiday TV film), are good at public holidays. The problem is, with just eight a year, we don't have enough. Now the Fabian Society is urging the Government to create a few more, better distributed throughout the year. But, true to their gradualist origins (they are named after Fabius, a Roman general who aimed to defeat Hannibal in small stages), the Fabians propose only four more.

We say, be bold! Match Italy, whose economy thrives on 16 official holidays (plus a few unofficial ones; when a saint's day falls on a Tuesday or Thursday, Monday or Friday often get thrown in to make a long weekend). In one fell swoop, Labour could boost national morale and the tourist industry. What an election promise!

webTitle: Leader: Arafat can stop the bloodshed

fields.headline: It's Arafat's call
fields.standfirst: PLO leader can stop the bloodshed
fields.trailText: PLO leader can stop the bloodshed.
fields.body:
A disaster is unfolding for the Palestinian people. Economic life is almost at a standstill, freedom of movement almost impossible. The Palestinian Authority of Yasser Arafat faces bankruptcy while Palestinian fatalities climb daily. Weeks into the al Aqsa intifada Mr Arafat's lieutenants were predicting the crisis would soon be over, ushering in the creation of a Palestinian state with its capital in Arab East Jerusalem and allowing the return of Palestinian refugees.

Instead, six months after the intifada started, the reverse has happened. In snubbing the efforts of President Clinton to mediate a final deal in his last days in office, Mr Arafat threw away a decade of gains for the Palestinian people under the Oslo peace process.

Meanwhile, the scale of the Palestinian state the new Israeli government says it can accept has shrunk from 97 per cent of the Occupied Territories that was on offer initially to an emasculated 42 per cent now. At the same time, the Palestinian cause in the wider world has been marginalised as never before. In the new White House of George Bush, Arafat is no longer welcome.

It has become commonplace to blame the suffering of the Palestinians on Israel alone. Certainly, their response to the intifada has been unnecessarily brutal. But it is time to recognise that Mr Arafat is ultimately responsible for its high-risk strategy; a strategy that is palpably failing and will lead to further disaster for his people. Mr Arafat should now take the biggest gamble of his long career - and regain the moral high ground - by calling an end to the violence on the Palestinian side.

webTitle: And all because the lady loves...

fields.headline: And all because the lady loves...
fields.trailText: A costly engagement ring hidden as a surprise in a chocolate Easter egg has proved the cause of intense pre-marital tension for a young Italian couple.
fields.body:
A costly engagement ring hidden as a surprise in a chocolate Easter egg has proved the cause of intense pre-marital tension for a young Italian couple.

The £1,300 ring has gone missing after the fiancée, a 26-year-old law graduate, decided to exchange the plain chocolate egg for a milk chocolate equivalent.

When he discovered what had happened, the prospective bridegroom, a 30-year-old plumber, rushed back to the shop where he had purchased the egg, only to find that it had already been resold.

The missing ring has put the relationship under considerable stress, with angry recriminations from the donor and floods of tears from the unlucky recipient.

'The episode has caused a lot of tension, even resulting in a very strong slap in the face for the fiancée,' Luca Maori, the Perugia lawyer who first publicised the case, said yesterday. 'It was she who contacted me originally, because she was considering taking legal action for the minor physical injuries she suffered.'

Maori yesterday made an appeal on state television to whoever found a gold ring with a heart-shaped diamond and three rubies in a plain chocolate Easter egg to return it to the shop. They can expect a handsome reward, he said. 'I have all the papers ready for the damages suit, but we will hold off for the moment. With all the publicity that the case has aroused, it is clear that the tensions have evaporated somewhat,' he said.

Maori said he was now more optimistic that the couple would settle their differences and agree a reconciliation than that they would recover the ring. 'For one thing, the fiancée has promised she will learn to appreciate plain chocolate,' he said.

So far the valuable surprise has caused far keener disappointment than the plastic trinkets usually found in chocolate eggs.

webTitle: Java zealots vow to fight for President

fields.headline: Java zealots vow to fight for President
fields.trailText: An army of Muslim political zealots, 40,000 strong, has pledged to defend to the death the embattled Indonesian President, Abdurrahman Wahid, as he desperately struggles to stave off impeachment.
fields.byline: John Aglionby in Surabaya, East Java
fields.body:
An army of Muslim political zealots, 40,000 strong, has pledged to defend to the death the embattled Indonesian President, Abdurrahman Wahid, as he desperately struggles to stave off impeachment.

The grassroots 'people power' organisation was formed earlier this month in Wahid's heartland of East Java. It threatens to descend on Jakarta and do whatever is necessary to prevent a change of power. Although the President has distanced himself from it, observers believe he may be relying on it as a weapon of last resort.

Recruits to the Defenders of Truth Forum (FPK) don't look like zealots. One who spoke to The Observer last week is Hajjah Nur Yaumin, who is a sophisticated businesswoman. But she insists: 'I was called by Allah to do this, and I cannot disobey my God.' One of more than 110 women in the organisation, she adds: 'If I have to fight I will. I've never used a gun before, but I'm ready to.'

Wahid, an almost blind Muslim cleric who became Indonesia's first democratically elected President in October 1999, is close to being ousted by an increasingly hostile parliament.

Unhappy with his response to a memorandum of censure over his suspected involvement in two financial scandals, legislators are gearing up to issue a second and final warning when they return from a recess at the end of this month.

If Wahid's response is again unsatisfactory, parliament can call a special session to impeach Wahid and demand his dismissal. This means that Wahid may have only two weeks left to broker a deal with his political foes: Vice-President Megawati Su-karnoputri, parliamentary Speaker Akbar Tandjung and supreme assembly Speaker Amien Rais.

Wahid's attitude to the FPK is ambiguous. 'It's a case of doublespeak,' said Dr Daniel Sparringa, a sociologist at Surabaya's Airlangga University. 'He cannot be seen to be encouraging them, but the reality is he has few other cards left to play.'

The FPK was formed by Wiro Sugiman, an air conditioning repairman in Surabaya, after being disappointed by what he called legislators' 'selfish egotism'. He insists the organisation is not about Wahid.

'We were not formed by Gus Dur,' he said, using the President's nickname. 'We were not formed by any political party. We are a people's organisation and our aim is to express the people's aspirations. We are ready to defend the truth, the rightful President, the constitution, the nation and the country until blood is spilt. The will of the people must take priority.'

This 'will' is being trained at several remote locations across East Java. Television footage shows men practising martial arts and building their 'inner strength'. This involves appearing impervious to being slashed with a knife or beaten with wooden staffs. 'You'll see the results in Jakarta,' said Sugiman. 'There'll be people who can walk on water, others will be able to grip barbed wire. Trust me.'

What worries most politicians in Jakarta about FPK is not its political aspirations but its religious foundations. Its base is the world's largest Islamic organisation, Nahdlatul Ulama (NU), which claims more than 40 million followers and is concentrated in East Java. It was founded by Wahid's grandfather and Wahid himself led it for 15 years.

'Wahid is revered like a sacred man here,' said Ishom Hadzik, a younger generation NU cleric in the President's hometown of Jombang, 50 miles west of Surabaya. He looks at Wahid more dispassionately than the predominantly less well educated members of FPK.

'The problem,' he said, 'is that people have not learnt how to separate Wahid the religious leader from Wahid the President.'

webTitle: ... and there's always the Libyan desert

fields.headline: ... and there's always the Libyan desert
fields.trailText: It may seem an unlikely destination for holidaymakers. But Libya is trying to extinguish the Western image of it as a pariah state and become an oasis for Britons seeking hooligan-free sunshine and culture without queues.
fields.body:
It may seem an unlikely destination for holidaymakers. But Libya is trying to extinguish the Western image of it as a pariah state and become an oasis for Britons seeking hooligan-free sunshine and culture without queues.

A plan to develop tourism in the North African state is being implemented by the country's Tourism Investment and Promotion Board. A source at the board said Libya was keen to welcome tourists from the UK. 'The British will love the historic archeological sites, the desert and the weather. We are developing parts of the country to create the infrastructure required for visitors.'

Libya even hired a British consultancy. Jim Fletcher, 47, who recently completed work on the project, said: 'Our 20-year forecast came up with a figure of just over one million visitors by 2020.'

Around 60,000 tourists a year now travel to Libya, but few make the journey from the UK, with the country still largely seen as a haven for terrorists and religious fundamentalists. Fletcher was a regular visitor when working on the project for London-based High-Point Rendell and considers such views to be outdated.

'Most of Libya's 60,000 tourists come from France, Italy and Germany,' said Fletcher.'

While resorts and luxury hotels are being built, Libya is aiming at select areas of the market and has no plans to take on the Costas of Spain or the Greek islands in a beach war. Fletcher said: 'Remember that alcohol isn't available and won't be in the conceivable future. That will put off a lot of people.'

Lovers of Classical ruins will find ancient temples and theatres dramatically sited beside the Mediterranean, and statues and mosaics as fine as any in Europe. All they lack are the crowds. Tripoli boasts a castle, a harbour, a maze of alleys and covered markets, and fine examples of Ottoman and Italian architecture. Close by are two Roman sites: Sabratha and Leptis Magna.

Libyans are hospitable to visitors and, unlike many North African destinations, the country's streets and souks are free of touts.

The 1,600-mile coastline remains largely unspoilt, and the route from Tripoli to the second city, Ben-ghazi, offers spectacular views.

British travellers to Libya need a visa and must be part of an organised group, although this latter requirement could be dropped soon.

A few tour operators and airlines such as British Airways jumped into the market soon after the relaxation of sanctions two years ago when Libya handed over two suspects in the Lockerbie bomb case.

The bid to prise pounds out of British pockets has come from Muammar Gadaffi, Libya's leader. 'Nothing happens in Libya without the man at the top's say so,' said Fletcher. 'It was the Libyan government that funded our study, so clearly Gadaffi wants tourists from our country to visit his.'

Libya is prepared to spend several million pounds on creating the infrastructure needed: new roads, possibly a new airport, desert lodges and beach resorts.

fields.headline: Boiling point in the ghetto
fields.standfirst: Police have the streets of the Ohio city under control - for now. But the burial of one more black victim could spark a chain reaction, reports  Ed Vulliamy
fields.trailText: Police have the streets of the Ohio city under control - for now. But the burial of one more black victim could spark a chain reaction, reports  Ed Vulliamy.
fields.body:
The ghetto has not looked like this, they say, since the days after Martin Luther King was assassinated. Cincinnati's dark streets are ghostly and deserted; the only sounds are the wails of sirens in the mid-distance and the drone of helicopters casting their searchlight beams across the spectral slumscape.

The only movement is that of the State Troopers' grey patrol cars and white armoured vans full of helmeted riot police, more Blade Runner than a busy metropolis on the shores of the wide Ohio. The streets had emptied on Friday night as an 8pm curfew fell across the last golden sunlight.

Downtown, only the birds chirped and signs flapped as the last office workers hurried for their cars loaded up with take-out food. Only a few stragglers outside O'Byron's pub refused to believe this was happening on Good Friday.

In the ghetto, a church rally by the leader of the National Association for the Advancement of Coloured People had ended abruptly to the anger of his audience. 'It wasn't enough time,' said one Dead Hawkins, 'We're going away mad.'

The NAACP's president Kweisi Mfume had clasped hands with the still dazed mother of the boy whose shooting by a police officer had provoked the scenes of only 18 hours earlier - another, more tumultuous, first for Cincinnati since 1967: fury and shooting, burning and looting which - after two nights of the usual tragic wreckage within the ghetto confines - had broken onto the white man's turf.

This time, the cops were charging for real and the crowd was shooting back - an officer was slightly wounded. This time, Swat teams were throwing up barricades and their snipers leaping over the rooftops. Every American riot tells a story, and on the surface it is the same: an incident undams years of tension between angry and poor black youths and a white police force stained by racism - whether in Cincinnati or its big cousins, Detroit and Chicago in the North, Los Angeles or Miami in the South.

Like its northern counterparts, Cincinnati's slums were once middle-class neighbourhoods into which white Appalachian hillbillies moved first, then sharecroppers from the plantations in the great migration north. Time was when blacks taking the trains south from Cincinnati's great Union Terminal would have to occupy segregated compartments, while those arriving would be travelling with the whites.

Cincinnati's ghetto is unique - indeed 'ghetto' is hardly the right term in an urban area that is 43 per cent black. It is called Over-the-Rhine, a name explicable by the moulded lettering on the front of the church that towers over the place: 'Deutsche Protestantische St. Johannes-kirche. 1865' - now the Apostolic Bethlehem church.

The community was founded by German immigrants and is one of America's nineteenth-century urban wonders: buildings of a design made more famous in San Francisco, only of brick, adorned by iron thickets of fire escape ladders. The world has seen these streets in the movie Traffic, with all its familiar ghetto hallmarks - ubiquitous porn shops and a rough-and-tumble summer street life.

It was here that Timothy Thomas was raised and drove his 1978 Chevy around. Eleven times since March 2000 he had been stopped by police and cited for 12 offences, mostly driving without carrying his licence or not wearing a seatbelt. The core of the row that rages not only here but across the US is that Timothy was victim of what is politely called 'racial profiling' - that is, he was picked on because he was black.

Twice he ran from the police as they chased him and twice slipped the net, but the third time he died from a bullet fired by officer Steve Roach. He fell lifeless outside an abandoned building in a little alleyway, number 1313 Republic Street, where the tributes are modest - bottles of wine or beer on his flagstone deathbed, and a placard: 'No seatbelt equals death.'

'It just goes on and on,' said Melvin Wills, hanging an arm out of his car at the corner of Republic and 13th. And so it does in Cincinnati, for it was not only Timothy's death that caused the rioting.

Eighteen black men and boys have been shot dead by the police in Over-the-Rhine since the start of last year - a concentration of police violence that outstrips any other US city. The Rev Fred Shuttlesworth, who marched with Martin Luther King from Birmingham to Selma in the great hike of the 1960s, remains a minister in Cincinnati, of the Greater New Light Baptist church.

He is now 79 but has been on the streets all week, sleepless. 'Race relations haven't changed very much since those days,' he ponders now. 'If anything, things are worse if everybody thinks they have changed yet, in reality, those changes are not every blood-vein deep - then the system never really changed.'

His home town of Cincinnati, he says, 'has had time to change, but the whites have blocked progress and the police is more a prosecutor than a protector. The anger is justified but the violence is not. However, people will rebel if they don't see themselves progress. The riots happening now are the result of Cincinnati not responding to change.'

Although the mayor Charlie Luken is no Rudy Giuliani and admits to 'a serious race relations problem', there are few northern cities in which blacks are so proportionately unrepresented in the police or government. While unemployment is minimal among whites at 2 per cent, it tops 20 per cent in Over-the-Rhine; in schools there is almost total segregation. Current census figures show Greater Cincinnati to be the eighth most segregated metropolitan region in the U.S. The city lost nearly 45,000 whites, leaving an urban area that is 43 per cent black with middle-class blacks also fleeing the slums around the city centre.

Another veteran who saw this coming is Cecil Thomas, who left the police to head the city's Human Relations Commission. He warned that Cincinnati was 'one questionable shooting away from riots,' and on Wednesday was one of a group of 20 who formed a human wedge between an advancing crowd of youths and columns of riot police just as the confrontation was about to blow, physically separating each side. Then the police advanced and a man called Larry Brenton shouted: 'We need to take this fucking city down! I'm tired of getting up every morning and finding out someone else I knew has been murdered by the police.'

Uprisings invariably throw up leaders and in this case the figure is the Rev Damon Lynch. Whatever President George Bush intended by placing his trust in 'faith-based' leaders, it is unlikely he had people like Lynch in mind. Pastor of the New Prospect Baptist Church in the heart of the ghetto, he wears a gold earring, was with Cecil Thomas in that human wedge, then stayed on the front lines of the demonstrations as police horses and then plastic bullets were unleashed across the boulevards around the ghetto.

The following day, outside his church office window, children played on swings in a scrappy playground as he prepared to host yesterday's funeral of Timothy Thomas. All afternoon his cell phone rang with calls about arrangements for the presence of the Governor and the Mayor - unsettled enough to make sure that they spent their Easter Saturday attending the last rites of a serial traffic offender. So too would a crowd of thousands on the steets outside the church - and the hundreds of riot police, unsure whether the precarious peace that had almost held since Wednesday's violence could last the weekend after the funeral.

'Is it consistent?' asks Pastor Lynch. 'We've had 15 young blacks killed by the police since 1995 and seven since November - I call that consistent. In every case except one the officer was white.' Cincinnati, he says, now incorporates, 'the worst of the North and the worst of the South. It's a southern town trying to be a northern metropolis and it's not. Racism here is worse than in the new South and the police come from within that culture from the west side of town where the blacks just don't go - they'd be lynched, it's not our town. There, they learn that African Americans are the scum of the earth - then they are sent here.'

What motivates Pastor Lynch - politics, faith, or what? 'It ain't politics,' he almost snaps. 'It's faith. It's my calling. It's what God asks of me.' He has a portrait of Martin Luther King on the wall and a Koran on the floor. 'This is Easter time,' he says, 'Today is Good Friday and we mourn. Tomorrow we bury the kid, and on Sunday we look for the resurrection of our community. Three days of Easter.'

A man called Chuck Walters walks in and says: 'Keep praying, brother, we're with you.' Later, outside with friends, he asks to see the pastor's list of 18 men killed since February 1995. He points at the name of Alfred Pope, shot dead in March last year. 'That's my stepson, found with 10 gunshot wounds in his back, handcuffed from behind in the surrender position. Can't count the time we went to City Hall looking for answers but we never got one. We're tired here, we're all tired. The cops' families come up here from Kentucky and the hills where all they can talk about is niggers. We're tired of being treated this a-way.'

On Good Friday evening, women and the elderly chatter on steps beneath the fire escapes while the men collect in groups to banter. The riot police vans prowl the little streets, and choppers fly low above the rooftops. There's a bar called the Race Cafi (on Race Street) where drinkers are squeezing in a last Schlitz before curfew. 'Maybe it'll blow,' ponders Cyril Harris, 85, who has seen it all, from Alabama to the riots last time around. 'Maybe it won't.'

Cincinnati, he says, now incorporates, 'the worst of the North and the worst of the South. It's a southern town trying to be a northern metropolis and it's not. Racism here is worse than in the new South and the police come from within that culture from the west side of town where the blacks just don't go - they'd be lynched, it's not our town. There, they learn that African Americans are the scum of the earth - then they are sent here.' What motivates Pastor Lynch - politics, faith, or what? 'It ain't politics,' he almost snaps. 'It's faith. It's my calling. It's what God asks of me.' He has a portrait of Martin Luther King on the wall and a Koran on the floor. 'This is Easter time,' he says, 'Today is Good Friday and we mourn. Tomorrow we bury the kid, and on Sunday we look for the resurrection of our community. Three days of Easter.' A man called Chuck Walters walks in and says: 'Keep praying, brother, we're with you.' Later, outside with friends, he asks to see the pastor's list of 18 men killed since February 1995. He points at the name of Alfred Pope, shot dead in March last year. 'That's my stepson, found with 10 gunshot wounds in his back, handcuffed from behind in the surrender position. Can't count the time we went to City Hall looking for answers but we never got one. We're tired here, we're all tired. The cops' families come up here from Kentucky and the hills where all they can talk about is niggers. We're tired of being treated this a-way.' On Good Friday evening, women and the elderly chatter on steps beneath the fire escapes while the men collect in groups to banter. The riot police vans prowl the little streets, and choppers fly low above the rooftops. There's a bar called the Race Cafi (on Race Street) where drinkers are squeezing in a last Schlitz before curfew. 'Maybe it'll blow,' ponders Cyril Harris, 85, who has seen it all, from Alabama to the riots last time around. 'Maybe it won't.'

webTitle: Rebel flag sparks a new civil war

fields.headline: Rebel flag sparks a new civil war
fields.standfirst: A bitter row in Mississippi over whether to bring down the Confederate banner has revived old hatreds, reports  Ed Vulliamy
fields.trailText: A bitter row in Mississippi over whether to bring down the Confederate banner has revived old hatreds, reports  Ed Vulliamy.
fields.body:
Thirty-five years ago the lanes of Neshoba County were lined with burning crosses. Now they are lined with houses built by people who were children when three civil rights workers were murdered here by the Ku Klux Klan. No one was ever brought to justice. Now those state institutions which once protected the murderers have themselves reopened the Neshoba case and they are hot on the killers' trail.

This is the new Mississippi. But old habits die hard. On Tuesday, Mississippi will go to the polls to vote on whether to keep the Confederate battle emblem as part of its state flag or scrap it for a new design.

If it retains the flag, Mississippi will stand alone in doing so. Georgia abandoned it this year, while South Carolina and Alabama withdrew the flag from aloft their state capitols despite protests.

Mississippi's vote is not just about a flag. It is about the meaning of the South and the interpretation of the Civil War itself. A view endorsed by senior figures in the Bush administration is that it was the autonomy of states, not slavery, which was the underlying cause of the war.

Supporters of the old flag insist they defend not racism but southern heritage and the memory of soldiers who fell in the Confederate cause. Their opponents counter that the Confederate flag is a symbol of slavery and segregation.

Nowhere is the argument more keenly felt than Mississippi. Segregation has nominally ceased, but in the economy it vividly remains and in schools the racial divide is deepening. Polls suggest Mississippi will vote to keep its symbol flying over every public building and auto dealership.

Mississippi's chamber of commerce is the most enthusiastic backer of a new flag, citing ridicule and the kind of economic boycott that was threatened against South Carolina. And no figure symbolises the new flag more than the remarkable Attorney-General, Mike Moore, who has cut to the core of the state's racist past by prising open all the major unsolved Klan murders of the 1960s.

'The Klan,' he says, 'infiltrated the government and infiltrated the law enforcement community. If anybody said anything they were afraid maybe they would get thrown in jail or maybe their heads would get busted open. Maybe their kids would be hurt.'

Most notorious was the murder of Michael Schwemer, James Chavey and Andrew Goodman, killed by the Klan when they came to register votes at Mount Zion church in Neshoba county.

The language of Mount Zion's present congregation is passionate. 'Easter represents the resurrection of Christ,' says the Rev Illiad Kelly. 'If we can revive our state through the creation of a new flag, that will bring about a rebirth in the heart of all mankind.'

Near Mount Zion, Clifton Green was last week laying fibre optic cable for telephones. 'That's what this flag business is about: is Mississippi still a Klan state or not?' he said.

The lobby in favour of keeping the flag could not disagree more. Prime movers to retain the flag are the Sons of Confederate Veterans and their lawyer ally, Greg Stewart, who insist the issue is about 'heritage and respect for the Confederate soldier'.

Stewart says: 'Black Mississippians are on the receiving end of racism every day. They know the solution is not to snatch down the flag.' He points out that in polls one in three blacks favours keeping the old flag along with 73 per cent of whites. Jim Giles of Southern Heritage adds: 'We will win anyway because people don't like the politically correct minority imposing its will.'

What is undeniable is the way in which the Confederate flag has increasingly become the emblem of race hate. A Saturday night prayer vigil around the state capital has been organised by the Conservative Citizens' Council as part its campaign to keep the flag. It calls it 'an insignia of racial consciousness and solidarity among white southerners'. And the council? It was formed in 1954, an outgrowth of the White Citizens' Council, as a political wing of the KKK.

The CCC argument touches on a wider debate in American society. For decades, southern historians have argued that the South was fighting for states' rights and an agrarian, decentralised society not in favour of slavery. But suddenly comes a spate of books from historians reconfirming slavery as the core of America's war against itself.

In the heart of old slave country, some are not embarrassed about being identified with racism. In a Neshoba county casino, Jennifer Drum mond and Helen Mitchell were taking a break from the slot machines. 'The white people in this state pay taxes for the schools they go to and their welfare. I'm not against them, but where I'm from you got home-boy niggers who just spend their lives in the field that never knew how to do a day's work,' said Mitchell. 'Nothing wrong with our flag we need outta-state Yankees to tell us about.'

webTitle: Jospin runs into trouble with women trouble

fields.headline: Jospin runs into trouble with women trouble
fields.standfirst: Female campaigners turn up the heat:  Even his own mother is attacking the French PM
fields.trailText: Female campaigners turn up the heat:  Even his own mother is attacking the French PM.
fields.body:
In a list of woes that pushed him to crisis point last week, Lionel Jospin's trouble with women could be the deciding factor on whether he stands for the presidency next spring. At the top of the list is his own mother's support for the most popular strike of the year - 15,000 pink-overalled midwives.

Mireille Jospin, 90, and still a midwife, even joined a street demonstration during three weeks of protest that have made her son, the Prime Minister, 63, seem even more austere than his reputation has him. Her remark: 'He does what he likes and so do I', has become a slogan for a female opposition.

In the past month, Jospin can rarely have opened a newspaper without wondering why his campaign to give women a more active role in political life has added nothing to his popularity. The Socialist Party's parity legislation, forcing parties to sponsor sexually balanced lists of candidates, backfired in last month's municipal elections which returned more right-wing than left-wing female councillors.

The success of Martine Aubry, the Labour Minister who left the Cabinet to become mayor of Lille, robbed Jospin of his most creditable political ally while the defeat in Avignon of her ministerial replacement, Elisabeth Guigou, has severely undermined her resilience and authority, encouraging the worst wave of worker defiance since the unexpected left-wing landslide in 1997.

Jospin has been more open to feminist pressure than any Prime Minister in the 43 years of the Fifth Republic, having responded to a lobby led by his philosopher wife, Sylviane Agacinski, on the parity issue. But this has won him little sympathy inside the Cabinet where his most sarcastic critic, Environment Minister Dominique Voynet, told him last week to take a holiday because of his increasing irascibility.

His impulsiveness surfaced dramatically when he bawled out two women journalists during an official flight from Brazil because they reported his admission at a students' meeting that the Right had won the municipal elections. He apologised for his lack of politeness, but must have felt haunted by feminine power when he returned to see the front pages packed with photographs of Marks & Spencer protesters with hardly a male face in sight.

The acknowledged leader, Véronique Limousin, whose face is now instantly recognisable, recalled that she had voted left in 1997 but now felt that Jospin's administration had let the workers down.

A few days after the M&S announcement, while on a visit to flooded Abbeville in the Somme, Jospin was met with insults by housewives who accused the government of diverting excess water from the Seine into the inundated North, before removing a temporary walkway and leaving Jospin to paddle.

Six years ago, a Gaullist Prime Minister, Alain Juppé, who had also put together a Cabinet that included 12 women, got so fed up with the arrangement that he sacked most of them on the same day, calling them 'bimbos'. François Mitterrand, the late Socialist President, also lost patience with France's only woman Prime Minister, Edith Cresson, dismissing her after only 10 months when she complained of her incapacity to control her male-dominated Cabinet.

Jospin is unlikely to endorse Juppé's opinion of his female colleagues but he will be glad when Voynet leaves in June. She will take charge of the Green Party's pre-electoral plans after attacking Jospin's strategy and describing his entourage as 'creeps'.

Jospin's second presidential bid after losing to Jacques Chirac in 1995 hangs on reaction to his pre-electoral programme, which he will defend on television on Tuesday after a cool reception by his Communist and Green partners. The plan includes about 40 mini-reforms ranging from better welfare to anti-crime measures. By then, one of the most damaging strikes - a fortnight's protest by railwaymen - should be over, but he still has to overcome Communist claims that he has pursued right-wing policies.

His government's main reform, introduction of a 35-hour a week and the creation of a million jobs, has not overcome suspicion of complacency towards big business.

The Prime Minister's dilemma could be Voltaire's fault. Mireille Jospin's battle for the midwives has revived the story of Jospin's precocious intellectual influence. Like his three brothers and sisters, he was born at home but his parents' bed was out of bounds because his sister was confined there with measles. A sofa was pressed into service but was too low and had to be propped with the entire collection of the philosopher's bound works.

webTitle: Kenya brings its heroes to book

fields.headline: Kenya brings its heroes to book
fields.trailText: Kenya's Susan Chepkemei might have hoped her new world half-marathon record would command big headlines at home. Sadly for her, Kenyans expect their heroes, like most things, to come from abroad.
fields.body:
Kenya's Susan Chepkemei might have hoped her new world half-marathon record would command big headlines at home. Sadly for her, Kenyans expect their heroes, like most things, to come from abroad.

A US philosopher is trying to change that by publishing children's books about great East Africans. It is a novel way of encouraging one of the world's most aid-dependent countries to take pride in itself.

Last year, Lila Luce, a longtime Nairobi resident, went book-hunting for her housemaid. She had something about Jomo Kenyatta, Kenya's founding father, in mind - but all she could find was TinTin. 'Why should Africans read stuff from Europe?' she asked: 'What does it say about Africa when young Kenyans can't read about Kenyatta?'

Luce asked Nairobi's leading writers and critics for book ideas to fill the gap. 'They were surprised but all keen,' said Luce, a former University of Arizona professor turned conservationist.

Jomo Kenyatta: Father of Harambee is one of Luce's first five fictionalised African lives. Harambee, or 'pulling together', was Kenyatta's talisman word during his 40-year struggle to end British colonial rule and forge an African nation. All that remains of it in Kenya's tribally divided society is a decrepit government office block, Harambee House, notorious for having one of the most dangerous lifts in Africa.

Considering Kenya was created as a colony, it is unsurprising that three of the five were freedom fighters. But their stories are very different. Elijah Masinde was a mystic and an activist from western Kenya who preached a return to African religions, reportedly while standing on the tip of a spear. He was imprisoned by the British, and then by President Daniel arap Moi shortly before his death in 1987.

Mekatilili Wa Menza was a poor woman from east Kenya who led resistance to the colonisers' unpopular hut tax. Her village was razed and she was imprisoned, but the tax-collectors gave up before she did.

Kenyatta came from the Kikuyu, Kenya's biggest tribe. During Moi's 24-year rule the Kikuyu have been marginalised and Kenyatta subtly discredited. Few young Kenyans know much about him. Kenyatta's family was poor, but he was the brightest boy at his missionary school. He spent nearly 20 years in England, where he became an academic heavyweight, worked as a farm labourer and even acted in a film.

Egara Kabaji of Kenyatta University tells Kenyatta's story with one eye on the posthumous criticism. When the colonial administration's spoils were divvied up, some said the best land was going to Kenyatta's close friends and family, he writes. Otherwise, Kabaji skirts politics, cheerfully relating some of Kenya's most fraught and bloodiest years. Even Britain's ruthless putdown of the tinpot Mau Mau uprising is not dwelt on for long.

'People love and hate Kenyatta for different reasons, but he was definitely a great man who Kenyans need to know about,' said Luce. 'This is not about politics, it's about role-models, confidence, pride.'

Luce's books are being vetted by the Education Ministry for use in schools. She has no doubt the demand is there. 'Kids love these books, they eat them up like crisps.'

webTitle: Reality bites for film tough guys

fields.headline: Reality bites for film tough guys
fields.trailText: Robert Downey Jr isn't the only actor who gets in trouble. Steve Buscemi, the tough guy actor famous for his roles in  Pulp Fiction and  Fargo , found himself in a bar-room brawl last week that left him bruised and bloody, and another actor,  Swingers star Vince Vaughn, temporarily in jail.
fields.body:
Robert Downey Jr isn't the only actor who gets in trouble. Steve Buscemi, the tough guy actor famous for his roles in Pulp Fiction and Fargo , found himself in a bar-room brawl last week that left him bruised and bloody, and another actor, Swingers star Vince Vaughn, temporarily in jail.

The two actors, in the North Carolina seaside town of Wilmington to film Domestic Disturbance (also starring John Travolta), were patronising the Firebelly Lounge when the fight broke out early last Thursday. Buscemi was stabbed in the throat, head and arm.

According to reports, police were first called to break up a scuffle that apparently started after the girlfriend of one of the bar's regulars started talking to Vaughn. Tempers became heated and people went outside where there was a m lée during which Buscemi was stabbed. A local man was charged with assault with a deadly weapon. Vaughn, the film's screenwriter Scott Rosenberg and two other Wilmington men were charged with assault.

The incident has highlighted the apparent dangers of being a star in public. On Friday, rapper Jay-Z was arrested outside a Manhattan nightclub after a loaded handgun was found in his limousine. For rappers, getting arrested may be part of the job description but for actors the phenomenon is less well established as a career move.

The Buscemi incident highlights what actors have been saying for years: that members of the public frequently mistake them for the characters they play and want to chance their luck in a fight. They say strong-arm bodyguards are a necessity, even for actors who are not famous.

Stars have reported being stalked by an increasing number of obsessed fans. Though they do not publicise the fact for fear of attracting more, the stalker phenomenon is on the increase, say firms that supply security.

But Buscemi's dust-up does not match this profile. Once outside the safe confines of lower Manhattan and rich, white neighbourhoods of Los Angeles, the famous are fair game, especially in redneck country where many films are now shot.

fields.headline: World in brief
fields.trailText: Ankara attempts to quell anger over poverty
fields.body:
Ankara attempts to quell anger over poverty

Turkey's embattled government outlined a new economic programme designed to attract foreign loans and calm anger on the streets, where tens of thousands of people have been protesting against economic hardship, writes Chris Morris in Istanbul.

Since a high-level political row sparked the economic crisis in February, hundreds of thousands of people have lost their jobs and prices have risen dramatically. The price of petrol, a key indicator, is up by nearly 60 per cent.

There were further protests yesterday in cities across the country, but there was no repeat of the violent clashes seen in the capital on Wednesday.

In Istanbul yesterday, tens of thousands of demonstrators called on the government to resign, and cursed the International Monetary Fund for interfering in the economy.

Bomb kills nine in Dhaka

At least nine people were killed and dozens injured in an explosion at a concert in a park in central Dhaka, Bangladesh.

The bomb went off as the spectators enjoyed songs and dance celebrating the Bengali new year.

It was not clear who was responsible, though the festival has been condemned by Hindu extremists. Police said the bomb's carrier had been killed.

WWI arms dump scare

Police called in psychologists to persuade a group of 30 people to join the 12,500 already evacuated from Vimy in France where a stockpile of arms from the First World War is stored. Some of the containers are cracking. The evacuation is expected to last for 10 days until 20 tons of munitions are removed. One evacuee said: 'We didn't expect to spend our holidays this way.'

Swiss pursue Borodin case

Geneva's outspoken chief prosecutor has vowed not to drop a money-laundering case against ex-Kremlin aide Pavel Borodin, above, even though Borodin has been freed on bail and allowed to return to Russia. 'There is no turning back,' said Bernard Bertossa in a newspaper interview.

Since a high-level political row sparked the economic crisis in February, hundreds of thousands of people have lost their jobs and prices have risen dramatically. The price of petrol, a key indicator, is up by nearly 60 per cent. There were further protests yesterday in cities across the country, but there was no repeat of the violent clashes seen in the capital on Wednesday. In Istanbul yesterday, tens of thousands of demonstrators called on the government to resign, and cursed the International Monetary Fund for interfering in the economy. webTitle: Thousand-mile trek for better life ends in death on the beach

fields.headline: Thousand-mile trek for better life ends in death on the beach
fields.standfirst: Paul Harris in Tangier meets the African migrants who risk all to enter Europe in the search for an education or paid work - and the ruthless smugglers who promise help but deliver them into danger
fields.trailText: Paul Harris in Tangier meets the African migrants who risk all to enter Europe in the search for an education or paid work - and the ruthless smugglers who promise help but deliver them into danger.
fields.body:
Ken Umoli travelled a long way to get to Tangier. But the young Nigerian remembers the worst moment of the six-month journey as if it were yesterday. Trekking through the Sahara somewhere near the border between Mali and Mauritania, one of his companions, a Senegalese man, ran out of water. The man begged to be given some of his friends' precious supplies, but Umoli and the others knew that to do so would risk death themselves.

So they left him to perish under the hot sun. They walked on, ignoring his cries for help, which soon faded. He died in the sands. They made it to the next oasis.

'It was a difficult thing, but what else could we do? There are a lot of bodies in that desert. Sometimes you see bones by the roadside. They are all Africans heading for Europe,' Umoli said last week.

The journeys of refugees like Umoli to Tangier start in countless places all over Africa, from the villages of Nigeria to the slums of Senegal and the war zones of Sierra Leone. The lure of getting to Europe and securing a job in its buoyant economy is a powerful attraction to Africa's millions of poor and needy.

The routes they follow are tortuous and varied. The lucky few work for years and save up the money to fly to Morocco; others catch buses or hitch lifts. Thousands simply walk. They always head north, usually passing through Mali and its ramshackle capital, Bamoko, before attempting the deadly Sahara.

Many die on the way. They fall victim to bandits and robbers, or merciless smugglers who steal their few possessions and take their lives. Or, like Umoli's Senegalese friend, they fall victim to the heat, perhaps getting lost in the shifting sands, their bodies never found. Their relatives back home will never know if they achieved the dream of a better life or died on the way. The trip can take up to two years.

But if the starting points are many, the end is usually the same. The North African coast at Tangier is nine miles from Europe. It is a short distance across the Straits of Gibraltar - and from there on to Britain, Germany, Switzerland, anywhere there are jobs. But the trip across the water is the most deadly leg of the journey.

The Straits have been called the largest mass grave in Europe. Over the past three years it is thought 3,000 people have died attempting to cross.

The currents in the Straits, where the Mediterranean meets the Atlantic, are strong. If a boat engine dies or runs out of fuel, the craft can drift out into the ocean. Death does not come quickly to the terrified passengers crammed together. First comes the thirst, then the sunstroke. Those who fall in the water risk fuel burns from the petrol slicks floating on the waves.

Some boats are hit by the tankers and ferries sailing through the Straits, the busiest shipping lane in the world. The massive ships do not even notice the tiny rafts ahead of them as their bow waves swamp the dinghies, sending men and women tumbling into the sea.

In the public cemetery at Tarifa, on the southernmost tip of Spain, there are rows of unmarked graves reserved for the corpses washed up on the shore. Sometimes the bodies are buried three to a plot. The graves are one of the few visible reminders of the tragic exodus. Most bodies are carried out into the Atlantic.

Despite the risks, hundreds of Africans still come to Tangier where they wait, struggling to raise the money to pay smugglers to take them across. Each Friday at the Western Union branch in the city, crowds of Africans gather, eager to see if relatives have sent them cash to make the crossing.

Ben, also Nigerian, has been waiting in Tangier for two years and still can't raise the smugglers' 'fare'. His wait for help has been in vain. 'I have no money. Only God can help me now,' he said. But still he will not go back. He told me he was 25, but looked barely out of his teens.

There are probably 500 Africans in the city waiting to migrate and hundreds more camped out in the bush around Tangier and along the coast.

The smugglers' boats leave on any night when the conditions are right. The places of those leaving on the boats are quickly filled by those arriving in the city. Their story is always the same. They have fled poverty or war back home and want a new life and a job in Europe. Umoli has a tattered blue notebook crammed full of website addresses for universities in Britain. He wants to study economics at Bristol.

'Life is a risk. You have to take risks to get what you want,' he said, sitting on a mattress in a dingy hostel deep in the old city of Tangier. Above his bed, scribbled on the wall, was a brief message from a previous African occupant of the room - one who might have made it, or might have died. 'O Lord hear to my cry, give ear to my prayer,' it read.

Abdul and Mohammed are people smugglers. If Umoli is going to get across he will need the help of the likes of them, middlemen who arrange deals between the Africans and the kingpins controlling the trafficking routes.

They were sitting in the upstairs room of a café surrounded by a fug of hashish smoke from a joint they passed between them. In front of them sat a Nigerian, Sunday Fawi Adebiye, who had been waiting for an uncle in America to send him money.

Abdul listened to the Nigerian's story, pretending to be sympathetic.

'Soon, soon, maybe there will be a boat for you. But you need the money,' Abdul said, gripping Adebiye's arm in a friendly gesture. Then he reeled off a sliding scale of prices, ranging from a basic trip to going across and straight into a pre-arranged job in Spain.

Adebiye looked hopeful. But, of course, Abdul was lying: there will be no job waiting in Spain. No matter how much is paid, the service is always the same: you trust your life to a flimsy inflatable dinghy; the boat heads for Spain and, if you live, you will be dumped on the shore or caught by the coastguard.

'We just put them in the Zodiac, off they go and then we pray that they will be safe,' Abdul said.

Some boats are piloted by the refugees themselves, others by Moroccans, and usually also carry drugs, mostly hashish but sometimes heroin and cocaine. Drugs are intrinsic to the smuggling rings. It is a dangerous business and it is run by ruthless men who have no illusions about what is more valuable to them - drugs or people.

The smugglers pay huge bribes to the police and customs to allow them to carry out their trade in Tangier, but the refugees still face an uncertain existence there, playing a constant game of cat and mouse with the authorities.

Fearing arrest if caught on the street, most would-be immigrants in Tangier rarely emerge from their cheap boarding houses. They go out only occasionally into one square, which is surrounded by tall walls. They used to go to an outside terrace nearby, from where you can see Europe on the horizon. But no more: police raids have been frequent.

When they are picked up the refugees are taken to the Algerian border and dumped there in 'no man's land'. But they always return.

As their taxi bumped down a rough track to a rocky beach last week, Mohammed and Abdul pointed out a spot where a dinghy had left for Spain the night before.

Wearing several layers of clothing and clutching their belongings in bin liners, the desperate migrants had crowded into the boat and headed for Spain. It carried 20 Africans and was piloted by two Moroccans. It also had a cargo of hashish. The journey was successful. Not so, however, a trip three weeks ago. Four bodies were washed up on the beaches of Tarifa, but refugees in Tangier told The Observer at least 30 people had been aboard and were all presumed dead.

Mohammed was unmoved. The smugglers always get paid before the trip. If a dinghy sinks, they have lost nothing but a cheap rubber boat and they know there will always be more customers willing to pay up to $1,000 for the trip. 'Money talks, bullshit walks,' he said.

For Ossas Osula the money and the risk was worth it. The 37-year-old Nigerian economist has finally made it to Europe. He has a flat in Malaga, about an hour's drive up the coast from Tarifa, and is waiting for his work permit.

For those still stranded back in Tangier, Osula must seem a success story. But he nearly did not make it when his dinghy sank.

He made the trip last August, paying $700. On the Moroccan beach he was taken to there were 70 Africans waiting for two dinghies. Osula was in the first boat. The second never arrived - the middleman ran off with the cash.

Osula thought he was lucky to be on board. Then, after an hour and a half, water began to appear in the bottom of the boat. Then the rubber sides started to feel soft. The dinghy was old and had been badly patched - it was sinking. People panicked, shouting and screaming. They threw the heavy outboard motors away and started to paddle with their hands. Death seemed imminent.

'We all thought we were dead. There was nothing we could do. Sometimes we were paddling forwards, sometimes sideways, it was a huge panic,' he said.

Then a miracle happened: a Spanish fishing boat, attracted by the screams, came to their aid. The coastguard was called and the terrified passengers taken to Tarifa. 'Right up to the minute we were rescued, I thought we were all dead,' Osula said.

After several days in police detention they were released. Osula slept on the streets, eventually making his way up the coast where he found a local city charity, called Cedep, that has been set up to deal with the African influx. Now, along with dozens of others, he attends Spanish lessons and is eager for the chance to start work.

Although Spain has recently tightened its immigration laws and has promised to deport those arriving on its shores, there is still a chance for people like Osula. Opposition to the new rules has been strong and they have not yet been enforced. Some of the refugees drift into crime or prostitution, but most find rooms or hostels where they are fed and clothed. Then begins the long wait for work papers.

This is the final stage of the journey. It can take years. For those that come to Malaga, Cedep has a programme to provide jobs in the local hotel, catering or construction industries.

For the brave and lucky few, a journey of thousands of miles, several years and life-threatening risks ends up in a kitchen or a building site on the Costa del Sol - their dream come true.

'I don't want to be a millionaire, I don't want to be a billionaire,' Osula said, 'I just want a job and to live like other people live. To live life like a human being.'

webTitle: Comment: Breaking up is hard for Alastair to do...

fields.headline: Breaking up is hard for Alastair to do...
fields.standfirst: ...but for the sake of Tony Blair, the Government and himself, he should do the decent thing and leave Downing Street forever
fields.trailText: ...but for the sake of Tony Blair, the Government and himself, he should do the decent thing and leave Downing Street forever.
fields.body:
So farewell then, Alastair Campbell, poised to slip back into the shadows after the glare of the media spotlight became too bright for even the Sultan of Spin to bear. Downing Street's chief press secretary is a victim of the personality-driven politics the former tabloid journalist did so much to foster, while denouncing the press's growing obsession with the people, not the policies.

He gave us Tony Blair the cuddly family man; Tony Blair the commanding presidential figure; Tony Blair the respected international leader; and Tony Blair, the Margaret Thatcher of New Labour. And he gave us Alastair Campbell, the aide of influence who was close to Tony Blair, worked hard to get New Labour elected, offered sound advice - and wanted the world to know.

Campbell had a destructive weakness for self-publicity that turned him from a source to a victim in the eyes of many newspapers. The writing was on the wall, as it was for his old sparring partner, Charlie Whelan, when he became not just the story but a story he could not control when an increasing number of journalists refused to swallow the line.

Like his old friend, Peter Mandelson, Campbell has never been much good at following the advice he readily offers others. Campbell sneered at Gordon Brown for inviting a TV crew into the Treasury and pronounced, probably accurately, that the resulting film damaged the Chancellor. So what did Campbell do? He invited Michael Cockerell and a BBC film crew into Number 10.

The PR maestro smiled in front of the cameras, a Rottweiler playing the role of a poodle as he dropped his catchphrase 'Crap - that's C-R-A-P' for a viewer-friendly 'garbagick' (a term of abuse not heard before or since) and went on a charm offensive. One female journalist swore Campbell even wore make-up under the TV lights.

The resulting home movie raised his already high profile and left the hapless politician he was supposed to work for, Tony Blair, looking like a puppet manipulated by the spin doctor. Cue Rory Bremner and Sunday night scenes of a hulking Campbell bullying a timid Blair in confrontations which, thanks to Cockerell, look as if they are from yet another fly-on-the-wall documentary.

Campbell has always been a 'personality', a colourful character with a quick wit who likes to mix it physically as well as verbally, as the Guardian 's Michael White discovered when he failed to greet the death of Robert Maxwell with the respect that Campbell considered fitting. That he added to the gaiety of Westminster is without doubt, if somewhat ironic, given his obsession with turning MPs into on-message robots controlled by the party machine.

Cockerell, Bremner et al highlight the corrosive influence on democracy of Campbell, who has reduced debate and helped concentrate power at the centre to an unhealthy degree, stifling discussion and marginalising the role of elected politicians. MPs and Ministers fear unelected Campbell's influence, afraid that a word from him in the ear of Blair can end careers - think Peter Mandelson - or lead to press criticism - think Clare Short - or leave the public believing that the Prime Minister fears - this time think Gordon Brown - you suffer from 'psychological flaws'.

Campbell attends Cabinet meetings and has more clout than most of its members, able to fire off a fax to Harriet Harman ordering her to shut up, and write the resignation letters of several Ministers, including Ron 'Walk on the wild side' Davies. Which other press secretary could ever have delivered a wife-or-mistress ultimatum to a Foreign Secretary en route to Heathrow?

One female Labour back bencher with a messy relationship behind her fears that if she ever stepped out of line, the grizzly details would somehow be leaked to a red top and she would endure days of public torment. Such paranoia cannot be healthy in politics.

The relationship between Campbell and Brown remains fraught. Campbell privately mocked the Chancellor as an 'out-of-control colossus' after last month's budget persuaded the Sun, a paper Campbell considers his own after convincing it to back Blair in 1997, to announce it would back Labour in 2001.

There have been signs that the novelty of being at the premier's side is wearing off and that the fact that his grip on the press is slipping is taking its toll, as the Daily Mail in particular targets him. Once he would appear, Zelig-like, in the front row of British diplomats to take the salute and shake the hand of the Chinese premier in Tiananmen Square or bow his head alongside Prince Charles at the coffin of King Hussein of Jordan. Cracking jokes with Bill Clinton was one thing; trying to understand Bush quite another.

While some journalists will lose a good contact, indeed their only contact, when Campbell stops briefing, many more will write his obituary and then recall how he gave them little information, wrong information or leaked their information to rival publications. A respected columnist, sympathetic to New Labour yet admired for his independence of mind, once disclosed - on lobby terms, of course - that he preferred dealing with Bernard Ingham, Margaret Thatcher's spokesman, because he was straighter to deal with than Campbell.

Familiarity with the Westminster lobby may have produced contempt in Campbell for the way it operates, but, equally, a number of colleagues have similar contempt for Campbell's methods, the favouritism and factions, a system that built him up and now risks knocking him down.

He deserves applause for going on the record as agreeing to be described as the 'official spokesman' in briefings. That this fuelled the cult of the personality, newspapers deciding to go a step further and call him Alastair Campbell because that is his real name, will not be lost on him. He is, in part, the author of his own downfall.

Campbell the journalist served on Maxwell's Daily Mirror and Sunday Mirror, then on Rupert Murdoch's now closed Today newspaper as a self-styled Labour propagandist, praising the party leadership and criticising politicians on the Left who dared to criticise the leadership. He remains notoriously intolerant of journalists on centre-Left newspapers who refuse to swallow the Downing Street line and rails against the media's obsession with personalities, their focus on the trivial and their inability to see what he calls the big picture. And what 'great' story is Campbell remembered for? Claiming that John Major tucked his shirt into his underpants.

His efforts to portray Blair as a man of the people have, on occasion, left the PM looking a bit of a wally as Campbell's tabloid instincts got the better of him. His advice two years ago that Blair should back a campaign to free Deirdre Rashid, a fictional character jailed in Coronation Street, not a real-life woman behind bars in a miscarriage of justice, will for ever blunt his criticism that papers do not take the Government seriously.

Campbell will be doing the right thing if he gives up his post the month after next, since it might prove nigh on impossible for a second-term Labour government to persuade a sceptical electorate that it is improving public services, concentrating on substance, not style, while he remains the official spokesman. Yet he has been spinning that he would like to switch to a White House-style post as a director of communications, coordinating communications and planning big events, effectively pulling the strings behind the scenes, a backseat driver.

When Campbell resigns once the election is called to allow him to campaign, he should clear his desk and depart from Downing Street for good. That would be good for Labour, good for democracy and perhaps good for Alastair Campbell.

 Kevin Maguire is chief reporter on the Guardian
