MPs and Ministers fear unelected Campbell's influence, afraid that a word from him in the ear of Blair can end careers - think Peter Mandelson - or lead to press criticism - think Clare Short - or leave the public believing that the Prime Minister fears - this time think Gordon Brown - you suffer from 'psychological flaws'. Campbell attends Cabinet meetings and has more clout than most of its members, able to fire off a fax to Harriet Harman ordering her to shut up, and write the resignation letters of several Ministers, including Ron 'Walk on the wild side' Davies. Which other press secretary could ever have delivered a wife-or-mistress ultimatum to a Foreign Secretary en route to Heathrow? One female Labour back bencher with a messy relationship behind her fears that if she ever stepped out of line, the grizzly details would somehow be leaked to a red top and she would endure days of public torment. Such paranoia cannot be healthy in politics. The relationship between Campbell and Brown remains fraught. Campbell privately mocked the Chancellor as an 'out-of-control colossus' after last month's budget persuaded the Sun, a paper Campbell considers his own after convincing it to back Blair in 1997, to announce it would back Labour in 2001. There have been signs that the novelty of being at the premier's side is wearing off and that the fact that his grip on the press is slipping is taking its toll, as the Daily Mail in particular targets him. Once he would appear, Zelig-like, in the front row of British diplomats to take the salute and shake the hand of the Chinese premier in Tiananmen Square or bow his head alongside Prince Charles at the coffin of King Hussein of Jordan. Cracking jokes with Bill Clinton was one thing; trying to understand Bush quite another. While some journalists will lose a good contact, indeed their only contact, when Campbell stops briefing, many more will write his obituary and then recall how he gave them little information, wrong information or leaked their information to rival publications. A respected columnist, sympathetic to New Labour yet admired for his independence of mind, once disclosed - on lobby terms, of course - that he preferred dealing with Bernard Ingham, Margaret Thatcher's spokesman, because he was straighter to deal with than Campbell. Familiarity with the Westminster lobby may have produced contempt in Campbell for the way it operates, but, equally, a number of colleagues have similar contempt for Campbell's methods, the favouritism and factions, a system that built him up and now risks knocking him down. He deserves applause for going on the record as agreeing to be described as the 'official spokesman' in briefings. That this fuelled the cult of the personality, newspapers deciding to go a step further and call him Alastair Campbell because that is his real name, will not be lost on him. He is, in part, the author of his own downfall. Campbell the journalist served on Maxwell's Daily Mirror and Sunday Mirror, then on Rupert Murdoch's now closed Today newspaper as a self-styled Labour propagandist, praising the party leadership and criticising politicians on the Left who dared to criticise the leadership. He remains notoriously intolerant of journalists on centre-Left newspapers who refuse to swallow the Downing Street line and rails against the media's obsession with personalities, their focus on the trivial and their inability to see what he calls the big picture. And what 'great' story is Campbell remembered for? Claiming that John Major tucked his shirt into his underpants. His efforts to portray Blair as a man of the people have, on occasion, left the PM looking a bit of a wally as Campbell's tabloid instincts got the better of him. His advice two years ago that Blair should back a campaign to free Deirdre Rashid, a fictional character jailed in Coronation Street, not a real-life woman behind bars in a miscarriage of justice, will for ever blunt his criticism that papers do not take the Government seriously. Campbell will be doing the right thing if he gives up his post the month after next, since it might prove nigh on impossible for a second-term Labour government to persuade a sceptical electorate that it is improving public services, concentrating on substance, not style, while he remains the official spokesman. Yet he has been spinning that he would like to switch to a White House-style post as a director of communications, coordinating communications and planning big events, effectively pulling the strings behind the scenes, a backseat driver. When Campbell resigns once the election is called to allow him to campaign, he should clear his desk and depart from Downing Street for good. That would be good for Labour, good for democracy and perhaps good for Alastair Campbell.  Kevin Maguire is chief reporter on the Guardian

fields.headline: Oh, how clever! A vain, conceited woman writing a diary
fields.body:
Monday: The remaining three journalists in Britain who haven't spent the weekend writing about Sophie Thing or Helen Fielding - the whole of which seems to have morphed in my mind into some terrible amalgam called Sophie Jones's Diary (original thoughts had nil, vg, yummy dream of clean no-touching Daily Mail sex with person even stupider than self and use nice tissues spray nice Glade afterwards talk ski hols yummy roll over to Eddie then remember pointless no hope etc 'cos used to be known as Dockyard Doris aargh aargh) - would appear to be concentrating on whether I'm some scheming tricoteuse trying to overly influence Tony on Republicanism, just because I might a) believe in it, astonishingly, and b) mildly resent being slagged off in public by someone whose only possible contribution to the terminally brackish Windsor gene pool will be the ability to understand why the upper-middle class revere greed and resent democracy, tricks with which I think even they might be finally growing vaguely au fait after just a few hundred years.

Knit one, purl one, clack clack clack.

Tuesday: Tories in a lather over this guy in Sunderland who's an expert on the modern global media, the DVD recording innovation, international jet travel and the concept of preferential European exchange rates but can't quite get his head around the idea of the standard-metre-bar kilogram, first introduced in 1889. Alastair wanted to have him fined in groats, which raised a laugh until Prescott added, mournfully, that most of them had probably been shot by the soldiers.

Wednesday: Royals, foot and mouth, transport, health... the entire country seems to have become a vast simulacrum of one of those journalists' pubs where everyone moans endlessly about the management but then trots back upstairs because there's nothing else to do, and Alastair, for one, seems to have had enough and wants to back out of the light for the next session.

A few endearing little tributes to him already appearing, where his famously finessed bons mots are recalled in all their subtle brilliance. There's the marvellous riposte to Michael Foot on the Trident question ('Do you like hospital food?'), for instance; the dexterous put-down to mild Japanese journalists over our ethical foreign policy ('F- the c- off, you c-ing f-ers'); the ever-winning comeback to editors over mounting press criticism at home ('Tell me where Cohen lives or I start drowning puppies')... ah, but we'll miss it all. And I'm sure dear Al will still be around in the background, and there's nothing to these rumours that he wants to work somewhere where he can exert real influence on the country. I mean, Rory Bremner's already got that bloke, hasn't he?

Thursday: Another awful, traumatic visit for poor Tony, but he does have to keep them up, show face etc, even though the whole thing's such an obvious doomed farce. And so, again, he goes through the motions: doing all we can... incredible sacrifice... country will never forget... one day misery forgotten... out of our hands, but in our thoughts. Terrible, torn, mournful faces, but at least they listened.

And then, as if the teachers hadn't been enough, on it was to more bloody farmers.

Friday: Good Friday marked (along with nice snowman card from Harriet) by exuberantly-detailed pictures of dying lambs, burst cattle and other Gustave Doré seventh-circle engraving stuff like pits, pyres, boils, barrows, bloat, stripped flesh, pus, goitre, Widdecombe. Welcome, ye tourists, to Britain, twinned with Golgotha.

fields.headline: Pendennis
fields.standfirst: Simon's simple pleasures
fields.trailText: Simon Walker's simple pleasures.
fields.body:
The Queen's communications secretary Simon Walker has been blamed - rightly or wrongly - for arranging the Countess of Wessex's recent catastrophic interview with the News of the World. Bemused courtiers express surprise at Mr Walker's reported £250,000 salary. But is that all? A senior figure at British Airways, from where Mr Walker is seconded, whispers: 'Simon remains entitled to complimentary BA tickets, just like any other member of staff.' And the normal cost of four business class returns to China, where Mr Walker is now on holiday with his family? £20,820. Nice work indeed, if you can hold on to it.

 Steve Norris, the frisky Tory vice-chairman, handles these things much more elegantly. 'As Transport Minister Steve knew it would cause a storm if he were ever to solicit favours,' discloses a Tory admirer. 'So if he was to travel abroad, he would ask his private secretary to write to the managing director of whichever airline he was about to use pointing out that the Minister categorically insisted on being given no special treatment whatsoever. It worked a treat. Every time Steve went anywhere, he was given the full VIP treatment; upgrades, champagne and the lavish attention of all the air hostesses he could handle.' What a guy.

 Is there something wrong with the central London postal service? Almost a month ago, Mr Stephen Byers insisted that he would be 'throwing the book' at the Daily Mail. The paper had claimed that the Trade and Industry Secretary improperly handled his department's report into the Maxwell affair. But where on earth is the libel writ which Mr Byers promised? We only ask.

 Unfortunate tidings for harrumphing right-wing journalists hoping to assume the editor's chair at the Spectator when its current holder Boris Johnson becomes a Tory MP. A source close to Spectator proprietor Conrad Black tells me firmly: 'This job really should be a launching pad for a career, not a resting stop for those who have failed to achieve their ambitions and are now looking for a comfort zone.' Let's pray that this news will not spoil the Easter celebrations of Messrs Simon Heffer, Stephen Glover, George Walden and Bruce Anderson - all rumoured aspirants to the capacious seat once occupied by Nigel Lawson.

This week sees the timely paperback issue of Michael Arditti's splendid novel, Easter. The book has been critically acclaimed but is it really 'Trollopean', as Radio 4 describes it? Take a typical passage: '"Are you sure you're all right?" the Bishop asks. "I have an inflammation upon my entrance," explained the Archdeacon. The Bishop stares at him coldly. "Most people, Archdeacon, would call it an exit."' Try as we might, we can't find anything similar in Barchester Towers.

 At long last, some good press notices for the Tories. 'Earnest without seeming high-handed, high-minded but not cynical,' says the Los Angeles Times. 'It's been an incredibly difficult time, but now it's a new day. They have overcome their adversity,' insists the New York Times. If only, William, if only. The rave notices are, sad to say, reviews of a new album by an American band of the same name. Just bars into the first track from Upside of Down, the Tories' frontman sings: 'If I was on fire, would you notice?'

 Will the canonisation of Polly Toynbee as patron saint of New Labour have to be postponed? The award-winning Guardian columnist and pin-up of liberal Britain has committed a cardinal sin. In her new book Did Things Get Better? 'Saint' Polly, celebrated for her closeness to Number 10, repeatedly misspells the name Alastair Campbell as Alistair. And as we all know only too well, Alastair can be terrifyingly, furiously, spectacularly unforgiving if crossed. May the Lord have mercy upon Polly's soul.

webTitle: Comment: Northern Ireland on the train to nowhere

fields.headline: On the train to nowhere
fields.trailText: A pre-glasnost joke summing up the sclerotic nature of Brezhnev's Soviet Union ran: A train is hurtling from Moscow to Leningrad when it stops suddenly. The passengers panic and run to the front of the train where they spot Lenin reading  Pravda.
fields.body:
A pre-glasnost joke summing up the sclerotic nature of Brezhnev's Soviet Union ran: A train is hurtling from Moscow to Leningrad when it stops suddenly. The passengers panic and run to the front of the train where they spot Lenin reading Pravda.

'Comrade Lenin,' they cry, 'the train has broken down please help us.' Lenin climbs out of a window on to the roof. The father of Bolshevism gives a speech to rival that made to the Finland Station, his rhetoric about the necessity to complete their journey so powerful that the railway workers and passengers get to the back of the train and push it forward.

After several hours the train pulls up again. This time the panicking passengers run to the second carriage and find Stalin smoking his pipe and making out lists of people. 'Comrade Stalin,' they cry, 'the train has broken down, please help us.' So Stalin gets out of the train and walks along it, until he picks out one of the rail workers and shoots him. Passengers and rail staff cower with fear and then slope off to get behind the train and push it forward.

As they near Leningrad the engine packs in once more. Again the passengers run to the head of the train. In the third carriage they see Brezhnev, smoking a cigar and eating caviar. 'Comrade Brezhnev,' the passengers cry, 'the train has broken down, please help us.' Brezhnev asks: 'Are there curtains on this train?' When the passengers say yes, Brezhnev pulls the curtains across the window and shouts: 'Don't worry comrades, the train is moving.'

The joke came to mind last Tuesday while I sat on the platform of a Democratic Dialogue debate on the Good Friday Agreement's future. A sociologist read out a raft of disturbing statistics on Protestant attitudes to the Agreement, all outlining a loss of faith in the peace accord and the subsequent danger of electoral meltdown for pro-Agreement unionism.

But instead of seizing on the potential disaster ahead, many of the assembled academics, community workers and other interested parties sought solace in a solitary statistic - that 66 per cent of the overall population would still vote Yes in a new referendum. This they argued was proof of the Agreement's resilience. But their optimism was surely an Irish version of Brezhnev pulling the curtains. In 1998 a narrow majority in the unionist community voted Yes; three years on the situation is reversed.

Among many of that enthusiastic tribe in the Yes camp, the south Belfast liberal intellectual, lies a fundamental misunderstanding of the Agreement's essence. The error was repeated last week by sections of the UK media, clearly been charmed by Tim Pat Coogan and his 'Count the Catholics' theory for instant peace and unity in Ireland.

The peace deal is a settlement rather than a stepping stone à la Michael Collins. When I pointed this out it touched a nerve among Sinn Fein sympathisers. They would not accept that the Agreement is a political fait accompli because the Provisionals like to portray the Agreement as a transition towards a united Ireland, ignoring the principle of consent and a Stormont Assembly.

In other words, pace Margaret Thatcher, Ulster is NOT to be governed in the same way as Finchley. But what if the situation was the other way around? What if Coogan's grim vista came true and there was a 50 per cent plus one Catholic majority. Leaving aside objections that all Catholics are nationalists, would this mean a united Ireland? Surely not if nationalists stick to the spirit of the Agreement they signed, particularly its insistence on cross community support.

Underpinning the Agreement lies the principle of anti-majoritarianism: that only government by power-sharing and mutual communal consent can work. You only have to look at Yugoslavia's break-up and the narrow majorities in favour of ceding from the federation to realise majoritarianism produces recalcitrant minorities leading to division, bitterness and ultimately civil war.

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: Premiums soar | Taxing times | Avoid cowboys
fields.body:
Premiums soar

The cost of home insurance is going up for the first time in four years as insurers try to claw back money paid out on flood claims, says broker AA Insurance Services.

Building insurance will now cost an average of £134 a year due to a rise in premiums of 1.62 per cent, while home contents insurance will be £107 after a 1.44 per cent rise in premiums.

AA insurance services says it can shave more than 30 per cent off your premiums by scanning the market. Ring 0800 444 777.

Taxing times

More than 8.6 million people who last week received a tax return have until 31 January 2002 to submit the form. A £100 fine will be levied on people who miss that deadline. Those who want the Inland Revenue to calculate their tax are urged by the Revenue to get the form back four months earlier, by the end of September this year. Tax advisers encourage people doing their own returns to meet the 30 September deadline.

Help is available in the Lloyds TSB 367-page paperback Tax Guide 2001/2002 (£7.99 in bookshops). It is available at £6.99 (including p&p) to Observer readers on 020 8324 5530, bookshop@bvcd.prestel.co.uk or by sending a cheque to Profile Books, 250 Western Avenue, London W3 6EE.

More for less

If you are thinking of taking a city break this spring, your pound will stretch furthest in Istanbul and Stockholm, according to a survey by American Express Foreign Exchange.

Of the 10 destinations surveyed, New York and Prague will leave you most out of pocket. In the Big Apple you will receive 11.43 per cent less than last year. In Paris, Amsterdam, Rome, Venice, Barcelona and Madrid you will receive around 3 per cent less for your sterling.

In contrast you will get a whopping 56 per cent more Turkish lira to the pound, and 6 per cent more Swedish kroner, year on year.

Avoid cowboys

As the home improvement season gets under way you may wonder how you can protect yourself against cowboys.

Home improvement service Improveline is launching a free ratings system to ensure contractors are vetted for quality and professionalism.

Contractors are awarded points on the basis of criteria such as the guarantees they offer and the insurance cover they have. You can see it online at www.improveline.com.

Yell.com has also launched an information service that can help you locate and choose the best professionals.

fields.headline: You don't have to bend over backwards
fields.standfirst: In uncertain times, flexible mortgages are a popular choice.  Jill Insley answers your questions
fields.trailText: In uncertain times, flexible mortgages are a popular choice. Jill Insley answers your questions
fields.body:
Foot and mouth disease, the recent stock market crash and the threat of recession have cast a pall over the start of the house hunting season this year.

Lenders report that existing homeowners are also keen to reduce their mortgages as soon as possible through one-off, large contributions or smaller, regular overpayments. Paying off debt is a good way to shore up against negative equity or the loss of your job. But, with deposit account interest rates falling and the stock market fluctuating, some lenders argue that homeowners should regard paying off their mortgage as an investment, too.

Intelligent Finance, the internet and telephone bank, calculates that someone who invested £25,000 in the stock market at the beginning of the year would have lost about £2,500 by now.

If they had used the money to 'offset' the mortgage interest on an IF current account mortgage, they would have reduced the cost of their mortgage repayments by more than £400 over the same period.

The simplest way to overpay your mortgage is to continue making the same size of monthly payments when your interest rate is reduced. You should contact your lender's local branch to arrange this. But if you want more control over your money - the chance to withdraw equity, stop or reduce mortgage payments or repay early - consider a flexible mortgage. Fifty-seven lenders offer a version of the flexible loan. These vary considerably, so check the options to make sure they suit your circumstances.

To help you decide which loan is right for you, Cash has asked mortgage broker London & Country to recommend the best loans for different borrowers.

'I want to overpay regularly and be able to pay in lump sums as and when'

If you don't need great flexibility apart from early repayment the main factor for choosing is likely to be price. Alliance & Leicester offers a flexible loan discounted by 2.25 per cent for one year (giving an initial pay rate of 4.99 per cent), followed by a rate set at 0.95 per cent above the Bank of England's base rate for 10 years. There are no penalties at any time and interest is calculated monthly, so the benefit from overpayments will be felt almost immediately.

'I want to draw out money in the future and be able to take a payment holiday every now and again'

Standard Life Bank not only allows borrowers to withdraw any overpayments made, but also to draw down equity in the property up to 90 per cent of its value. So, if you have borrowed £75,000 on a home costing £100,000 but later find that you want to spend £15,000 on a new car, you can draw that money from your mortgage account at whatever rate is being applied. You can also use the reserve to take payment holidays. Standard Life offers a discount of 1.76 per cent off its standard variable rate (currently 6.75 per cent but falling to 6.5 per cent at the end of April) for the first six months.

'I would like to combine my current account and mortgage to cut down the amount I have to pay'

Intelligent Finance offers a current account-style mortgage that enables you to keep the different services separate. It offers current and savings accounts, personal loans, credit cards and mortgage, so you can see exactly how much you owe and how much you can spend. The choice of products is entirely yours - you don't have to switch your current account over to IF. Better still, any money in your current and/or savings accounts can be set against borrowings to reduce outstanding interest. For example, if you have a £100,000 loan but £10,000 in your savings account you will only have to pay interest on £90,000. IF offers a six-month discount of 1.5 per cent on its standard variable rate of 6.5 per cent (dropping to 6.25 per cent on 1 May).

'I'm a first-time buyer'

First-time buyers are often on tight budgets and want fixed monthly payments. Britannic Money offers a fixed rate of 5.85 per cent for two years on its current account mortgage. Described by London & Country's David Hollingworth as 'fantastic for first-time buyers', you can borrow up to 95 per cent of value with no mortgage indemnity guarantee (MIG) and no early redemption penalty. You also receive £150 towards the valuation fee and £200 towards legal costs. For a 25 per cent deposit, the rate is even lower at 5.35 per cent.

The Woolwich's Offset Together mortgage enables parents or any other person to deposit money in an account that can be set against the cost of the mortgage. The parent retains control over the money and can withdraw or add to it at any time, but the borrower benefits from a reduction in the amount he or she has to pay every month.

The Offset Together mortgage will lend you 3.25 times your income plus one times your partner's or 2.5 times joint income and up to 95 per cent of the property's value. However, interest is charged at the Offset standard variable rate, currently 6.25 per cent, and you will have to buy MIG if you are borrowing more than 90 per cent of value.

Stamp duty

The tax regime introduced in March 2000 levies no stamp duty on properties priced up to £60,000. From £60,001 to £250,000 it is 1 per cent.

On properties from £250,001 to £500,000 it jumps up to 3 per cent, and a property valued at more than £500,000 has 4 per cent duty.

Estate agents say these rises deter people from buying houses priced 'on the cusp' between different rates of duty. For example, someone buying a house on sale for £250,000 pays £2,500 in duty. If the house is priced at £255,000, the buyer pays £7,650.

webTitle: Money writes: Unwanted loan led to window pains

fields.headline: Unwanted loan led to window pains
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
In May 1999 we paid Anglian Windows £5,050 for double glazing but, when we told the sales consultant we wanted to pay cash, she offered a £520 discount if we took out a loan through Associates Capital Corporation.

She calculated that the £520 would take care of the interest and advised us to take insurance for £550. As there seemed hardly any difference in the two ways of paying, we did as she advised.

In January we asked to pay off the balance, which came to £3,224, some £1,700 more than we expected. We were told we had a 10-year loan. We contacted the showroom manager and, when nothing happened, the deputy director of customer services. We are still in absolute darkness.
JV, London

This is the second complaint within a few weeks to Money Writes about Anglian Windows' credit agreements, and it has rattled Anglian. The company says any sales consultant found to have deliberately misled customers over credit will be sacked immediately.

It says it wants to improve communications with customers and, prompted by Observer readers' complaints, is rushing out a leaflet explaining to customers how credit agreements work and what they cost.

Anglian has agreed to refund the extra costs you incurred by taking credit so you will pay the cash price - as you wanted to do in the first place.

Home insurance: Empty threat

Last November my father went into hospital and then moved into a residential home. We need to sell his flat, but sorting everything out takes time. We cannot even begin until my father has definitely settled into the home.

His house contents insurance is due for renewal, but Endsleigh is refusing to renew the policy because there is now no one living in the flat.
SS, Langley

Endsleigh says it has a standard clause about property unoccupied for more than 30 days and, concentrating as it does on younger customers, has not come across this situation before.

But it is backtracking and has agreed to renew. It admits handling your inquiry badly and, although you were given a technically correct response, says local staff should have taken advice from head office.

Endsleigh says it is now standard practice to renew in these circumstances at the standard rate, though it insists you turn off the gas, drain the water system and remove valuables.

You should always tell insurers when a house is empty this long, regardless of the renewal date.

Pension share: My missing wife

I Started an annuity with Standard Life in 1995. I noticed when I took up the pension that provision had been made for a half pension to be paid to my spouse after my death.

I am 70, divorced many years ago and see little prospect of remarrying. Does this extension of pension rights to a non-existent spouse have any impact on the amount of pension I receive?
TW, Bath

If you bought this annuity with a company pension fund, you probably had no choice about taking the widow's pension.

But that provision certainly does reduce the amount you now receive. If you bought the widow's benefit on a financial adviser's recommendation, you should complain to the person who sold you the policy.

Remortgaging: I'm paying more

I am alarmed at the increase in my mortgage payments since I remortgaged with Bradford & Bingley.

Last year they went up from £156 a month to £176.90 and this year they have risen another 32 per cent to £233.90.
GM, Blackpool

Bradford & Bingley changes its monthly mortgage payments once a year. After the £156 figure was set, interest rates rose twice, in February and March 2000, so for the rest of the year you paid less than you owed.

In April 2000, mortgage interest tax relief (Miras) was abolished, pushing your payments up by another £19, which you started to make up only from 2001.

On top of that, the interest rate applying in January 2001 is higher than the 2000 figure so you are now paying a higher mortgage rate as well as making up last year's under-payments.

Since the new year your mortgage rate has already fallen by 0.25 per cent and another reduction is likely. If you wish, you can ask Bradford & Bingley to recalculate this year's payment now to take account of the lower rate.

 Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER and include a telephone number. Do not enclose SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

Airport tax

Money writes readers are clued up about reclaiming Air Passenger Duty when they have been unable to use tickets, sometimes with success. Airlines forward the duty to the Government only when passengers actually fly.

WW of Chislehurst says: 'I had two tickets with Buzz for travel from Stansted to Dusseldorf. I asked for a refund of the taxes and almost by return received £21.25 per ticket.'

JF of Wakefield received £20 back from a Ryanair flight to Cork but its other customers have been less fortunate. IG of London booked one flight with Ryanair to St Etienne but had to cancel because she could not get a hire car: 'I rebooked for a week later, only to miss the flight because of delays at the airport. I had already applied for a refund of taxes and charges for the first booking and was refunded £30.80 for two people. I applied for a refund of the second booking, only to be told that Ryanair would now only refund the UK Government tax of £10 per person but that was cancelled out by a £10 per person administration fee.'

She adds: 'I have been battling to get proof of when the refund administration fee was introduced. They claim it was 17 November, the day before my second flight.'

One reader, who gives no name or address, believes airlines should keep the duty: 'It is obviously a problem of high taxation and we would all be better served if you spent your energy on protesting about the tax rather than about the airlines that have made travel possible for the masses.'

fields.headline: On the market
fields.standfirst: Framlington UK Smaller Companies Fund
fields.trailText: Framlington UK Smaller Companies Fund.
fields.body:
Contact 0845 777 5511

Aim To generate capital growth by investing in UK companies with a market capitalisation of less than £1bn.

Bells & whistles The fund will be managed by Roger Whiteoak, who won Standard & Poor's Micropal Award in the UK smaller companies sector in 2000 while managing the Rathbone UK Smaller Companies Fund. Framlington says: 'This new fund will enable investors to get in on the ground floor with one of the UK's leading smaller company managers at a time when the market offers great value.'

How it works The manager will look for long-term growth opportunities in healthcare, media, information technology, electronics, aerospace and outsourcing plus sectors that will benefit from further cuts in interest rates, such as building. The portfolio will contain between 80 and 100 stocks.

Minimum Lump sum £1,000, monthly savings £50.

Charges Initial charge 5.25 per cent (discounted to 4.25 per cent until 27 April), annual management charge 1.5 per cent.

Tax Tax-free through an Isa or Pep transfer, otherwise liable to capital gains tax.

Risk High.

Should you buy it? Jason Hollands of London adviser Bestinvest is cautious: 'Roger posted some excellent returns at Rathbones, has some strong views on themes and is obviously bright, but it's hard to know how much influence Hugh Priestley [the Rathbones investment director who used to manage the firm's UK smaller companies fund] had over him and the fund. Framlington is not a company we would chose for this area. I would hold back from investing early in this fund.'

Chris Wicks of Glossop firm Bridgewater is more enthusiastic: 'The Rathbones fund was excellent while Roger was there, which has to be an endorsement for this fund. It's a good time to buy, and if you are a disciplined investor buying into market weakness, you could do very well over a five-year period.'

Points out of 10 Hollands - 5, Wicks - 8.

fields.headline: Banking data 'up for grabs'
fields.trailText: Thousands of private bank account details were illegally distributed and then stolen after a security breach at Britain's biggest card payment company.
fields.body:
Thousands of private bank account details were illegally distributed and then stolen after a security breach at Britain's biggest card payment company.

The Bank Automated Clearing Service (Bacs) gave the names, account numbers and sort codes of thousands of bank accounts on a CD to a company that was helping Bacs improve its computer systems. The details were copied on to a laptop belonging to the software company, Macro 4. The problem came when that laptop was stolen from the car of a Macro 4 employee three weeks ago.

Under the Data Protection Act, it is illegal to copy and distribute private bank data. The Information Commissioner - the government data privacy watchdog - told The Observer last week it would investigate. The police have yet to recover the laptop and security experts fear that the details may be used for bank fraud. 'This information gives you the keys to someone's bank account,' said Michael Comer, a security expert at Maxima, a City fraud security company. 'You could use this to create counterfeit cheques, blackmail someone, or draw money from an account.'

Bacs manages more than 4 billion transactions a year. Every time a debit or credit card transaction is made, the account details go through its computers. Bacs declined to comment on allegations that the copies of sensitive data had been made with the permission of two senior executives at the company. They confirmed the copying and theft but refused to say if the owners of the accounts had been informed.

Macro 4 asked for examples of the data Bacs processes to help it to develop a new archive system for all transactions. It is customary for dummy data to be supplied in such instances.

fields.headline: What's the catch?
fields.trailText: Halifax platinum credit card.
fields.body:
If you have a Halifax platinum credit card and have been offered a cheque to draw funds on the card, be aware that there will be a handling charge. A reader who failed to notice the charge in the small print was astonished when an £18 fee popped up on his first statement.

Credit card cheques work in the same way as any other cheques except that they draw on the credit card instead of your current account.

Each Halifax credit card cheque written is treated as a cash advance - there is a handling charge of 1.5 per cent each time you use a cheque (the minimum charge is £1.50 and maximum £20), and once it has cleared you'll pay interest at the usual cash advance rate of 2.9 per cent in the introductory five-month period and 16.9 per cent thereafter. Halifax says that the charges are clearly stated in all the marketing literature.

But our reader says: 'It seems grossly unfair to me that such a charge should be hidden in the terms and not acknowledged anywhere on the cheque book itself. The instructions extol the virtues of the cheques as an ideal way to pay off other high street credit cards.'

He was encouraged to write a cheque for a £100 because it would qualify him for entry into a prize draw.

 Seen an advertisement or offer which sounds too good to be true? Write to What's the Catch? 119 Farringdon Rd, London EC1R 3ER.

webTitle: Big Issue, sir? Or maybe a bank loan?

fields.headline: Big Issue, sir? Or maybe a bank loan?
fields.trailText: The magazine for the homeless The Big Issue, is already a British institution. Now it has plans to become a financial institution as well.
fields.body:
The magazine for the homeless The Big Issue, is already a British institution. Now it has plans to become a financial institution as well.

The street magazine's pugnacious founder, John Bird, is talking to Royal Bank of Scotland, Apax Partners and management consultancy McKinsey about starting a £30 million lending bank to fund businesses and retrain the homeless. It is thought that the project will be the centrepiece of The Big Issue 's tenth anniversary celebrations in September.

Royal Bank and Apax may contribute funds, with McKinsey taking responsibility for the bank's structure. It is not clear whether the Big Issue Bank will take equity positions in the businesses it helps start up.

The magazine was originally a monthly, distributed in central London. It is now a nationwide weekly with an annual turnover of more than £3.5m. It is regarded as one of the best advertising media for accessing youth markets. Homeless vendors buy the magazine for 40p and sell it for £1. The Big Issue is a non-profit organisation.

The brainchild of Body Shop co-founder Gordon Roddick, The Big Issue was inspired by a similar street magazine in New York.

fields.headline: Insurers' £10bn black hole
fields.standfirst: Guaranteed annuities scandal to force life firms into frenzy of takeover activity
fields.trailText: Guaranteed annuities scandal to force life firms into frenzy of takeover activity
fields.body:
The life insurance industry is having to stump up £10 billion to pay for guaranteed annuities, the pension product that plunged Equitable Life into crisis late last year, with the final bill set to be considerably higher.

Equitable's guaranteed annuity rate (GAR) liability, put at £1.5bn last summer, has now grown to £2bn.

Bonus payouts to policyholders are likely to suffer as the 40 life offices affected look for capital to pay their GAR bills. Some life offices may have to close to new business as a cost-cutting measure while others will require a cash injection from shareholders. Others could be forced to put themselves up for sale, triggering a wave of mergers and acquisitions.

Experts say the hardest hit will be those where a large GAR liability is coupled with a weak financial position. These include Abbey Life, SunAlliance & London, Norwich Union life and pensions, National Mutual, and MGM Assurance.

Guaranteed annuities have become a liability because the rate at which the guarantee was set when the policies were sold in the 1970s and 1980s is much higher than annuity rates currently being paid. By law, the life industry has to set aside sufficient funds to bridge the difference.

But this year's falling stock market returns and mounting costs from the introduction of stakeholder pensions have caused the liabilities to grow in size. Several life offices are developing a solvency gap, which needs to be covered.

An analyst says: 'Solvency has deteriorated due to recent technical changes and the poor market. Life offices have also spent money preparing for stakeholder pensions. In aggregate, the effect is negative and will impact on life office's bonus-paying ability. Some may even have to close.'

It will be 15 years before we know the full extent of the GAR problem because that is when the majority of people sold the policies retire. One in four life offices has yet to establish how the outcome of the Equitable Life case will affect them.

Abbey Life has already received hundreds of millions of pounds of shareholders' money from parent Lloyds TSB. Lloyds is understood to have poured £100 million into Abbey Life since 1998, when it had to inject £176m because the life office fell below the legal minimum solvency levels due to escalating GAR and pensions mis-selling costs.

Investors in Royal & SunAlliance may be asked to bail out subsidiary SunAlliance & London, which has been landed with a £700m annuity bill. Norwich Union's life and pension fund is facing a £1.1bn hit. It says the liability has been fully accounted for, but an industry analyst says the NU fund is 'relatively weak' and will feel the strain.

National Mutual, which has a £200m liability, is reviewing its mutual status with a view to a sale and it is believed MGM Assurance could follow suit.

Around five brands will initially qualify for a Saltr (savings and long-term risk) quality mark, according to the Association of British Insurers, although 49 brands representing a larger number of companies have signed up for the initiative. It is thought many will not be up to speed until the end of next year at the earliest.

fields.headline: New probe at Equitable
fields.trailText: The new board of crisis-hit insurer Equitable Life has hired top City law firm Herbert Smith to probe the conduct of the former board and its advisers, who presided over the demise of the company with £2 billion of liabilities.
fields.body:
The new board of crisis-hit insurer Equitable Life has hired top City law firm Herbert Smith to probe the conduct of the former board and its advisers, who presided over the demise of the company with £2 billion of liabilities.

The firm has been appointed to collect possible evidence against the former board under ex-chief executive Chris Headdon, its former law firm Denton Wilde Sapte, and auditors Ernst & Young.

A spokesman said: 'There is no smoking gun yet. But the new board feels obliged to take a look at what went on. They are leaving no stone unturned.'

Equitable had to sell itself to Halifax after a House of Lords ruling on guaranteed annuities left it with a potentially crippling liability.

webTitle: SFO to press on with Young fraud charge

fields.headline: SFO to press on with Young fraud charge
fields.trailText: The Serious Fraud Office is set to risk another Maxwell-style humiliation by going ahead with prosecutions in the Peter Young fraud case. The former star City fund manager, alleged to have defrauded investment bank Deutsche Morgan Grenfell of £180 million in 1996, was last year found mentally unfit to stand trial. A jury heard that Young, now a transvestite, tried to castrate himself in a bid to become a woman, writes City editor Paul Farrelly .
fields.body:
The Serious Fraud Office is set to risk another Maxwell-style humiliation by going ahead with prosecutions in the Peter Young fraud case. The former star City fund manager, alleged to have defrauded investment bank Deutsche Morgan Grenfell of £180 million in 1996, was last year found mentally unfit to stand trial. A jury heard that Young, now a transvestite, tried to castrate himself in a bid to become a woman, writes City editor Paul Farrelly .

Two and a half years ago, three of Young's alleged accomplices were also charged with conspiracy to defraud and offences under the Financial Services Act.

This weekend the SFO confirmed that it planned to press ahead in the autumn with a trial of ex-Morgan Grenfell manager Stuart Armer and stockbroker Erik Langaker. Plans to prosecute Jan Helge Johnsen - an ex-colleague of Langaker's at broker Fiba Nordic Securities - have been stayed because he is ill. All have denied the charges.

Before bringing the case, the SFO also intends to stage a separate 'trial of the issues', to try to gain a jury's verdict on the alleged facts of Young's fraud. Such a procedure, used in murder cases when the defendant pleads insanity, is potentially difficult in fraud cases, say police.

The strategy could rebound on the SFO, which was embarrassed by the 1996 acquittal of Kevin and Ian Maxwell over the £400m looting of Mirror pension funds. The jury felt that the guilty party was dead tycoon Robert Maxwell.

webTitle: BT moves to spread cost of 3G mobile network

fields.headline: BT moves to spread cost of 3G mobile network
fields.trailText: Debt-laden BT is preparing for a crunch meeting with the Government over how it will finance its next generation of mobile services and the expansion of broadband networks.
fields.body:
Debt-laden BT is preparing for a crunch meeting with the Government over how it will finance its next generation of mobile services and the expansion of broadband networks.

Senior officials at the Department of Trade and Industry are concerned that progress in building broadband networks may be hampered by BT's £4.5 billion payment for a 3G mobile licence.

BT executives including Sir Peter Bonfield and finance director Philip Hampton are planning a meeting with officials from the DTI and regulator Oftel to present their case.

BT has already indicated its wish to collaborate with either Vodafone or One2One on building networks for 3G mobile services.

Now it wants to team up with such rivals to offer packages to customers in a bid to reduce competitive pressures when 3G services are launched.

The DTI fears that such a move would reduce competition. However, it is also concerned that the slow roll-out of broadband lines is jeopardising the Government's vision of placing Britain at the forefront of the global e-economy.

But it is wary both of BT's opposition to investing heavily in broadband - which the company claims is not supported by consumer demand - and of the operator's reluctance to open its local exchanges to rival operators.

Sharing service provision and building networks would spread the estimated £2bn-£5bn costs of construction.

fields.headline: Getting ready to spend
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown is known for his support of local football team Raith Rovers, but really he's just like Manchester United. The big statistics are firmly on his side - his time as Chancellor of the Exchequer has seen inflation and unemployment come down to 25-year lows, and mortgage rates are at their lowest since the Sixties. It is not difficult to see why he's smiling and relaxed.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown is known for his support of local football team Raith Rovers, but really he's just like Manchester United. The big statistics are firmly on his side - his time as Chancellor of the Exchequer has seen inflation and unemployment come down to 25-year lows, and mortgage rates are at their lowest since the Sixties. It is not difficult to see why he's smiling and relaxed.

But just like the Premiership champions, Brown has his detractors. Some accuse him of being aloof and arrogant, and say that Labour has failed to make a dent on the longer-term goals of improving public services and productivity, vital for raising living standards.

In a remarkably candid defence of his four-year tenure, Brown said his policies had helped 'restore the work ethic' in parts of the country, and he went out of his way to give credit to other government departments. He also gave the first indication of Labour's plans for a second term, arguing that, as in the US, reforms aimed at increasing productivity take time to produce results.

The Chancellor rejected criticism that New Labour had wasted its first term by keeping too tight a rein on public spending.

'We had a £28bn deficit; we had the prospect of a return to the old stop-go of the past with inflation rising. Disappointing as it was for some of the people staffing the public services, they must not forget that it's only because we tackled the deficit and took difficult decisions, some of which were very unpopular, that we managed to create the foundation from which we can build these sustainable rises.'

Though spending growth has been slower than under the last Conservative government, Brown maintained that its quality was much better, and said spending would grow much faster over the next three years: 'What happened under the Major government was that more money was being spent, but on unemployment and debt interest. Because we've managed to reduce debt from 44 per cent to almost 30 per cent, we are now having to pay substantially less in interest payments, and that is additional money going to education and health.

'So there are two things that have really happened. First, we are able to sustainably invest more and, second, more of what we are able to invest is going to the vital public services, the frontline services. When people look at that turnaround they'll see that it is now possible to look forward to sustainable im-provements in healthcare, education and transport services.'

Brown then hinted at Labour's manifesto plans for the second term, where he will marry the pursuit of better public services with the Holy Grail of improved productivity in the economy. He drew parallels with the US during the Clinton years. In the first term there was big employment growth and little productivity growth. In Clinton's second term, this enlarged workforce became more productive. 'I think we are moving into that second phase in Britain, where we are managing to combine employment growth with productivity growth,' he said.

Indeed the Chancellor dropped a heavy hint that he saw the strong pound as an unspoken pillar of promoting productivity growth in the economy.

He said: 'Manufacturing has in my view responded very well to the challenge that's been presented by the weaker euro, and I think that the innovation that has taken place in manufacturing, despite all the difficulties, is something that is increasing productivity and yielding output gains as well.' But he refused to reply directly to the question of whether the pound was competitive at current rates.

However, the Chancellor indicated that he thought other European countries were on his side about infrastructure spending being more important than a strict interpretation of the stability and growth pact which, technically, is in conflict with his own fiscal rules.

Towards the end of our interview the Chancellor, who is in charge of the election campaign, waxed lyrical about the way New Labour's first term had prepared the groundwork for the second. For the first time in public, he linked his welfare-to-work programme to the reinstallation of the work ethic that he implied had withered under Thatcherism.

'At the first press conference when we made the Bank of England independent, I said that I wanted to restore the objective that had been shared by many governments after the Forties, that we pursue high and stable levels of growth and employment, with the prospect over time that we could restore full employment to this country. But we know that in the modern world you cannot create a full-employment society unless you have a highly productive economy.

'We set out to create stability, a restoration of the work ethic in the areas where it had been dissipated, and to start to rebuild our public services. We're obviously prepared to be judged by the changes we've made so far, but I think our message to the British people is that there is a lot more to do, the work certainly goes on in rebuilding our public services, it goes on in trying to rebuild our productivity growth rate, and in trying to rebuild the employment potential of many communities which have suffered heavily over the past 20 or 30 years.'

Brown promised 'imaginative ways' to tackle and abolish poverty among children and pensioners and 'more radical reforms' of the New Deal. 'These are big challenges ahead, and challenges that obviously we cannot achieve in a period of one month or a year, or even the past Parliament,' he said.

So 7 June it is then.

All the world to play for, says Brown

fields.headline: Lloyds faces £3bn forced disposal
fields.trailText: Lloyds TSB may be forced to sell Abbey National's large consumer finance unit, First National, to gain clearance for the £18 billion takeover of its high street rival.
fields.body:
Lloyds TSB may be forced to sell Abbey National's large consumer finance unit, First National, to gain clearance for the £18 billion takeover of its high street rival.

The hostile bid is being investigated by the Competition Commission after the Office of Fair Trading concluded that the takeover would restrict competition in the current account and small business markets.

Last week the Commission warned that the bid may be blocked altogether - or it could force Lloyds TSB to sell its mortgage subsidiary, Cheltenham & Gloucester, as a condition for clearing the bid.

However, it has now emerged that the Commission may also demand the disposal of First National as a remedy, according to news service ShareCall, though it is unclear whether that would be in addition to the sale of C&G. 'It's an area we are looking into, and First National is one of the options for divestment, as are other businesses such as Cheltenham & Gloucester,' said a spokeswoman.

Some analysts say Abbey's takeover could give Lloyds TSB more than 25 per cent of the consumer finance market.

The story has come to light amid rumours that Lloyds TSB may offer to sell First National as an olive branch to regulators. It could be worth up to £3bn. Prime candidates for the business would include Bank of Scotland, which aborted its own merger talks with Abbey National after Lloyds entered the fray.

First National is one of Britain's biggest consumer credit businesses, with loan assets of about £8.5bn. Its activities include mortgages, car finance and in-store credit deals for shoppers.

webTitle: Beyond petroleum to what, ask greens

fields.headline: Beyond petroleum to what, ask greens
fields.standfirst: BP Amoco faces a tough AGM, says  Roger Cowe
fields.trailText: BP Amoco faces a tough AGM, says Roger Cowe
fields.body:
On Thursday there will be a fierce debate on two controversial resolutions at BP Amoco's annual meeting.

It will be the culmination of a difficult couple of months, during which the company's stock has plummeted with the environmentalists it has been striving to court, with US shareholders who have been given the cold shoulder, and with others in the UK who pursue socially responsible investing (SRI).

BP will win the vote but it has lost friends in the process. The pre-AGM shenanigans also raise serious questions about the effectiveness of SRI as it has evolved in Britain over the past couple of years.

There will be two critical resolutions on the agenda in addition to the usual clutch of innocuous items. One, backed by Greenpeace, calls on BP to publish its strategy for exiting the fossil-fuels business. The second demands the sale of its investment in PetroChina, the Chinese oil company that is under attack for its involvement in Tibet and the human rights record of its parent company.

Until the end of February, BP was facing four resolutions, not two. The other two were also about Tibet and global warming, and they have failed to make the final agenda owing to what critics describe as hard-line, legalistic manoeuvres by the company. The group told the shareholders behind the motions - coalitions of pressure groups and social investment funds - that they do not conform to UK company law requirements.

BP cited legal opinion that investors holding American depository receipts (ADRs) are not technically shareholders so their support did not count towards the 100 names needed to lodge a resolution in the UK. The lawyers also said the resolutions were effectively attempting to amend the company's articles, so should be lodged as special resolutions.

Greenpeace and the Free Tibet campaign managed to rewrite and resubmit their efforts with the requisite shareholder backing and within the tight timescale required. The other groups could not. The affair has left BP's reputation for openness and conciliation in tatters.

'BP put up unreasonable and discriminatory barriers to us filing,' said Simon Billeness, senior research analyst at the US social investor Trillium Asset Management, and the proposer of an environmental resolution last year that won backing from one in eight of BP's shareholders.

'The problem is their inflexible insistence on governing a global company according to nineteenth-century UK company law,' he added. 'But they have really created more problems for themselves.'

Craig Mackenzie, head of corporate governance at Friends Ivory & Sime, shares the more conciliatory attitude of UK shareholders. But he said: 'It was carelessly handled from a reputation point of view. It is not good management to knock back these resolutions if you are committed to openness.'

BP insists it has simply followed the rules. But this tis undermined by the fact that it raised no objection to a similar resolution, backed by US ADR holders, at last year's annual meeting.

Stephanie Tunmore, the Greenpeace campaigner behind resolution 18 on Thursday, said: 'BP has shot itself in the foot. There is a lot of anger over the way they have dealt with this.'

Pirc, the corporate-governance group that advises many local-authority pension funds, has described the company's behaviour as 'corporate arrogance'.

While BP stands accused of arrogance, SRI funds face questions about their effectiveness. The growing ranks of funds at companies such as Henderson, CGNU and Friends Provident might have been expected to back the resolutions as social and environmental responsibility is what they are all about. But most seem reluctant to do so, raising questions about whether SRI is really just a marketing gimmick rather than a serious attempt to change the way the City behaves.

Pirc has advised its clients to back the Greenpeace resolution. Stuart Bell, Pirc's head of research, said he could see no problem with supporting the resolution and he was 'perplexed' by the attitude of SRI fund managers.

Their failure to come out against BP has raised fears that the recent extension of ethical investing into mainstream fund management has merely resulted in ethical investors being sucked into the traditional City culture of non-confrontation.

'There is a question about whether investment managers are the appropriate people to deliver corporate change,' said one observer. 'Maybe they are too conflicted, too constrained by short-term demands.'

Mackenzie of Friends Ivory & Sime disputes this. Like other social investors, he argues that fund managers have to take their voting duties seriously and cannot support the Greenpeace resolution because of doubts about some of the wording.

But he insists that pressure from funds like his will push BP along the road to addressing the climate change threat to their core oil business. 'I hope we can persuade them to publish a detailed policy position on climate-change,' he said.

Tunmore regretted the lack of support from funds that are supposed to be pressing for action on climate change but said the size of the vote was less important than the fact that BP has been forced to address the issue.

To apply serious pressure, however, organisations like Greenpeace need to win significant backing - like last year's 13 per cent vote.

If companies are going to make it more difficult for such resolutions to appear on agendas, and even SRI funds are going to shy away from backing those that do make it, campaigners may feel it is better to go back to the old tactics of demonstration and disruption rather than debate.

The second demands the sale of its investment in PetroChina, the Chinese oil company that is under attack for its involvement in Tibet and the human rights record of its parent company. Until the end of February, BP was facing four resolutions, not two. The other two were also about Tibet and global warming, and they have failed to make the final agenda owing to what critics describe as hard-line, legalistic manoeuvres by the company. The group told the shareholders behind the motions - coalitions of pressure groups and social investment funds - that they do not conform to UK company law requirements. BP cited legal opinion that investors holding American depository receipts (ADRs) are not technically shareholders so their support did not count towards the 100 names needed to lodge a resolution in the UK. The lawyers also said the resolutions were effectively attempting to amend the company's articles, so should be lodged as special resolutions. Greenpeace and the Free Tibet campaign managed to rewrite and resubmit their efforts with the requisite shareholder backing and within the tight timescale required. The other groups could not. The affair has left BP's reputation for openness and conciliation in tatters. 'BP put up unreasonable and discriminatory barriers to us filing,' said Simon Billeness, senior research analyst at the US social investor Trillium Asset Management, and the proposer of an environmental resolution last year that won backing from one in eight of BP's shareholders. 'The problem is their inflexible insistence on governing a global company according to nineteenth-century UK company law,' he added. 'But they have really created more problems for themselves.' Craig Mackenzie, head of corporate governance at Friends Ivory & Sime, shares the more conciliatory attitude of UK shareholders. But he said: 'It was carelessly handled from a reputation point of view. It is not good management to knock back these resolutions if you are committed to openness.' BP insists it has simply followed the rules. But this tis undermined by the fact that it raised no objection to a similar resolution, backed by US ADR holders, at last year's annual meeting. Stephanie Tunmore, the Greenpeace campaigner behind resolution 18 on Thursday, said: 'BP has shot itself in the foot. There is a lot of anger over the way they have dealt with this.' Pirc, the corporate-governance group that advises many local-authority pension funds, has described the company's behaviour as 'corporate arrogance'. While BP stands accused of arrogance, SRI funds face questions about their effectiveness. The growing ranks of funds at companies such as Henderson, CGNU and Friends Provident might have been expected to back the resolutions as social and environmental responsibility is what they are all about. But most seem reluctant to do so, raising questions about whether SRI is really just a marketing gimmick rather than a serious attempt to change the way the City behaves. Pirc has advised its clients to back the Greenpeace resolution. Stuart Bell, Pirc's head of research, said he could see no problem with supporting the resolution and he was 'perplexed' by the attitude of SRI fund managers. Their failure to come out against BP has raised fears that the recent extension of ethical investing into mainstream fund management has merely resulted in ethical investors being sucked into the traditional City culture of non-confrontation. Tunmore regretted the lack of support from funds that are supposed to be pressing for action on climate change but said the size of the vote was less important than the fact that BP has been forced to address the issue. To apply serious pressure, however, organisations like Greenpeace need to win significant backing - like last year's 13 per cent vote. If companies are going to make it more difficult for such resolutions to appear on agendas, and even SRI funds are going to shy away from backing those that do make it, campaigners may feel it is better to go back to the old tactics of demonstration and disruption rather than debate.

webTitle: Ritblat and Saudis lead race for BP's slice of Mayfair

fields.headline: Ritblat and Saudis lead race for BP's slice of Mayfair
fields.trailText: It's the Mayfair sale of the century and legions of salivating property investors are busting a gut to sink their teeth into it, writes Nick Mathiason .
fields.body:
It's the Mayfair sale of the century and legions of salivating property investors are busting a gut to sink their teeth into it, writes Nick Mathiason .

BP Amoco's pension fund is selling a 10-acre Mayfair estate in and around Berkeley Square for up to £330 million. This weekend, its trustees are close to deciding which blue-blooded aristocrat will seize control - an announcement is expected this week.

Those in the frame are a veritable who's who of the fabulously wealthy.

They include Britain's third-richest man, the Duke of Westminster; a mysterious Syrian; members of the Saudi Arabian royal family; the secretive Barclay brothers; and veteran British Land chairman John Ritblat.

The portfolio consists of 100 buildings on the west side of Berkeley Square - made famous by the wartime song featuring a singing nightingale - plus properties in neighbouring streets.

Tenants include famous haunts of the well-heeled including gunmaker Holland & Holland, Annabel's nightclub and the Clermont Club, once frequented by Lord Lucan.

Apart from the cachet of owning some of Britain's most famous street names, investors will be eager to actively manage this estate by ejecting tenants and redeveloping buildings to create more space.

But many businesses fear a new owner without a 'Mayfair sensibility' will cause havoc. 'I fear for the future of this area if an outsider with little understanding of Mayfair wants to make changes in a desperate effort to get a return on their capital,' said one.

The long-standing favourite to scoop Berkeley Square is the Duke of West minster's property company, Grosvenor Estates. Grosvenor is the dominant landowner in Mayfair - one of the world's most expensive tracts of real estate. But it has bid just £310m - £20m shy of the top bid.

Insiders say BP's trustees would have liked to do a deal with Westminster because they believe the aristocratic landowner has impeccable credentials. But this appears unlikely.

Although his Mayfair assets, worth about £1.6 billion, made him the logical choice, two other bidders have emerged from the pack.

The Saudi Arabian Royal family led by Prince Alwaleed bin Talal bin Abdul Aziz - said to be the richest man outside America - is believed to be the leading bidder. In 1997 the Saudis bought £120m of property in Berkeley Square. And two months ago Alwaleed banked a profit of more than £40m from the sale of two-thirds of his shares in Canary Wharf.

The shortlist includes secretive Syrian-born investor Simon Halabi, who is poised to buy the Lanesborough Hotel on London's Hyde Park Corner for what would be a world record room-rate. Halabi, a Mayfair resident, is part-funded by 'Black' Jack Dellal, a property tycoon worth more than £800m.

And insiders were staggered 10 days ago when Ritblat of British Land posted a bid of over £300m. He hadn't even entered the first-round bidding. Ritblat, poised to securitise his Sheffield Meadowhall shopping centre for more than £1bn, owns many prestigious properties in London, including the Broadgate office complex.The rumour mill suggests the contest is now a fight between Ritblat and the Saudis.

webTitle: Left to sink in sea of debt

fields.headline: Left to sink in sea of debt
fields.standfirst: Another of Britain's great shipbuilding names, Cammell Laird, faces closure again despite a healthy order book, but all is not lost yet, says  Oliver Morgan
fields.trailText: Another of Britain's great shipbuilding names, Cammell Laird, faces closure again despite a healthy order book, but all is not lost yet, says Oliver Morgan
fields.body:
When John Quigley answered his phone last Wednesday morning he knew the news was bad. On the line was Brett Martin, corporate development director of the Merseyside-based shipbuilder Cammell Laird. Martin told Quigley, the AEEU union's shipbuilding national officer, that the company's shares had been suspended. There would be an announcement later in the day.

Quigley, a laconic Scot, was uncharacteristically furious. But unlike his colleagues in the union's metals division, who publicly lambasted steelmaker Corus last month over its treatment of workers, his anger was not aimed at the company.

Instead, as he briefed colleagues, the brunt of his criticism was reserved for US cruise giant Carnival, owner of the Italian shipping line Costa Crociere, which had terminated work on an extension for its vessel Costa Classica in November - after Cammell had spent £40 million on it.

Since then, Cammell's financial position and the future of its workers had been in jeopardy. The company's shares collapsed from more than £1 in October to 6p on Thursday.

Quigley was also frustrated with the Government. In October it had not awarded any of six valuable naval support vessels to Cammell - two went to Belfast's Harland & Wolff and four to a German yard. Second, it had not provided a bankable package of support under EU rules to help Cammell win a $500m order for two cruise ships for another operator, Luxus. Quigley told The Observer: 'It is most unfortunate, because here was the first real chance to get British shipbuilding back into the profitable cruise market since the 1970s.'

Cammell lost the naval contract before Costa pulled out. Many at the Birkenhead yard feel they were penalised for creating what, last autumn, seemed like a successful business.

Meanwhile, the atmosphere at the company's Birkenhead and Tyneside yards as its 1,800 employees arrived on Wednesday was a mixture of business as usual - there are ship contracts worth £40m under way - and deep anxiety.

Ted Gilbertson, the AEEU's regional officer, heard the news on the morning TV. He said: 'People have continued to work, which is a great credit to them. But the question on everybody's minds is are we going to get paid next week? There is frustration and fear and anger because people fear the worst.' He blames the Costa fiasco, saying: 'There were two effects - the company was not paid, and it put its financial position and technical competence in question with other potential customers and with the DTI.'

When it came, at just before 5pm, Wednesday's announcement was bad, but it did not spell immediate closure at Birkenhead or Tyneside. Instead receivers were called in.

It could be the end of the line for a historic shipping name that has already had two lives. In its first incarnation, the company, founded in 1824, became one of the world's great shipbuilding names, making the Ark Royal aircraft carrier and Cunard liner Mauretania . But competition from the Far East in the 1980s undermined the competitiveness of UK shipbuilding, and Cammell followed other famous names into closure in 1993.

It was rescued by John Stafford, an accountant and owner of ship repairer Coastline Industries, who refocused on higher-margin ship repair and conversion work. Profits rose and expansion followed, growing overseas operations, which now employ 1,700. Last autumn it still appeared healthy.

Then came the Costa débcle. The Classica had sailed to Birkenhead from Genoa, but it was ordered home half way. Costa said it wanted arbitration because Cammell was overrunning its deadlines and there were technical problems. Cammell countered that independent reports said overruns could be made up, and that these and engineering problems were caused by Costa changing specifications. Jobs began to haemorrhage - some were laid off in the week before Christmas.

Corporate development director Martin said: 'They say there were technical issues but you have to ask yourself why did they send the ship off and then try to renegotiate the contract while it was at sea? I think they acted in bad faith.' But Cammell's arguments came to nothing. In January, Costa confirmed it was not going ahead.

The shipbuilder was still hopeful that the Luxus liners - contingent on a DTI aid package - would fill the gap. But negotiations with the DTI foundered. The uncontroversial part of the package was $40m of aid under the shipbuilding intervention fund. But there were problems with guarantees Luxus's bankers required and on a performance bond that the DTI required in return from Cammell. The DTI improved its offer but it was not enough. Meanwhile Stafford, the man who had rescued the business, resigned on 29 January. Martin said: 'I'm not bitter. Perhaps other governments would have tried harder.'

Last month, Cammell, creaking under debt, called in investment banker Close Brothers to restructure the company. It was too late. The trigger was a deadline this Tuesday for a £7.5m payment to bondholders, along with a £10m payment on its overdraft.

The bond payment was due on €125m (£77m) of loan notes issued in November to help finance expansion from ship repair into big-time work like Costa and Luxus.

Before the offering, Cammell had operated off a £46m overdraft facility with Royal Bank of Scotland. RBS had extended this facility, on condition that payment from Costa came in on time. It did not.

The financial markets have been expecting doom at Cammell. As bad news gathered pace, the value of the bonds followed the share price: this month they were trading at 16 per cent of face value, indicating the market expected a default.

At the time of the bond issue, analysts were puzzled as to why management had not gone for a rights issue. One said it indicated they were nervous about the Classica contract, and felt this would have prejudiced a rights issue. Martin says simply that market conditions were not favourable.

Encouragingly, ABN Amro's engineering analyst, Sandy Morris, says: 'This remains a very efficient ship-repair business. Problems started when it began to overstretch with these big contracts. There is still a viable business here.'

Receivers are negotiating with customers, including the MoD, P&O and Stena, over payment for work done on the ships currently on Cammell's books. They are also seeking a £5m overdraft for the four to five weeks during which they are optimistic a sale can be agreed.

Time may be running out, but the clock has not stopped yet for Cammell or its management.
