webTitle: The call of the wild side of the market

fields.headline: The call of the wild side of the market
fields.trailText: Strangely, trading in the grey market became stronger as last week wore on. Whether it was the euphoria of the forthcoming holiday or not, volatility was unexpectedly high. The Street became a Street of Dreams once more.
fields.body:
Strangely, trading in the grey market became stronger as last week wore on. Whether it was the euphoria of the forthcoming holiday or not, volatility was unexpectedly high. The Street became a Street of Dreams once more.

Amazon.com and Yahoo led a strong rebound in the new economy at the beginning of the week, continued by Cisco Systems, Sun Microsystems and JDS Uniphase later in the week, all regular favourites of the spread better. Ebay, too, won plenty of support: stronger-than-expected data saw hordes of speculators return to the net's greatest auction house.

The recovery in America made European bourses smile too, and inspired significant gains all over the Continent.

This increased volatility in index values tempted many options strategists to find ways of taking advantage of 'inflated' premiums. The particular favourite remains the Nasdaq for most, with the belief prevailing that any low, if not already visited, cannot be much below current levels.

Covered call writing is popular: selling a June Nasdaq call 150 points out of the money for roughly 100 points, and buying the index, would net the fortunate speculator 250 units should the Nasdaq rise through the call level - a not insignificant return on an index valued only at 1,600.

The downside lies in owning the Nasdaq at 1,500, as the market slides lower, but at these levels many begin to feel more comfortable owning the pariahs of last year. Surely the slide must stop soon!

The great advantage of equity spread betting over the physical trading of shares is the ability to sell short. Popular sales centre on leisure stocks, the perception being that belts may have to be tightened this year. Popular buys have been stocks of the new age, as well as the banks. The sustained period of low interest rates is thought likely to underpin this sector for many months to come.

Currency speculators have found the road rather rocky of late. The fall in dollar interest rates, coupled with the intransigence of the ECB, should in theory make the euro a more attractive buy, as its interest return on the euro improves against the dollar's.

This idea has been shown to be too naive. As the ECB appears to deny that any action is required on its part in response to slowing growth and demand across Europe, so investor confidence in the currency is waning, and a lot of the shine that the euro gained earlier this year is now being lost.

The mood of those who speculate on the general election has turned again. Two weeks ago, there were ready sellers at 374 of the number of seats the Labour Party would claim at the next general election. Now, the mood has quietened down once more, and Labour supporters have returned to edge this price slightly higher now.

If there is one issue upon which people can be guaranteed to bet with their hearts, rather than their heads, it is elections. Despite an overwhelming lead in the polls, which suggests that the result of 1997 can indeed be repeated, that thought clearly galls the majority of punters, who are quick to sell the Government's chances at the slightest hint that the tide may turn.

How the market works

Spread betting is a relatively new form of gambling that has started to draw a huge following in the Square Mile. Spread bets can be made on virtually anything - from the number of throw-ins during a football match to the valuation of a company, or even a whole market, over a certain period.

One of the reasons spread betting is popular in the City is that it allows gamblers to bet both up and down. So, if punters think the Nasdaq is due for another slide south, they can back that hunch. In a bear market this option is invaluable.

But punters should be aware that spread betting carries huge risks. This is because gamblers can bet on the difference between a prediction of what will happen and the actual result. A bookmaker will set a 'spread', and the punter bets on whether the result will be higher than the spread (by 'buying') or lower (by 'selling').

An example: the FTSE is at 5,500 and you believe it will fall by the end of the week. The firm is offering a spread of 5,500 to 5,800, so you opt to sell at £1 a point. But US markets rally and drag the FTSE up to finish the week at 6,000. So you owe the firm £200 - 6,000 minus 5,800, multiplied by £1. Given the risks, it is no surprise that spread betting firms require a deposit up front.

More cautious punters will utilise 'stop' measures to reduce their exposure to the downside. Sophisticated spread betting fans will use 'call' options - the right to buy at a specified price on a particular date. Or they may look at a 'put' option - the right to sell at a specified price on a particular date.

'Covered call writing' happens when a punter sells an option for a specified price at a specified time. The person buying the option pays the seller a premium, thus limiting the seller's exposure. If the option is 'out of the money' its specified price is above the current level for a call but below the current level for a put - and speculators can make a killing. Some speculators are now eyeing options on Nasdaq. As many Nasdaq options are currently out of the money the speculators believe they can buy options on the cheap - and clean up when the market recovers.

The Gladiator is the nom de plume of a professional spread better. This column is the first in a regular series

'Covered call writing' happens when a punter sells an option for a specified price at a specified time. The person buying the option pays the seller a premium, thus limiting the seller's exposure. If the option is 'out of the money' its specified price is above the current level for a call but below the current level for a put - and speculators can make a killing. Some speculators are now eyeing options on Nasdaq. As many Nasdaq options are currently out of the money the speculators believe they can buy options on the cheap - and clean up when the market recovers. The Gladiator is the nom de plume of a professional spread better. This column is the first in a regular series

webTitle: How Marconi lovers misread the signals

fields.headline: How Marconi lovers misread the signals
fields.trailText: There is, it seems, no right or wrong in business, just good and bad timing. Marconi, the revamped former GEC, is the latest firm to fall victim to this.
fields.body:
There is, it seems, no right or wrong in business, just good and bad timing. Marconi, the revamped former GEC, is the latest firm to fall victim to this.

Eighteen months ago, when GEC spun off its defence activities to British Aerospace, the group was praised. After the £7 billion sale the new Marconi, reviving a classic British marque, would focus on the fast-growing market for telecommunications equipment instead of the uncertain arms industry.

Two rapid-fire US deals - the acquisition of Fore Systems for £3bn and of Reltec for £1.3bn - confirmed Marconi as an aggressive player with new economy ambitions. Seen as Europe's emerging rival to US giant Lucent, Marconi shares soared, reaching £12.50 at their peak last autumn.

Now, with the stock bumping along at little more than £3, that all looks classic top-of-the-market stuff. And Marconi finds itself bracketed with low-tech ICI, which also sought higher-margin havens with a transforming new deal four years ago: right idea, but awful timing.

While ICI's management, headed by the popular Brendan O'Neill, has barely been tainted by its misfortune, the same cannot now be said for Marconi chairman Lord Simpson and his underling, John Mayo. In the City's eyes, these two dealmakers have committed a cardinal sin. Namely, during the hi-tech carnage they stayed silent, ignored - until last week - City pleadings for an update when rivals' profit warnings were coming thick and fast, and left all the middle-aged scribblers at City brokers groping in the dark.

All, that is - or so it seems to a few frothing analysts - apart from house brokers CSFB and UBS Warburg, who were prescient enough to downgrade forecasts ahead of last week's announcement of 3,000 job losses. Naturally, those smart analysts say it was just good broking. There will be repercussions. If there's one thing the City hates more than nasty surprises, it's being made to look stupid.

The extremes of City feeling now over Simpson and chums are neatly encapsulated by the different approaches taken last week by the market's two most influential opinion-formers: the Financial Times's Lex column and the Wall Street Journal's Heard in Europe.

While Lex was at its most forgiving, the WSJ was scathing. With justification, the paper pointed out that Marconi's estimated £800 million operating profit for the year was only in the current range of broker's estimates because analysts have been cutting forecasts. And reference to operating profit leaves scope for further unpleasant surprises above and below the line. A couple of leaks in last Sunday's press only sharpened the paper's pique. Until it stopped mumbling with rocks in its mouth, the WSJ said, Marconi was a 'B-list actor', and one to avoid.

The FT 's more measured judgment may well be right: at these levels, it looks as if the shares should recover. In the short term, however, its US rival's rant - reflecting the tone of many of the big brokerages - is likely to be more influential. Despite a listing on Nasdaq and a big US roadshow last year, only 12 per cent of Marconi's shares are held by US investors.

The prospect of more US buying was one factor propelling Marconi to giddy heights. That now looks elusive, and investors should remain wary until the annual results on 17 May, at least.

Fat cats are back

Fat cats are firmly back in fashion. Last week's row over acquisition-inspired rewards at Royal Bank of Scotland will be mirrored this week when Schroders grants former chairman Sir Win Bischoff a £5m 'special bonus' for flogging off its corporate finance division to Salomons.

With the Schroder family holding 47 per cent of the shares, the National Association of Pension Funds is far less likely to win this battle than it ever was with the Scots at RBS. It gains full marks for trying, but after three defeats - Vodafone, RBS and Schroders this week - institutions ought to gang up and issue an ultimatum to any further boards helping themselves to a few million just for doing their job.

Ironically the fat £800,000 'guaranteed bonus' due to new Marks & Spencer chief executive Luc Vandevelde looks less galling. Given the scale of past losses, the big surprise at M&S is that the hard decision to close its loss-making European stores was not taken much earlier.

Takeovers, however, rarely add value for shareholders, unlike with organic growth (just look at what Brooks Brothers didn't do for M&S). They happen mainly because of management ambition. The prospect of huge transaction-related bonuses distorts the rationale further.

It is also a rule of the Takeover Code that any changes to directors' remuneration because of big deals has to be declared at the time. Maybe the Panel, too, might make its views known?

fields.headline: Short and sweet
fields.trailText: Short and sweet
fields.body:
A few years ago, Penguin Books struck it rich with a series of short books, 60p editions of extracts from some of its classic authors. The inspiration for this wheeze was said to have come from Spain. My own favourite, then and now, was a tiny edition of Marcus Aurelius's Meditations.

Part of Penguin's success was attributable to the celebration of its sixtieth birthday. The book trade, in a rare burst of enthusiasm for innovation, gave so much support to these little books that they monopolised the best-seller lists. For a few heady months, it seemed that such books were to be a kind of philosopher's stone that would transform the dross of Grub Street into pure gold.

A number of imprints, notably Orion, attempted to conjure the Penguin alchemy, failed to use the right magic and lost money. When the gold-rush subsided, it was clear that short books were all very well as part of anniversary celebrations for a much-loved national institution, but that in the merciless arena of the book trade, they presented two giant problems for the trade - where to stock them and how to sell enough units to generate a plausible return on investment.

Apart from these mundane difficulties, the idea of the short book had a lot to recommend it to the general reader. It suited the pace of modern life. It was both portable and cheap. It encouraged readers into experimentation. And it fitted into a tradition that encompasses Thomas More's Utopia and George Orwell's Animal Farm.

Short books were also a crisp retort to the curse of the (often American) Big Book. As more and more British publishers found themselves not merely buying the rights to American titles, but physically importing American typesetting, American bindings and even American covers, the elephantiasis that's always afflicted the American book (like the American motor car) was beginning to be noticeable in British books as well. Who, in recent years, has not struggled with Norman Davies's doorstop history of England, The Isles?

The benign influence of short books was sustained long after they had vanished from the shops. There's no way of proving this, but I believe that the phenomenal success of Dava Sobel's Longitude in 1996 was due in part to a renewed public appetite for good writing in readily digestible form.

Longitude inspired a host of grisly imitations, but none of these damaged the genre's attraction. Some publishers, notably Profile, managed to find a market for short books by, for instance, Alan Bennett and Colm Tóibín. Never mind that you could probably make money publishing Alan Bennett on discarded chip paper, the success of Profile books paved the way for what is just beginning to look like a trend. This month, in fact, sees the publication of no less than three kinds of short book.

First of all, from Granta there's Ian Jack's brilliant essay on the Hatfield rail disaster, The Crash That Stopped Britain (£4.99 pp96). Second, there is the Oxford University Press relaunch of its 'world's classics', important books by the best English writers at prices between £2.99 and £5.99.

Finally, there is the launch of the aptly named Short Books, a new imprint that claims to produce 'informative, entertaining reads at a manageable length' (ie about 20,000 words) The first list contains six fascinating short lives, ranging from Rupert Christiansen's Arthur Hugh Clough to Kate Hubbard's Bess of Hardwick, both published at £4.99. A second list of promising journalistic commissions will follow in August.

Standing somewhere between a magazine editor and a publisher, the co-founder of Short Books, Rebecca Nicolson, a former journalist, says: 'Like it or not, reading habits are changing. In an age when value for time matters as much as value for money, shortness is here to stay.' This may very well be true, but the question is: will the British book trade remember the success of the Penguin campaign when the Short Books sales reps come to call?

And if they do make the new imprint welcome and find a space for the new titles among the piled-high displays of Delia Smith and Jamie Oliver, will the public respond in sufficient numbers to make the venture profitable? Here, as always, content is all.

The Short Books list of future contributors includes Paul Theroux, William Boyd and W.G. Sebald. If - and it's a big if - the British book trade and the British reading public can be persuaded that less is more, Short Books will quickly look like a very good idea whose time has come.

webTitle: Well, at least it's low on calories

fields.headline: Well, at least it's low on calories
fields.standfirst: If you loved Four Weddings and swooned over Notting Hill, you'll like Bridget Jones's Diary. If, on the other hand...
fields.trailText: Philip French: ...a moderately amusing film in conventional sitcom fashion, and is a form of flattire, the genre in which flattery poses as satire
fields.body:
Are men especially attracted to stupid, pretty women? This is the view of popular culture since the introduction of universal female suffrage. First, there was the dizzy blonde in pursuit of a millionaire husband, who reached her apogee in Marilyn Monroe. She was succeeded by the ditzy brunette, a rather smarter type, but less orderly and ruthless, generically known as 'kooks', played by Shirley MacLaine, Audrey Hepburn, and Liza Minnelli, reaching an apotheosis in Diane Keaton's Annie Hall.

Now we have the airhead heroine, usually a natural blonde, vulnerable, a terrible worrier, riven by doubts in a post-feminist manner, still looking for a rich Mr Right and best exemplified by Lisa Kudrow's Phoebe in Friends and the heroine of Helen Fielding's newspaper column, novel and now film, Bridget Jones's Diary.

From the same production team as Four Weddings and a Funeral and Notting Hill, this is a moderately amusing film in conventional sitcom fashion, and is a form of flattire, the genre in which flattery poses as satire. It appears to be sending up the trendy metropolitan media world in which the unmarried thirtysomething Bridget works, the affluent, Home Counties, middle-class circle of her parents and their grotesque friends, and the insecure, man-chasing Bridget herself. But the filmmakers are uncritically in love with their heroine and her milieux and have romanticised them to an almost laughable degree.

The office cad, Daniel Cleaver (Hugh Grant), Bridget's Mr Wrong, flirts with her by computer and seduces her, drives a Mercedes convertible and lives in a Thamesside apartment of breathtaking luxury. Her Mr Right, the strong, silent Mark Darcy (Colin Firth), is a celebrated civil rights lawyer of impeccable probity whose parents live in a country house that could give Castle Howard a run for its tourist dollar. The film's London is a clean, sparkling place out of a tourist brochure and the idyllic opening and closing Yuletide scenes in the snow are like Dickens at his most celebratory.

As appealingly played by Renée Zellweger, the film's Bridget is doubly affected in that we have an American affecting a plausible British accent, but the Sloaney drawl she uses is itself an affectation. She is also inconsistent in her naivety. In the book, she knowingly talks of herself as a 'child of Cosmopolitan culture', yet doesn't know the sporting phrase 'throwing a match'. In the film, despite having a degree in English and working as a publicist for a smart publisher, she thinks F.R. Leavis is still alive and when being interviewed for a TV job professes to believe that El Niño is a Latin American dance.

These are the things we laughed at in Monroe and Judy Holliday. They are also what appeal to both the sly suave Daniel, and the decent, kindly Darcy. In Daniel's case, they make her easier to seduce and cast aside; in Darcy's, they're the perfect attributes of the submissive, admiring partner he requires.

The co-writers - Helen Fielding, Andrew Davies (in whose TV adaptation of Sense and Sensibility Colin Firth became a star) and Richard Curtis (author of Four Weddings and a Funeral and Notting Hill ) - have largely dropped the diary format after the opening few minutes, though the diary itself is used as a plot device in the swooningly romantic climax.

We thus see Bridget more objectively than in the book, though whether this makes her narcissism and comic whingeing less tiresome is another matter. In both novel and film, we are clearly intended to find her not merely funny but also sympathetic, moving and exemplary of our age - as Owen might have said (Deborah Owen, the literary agent, that is, not Wilfred Owen), the poetry is in the self-pity.

Of the film's three authors, Richard Curtis seems the dominant influence. What one might regard as his Hugh Grant Trilogy (Four Weddings, Notting Hill and Bridget Jones) resembles Howard Hawks's John Wayne Trilogy ( Rio Bravo, El Dorado and Rio Lobo) which, despite having different literary sources, are versions of the same story with similar characters and settings. 'I'm not a damn bit interested in whether somebody thinks this is a copy,' said Hawks, 'because the copy made more money than the original, and I was pleased with it.'

So almost everything appears familiar, from the character who obsessively uses the word 'fuck' (as if laughter would flow exponentially from the repetition) through the climactic car chase to the calculatedly embarrassing scenes in which the heroes and heroines make idiots of themselves in public.

The most excruciating of the latter comes when Bridget delivers a disastrous speech at a book launch attended by some leading figures in the London literary world, among them Salman Rushdie, who makes the most wincing personal appearance since Graham Hill congratulated Yves Montand on his success on the Monaco circuit in Grand Prix. This sequence should have been one of the film's best, because it could have enabled Sharon Maguire, making her feature debut here, to draw on her experience making documentaries.

Another Curtis device, which may well have influenced Fielding's book, is to have the heroine surrounded by a devoted group of colourfully eccentric friends, one of them the gay confidant that's mandatory for every movie heroine nowadays.

They're always there to bring her comfort and advice (and to help her with the wine and vodka), though if there were many such people at large in real life there would be queues a mile long at the admission gate of every Trappist monastery in Europe.

webTitle: Brown: let Africa have cheap drugs

fields.headline: Brown: let Africa have cheap drugs
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gordon Brown this weekend stepped up pressure on multinational pharmaceutical companies to allow developing countries access to drugs to treat serious diseases.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown this weekend stepped up pressure on multinational pharmaceutical companies to allow developing countries access to drugs to treat serious diseases.

With 25.3 million people infected with HIV in sub-Saharan Africa, Brown urged drug companies to act more quickly to avert disaster.

In an exclusive interview with The Observer, Brown said: 'They [the drug companies] must show they are putting resources into resolving these issues. We are talking about preventable deaths. We are talking about a problem that if addressed collectively by the world community could be solved.' Brown wants to set up a global fund to buy drugs to treat Aids, malaria and tuberculosis. 'Where the pharmaceutical companies have responsibilities, they've got to accept them,' he warned.

The Chancellor's comments come as 37 of the world's biggest drug companies, including the UK's GlaxoSmithKline, resume on Wednesday their court action against the South African government over what the drug companies believe is a violation of their intellectual property rights. South Africa wants to buy huge amounts of cheap, generic anti-retroviral drugs from abroad.

Brown is prepared to give pharmaceuticals R&D tax credits to make good any loss of earnings through the provision of cheap drugs and to set up a global fund to create a market for the development of such drugs. 'Only 10 per cent of medical research goes to the problems that afflict 90 per cent of the world's population,' Brown said.

The Association of British Pharmaceutical Industries said: 'It's not entirely our responsibility. We can't be an NHS for the whole of Africa.'

All the world to play for, says Brown

fields.headline: Bayern Munich (1) v Man United (0)
fields.trailText: Wednesday, ITV, 7.45pm.
fields.body:
Wednesday, ITV, 7.45pm.

Sir Alex Ferguson knows that if United are to progress they can't afford a repeat of their dismal display against Coventry when they gave away two sloppy first-half goals. 'I want us to score an early goal,' said the United manager, 'but what matters most is that we don't lose one. This will be the hardest game we will have in the Champions League this season, even if we get to the final.' Bayern, he says, will look to defend their lead and probably try to sneak an early goal as a buffer. But 'they'll have a problem if we are still in it with 20 minutes to go.'

MAN TO WATCH: Paul Scholes.

The midfielder - the joint leading scorer, with six, in the Champions League this season - was only average in the first leg. United's biggest problem this season has been a lack of away goals in Europe, but if Scholes makes some of those famous late runs into the box count, it could be bye, bye Bayern.

Real Madrid's reserves of energy are clearly running low. In particular, star player Luis Figo's form has suffered - an ironic side effect of his frequent flights around the world collecting awards. And, to make matters worse, key striker Raul is suffering from tendinitis and is doubtful for a game in which Real have to score. The one plus point for Madrid has been the consistent form of Steve McManaman who Real will rely on to supply the ammunition for Morientes.

MAN TO WATCH: Mario Jardel

In his past three games against Madrid, all for his former club Porto in the Champions League, Galatasaray's robust Brazilian striker has scored four goals, so he clearly relishes playing the Spanish giants. Madrid beware.

fields.trailText: Tuesday, ONsport 2, 7.45pm.
fields.body:
Tuesday, ONsport 2, 7.45pm.

A 4-1 win in the league last week, at Rayo Vallecano, ended a run of three consecutive defeats for Hector Cuper's men. Valencia are confident that their home form - they are unbeaten in Europe at Mestalla - will see them through. An injury to Argentine international Kily Gonzalez is a blow, but habitual substitute Vicente Rodriguez has proved an able deputy wide on the left. Cuper is set to play with two central strikers, John Carew and Juan Sanchez, with playmaker Pablo Aimar in the hole behind, and Mendieta the supplier wide on the right.

MAN TO WATCH: Gaizka Mendieta

It was almost impossible for Mendieta to maintain last season's superb form (which saw him acclaimed one of the best attacking midfielders in Europe), Cuper said recently, but goals for Spain and last week at Vallecano indicate that the livewire midfielder is back to somewhere near his best.

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: Boksic: golden goals
fields.body:
Boksic: golden goals

Middlesbrough's Alen Boksic is the only Britain-based player among the world's top 10 biggest-earning footballers. The survey, published in Spain last week, places the 31-year-old alongside Zinedine Zidane, Alessandro Del Piero, Luis Figo and Hernan Crespo, all of whom take home a nifty £3million a year, or £58,000 a week. Boro's cash has spread thickly: an Opta breakdown shows how Boksic has, so far, mopped up £1,660 for every minute he's played, £272,727 for each of his 11 goals, and a cracking £1.5m for each of his two (count them) goal assists. The 'crafty Croat' ( Mirror ) follows other big earning Boro tourists Juninho, Emerson, Ravanelli and Branca, who all wanted to play for a London club before seeing the terms on offer, and finishes behind only Alvaro Recoba (£4.5m), Raul (£3.6m), Rivaldo (£3.57m) and Batistuta (£3.45m) in the list.

Brazilian nuts go public

The Brazilian footballer arrested last week for stripping during a goal celebration is ready to sign up as a model for a gay magazine. The player, William Pereira Farias, tore off his shirt and shorts after scoring during a televised away game, then threw his shorts at the home side's fans before running away and being sent off. 'He broke the laws of respectful behaviour,' said police officer Alfredo Faria after the arrest. 'He offended the townspeople and will be suspended.' Pereira was charged with indecent exposure - a possible six-month sentence - and locked out of his house by his girlfriend. 'I thought I was going to have to sleep in the street,' he told reporters. 'It wasn't easy to make her let me in.' Now he's set to give up football for gay modelling. 'I've hardly earned anything from football, and my salary is a joke,' he revealed. 'I'm thinking carefully about the offer.'

Spurs fury fatigue: fans washed up

After 19 months of Tottenham pressure groups, chants of 'We want our Tottenham back', fury against Alan Sugar for only spending £11m on a striker, abuse hurled at George Graham, the players and each other, Spurs fans responded magnificently to the return of King Glenda against Bradford on Wednesday. 28,306 turned up - 6,700 down on the season's average, 7,300 down on the last home game v Coventry, and 7,800 down on Hod's 0-0 visit to the Lane with his Southampton side in January.

Press release of the week

'Alan Shearer To Make Debut As Metro Radio's New Signing!'

Newcastle's captain, premature pensioner and all-time least interesting person this side of Howard Wilkinson, makes his radio co-commentary debut tomorrow for Tyneside's Metro Radio. Shearer, out for the season with tendinitis, agreed to the move to the delight of radio execs, who reckon 'thousands of loyal Geordie fans' will be thrilled by the news. 'If we can't have Alan out scoring goals for us on the pitch, then we felt that the next best thing would be to get some of his expert insights live on air during the game. It's a real coup for us.' Shearer thinks so too - and if the press release is anything to go by, listeners are in for a feast: 'Alan added jokingly, "I'll be warning the lads all week that if they don't perform on Monday afternoon I'll be live on air to give them some serious stick!!".' Great!!

French: peace is for wimps

'Fair Play Day', staged in the French first division last week, collapsed in farce after 42 players were booked and two sent off. The cards made it the second most ill-disciplined weekend of the season, despite players wearing shirts saying 'Peace and foot' - short for football - and captains reading out messages of fair play. Refs also awarded six penalties: second only to a completely brutal week in December which saw 44 yellows and two reds.

Quote of the week

Big-thinker Ade Akinbiyi, in the Wolverhampton Express and Star

'I was watching the Blackburn game on TV on Sunday when it flashed on the screen that George Ndah had scored in the first minute at Birmingham. My first reaction was to ring him up. Then I remembered he was out there playing, so I rang his brother instead.'

Said & Done: david.hills@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Tigana and Brighton clinch promotion
fields.trailText: While Fulham clinched promotion from the First Division, Brighton did likewise from the Third.
fields.body:
While Fulham clinched promotion from the First Division, Brighton did likewise from the Third.

Blackburn moved a step closer to claiming the other automatic promotion spot in the First with a goalless draw at Stockport.

Preston, on the edge of the play-off zone, must be kicking themselves over their failure to put more distance between themselves and their closest rivals, Nottingham Forest.

They established a first-half lead through David Healey, but allowed John Olav Hjelde to bring Forest level in the last minute.

At the other end, Tranmere, who had raised themselves off the bottom with that tremendous midweek win against Birmingham, landed back in their dreaded old spot with a 1-0 home defeat against by Norwich.

QPR came from behind for a 1-1 draw at Portsmouth, while the other bottom three team, Crystal Palace, were hammered 4-1 at Sheffield Wednesday.

Palace had taken the lead, through Andy Morrison and, when they were trailing 2-1, Dean Austin missed a penalty. Wednesday's scoreline was matched by Gillingham.

In normal circumstances Chesterfield would also have been celebrating promotion following Hartlepool's defeat by Hull. But, of course, the champagne has had to be put on hold through the decision by a three-man league inquiry to deduct nine points from their total because of financial irregularities.

The punishment, which has been allied to a £20,000 fine and is almost certain to be rarefied this week, has been viewed with disbelief by their Third Division rivals.

Though the majority of the 90 charges against Chesterfield were unproven, Hartlepool's manager, Chris Turner - whose team would have benefited the most had Chesterfield been demoted or had 50 points deducted, as was expected - said: 'I was very surprised with the outcome.

'Where did they get nine points from? It won't change anything. Chesterfield will get promotion because they are the best team in the division but if it was illegal, their way of doing things, then it is sending out all the wrong signals to other clubs.'

Chesterfield were found guilty of contract irregularities over striker Luke Beckett during his transfer from Chester. It meant that the player was obtained at a Football League tribuna at less than the market value.

Beckett is the Spireites' top scorer this season with 14 goals and and his presence clearly rankles in a division where money is tight.

Mansfield manager Billy Dearden is particularly aggrieved. 'We had agreed terms with Beckett but when Chesterfield showed an interest in him he went there,' he said. 'He has scored goals and he shouldn't have been playing because he was not really a Chesterfield player. If this was the FA Cup and you played a player who was not registered you would be kicked out. Chesterfield have got away with Beckett.'

Dearden believes the ruling will open the door to miscreants rather than close it. 'Other clubs will look at it and they may think, "If we do wrong things we might get away with it".'

Chesterfield intend to appeal and although many individuals connected with the club feel vindicated that their integrity and honesty have been upheld there are still some difficult times ahead. Nine members of staff gave evidence against the club, which may make for an uncomfortable situation for many, and a lot of bridge-building needs to be done.

Chairman Darren Brown has been banned for life from ice hockey, yet still remains a director of a football club even though the misdemeanours at Chesterfield were far worse than at his ice hockey club, Sheffield Steelers. Brown will be quizzed over a £400,000 loan from Chesterfield to his company, UK Sports Group. Questions will also be raised as to how a club that was financially solvent has managed to accrue so many outstanding bills, including monies to Chester for the transfer of Beckett. Brown is also facing a police investigation. This would then raise serious questions over the decisions of the League inquiry.

With Chesterfield in financial difficulties it is hard to see where the club now go. One suggestion is that former chairman Norton Lea will return and if that transpired then changes on and off the field would be almost certain.

fields.headline: Taylor heads for victory
fields.trailText: David Ginola's 20-minute cameo appearance lifted an end-of-season encounter seemingly destined for anonymity and earned Villa a victory that was looking beyond them.
fields.body:
David Ginola's 20-minute cameo appearance lifted an end-of-season encounter seemingly destined for anonymity and earned Villa a victory that was looking beyond them.

Despite enjoying an embarrassing advantage in the possession department, it was only when the Frenchman appeared as a substitute that Villa truly looked like converting that into goals.

The decisive moment came in the 81st minute, when Ginola checked back on Steve Watson, used a body feint to put Scot Gemmill out of the equation and crossed with his right foot for Ian Taylor to head home the winner from six yards.

That was just one of a number of memorable contributions from Ginola in his abbreviated stint. Has a Premiership footballer in recent memory made the comparatively difficult look so easy?

There was little early evidence that Everton were capable of extracting anything from the game, especially as it took 16 minutes for them even to have the ball in the home area, via a run and cross from former Villa defender Steve Watson.

It was another ex-Villa player who scored a spectacular, if unexpected, Everton equaliser. David Unsworth's Villa 'career' amounted to one reserve game and less than a month in the summer of 1998 as he briefly docked in the Midlands en route to a return to his first club, Everton, from West Ham.

Citing homesickness for his bizarre choice of career path, Unsworth received a predictably hostile reception from the Villa fans yesterday, even more so when his 21st-minute volley flew past David James. The goal took the wind out of a lively Villa opening that produced a goal for Dion Dublin after 72 seconds. With the balance restored by Unsworth's equaliser, however, Everton played with more poise and confidence even though the better chances still came the home team's way.

Lee Hendrie's glancing header from Wright's free-kick flew over and Mark Pembridge's 25-yard volley bounced kindly into the arms of James before the interval.

Shortly after, Merson's audacious 30-yard volley found Paul Gerrard out of his goal but cleared the bar before wing-back Wright set about a one-man onslaught on the Everton goal.

First, Gerrard had to stretch to cover his 53rd-minute strike from just outside the box, two minutes later his spectacular 30-yard volley struck the right-hand upright with the keeper beaten, then Wright's free-kick found Dion Dublin whose far-post header was touched over by the suddenly busy Gerrard.

Lee Hendrie's glancing header from Wright's free-kick flew over and Mark Pembridge's 25-yard volley bounced kindly into the arms of James before the interval. Shortly after, Merson's audacious 30-yard volley found Paul Gerrard out of his goal but cleared the bar before wing-back Wright set about a one-man onslaught on the Everton goal. First, Gerrard had to stretch to cover his 53rd-minute strike from just outside the box, two minutes later his spectacular 30-yard volley struck the right-hand upright with the keeper beaten, then Wright's free-kick found Dion Dublin whose far-post header was touched over by the suddenly busy Gerrard.

fields.headline: Grimsby less grim
fields.trailText: In the end Grimsby's desire for First Division survival was greater than Watford's push for promotion as they came from behind to win.
fields.body:
In the end Grimsby's desire for First Division survival was greater than Watford's push for promotion as they came from behind to win.

Tommy Mooney handed Watford the lead in the very last minute of the first-half with his 21st goal of the season.

The second-half burst into life when Kevin Donovan made a surging 60-yard run before laying the ball perfectly into the path of Steve Livingston whose first time shot was smartly turned around the post by substitute keeper Alex Chamberlain.

But Grimsby maintained the pressure from the corner and when an Alan Pouton cross came in, Peter Handyside headed in from close range to put the home team level on 58 minutes. Both teams then threw men forward in an attempt to get the winner.

The game opened up and the midfield was as open and as barren as the countryside. Coyne made a double save, first from Tommy Smith then Mooney to keep Grimsby in the game.

Grimsby attacked at the other end and they were rewarded for their persistence. Tony Gallimore burst down the left-hand side, and when his cross came in it evaded all the Watford defenders except Stacy Coldicott who poked home from close range. For both Coldicott and Handyside, their strikes today were their first goals of the season.

Watford's manager, Graham Taylor, used all his substitutions in an effort to salvage something from the game. Watford laid siege to the Grimsby goal late on, but stout defending kept the visitors at bay and they held out for three valuable points in their fight to starve off relegation.

Watford, yet again, are making it an eventful last few weeks of the season for their manager but they will need to win nearly all their remaining games if they are to give him an eighth promotion in his illustrious career.

For Grimsby this was a valuable three points as their run-in means they have to face all the teams in the promotion and play-off race.

fields.headline: Wanchope lifts spirits
fields.trailText: It was either a stroke of genius or outrageous good fortune, but Paulo Wanchope gave Manchester City something to hold on to with a winning goal that would figure prominently even in his video of memorable moments.
fields.body:
It was either a stroke of genius or outrageous good fortune, but Paulo Wanchope gave Manchester City something to hold on to with a winning goal that would figure prominently even in his video of memorable moments.

The Costa Rican kept his side in with at least a mathematical chance of avoiding the drop into Division One when he backheeled the ball into the net from eight yards midway through the second half after apparently losing control of Mark Kennedy's cross.

It could prove to be the most significant backheeled City goal since a similar effort from Denis Law relegated Manchester United in 1974. And coming, as it did, after Shaun Goater's fortuitous first-half goal, the Blues' fans left here hoping perhaps their luck has finally turned for the better, even if Middlesbrough's victory meant they gained little ground. But after a run of only two wins in their previous 22 matches, any hope is to be clung to.

These were two teams in crisis, although the term is a relative one in Leicester's case as their fans' dissatisfaction stemmed only from their team's decline from top in October to tenth.

The return of Tim Flowers in goal, for the first time since New Year's Day, and Robbie Savage, only 17 days after a cartilage operation, fortified Leicester but didn't lead to any change of luck, with the visitors taking the lead in the 17th minute in truly bizarre fashion.

Wanchope's header from Kennedy's cross appeared set to come to nothing when it bounced in front of Flowers, who shaped to punch it away only to see his right-fist jab hit Goater on the back of the cranium and end up in the net. Probably the last person in the ground to know what had happened was the goalscorer.

The lead lasted 24 minutes until Ade Akinbiyi once more showed how deadly he can be from a yard when he scrambled Steve Guppy's low cross past the keeper Carlo Nash at the near post.

News of Middlesbrough's first-half performance at Arsenal sent ripples of disbelief through the away fans. To help lift their spirits the public address announcer played the theme from The Great Escape when the teams came out for the second period.

Gerry Taggart nearly gave Manchester City a helping hand in the 65th minute when he headed Andrei Kanchelskis's cross on to his own bar before Wanchope's winning intervention.

fields.headline: Kavanagh rues miss
fields.trailText: Goal difference continues to separate these two teams in the play-off positions after a hard-fought stalemate. Walsall derived the greater satisfaction, shading the first half with neat, precise football, then defended solidly in the face of growing pressure. With two matches in hand on their rivals, they look a decent bet to stay the course. How much Graham Kavanagh's missed penalty will cost Stoke in the long run remains to be seen. Had Kavanagh succeeded from the spot, it could have been the boost his team were looking for after a dodgy start. Kavanagh, however, probably did more than anyone to wrest the initiative. In too many positions Stoke were lacking the purpose to make home advantage count. Had Walsall defender Tony Barras accepted a gilt-edged chance in their previous match against Millwall, they could have taken all three points instead of settling for one against the team looking increasingly likely to win the Second Division.
fields.byline: Stuart Barnes at the Britannia Stadium

Walsall derived the greater satisfaction, shading the first half with neat, precise football, then defended solidly in the face of growing pressure. With two matches in hand on their rivals, they look a decent bet to stay the course. How much Graham Kavanagh's missed penalty will cost Stoke in the long run remains to be seen. Had Kavanagh succeeded from the spot, it could have been the boost his team were looking for after a dodgy start. Kavanagh, however, probably did more than anyone to wrest the initiative. In too many positions Stoke were lacking the purpose to make home advantage count. Had Walsall defender Tony Barras accepted a gilt-edged chance in their previous match against Millwall, they could have taken all three points instead of settling for one against the team looking increasingly likely to win the Second Division.

That chance fell to Barras on the ground. Yesterday's came early on when his captain, Tom Bennett, floated over a centre from the left flank. Barras met it with plenty of power, but his direction was astray.

It was not the first time that fortune smiled on Stoke goalkeeper, Gavin Ward, who directed what should have been a routine clearance against leading scorer Jorge Leitao. Fortunately for Ward, the ball flew away from the goal instead of into it.

Ward seemed to be at the heart of much of the action. He took exception to an aerial challenge by Don Goodman, as did the referee who showed Goodman the yellow card.

Stoke struggled to piece their game together, and should have gone ahead from the penalty spot after 29 minutes. When the ball came loose from an excellent block by Ian Roper on Mikael Hansson, a rash challenge by Bennett on Andy Cooke was punished. Kavanagh struck the spot-kick hard enough, but too near James Walker who pushed it aside.

Stoke's leading scorer Peter Thorne produced a much better effort, taking on Roper and Andy Tillson before shooting narrowly wide of the far post.

Despite his miss, Kavanagh was easily Stoke's most progressive player, volleying over when a corner from Henrik Risom came loose to the edge of the box.

Kavanagh again tried his luck from 25 yards after a lucky ricochet off the referee, but this one comfortably cleared the crossbar.

webTitle: Observer review: A Moment Towards the End of the Play by Timothy West

fields.headline: West's wide story
fields.standfirst: Timothy West has a vast range and a precise niche in acting's history. Simon Callow salutes his memoir A Moment Towards the End of the Play
fields.trailText: Timothy West has a vast range and a precise niche in acting's history. Simon Callow salutes his memoir A Moment Towards the End of the Play
fields.body:
A Moment Towards the End of the Play
Timothy West
Nick Hern Books £15.99, pp286
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Time was when all actors of calibre wrote their books. They often bore somewhat whimsical titles - I'm especially fond of Whitford Kane's Are We All Met? although Sessue Hayakawa's Zen Showed Me the Way is a close runner-up. The books generally consisted of their life story interlaced with observations about the art of the theatre and generous acknowledgments of colleagues and friends.

Into this amiable tradition falls A Moment towards the End of the Play. The title is an allusion both to the standard photographic formula in playgoers' magazines of the past and to the fact that its author may be deemed, at the age of 65, to be nearing the final lap of his career, although in view of the extraordinary longevity of many thespians (John Gielgud shuffled off the mortal coil only recently and with the greatest reluctance at the age of 95) the title may prove to be unduly pessimistic - or optimistic, according to your point of view.

West's career has been exemplary, covering all possible media. He has been in weekly rep, in the grander civic reps, in the Royal Shakespeare Company and the National Theatre; he was a leading force in the classical touring company Prospect, being with it when it arrived in glory as the Old Vic's resident company, with it through its troubled tenure there, and in charge of it when it sank thanks to sabotage by the Arts Council blithely playing God with the destinies of its clients.

He was in radio rep for a year, was a stalwart of television and appeared in many films - though never, as he wryly acknowledges, as a star. He has directed plays and companies (he ran the Forum Billingham for a year, God help him), actively involved himself on the boards of theatres and theatre schools, taught, read books on tape by the mile and tirelessly performed poetry and prose all over the country - indeed, all over the world. He has given unstintingly of his time, though he is too modest to mention it, to the charities and causes in which he believes; he has been solidly and determinedly supportive of the Labour Party.

He (and his wife Prunella Scales) have tirelessly fought the corner of actors; marching, signing petitions, campaigning wherever such things were needed, though never pompously or humourlessly. His life has been that of a man committed to his profession. He has not achieved stratospheric fame (although I doubt whether he easily walks down the street unrecognised) nor large sums of money; he has no grand theory about life or art; he has not, as he admits in his book, worked with many larger-than-life figures. When he has, he has viewed them with shrewd coolness, as in the case of Peter Brook, in whose revolutionary production of Marat/Sade he appeared.

And yet he has a niche absolutely his own, and it is in actors like Tim West that the pre-eminence of British acting lies. Incapable of giving a bad performance, even when - as very occasionally - miscast, he is a world-beater when the role is right. Paradoxically, though his range is vast, his genius (not too strong a word) is a very specific one. No one will ever play Bolingbroke in Richard II better; his Shpigelsky in A Month in the Country was utterly unforgettable, spiky and lyrical. In a great ensemble, like the Berliner or the Malay, he would have been one of the jewels in the crown.

I doubt whether he would have liked it, though. His autobiography, like his earlier I Know Where I am, Where are You? reveals a man for whom, in his own words, 'it is the related benefits of an actor's life that attract me more than actual performance'. He has loved travelling, meeting people he would otherwise not have met, mastering skills he would never ordinarily acquire, and of all these things and people he writes with affection and appreciation. He has sensible advice about certain roles, much in the tradition of Gielgud's advice about playing King Lear ('get a light Cordelia') and is by no means overawed by the towering masterpieces of the repertory: Henry IV Part Two, played on its own, he says, can be 'tiresome'. He has clear views on most aspects of his profession, and expresses them forcefully, even with a certain welcome pepperiness.

As for his personal life, he touches on it lightly, even when it takes a tragic turn, as in the mental illness of his first wife. His writer's eye occasionally catches something poetically heart-breaking, as when he observes a love-lorn actress writing cyrillic letters in the sand in the hope that her Russian lover might see them as his plane flew overhead. He is a rational man, above all, and his remedy for distressing events is to move on. His brilliantly funny account of the events surrounding Peter O'Toole's Macbeth and the demise of the Old Vic when he was at the helm, which would have destroyed another man, is succeeded without undue reflection by his account of the next job. He has no truck with the mystery of the theatre, nor is he impressed by its capacity to storm heaven and earth; it is a service of proven importance to the community, and should be allowed to get on with its job.

West is a master raconteur and the book is delectably full of the stories and vignettes which he purveys with great wit. There are some sad tales of the deaths of actors, too, but his sense of the human comedy is too great to cast a lasting shadow. On, on. Rise above it.

fields.headline: London post office bombed
fields.trailText: An explosion  at a north London post office on Saturday night is believed to have been the work of the Real IRA. No one was injured in the attack, for which no warning was given.
fields.body:
An explosion at a north London post office on Saturday night is believed to have been the work of the Real IRA. No one was injured in the attack, for which no warning was given.

The bombers who planted a device outside a Post Office delivery depot were labelled "totally reckless" on Sunday, as fears grew that a renewed mainland terror campaign would escalate.

The device, packed with up to 1lb of high explosives, blew out windows, exploding "without any notice whatsoever," said deputy assistant commissioner Alan Fry, head of Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch.

This explosion comes six weeks after a bomb blast hit the BBC TV Centre in London.

At the time Mr Fry said he feared it was the escalation of a Real IRA terror campaign on mainland Britain.

"We have been predicting, since Christmas, that the mainland, and London in particular, would be subject to terrorist attacks," he said.

Saturday's device exploded at 11.28pm and was a similar size to the device at Hammersmith Bridge in June last year.

It blew out the glass from the windows of the depot, but nobody was inside and there were no reports of injuries.

But it was designed to maim or injure, and falling glass from the blast could have caused horrendous injuries or even killed.

"Whoever put that device down was totally reckless as to someone living in the area, drinking in the pub just beyond this device, walking past at the time of the explosion or in a vehicle, could have had a serious accident," he said.

Lab tests will confirm if the bomb was the work of the Real IRA, he added.

"Due to the number of recent attacks and the nature of this one, I suspect that this is the work of the Real IRA," Mr Fry said.

No claim of responsibility had been made by Sunday night.

A forensic fingertip search of the site was carried out and the focus of the investigation switched to laboratory work to establish the type of explosive and device used.

It was still unclear why the bombers targeted the depot at The Hyde, Hendon, which suffered minor damage in the blast.

"I don't know of a significance other than being a Post Office premises. That will fit in with the Easter Uprising, which of course is being celebrated, the anniversary of that event is this weekend," Mr Fry said.

"There are a number of other features that might fit in. There's the Good Friday Agreement and where the peace process is, and equally there was the film of Michael Collins on the television last night.

"Whether any of these events featured in the planning, in the reasons behind this explosion, I don't know, but clearly they are all lines of inquiry and all possibilities."

The BBC bomb blast is also thought to be the work of the Real IRA and it detonated inside a taxi as bomb disposal experts attempted to carry out a controlled explosion.

One London Underground worker suffered minor injuries in the attack.

Before the blast at the BBC premises in Wood Lane, Shepherd's Bush, coded warnings had been received.

From the police cordon around 100 yards away, two smashed windows could be seen and metal railings lining the road outside the depot were twisted, apparently by the force of the blast.

Gerry Madden, delivery officer manager at the postal sorting office, said 80 people work at the depot but no one was on duty on Saturday night.

He said: "Half-a-dozen windows were broken, nothing at all inside. Everything inside is perfect apart from a few scorch marks on the wall.

"No staff were due to be here until Monday night when everything will carry on as normal."

Stephen Cunliffe, manager of the Glen pub, just 50 yards from the sorting office, said the pub hosted a late disco on Saturday night and it was still busy at 11.30pm when the explosion happened.

He said: "I could hardly hear the explosion because of the music. Police evacuated us at 11.45pm. I'm concerned that this could have happened, but I'm glad that no one was injured. It was just a stroke of luck."

Mr Fry said it was of the "utmost importance" those responsible were found and brought to justice.

The depot is near the busy Edgware Road, which reopened following the police search, and he appealed to anyone who had seen "strange incidents" in the area to come forward.

The post office building is expected to open on Tuesday morning after the Bank Holiday.

Anyone with information about the blast is asked to contact the confidential Anti-Terrorist Hotline on 0800 789 321.

He said: "Half-a-dozen windows were broken, nothing at all inside. Everything inside is perfect apart from a few scorch marks on the wall. "No staff were due to be here until Monday night when everything will carry on as normal." Stephen Cunliffe, manager of the Glen pub, just 50 yards from the sorting office, said the pub hosted a late disco on Saturday night and it was still busy at 11.30pm when the explosion happened. He said: "I could hardly hear the explosion because of the music. Police evacuated us at 11.45pm. I'm concerned that this could have happened, but I'm glad that no one was injured. It was just a stroke of luck." Mr Fry said it was of the "utmost importance" those responsible were found and brought to justice. The depot is near the busy Edgware Road, which reopened following the police search, and he appealed to anyone who had seen "strange incidents" in the area to come forward. The post office building is expected to open on Tuesday morning after the Bank Holiday. Anyone with information about the blast is asked to contact the confidential Anti-Terrorist Hotline on 0800 789 321.

Under £200

France: Spend a week at a villa set in a vineyard in the south of France with www.villadeals.com from 21 April for £199 excluding flights. Each property has its own small private garden and the estate boasts two swimming pools and a tennis court. Flights and car hire can also be arranged.

Greece: Visit Captain Corelli's Cephalonia before fans of the film, launched next month, discover the island. Kosmar Holidays (0870 7000747) is offering a week's holiday for £179 per person for departures on 6 May from Gatwick.

Under £300

Cyprus: British Airways Holidays (0870 2424243) is offering two nights at the four-star Mediterranean Beach Hotel in Cyprus from £289 per person for departures between 20 April and 30 June. The price includes return flights from Heathrow and bed and breakfast accommodation. Bookings must be made by 15 May.

Athens: Visit Greece's capital before the summer heat makes it unbearable. Travelscene (020 8424 9648) has two-night weekend breaks at the three-star Hotel Christina for £272 per person based on two sharing. Departures are on 4 or 5 May and 11 or 12 May. B&B accommodation and return flights from Heathrow are included.

Verona: Lupus Travel (0800 0180043) has two-night stays in the two-star Giulietta e Romeo hotel for £225 per person for departures between 17 April and 30 June. The price includes B&B accommodation and return flights from London Gatwick.

Under £400

Tuscany: Cresta Holidays (0870 161 0900) has three-night breaks at the three-star Villa Liberty in Siena for £371 per person including return flights and B&B accommodation for departures from Gatwick on 27 April.

Ireland: Gorge yourself on mussels at the annual international Mussel Fair in Bantry Bay between 10 and 13 May. Country Cottages in Ireland (0870 585 1177) is offering a selection of short breaks for the festival. Tunisia: Cadogan Holidays (02380 828302) is offering three-night breaks to the four-star Sol Azur Hotel in Hammamet for £416 per person. Facilities include a swimming pool, tennis courts, and a thalassotherapy centre. The price includes B&B accommodation, return flights and private transfers.
