fields.headline: Passion for  fashion
fields.standfirst: Forget Paris, move over Milan. Antwerp is the perfect destination for a shopping spree - and you can fill up on Belgian beer and chocolates too.   Tamsin Blanchard  puts her credit card and waistline at risk
fields.trailText: Forget Paris, move over Milan. Antwerp is the perfect destination for a shopping spree - and you can fill up on Belgian beer and chocolates too. Tamsin Blanchard puts her credit card and waistline at risk.
fields.body:
Every fashion editor will tell you that the best places to shop are New York for T-shirts, jeans, basics and Kiehl's moisturiser, and Milan for Prada shoes at a third of their usual price. But before you go jetting off, we can let you into a secret: if you're sick of every high street looking the same, want to impress even your most fashionable friends, and want to have some fun while you're at it, there is nowhere quite like Antwerp, the fashion capital of Flanders.

Since the early Eighties, when Belgian designers turned the fashion world upside down with their deconstructed clothes - all raw edges and inside out seams - Antwerp has become the fashion equivalent of Lourdes. It's a place of pilgrimage, with disciples visiting the crumbling old Academy of Fine Art to see where Martin Margiela and Co sewed their first stitches, and then to Louis, the shop that was the first to sell their collections. The fashion school is now in temporary premises, while a brand new Fashion Institute, complete with fashion museum, is being built. It is expected to open next year. Louis is still the best starting point for any shopping tour. It's a surprisingly small boutique, on Lombardenvest 2, in the old town. But it's the perfect place to get better acquainted with the best of Belgian fashion, from Ann Demeulemeester to Veronique Branquinho and Raf Simons.

I tried on a huge, experimental square of black jersey by Margiela. However, coming out of the changing room, face to face with the two shop assistants, was a humbling, if not humiliating, experience. I could tell immediately by their faces that this was not a good look. Even my fellow shopper, Jo Adams, Observer fashion editor, was laughing. Something to do with my mismatched black ankle socks and red trainers, perhaps.

Turn right out of Louis, and a two-minute walk along Lombardenvest takes you past Laundry Industry, selling high-street basics, Yosho, for unusual shoes, and De Groene Wolk, a designer baby boutique, to Korte Gasthuisstraat. Here you'll find retail therapy guaranteed to add inches to your waistline. Forget frocks for a moment. There's Goossens, the bakery which piles its windows full of delicious-looking fruit breads and cakes; Philips, the charming old biscuit shop, where you can buy freshly baked biscuits by weight, or tins of the hand-shaped butter-rich biscuits which are the symbol of Antwerp (Antwerpen means, literally, hand throw - the story goes that a giant once controlled the city, levying crippling taxes, until one day a young hero pulled his hand off and threw it into the river); and, of course, numerous chocolate shops.

The locals buy chocolates as part of their weekly shop, along with other necessities such as fruit and veg. And why not? For the most delicious hand-made chocolates imaginable, make sure you make a detour to Del Rey, on Appelmansstraat 5, where the truffles and pralines are made fresh every day in a workshop on the premises. The smell alone is enough to satisfy most chocaholics. Just the thought of it was making our mouths water, and anyway, our feet were hurting after an hour's shopping. So we stopped for a coffee break at Desir de Lille, the tea shop which specialises in waffles. I ordered some apple fritters which arrived, groaning under their own weight in icing sugar. It was at this point that my thoughts began returning to the Margiela tent dress. If it meant I could spend my days eating waffles and beignets , perhaps I didn't care what the shop assistants thought after all.

One of the many great things about Antwerp (along with chocolates, diamonds, waffles, beer, moules, jenever , and healthy portions of the best frites and mayonnaise in town, from Frituur No 1, at Hoogstraat 1) is that there are shops here that you won't find anywhere else, and they are all within walking distance. Ann Demeulemeester is on the corner of Leopold de Waelplaats and Verlatstraat. It's next to the kitchen specialists Obumex, where you'll find units designed by the minimalist architect John Pawson.

More established is Dries Van Noten. The turn of the century, mosaic-tiled Modepaleis, as it's called, is quite a landmark, on Nationalestraat 16. The shop assistants are friendly and helpful and will happily convert prices into sterling if you ask. And do ask, because while you will want to buy handfuls of delicately beaded chiffon tops, floral printed dresses, fantastically cut trousers, and juicy-coloured knits, these clothes are not cheap. They are however, the sort of clothes you will wear forever, like family heirlooms.

In May, the city will exploit its trendy new status when it plays host to Mode 2001, a major fashion festival, with designers from Belgium and abroad, taking over the streets and buildings until next October. There will be mapped out 'fashion walks' designed to take you past all the hotspots. For a preview, click on www.mode2001.be. The event is being organised by Antwerp's most colourful character, fashion designer Walter Van Beirendonck. His own shop, at St Antoniusstraat, 12, is a reason to visit Antwerp alone. With its window gallery, its sweeping counter designed by Marc Newson, its giant plastic sleeping teddy bear, and a rail of Van Beirendonck's own Aesthetic Terrorist T-shirts, it's a different sort of shopping experience. You can also buy clothes by Dirk Van Saene, recent Antwerp graduate Bernard Willhelm, and a handful of other up-and-coming designers.

A couple of days in Antwerp is all you need to shop, drink coffee, eat waffles, shop some more, drink beer and shop. There are clothes shops, junk and antique shops, shoe shops, furniture stores, and great places to eat too. And for every shop, there are at least two bars, serving Belgium's many hundred varieties of beer. Het Elfde Gebod, at Torfbrug 10, is a pub in the shadow of the cathedral and is packed with kitsch religious statues and iconography. After a few Leffes, you'll start to feel a little more saintly about the day's shopping and the gaping hole in your bank account.

Belgium... old and new

Beer
Belgium produces more than 350 brands of beer, and in Antwerp you'll find the famous Flemish white beers.

Smurfs
Remember those funny little blue people? Blame Belgian comic strip artist Pierre Culliford, who invented Les Schtroumpf (smurfs to you and me) in 1948.

Chocolates
The Belgians have been producing some of the world's finest chocolates for over a century. Pralines are the national speciality.

Fashion
Graduates from Antwerp's Royal Academy of Fine Arts have made their mark on international catwalks.

Design
The streets of Antwerp are lined with shops selling furniture, trinkets and accessories by talented new designers.

Art
Surrealism is deeply embedded in Belgian culture and you don't have to go to an art gallery to see it.

Shop till you drop

 People say Belgian designers' clothes are as difficult to wear as their names are to pronounce. But all you need to know are four names: Walter, Martin, Dries and Ann, and you're halfway to being an expert.Those in the know refer to the designers by their first names anyway; it implies they are all good chums. Expect to pay about £48 (3,000 Belgian francs) for an Aesthetic Terrorist T-shirt, £73 for an oversized Margiela T-shirt, from £161 for a Dries Van Noten dress and from £161-£258 for Ann Demeulemeester trousers.

 Coccodrillo, at Schuttershofstraat, 9, is one of the best places to go for shoes by Prada, Michel Perry, as well as Antwerp's finest, including AF Vanderforst (boots from £400), Margiela and Demeulemeester.

 If you can't afford to buy Van Noten and Demeulemeester new, it's worth bargain-hunting in Francis, Steenhouwersvest 14. This shop specialises in modern furniture from the Fifties to the Seventies, and has great chairs and lights. It has vintage Hermès scarves, old handbags and a rail of vintage and second-hand clothes. Prices are around £60-£70 for a dress.

 Once you've bought your outfit, it's on to accessories. Antwerp is the diamond capital of Europe but beware of conmen. There's enough competition in the diamond district (centred on the station) for customers to have the upperhand. Remember the 3 Cs - cut, carat, and clarity. To get an idea of what you should be paying or to buy a diamond and have it set while you wait, visit Diamandland, on Appelmansstraat 33.

 Find Antwerp's independent boutiques, such as Huis A Boon, the glove shop that dates back to 1884. It's at Lombardenvest 2-4, and is a great place for window shopping, or for buying every kind of glove, from driving to Madonna-style lace mittens.

 For mainstream shopping - everything from Zara to Antwerp's only department store - head for the Meir.

 Bazar Bizar, Steenhouwersvest 18, is a real find. It sells a bright and exotic collection of furniture, silks, sandals, trinkets and accessories from Morocco, Indonesia and the Far East. (Sandals from around £38). It also has an apartment above the shop, decorated in Arabian Nights style, which can be rented for £73 pp per night. It sleeps up to four. For more details, ring 0032 3 232 97 44 or click on www.bazarbizar.be.

 Don't plan a shopping trip in Antwerp on Monday or Tuesday; a lot of the shops are closed. However, on Sundays, the antique and bric-a-brac shops around Steehhouwersvest and Kloostersstraat are open.

Fact file

Getting there: Tamsin Blanchard flew to Antwerp from London City with VLM (tel 020 7476 6677). Fares from £120 including tax based on a minimum two-night stay. She stayed at Hotel 't Sandt, (tel 0032 3 232 93 90). Weekend rates for a double room with breakfast start at £84.

By car: a package is available from Eurotunnel Motoring Holidays (0870 333 2001) from £148 (1 May to 31 Oct) based on two sharing at the three-star Eden Hotel in the heart of the diamond district. Price includes return travel via Eurotunnel for a car and passengers and B&B accommodation. Antwerp is a two-hour drive from the Eurotunnel terminal.

By train: Eurostar to Brussels takes 2hr 40min followed by a 35min train ride to Antwerp.

More information: Tourism Flanders-Brussels, 31 Pepper Street, London E14 (0900 188 7799)

The locals buy chocolates as part of their weekly shop, along with other necessities such as fruit and veg. And why not? For the most delicious hand-made chocolates imaginable, make sure you make a detour to Del Rey, on Appelmansstraat 5, where the truffles and pralines are made fresh every day in a workshop on the premises. The smell alone is enough to satisfy most chocaholics. Just the thought of it was making our mouths water, and anyway, our feet were hurting after an hour's shopping. So we stopped for a coffee break at Desir de Lille, the tea shop which specialises in waffles. I ordered some apple fritters which arrived, groaning under their own weight in icing sugar. It was at this point that my thoughts began returning to the Margiela tent dress. If it meant I could spend my days eating waffles and beignets , perhaps I didn't care what the shop assistants thought after all. One of the many great things about Antwerp (along with chocolates, diamonds, waffles, beer, moules, jenever , and healthy portions of the best frites and mayonnaise in town, from Frituur No 1, at Hoogstraat 1) is that there are shops here that you won't find anywhere else, and they are all within walking distance. Ann Demeulemeester is on the corner of Leopold de Waelplaats and Verlatstraat. It's next to the kitchen specialists Obumex, where you'll find units designed by the minimalist architect John Pawson. More established is Dries Van Noten. The turn of the century, mosaic-tiled Modepaleis, as it's called, is quite a landmark, on Nationalestraat 16. The shop assistants are friendly and helpful and will happily convert prices into sterling if you ask. And do ask, because while you will want to buy handfuls of delicately beaded chiffon tops, floral printed dresses, fantastically cut trousers, and juicy-coloured knits, these clothes are not cheap. They are however, the sort of clothes you will wear forever, like family heirlooms. In May, the city will exploit its trendy new status when it plays host to Mode 2001, a major fashion festival, with designers from Belgium and abroad, taking over the streets and buildings until next October. There will be mapped out 'fashion walks' designed to take you past all the hotspots. For a preview, click on www.mode2001.be. The event is being organised by Antwerp's most colourful character, fashion designer Walter Van Beirendonck. His own shop, at St Antoniusstraat, 12, is a reason to visit Antwerp alone. With its window gallery, its sweeping counter designed by Marc Newson, its giant plastic sleeping teddy bear, and a rail of Van Beirendonck's own Aesthetic Terrorist T-shirts, it's a different sort of shopping experience. You can also buy clothes by Dirk Van Saene, recent Antwerp graduate Bernard Willhelm, and a handful of other up-and-coming designers. A couple of days in Antwerp is all you need to shop, drink coffee, eat waffles, shop some more, drink beer and shop. There are clothes shops, junk and antique shops, shoe shops, furniture stores, and great places to eat too. And for every shop, there are at least two bars, serving Belgium's many hundred varieties of beer. Het Elfde Gebod, at Torfbrug 10, is a pub in the shadow of the cathedral and is packed with kitsch religious statues and iconography. After a few Leffes, you'll start to feel a little more saintly about the day's shopping and the gaping hole in your bank account. Belgium... old and new Beer Belgium produces more than 350 brands of beer, and in Antwerp you'll find the famous Flemish white beers. Smurfs Remember those funny little blue people? Blame Belgian comic strip artist Pierre Culliford, who invented Les Schtroumpf (smurfs to you and me) in 1948. Chocolates The Belgians have been producing some of the world's finest chocolates for over a century. Pralines are the national speciality. Fashion Graduates from Antwerp's Royal Academy of Fine Arts have made their mark on international catwalks. Design The streets of Antwerp are lined with shops selling furniture, trinkets and accessories by talented new designers. Art Surrealism is deeply embedded in Belgian culture and you don't have to go to an art gallery to see it. Shop till you drop  People say Belgian designers' clothes are as difficult to wear as their names are to pronounce. But all you need to know are four names: Walter, Martin, Dries and Ann, and you're halfway to being an expert.Those in the know refer to the designers by their first names anyway; it implies they are all good chums. Expect to pay about £48 (3,000 Belgian francs) for an Aesthetic Terrorist T-shirt, £73 for an oversized Margiela T-shirt, from £161 for a Dries Van Noten dress and from £161-£258 for Ann Demeulemeester trousers.  Coccodrillo, at Schuttershofstraat, 9, is one of the best places to go for shoes by Prada, Michel Perry, as well as Antwerp's finest, including AF Vanderforst (boots from £400), Margiela and Demeulemeester.  If you can't afford to buy Van Noten and Demeulemeester new, it's worth bargain-hunting in Francis, Steenhouwersvest 14. This shop specialises in modern furniture from the Fifties to the Seventies, and has great chairs and lights. It has vintage Hermès scarves, old handbags and a rail of vintage and second-hand clothes. Prices are around £60-£70 for a dress.  Once you've bought your outfit, it's on to accessories. Antwerp is the diamond capital of Europe but beware of conmen. There's enough competition in the diamond district (centred on the station) for customers to have the upperhand. Remember the 3 Cs - cut, carat, and clarity. To get an idea of what you should be paying or to buy a diamond and have it set while you wait, visit Diamandland, on Appelmansstraat 33.  Find Antwerp's independent boutiques, such as Huis A Boon, the glove shop that dates back to 1884. It's at Lombardenvest 2-4, and is a great place for window shopping, or for buying every kind of glove, from driving to Madonna-style lace mittens.  For mainstream shopping - everything from Zara to Antwerp's only department store - head for the Meir.  Bazar Bizar, Steenhouwersvest 18, is a real find. It sells a bright and exotic collection of furniture, silks, sandals, trinkets and accessories from Morocco, Indonesia and the Far East. (Sandals from around £38). It also has an apartment above the shop, decorated in Arabian Nights style, which can be rented for £73 pp per night. It sleeps up to four. For more details, ring 0032 3 232 97 44 or click on www.bazarbizar.be.  Don't plan a shopping trip in Antwerp on Monday or Tuesday; a lot of the shops are closed. However, on Sundays, the antique and bric-a-brac shops around Steehhouwersvest and Kloostersstraat are open. Fact file Getting there: Tamsin Blanchard flew to Antwerp from London City with VLM (tel 020 7476 6677). Fares from £120 including tax based on a minimum two-night stay. She stayed at Hotel 't Sandt, (tel 0032 3 232 93 90). Weekend rates for a double room with breakfast start at £84. By car: a package is available from Eurotunnel Motoring Holidays (0870 333 2001) from £148 (1 May to 31 Oct) based on two sharing at the three-star Eden Hotel in the heart of the diamond district. Price includes return travel via Eurotunnel for a car and passengers and B&B accommodation. Antwerp is a two-hour drive from the Eurotunnel terminal. By train: Eurostar to Brussels takes 2hr 40min followed by a 35min train ride to Antwerp. More information: Tourism Flanders-Brussels, 31 Pepper Street, London E14 (0900 188 7799)

fields.headline: Who's minding the gap?
fields.standfirst:
A year in a developing country is de rigueur for students,
                                                  but some find themselves unwelcome. And ripped off
fields.trailText: A year in a developing country is de rigueur for students, but some find themselves unwelcome. And ripped off
fields.body:
It used to be called the 'year off' between school and university, and you were lucky if you got to France. Now it's a gap year - essential for the enterprising sixth-former - and it doesn't count unless you go somewhere very Third World. The gap-year phenomenon originated with the months left over to Oxbridge applicants between entrance exams in November and the start of the next academic year. Nowadays, Oxford and Cambridge make conditional offers before A-levels, like everyone else, but the gap year has exploded, becoming a kind of finishing school for the middle classes. One estimate puts the numbers taking such a break at between 100,000 and 200,000 a year.

The notion that digging a well in Ethiopia is a valuable experience has been helped by backing from the Department for Education and Employment and Ucas, the university admissions service, both of which have endorsed the value of deferring entry to university. The internet has, meanwhile, given pupils greater access to organisations providing gap-year experiences.

As a result, the number of gap-year providers has mushroomed into the hundreds. They offer expeditions, volunteering, work placements and cultural and language courses. Some are charities, others highly profitable companies. It is difficult to tell them apart at first sight - any sort of organisation can promise that you, like Prince William, can scrub floors in Chile - but they turn out to be very different.

Lisa O'Donnelly applied to teach English in Ethiopia with a commercial provider. Unusually, she had more than one year off before starting at the School of Oriental and African Studies in London and already had a qualification in teaching English as a foreign language. When she arrived in Africa, she found there was no school and no one to teach. 'I was in a physiotherapy centre for children with polio from all over Ethiopia. It was a good project, but there was nothing there for me to do. In England, I was told I needed an induction, for which I was charged £250. It was mostly about teaching English and I didn't want to go, because I'd already taught for a year at this stage, in India and Nepal.

'There were two of us going to this project in Ethiopia, but a month beforehand the other girl dropped out. I was warned if I didn't go, I'd lose all my money. I was also told there would be a language induction in the first week, but the local representative put me in a hotel five miles outside Addis and then disappeared for seven days. When I complained, I was told I didn't understand the Third World.

'The company claimed to have checked out the project, but it turned out that no one had been there. I paid £250 a month for a room on the project compound, even though my hotel had cost about 50p a night. I asked for a breakdown of the costs from the company, but they couldn't give me one. They said everything was admin.'

Last week, O'Donnelly, who fought to get back the several thousand pounds she paid, spoke at a conference in Manchester organised by Tourism Concern aiming to bring together students and provider organisations, and to consider whether gap years are as good for dirt-poor destinations as for the young Brits who descend on them.

Michael Lomotey, who is half-English, half-Ghanaian, organised the conference after being shocked by the behaviour of British gap-year students in Ghana. 'Their cultural insensitivity is incredible. They dress inappropriately, wearing shorts in the marketplace and they haggle without smiling. I've seen British gappers get into a fist fight with a taxi driver over the equivalent of 20p, which would matter to him, but not to them.

'On one flight out to Ghana, I travelled with 70 gappers. Most had received no training, no induction into the culture. I kept wondering if 10 of them were going to build a well and they'd each paid £1,000, what could the community have done with that money?'

Last May, 20 of the larger gap providers formed the Year Out Group, a trade association, in a bid to prevent the kind of experiences that Lisa had. The group now has 23 members and, according to its chief executive Richard Oliver, 'aims to agree standards and promote the benefits of a structured year out'. Its website offers a useful list of questions for students and parents: what exactly will I be doing? Is the host organisation paid? What are the hidden costs? And how will I be supported?

As Lavinia Bristol, who runs Project Trust, one of the best gap-year organisations, says: 'Eighteen-year-olds are extraordinarily bad at being discerning consumers. Even on our selection courses, they don't ask questions that you'd think might be obvious, such as how they're going to be looked after or how the project's been vetted.'

But more radical critics, like Jim Cogan, founder of Student Partnerships Worldwide, one of the oldest and most distinguished organisations, question whether gap years in poor countries are of any benefit. 'The danger is that if untrained British students go out to poor countries that are riddled with disease and malnutrition, they are likely to end up debauching themselves by the ocean or on the shores of Lake Malawi in little hedonistic enclaves. They can enjoy the cheap cost of living, have an interesting four months and come home. There is a big moral issue here, which is conveniently being overlooked.'

The trouble is that there are many different kinds of gap-year provider, some with more honourable intentions than others. On the one hand, there are organisa tions such as Project Trust, a charity that took over Voluntary Service Overseas' 18-year-olds programme, and selects its 200 participants on the basis of a five-day assessment on the Isle of Coll in Scotland. It provides a week-long training course and sends gappers to their projects for an entire year. Student Partnerships Worldwide trains 250 British students alongside the same number of young people from host countries for a month and specialises in teaching adolescents in countries with high levels of Aids and HIV how to avoid infection.

On the other hand, Teaching and Projects Abroad is a commercial company. Its 1,000 students can decide when they want to go and for how long. The question then arises: how different is this from an ordinary tour company? And if students can dip in and out of the projects, how important are the jobs they are doing?

Kevin Dynan, in charge of recruitment for the company (which would probably be called marketing elsewhere), points out reasonably enough that not all gappers are ready to make the 12-month commitment required by some organisations. 'With us, they go initially for three months, which is long enough to stick it out and also to make some contribution.' He says there is some in-country induction, and in areas where cultural faux pas are a real risk, 'we might have a chat with people before they go'.

He acknowledges that there are periods when no one is filling the posts, 'but in teaching, it's not necessarily a problem, as they're very much language assistants. Other projects are more about training - shadowing a doctor or working in a radio station'. And what's the difference between them and a holiday company? 'We're not interested in making huge amounts of profit.'

It is, in fact, extremely difficult to compare the costs of different organisations, because advertised prices often don't include airfares, insurance, pocket money or language and induction programmes and cover different periods of time. As a general rule, expeditions are more expensive than volunteering or work placements, and you are unlikely to get away with much under £3,000. Lavinia Bristol of Project Trust has attempted to calculate relative costs and concluded that Gap is the cheapest (with Project Trust next) and something called, improbably, Ski Le Gap is the most expensive.

Not least thanks to cheap flights and a better travelled population, the popularity of gap years looks set only to rise. Eighteen-year-olds are a tremendous resource and eager to be used, especially if that buys them a period in an exotic place.

fields.headline: Top 10 Tips
fields.standfirst: How to have a successful gap year
fields.trailText: How to have a successful gap year
fields.body:
1. Plan at least a year ahead. Places on projects fill up months ahead.

2. Do your homework by using guidebooks such as Lonely Planet or the Rough Guide series. Taking a Gap Year by Susan Griffith, published by Vacation Work (www.vacationwork.co.uk includes a directory of useful organisations .

3.. Use the internet to research potential destinations. The following have useful information: www.gapyear.com www.statravel.co.uk and www.usitcampus.co.uk

4. Prepare your CV, making sure it's geared to the work you want to do.

5. Apply for work visas well in advance - they take longer than tourist visas.

6. If returning to higher education, process all the application forms and attend the necessary interviews before you go.

7. Budget for each day of your trip and allow extra cash for emergencies.

8. Get all the jabs necessary for the countries you are planning to visit.

9. Ring the Foreign Office Travel Advice Unit on 020 7238 4503 or see the website www.fco.gov.uk for information on areas of potential unrest.

10. Get adequate travel insurance for your trip. Healthcare abroad is notoriously expensive.

fields.headline: Balearic islands vote in eco-tax
fields.standfirst: Tour firms warn levy to fund environmental projects will put off visitors
fields.trailText: A green tax on travellers to the Balearic islands should ensure their future as a major tourism destination by sustaining a fragile region, according to charity group Tourism Concern. Though major tour operators say the tax will deter tourists from going to the islands, Tourism Concern warns that without it, there might not be much left worth visiting.
fields.body:
A green tax on travellers to the Balearic islands should ensure their future as a major tourism destination by sustaining a fragile region, according to charity group Tourism Concern. Though major tour operators say the tax will deter tourists from going to the islands, Tourism Concern warns that without it, there might not be much left worth visiting.

The levy passed by the Balearics parliament last week adds about a euro (62p) a day to the price of a holiday, excluding children under 16 and pensioners.

Association of British Travel Agents spokesman Keith Betton said that could be enough to deter tourists in a highly price-sensitive market. But Tourism Concern director Tricia Barnett said: 'It is less than £5 a week per person. People have gone there as cheaply as they possibly can for a number of years. It doesn't seem to be such a terrible thing to contribute to the environmental regeneration of a highly degraded area.'

Spanish tourism officials have been trying to shrug off the Balearics' 'build high, get them in cheap' image by upgrading hotels and facilities. The tax is designed to carry on that work, generating about £40 million a year to help solve the problems of mass construction without the proper infrastructure, said Barnett.

The money could be used to prevent sand erosion in some overdeveloped coastal areas, which was leaving them without beaches, she added. More changes needed to be made in Ibiza, where hotels still draw their water from local wells. 'There is a huge demand on scarce resources,' said Barnett. 'This is the result of wanting things cheap and thinking short term.'

Both Abta and large tour operators have condemned the tax for being selective and only being charged on hotel clients rather than tourists going to private villas. Hoteliers plan to appeal against the measure, which is unlikely to be imposed before next year. It has not been decided how the tax will be levied. A spokesman from package operator JMC added: 'We are not convinced there is a desire to improve the Balearic environment.'

But Adam Walsh, director of specialist operator Alternative Mallorca, welcomed the initiative. 'It is an eco-tax which, if applied correctly, can't be a bad thing,' he said.

Millions of UK tourists visit the Balearic islands every year with the majority heading for Majorca.

fields.headline: Book ends
fields.standfirst: The Worst-case Scenario Survival Handbook: Travel
fields.trailText: The Worst-case Scenario Survival Handbook: Travel.
fields.body:
Riding on the coat tails of the successful The Worst-Case Scenario Survival Handbook comes this offshoot, crammed full of tragedy-specific tips for survival on the road, writes Kirsty Buttfield. The tone is set on the back cover: 'CAUTION: Book may not be used as a flotation device.'

It comes complete with diagrams, featuring advice on how to extract oneself from a variety of crises, including how to jump from a moving train, how to foil a UFO abduction, how to cross a piranha-infested river, and how to escape from the boot of a car.

The unlikely nature of many of these disasters helps to make this survival handbook an entertaining read and, although far-fetched, there are some useful principles outlined - for instance, one section is devoted to gestures to avoid that may be offensive in faraway places.

Some may consider the price of £9.99 a little high for a collection of imaginative 'what-ifs', but it does provide a good chuckle.

fields.headline: Get your kit on
fields.standfirst: Quark travel watch
fields.trailText: Quark travel watch.
fields.body:
Watch out for this one - a trendy time piece to take on your travels.

The Quark men's travel watch, made by Storm, has two faces so you can see what time it is at home while sunning yourself on a tropical beach. webTitle: Observer review: Wittgenstein's Poker by David Edmonds and John Eidinow

fields.headline: Take that thesis back, Karl, or I'll deck you
fields.standfirst: The conflict between Popper and Wittgenstein went beyond usual academic differences as David Edmonds and John Eidinow show in Wittgenstein's Poker
fields.trailText: The conflict between Popper and Wittgenstein went beyond usual academic differences as David Edmonds and John Eidinow show in Wittgenstein's Poker
fields.body:
Wittgenstein's Poker
David Edmonds and John Eidinow
Faber £9.99, pp267
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Karl Popper and Ludwig Wittgenstein ought to have had a great deal to talk about. Their origins were very similar: both Viennese Jews; both left and went to English-speaking countries; between them, they alerted the English-speaking world to the currents of philosophical thought evolving in Vienna and, between them, changed the whole tenor of philosophical investigations. They had similar, prickly personalities, and similar personal austerities; both became the unwilling object of a cult.

But the only occasion they are recorded meeting ended with Wittgenstein taking a poker to Popper and having to be restrained. They regarded each other, in fact, with undisguised hostility and contempt. Perhaps, when two people are very similar, their differences always become a mark of conspicuous contention; think how strange it would be if only one of a pair of identical twins decided to have her ears pierced, how it would draw the eye.

The philosophical differences between Popper and Wittgenstein were vast, and probably could not have been bridged, but one feels that their unremitting hostility towards each other came from a deeper, odder source. They looked at each other and saw that was what they might have become, what they had rejected, and their contempt rose.

Wittgenstein's greatness and originality is probably beyond question now and was promptly recognised. When he handed in his first book as his thesis, G.E. Moore's examiner's report read: 'It is my personal opinion that Mr Wittgenstein's thesis is a work of genius; but be that as it may, it is certainly well up to the standard required for the Cambridge degree of doctor of philosophy.'

But in many ways, Popper was the more recognisable philosopher. Where Wittgenstein dismissed most of the traditional questions of philosophy, such as ethics and metaphysics, in favour of a discussion of pure linguistic concepts, Popper always remained more worldly. The Open Society and its Enemies, a wildly controversial attack on Plato, is the sort of engaged book which philosophy has always produced.

Wittgenstein would have denied that it was philosophy at all, and the Philosophical Investigations represent something quite new and not in any sense - in the famous formula - a 'footnote to Plato'.

Wittgenstein's story is well known and still alarming. He came from an extremely rich Viennese family and gave away all his money (he said later, with uncharacteristic silliness: 'If you were going for a long hike up a steep mountain, you would deposit your weighty rucksack at the bottom'). Still, those patrician values had an odd way of surfacing in later life - he startled Cambridge friends by describing the gowns at a Trinity May Ball as 'tawdry' - and perhaps gave him the confidence to dismiss the work of contemporaries, not at all politely.

Not just contemporaries, either; to Wittgenstein, the whole tradition of German idealism was nothing more than, as Edmonds and Eidenow say, 'obfuscation, mumbo-jumbo and muddle-headedness'.

Wittgenstein was famously rude; when poor Lydia Lopokova said on a walk: 'What a beautiful tree', Wittgenstein barked back: 'What do you mean?' and she dissolved into tears. Talking to philosophers, Wittgenstein saw rudeness as a necessary dismissal; to discuss many of the traditional questions of philosophy was to reveal oneself as a charlatan.

Not everyone went along with the exhilarating dismissals of Wittgenstein and the Vienna Circle; A.J. Ayer later said: 'Well, I suppose the most important of the defects was that nearly all of it was false.'

Popper led the charge against, describing Wittgenstein's picture theory of language as 'hopelessly and indeed outrageously mistaken'. For Popper, the clearing out of philosophical discourse was the first task, not the only one, of the philosopher; cleaning the glasses through which the philosopher must then peer.

He believed in the existence of philosophical questions and when he was invited to talk on the subject to a Cambridge discussion group, the stage was set for disagreement and physical assault.

Not much is known about the details of the meeting, but it forms an intriguing centre to this entertaining and thoughtful book. There are enough very funny stories about Wittgenstein to make the story interesting even to a resolute non-philosopher like me, who shrinks from propositions like 'All non-ravens are non-black'.

Who won? Well, in some sense, Wittgenstein, since his ideas powerfully shaped all postwar thought and directed our attention towards the linguistic world. But Popper, in the end, made as considerable an impact - he was Mrs Thatcher's favourite philosopher, after all - and it is difficult not to reflect that Wittgenstein's stance, though a necessary one, resembles someone trying to turn back the tide.

People will always go on talking about questions of ethics and metaphysics and it takes more than a few Cambridge philosophers to dissuade them. Whereof we cannot speak, thereof we will go on guessing, I suppose.

webTitle: Observer review: Power by Michel Foucault

fields.headline: Denunciation, deviation and repetition
fields.standfirst: Foucault's fascination with sex and death had seditious motives, but does Power deserve its billing as part of his 'essential works'?
fields.trailText: Foucault's fascination with sex and death had seditious motives, but does Power deserve its billing as part of his 'essential works'?
fields.body:
Power: The Essential Works Volume 3
Michel Foucault
Penguin £25, pp480

Foucault, garbled and parrotted by academic hacks, has become something of an evil genius for our times. I thought of him the other day when someone in Oxford accused me of being a 'liberal humanist', which in today's academic police state is the most unforgivable of intellectual sins. My crime, to which I pleaded proudly guilty, was to actually mean something. Didn't I realise the individual, so gloriously exemplified by Shakespeare's characters, had been declared obsolete by Foucault, and that the liberal play of possibility in interpretation was a mere mask for the imposition of repressive prejudice? Knowledge, Foucault declared, can never know the world. No wonder academics are such zealous disciples: his paradox absolves them from having to teach anything.

In 1973, he brought the bad news to the Pontifical Catholic University of Rio de Janeiro, where he lectured on 'Truth and Juridical Forms'. God, he told the pontificating Catholics, had been killed off by Nietzsche; it remained for us to de-deify nature by recognising its instinctual chaos, its unknowable wilfulness. The world was a battle between insurgent desire and the blind brutality of power. Nothing is right; truth and justice - the follies of the liberal humanist, defended in the comic strip by a Superman who is definitely no Nietzschean - are the alibis of might.

Our only means of self-defence lay, for Foucault, in the defiance of unreasoning taboos. Intellectually or erotically, we should rejoice to find ourselves outlawed or classified as criminals, because we have offended the norms of a society whose business is to discipline and punish us. Among the occasional texts collected in this anthology is an essay on the 'Lives of Infamous Men', unearthed from the archives of the Bastille: a commentary on careers of terror and scandal, libertinage and profligacy, which subvert the official consecration of virtue and heroism. (This, I should add, is one of the few valuable pieces on offer: these Essential Works, mostly consisting of repetitious lectures and ephemeral journalism, are far from essential and sometimes, in several long interviews explicating Foucault's shorter, more epigrammatic books, they're not works at all.)

Foucault's campaign of sedition began with an abstract, theoretical study of 'procedures of classification in the order of empirical knowledge'. This led him to assail the institutions which apparently uphold reason and profess to cure physical or moral ailments. He denounced the madhouse, the medical clinic and the prison as agents of a false, censorious piety. He admitted his motives were seditious: 'For me, madness, sexuality and crime are more intense subjects.' Succumbing to this attraction, he saw himself as a colleague of the deviant heroes of Genet's novels.

One of the best pieces here is a short, impassioned assault on Georges Pompidou's guillotining of two prisoners in 1971. Their abrupt end demonstrates that the whole penal system is impelled by 'the desire for death, the fascination with death'; and that lust - symbolised by the rearing, phallic, blood-stained shape of the guillotine - was grounded, for Foucault, in a fatal sexual curiosity. This complicity between sex and death revealed to him 'the fascism in us all', just as it provoked Genet's sexual rhapsodies about the Nazis. The revelation was meant to be shocking: Foucault would not have enjoyed the spectacle of academics convening fascist rallies to enforce the credo of political correctness. And, in the years before his death from an Aids-related illness in 1984, he made a kind of self-destructive atonement for what he had discovered about his unholy, illiberal, inhumane nature.

Foucault's social science, properly understood, functioned as a coded autobiography. He berated the justice system as a greedy 'consumer of confessions', but specialised in a discreet, illicit confessional mode of his own. Thus in 1982 he extolled the Arab institution of the public bath house, which survives as 'a cathedral of pleasure at the heart of the city'. By then he was frequenting homosexual bath houses in the US cities where he lectured: gymnasia of liberated instinct, free from the 'society of supervision'.

His reflections on the perversity that prompts us 'to love power, to desire the very thing that dominates and exploits us' also read rather differently now we know about his adventures in the S/M dens of San Francisco. There he bowed down before power, derived a fierce thrill from its domination and exploitation of him, and stoically endured the medical consequences of what he called his 'limit-experience'. 'In the depths of his dream,' he believed, 'what man encounters is his own death.' It was a tragic perception, far from the amoral gaeity of Zarathustra. Could Foucault have been a liberal humanist after all?

webTitle: Looking for orchids in the Darien Gap

fields.headline: Garden of good and evil
fields.standfirst: Colombia's Darien Gap is a stinking 1,000-square-mile swamp full of dengue fever and the world's most dangerous snakes. But nothing could stop mild-mannered flower fanatic Trevor Hart Dyke in his search for undiscovered orchids. At least... until he was kidnapped for six months by a heavily armed group of guerrillas
fields.trailText: Colombia's Darien Gap is a stinking 1,000-square-mile swamp full of dengue fever and the world's most dangerous snakes. But nothing could stop mild-mannered flower fanatic Trevor Hart Dyke in his search for undiscovered orchids. At least... until he was kidnapped for six months by a heavily armed group of guerrillas.
fields.body:
Meet Tom. He's mad. Mad as a bat, as a badger, as a bag of spanners. In the nicest, most harmless way of course, but mad, barking, daft, tapped, a can short of a six pack, a ha'penny short of a shilling.

He admits it, too. And that's the first step back to health. But Tom doesn't want to get better. He wants to convert the world, he wants everyone to share in his secret joy, he wants to broadcast his passion in the most flagrantly promiscuous way, he wants everyone to hear the voices that have spoken to him since he was very, very young.

Tom Hart Dyke, a perfectly presentable 24-year-old from a small village in Kent, has no outward signs of delusion. But Tom is in love with plants.

Not any old plants either, though he admits a yen for eucalypts and a soft spot for certain spiny shrubs. Tom is obsessed with flowers. But not any old flowers. Tom is in love with the royal family of the flower world. He is genuinely, deeply, tragically in love with orchids. And, as everybody knows, lunacy and love go hand in hand.

Nearly a year ago Tom and a friend - Paul Winder, a merchant banker on a sabbatical from the City - hired two local guides and set off into the Darien Gap, a fetid, malaria-ridden slice of primary rainforest and swamp that straddles the borders of Panama and Colombia. Tom wanted to find rare orchids. His mate came along for a laugh. But, as swiftly became very clear, there aren't many laughs to be had in the Darien Gap.

There are roads all the way from Alaska to southern Argentina - except for in the Darien Gap. There is, more or less, some kind of law and order, too - except in the Darien Gap. Its stinking thousand or so square miles of jungle act as a sump under the two continents it bisects. So, in addition to the many and varied natural hazards (more of these later), it is full of bandits, fugitives, drug traffickers, junkies, bounty hunters, renegades, left-wing guerrillas, right-wing death squads, killers who have found religion, priests who have lost their faith - and Tom, his mate Paul and a cheap Chinese tent.

A road, shedding prosperity like a skin as it goes, coils down from the north through Central America. Yaviza - a small town with a few filthy hotels - is pretty much what you'd imagine would be at the wrong end of the American rainbow. Several trails lead off into the Darien Gap. One day in March last year, Tom Hart Dyke and his friend, full of bounce and brio, set off down one.

Early on the third morning they saw that their guides, who had been a little ahead of them, had stopped and were standing very still. Among the undergrowth 10 yards away were a dozen figures in camouflage fatigues. There was a short conversation in rapid and heavily accented Spanish. Despite the gloom of the deep forest, the pair saw the guns that were pointed at them and raised their hands and dropped to their knees. Then they lay down with their faces in the dark, moist jungle earth. The guerrillas, covering them with M16s and handguns, tied their wrists together behind their backs. Around them, the forest hooted and shrilled and cawed and croaked.

After half an hour, the guerrillas spoke directly to the two men for the first time. 'Are you going to run?' they asked. 'No' said Tom, and they were untied. The next time anyone heard from the pair was more than six months later.

Tom may be in love with orchids but the feelings aroused in others are earthier. The very name is derived from orchis, the Greek for testicle, and refers not only to the shape of the plant's tubers but also to the long-held belief that orchids sprang from the spilled semen of mating animals. The Greeks believed that plant parts resembled the bodily part they could be used to treat. So, logically enough, they dried the tubers and used them to treat impotence. Some in the Far East still do this, though orchid tubers are a popular cure for bronchitis, too.

A Herbal Guide, published in England in 1653, advised that orchids be treated with care: 'They are hot and moist in operation, under the dominion of Venus, and provoke lust exceedingly.' Even today, orchid lovers fervently splutter about a specimen's fine erect stamen, or luscious purple lips.

Dr Phillip Cribb is curator of orchids at Kew Gardens. He may be a minor deity in the botanical world as a whole, but he is Jupiter in the orchid-lovers' pantheon. He is also modest and approachable. His analysis of the attraction of orchids is less Freudian.

'People love orchids because of their incredible diversity,' he says. 'They are the largest family of flowering plants. There could easily be 30,000, including some of the world's most beautiful flowers. There are many new species still to be discovered.'

He's right about the variety. Some orchids weigh more than a tonne and spill out across a 100ft of forest, like a huge vine. The smallest is the size of a fingernail. Some smell wonderful. The carrion orchid doesn't. Some are extraordinary in their excess of colour, others are as drab as Charlie Dimmock's T-shirts. They grow in almost every climate, all over the world.

What they all share is an identical structure - arranged symmetrically are two petals, two sepals in front of them and a lower leaf that usually curls and is known as the lip. They are designed to attract insects, thus the pornographically lurid hues.

But if neither sex nor aesthetics draw you in, then social aspiration might. The Duke of Devonshire was one of the pioneers of the new 'orchid houses' and Queen Victoria was proud of her own collection. 'The orchid has always had a certain cachet,' says Dr Cribb.

And they've always inspired obsession and craving. Victorians apparently confessed to suffering a general 'orchidelerium'. They were the ones who really got the orchid fad going. And the demand from newly enriched, newly leisured classes was insatiable. Big collectors dispatched orchid hunters throughout the world. Then, as now, novelty and exoticism drove the market, and buyers paid thousands of guineas in London salesrooms for the latest specimens wrenched from the earth of Sarawak, Brunei, Nepal or Arunachal Pradesh. The collectors sent out to foreign parts were not aristocrats. Instead, the British gentry - and many newly rich self-made men in the textile cities of the north - stayed home and dispatched their servants out into the wild to do the grubby job of dragging the plants from the soil. Many of the orchid-hunters paid with their lives.

By the 1960s, commercial growers were mass-producing orchids for general consumption. But, though you can buy an orchid for a tenner at a garden centre, orchid fever is as fierce as ever. It's a £7bn-a-year business. The best orchids have as refined a pedigree as any Cruft's winning dog and sell for as much as a small house in Leeds. Top orchid breeders' top plants are priceless. With any one flowering orchid capable of producing thousands of seedlings, a popular and productive mature plant is a licence to print money. And where there is money and obsession and beauty and exotic locations, there is - in the style of all good thrillers - crime.

Keeping an eye on the old ladies with their Thermoses, the tweedy gents up from Buckinghamshire and the international criminal masterminds at Kew Gardens' annual orchid festival this year, were 14 police officers. They provided a 24-hour guard for the best orchids. The rest of the year, glass panels and CCTV do the job. Kew's orchids are among the best-guarded flowers in the world.

So what are the police scared of? A Rafflesesque flower thief with an MG and a Mayfair flat? A Dome-style smash-and-grab tuber raid, complete with speedboat on the Thames, sawn-offs and dialogue from the Long Good Friday ('Shaddup, you long streak of paralysed paphiopedilum')?

Charles McKay heads up Her Majesty's Customs and Excise 'Cites' (Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species) team at Heathrow. Under the convention, some rare species of orchid are proscribed - it is illegal to remove them from their habitats in the wild - others need permits in order to be transported and sold. Gram for gram, a very rare orchid can be worth more than Class A drugs.

Last September, two of McKay's men inspected a shipment of orchids from Taiwan for a British professional grower. Packed in boxes in the airport freight terminal were plants with a retail value of £60,000. Some had the necessary permits. Many didn't. The orchids, as experts at Kew confirmed, were indeed being smuggled. The consignment was confiscated, but no one was prosecuted. 'It's pretty hard to get hard evidence,' says McKay.

The case was not unusual. The Cites team seizes thousands of orchids each year. The best-known orchid scandal is the case of Henry Azadehdel, a self-taught botanist and UFO fanatic from Nottingham. In 1986, after years of travelling through China, Malaysia, Borneo, Chile and Peru, Azadehdel was stopped at Heathrow with 15 undeclared plants from Chile in his luggage. He was accused of plundering endangered orchid species around the world, bringing at least one of them to the verge of extinction in its natural habitat, and brought to trial. Though he had a previously undiscovered orchid named after him in recognition of his legitimate work, he was alleged to have made £200,000 from smuggling and selling rare plants at the same time.

One lady's slipper orchid, ripped from the ground in Borneo, was alleged to have been sold for £16,000. When the police raided three greenhouses at Azadehdel's home they found 438 orchids, worth £42,000, of which 334 were endangered species that had been 'jungle-collected'.

The argument among orchid lovers is whether Azadehdel was a fanatic whose obsession had got out of control, or a ruthless exploiter of a fevered market.

After inquiries all over the world, the Nottingham orchid buff went down for a 12-month sentence and got a £20,000 fine.

'I don't want any part of it anymore,' said Azadehdel in an interview after his conviction. 'The orchid world is dirty.'

So dirty that somewhere in the north of England, at a top-secret location known only to a few senior botanists, private security guards keep a watch on the last remaining specimen in the UK of a particular type of lady's slipper orchid. It had always been rare in Britain but a combination of avaricious amateur gardeners and the destruction of its natural habitat pushed it to the bring of extinction. For 80 years a single flowering plant held on - the sole survivor of the species. Then, a few years ago, experts managed to get seeds from it and raised thousands of seedlings in greenhouses. These are now being reintroduced to the wild and, last year, for the first time, one of the seedlings flowered in the wild. Like its parent plant, it had a slipper-shaped golden lip and petals that swept back and spiralled towards the ground and was very, very beautiful.

'It's terrible,' says Tom Hart Dyke shaking his head and grinning and hopping from one leg to the other. 'I mean it's bizarre, weird. I can't explain it. It's awful, terrible, and from such an early age. It is an obsession, an obsession - really only word for it.' And he shakes his head again and smiles beatifically.

Tom is standing in his orchid sheds at the bottom of the garden of his parent's house. The gardens are 140 acres of prime Kentish countryside and the house is a gigantic 16th-century rambling pile called Lullingstone Castle. It has portraits of men in ruffs on the walls, roundheads' armour and one of the few remaining Tudor gatehouses in Britain. Tom is showing me a purple, yellow and white slipper orchid and is so excited that his knees are actually shaking. This is a man who, when he had an few hours stopover in Tokyo airport, spent it finding a janitor to open up the airport garden 'to see if there was anything interesting'. 'No, no, terrible - not normal at all. I didn't even know how to spell "girls",' he says. 'Didn't care, don't care.'

They looked after him when he was sick, which was apparently fairly often.

And why the Darien Gap? 'Just fancied a poke about. Some amazing things there, amazing, amazing,' and he's off again, gabbling a stream of genera, species, habitats, colours.

Slightly foolhardy, perhaps? He seems almost taken aback. 'Ooh no, we asked about - asked in the hotels and things. Heard a bit about the situation. Thought it was safe.' And, in the best British tradition, stumbled off into the unknown, anyway.

The group that seized Tom and his friend, Paul Winder, were probably from the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (Farc) - the 15,000-strong left-wing guerrilla movement that has been fighting a brutal, filthy insurgency against the central government of Colombia for nearly 40 years.

No one knows how many people have died in the violence - tens of thousands - though most agree that in recent years the violence has got worse. Assassinations and massacres by right-wing death squads have forced Farc groups into the more inhospitable areas of Colombia. In the last few years, discipline has begun to break down in the movement. There are now hundreds of armed groups, whose allegiance to the Farc commanders seems slight. 'What did you think when you saw the guerrillas?' I asked Tom.

'Ooh, I thought, "Amazing, oh no, incredible, amazing".'

And what about when you were lying on the ground tied up with your face in the dirt and a gun at your back?

'Lord um er what did I think?

I just thought um "Oh bugger" mmm... that was it - "Oh bugger".'

For the next nine months, the pair were marched from camp to camp through the jungle, sometimes spending 30 successive days walking along rough jungle trails. Their captors never revealed their identities and never issued any coherent demands.

'We tried to live off each other. There were low times, high times and terrifying times, as well as fantastic times. It was a huge roller-coaster of emotions,' Winder told a press conference, on his return.

The guerrillas fed the two men on plantains and beef ('Amazing I put on weight,' says Tom), taught them rudimentary Spanish and constructed mats out of palm leaves to make them more comfortable. The guerrillas brought them orchids. As they didn't know where they were, their escape was hardly an issue.

They were given 5,000 pesos (about £1), a little food, a few old Coca-Cola bottles full of water and a machete, and then started walking.

Their arms and legs were shredded by sharp leaves and thorns. On the sixth day, they broke through on to a track. They recognised it. They were back where they started.

The guerrillas were not particularly pleased to see them again.

Mad, you see. Quite mad.

webTitle: Hospitals urged to cure NHS ills by planting trees

fields.headline: Hospitals urged to cure NHS ills by planting trees
fields.trailText: The tree huggers have been right all along: those big wooden things are good for you. In an unusual piece of creative thinking by civil servants, Department of Health officials are trying to persuade hospitals to plant trees where patients can see them.
fields.body:
The tree huggers have been right all along: those big wooden things are good for you. In an unusual piece of creative thinking by civil servants, Department of Health officials are trying to persuade hospitals to plant trees where patients can see them.

The Government believes the NHS's shortages of beds, staff, drugs and equipment could all be mitigated by some birches around the car park. The Department says that surrounding hospitals with trees is a more cost effective way to treat patients than spending on drugs and equipment, and will have the bonus of making staff work harder. The patients could even be told to plant the trees as part of their treatment.

The Department has paid for thousands of glossy leaflets extolling the health benefits of trees to be sent to health authorities and hospitals. The leaflet, called 'Sustainable Urban Forestry - Benefitting Public Health', says there are measurable advantages if bedridden patients can see trees. 'They need less pain-relieving medication, they are better patients and they need to stay in hospital for a shorter period of time, so surrounding hospitals with views of trees can improve both healthcare and economic efficiency.'

Planting trees could be made more cost efficient by getting patients to do it. 'Growing, planting and caring for trees is very therapeutic and it has been widely used for a long time to help people with learning difficulties, physical disabilities and those recovering from stroke,' says the brochure. In addition, 'the trees will make staff feel less stressed, improve their quality of life at work and help make them even more effective.'

A spokesman for the Department of Health said the strategy was based on scientific research: 'There is growing evidence of the health benefits of trees. Research has shown that patients recovering from surgery who can see trees need less medication and have faster recovery times. This is good for patients and good for hospitals.'

Professor John Ashton, regional director of public health for North-West England, has had talks with local hospitals to get them planting. 'There's something primeval about trees that makes people feel comfortable and relaxed,' he said. 'If the hospital environment is drab, it's not surprising if people don't get better. In the North-West there are now 12 hospitals that are looking at their total environment.'

 The leaflet can be obtained through the National Urban Forestry Unit, telephone 01902 828 600 National Urban Forestry Unit

webTitle: Leader: Our DNA should not be for sale

fields.headline: Our DNA should not be for sale
fields.standfirst: Don't create a genetic underclass
fields.trailText: Don't create a genetic underclass.
fields.body:
Knowledge about human DNA, and its predictive power about our character and our health, already provides awesome testament to the scale of scientific advance in the last 50 years. It is the sort of issue which creates a significant moral challenge for the new century precisely because it outmatches our inherited legal and ethical frameworks.

Using gene technology to improve medical techniques is reasonable and entirely welcome, but this progress becomes alarming if it is sought in order to change the shape of future human organisms and the structure of our social systems. In America, the sex of children is already up for sale, with companies offering to screen out sperm carrying the 'wrong' chromosomes. An obscure Canadian sect - the Raelians - is trying to clone a dead child. This is unacceptable. But as our knowledge deepens, the borderline of acceptability becomes harder and harder to police.

Until now, the British view has been laissez faire to the point of negligence. While the Home Secretary wants to allow the police to build a national DNA data bank, his colleagues have been indifferent to consumer demands for protection from insurance company inquiries about our DNA. This 'pro-business' Government has not dared give offence to the insurance industry. However, as we report today, Alan Milburn, the impeccably Blairite Health Secretary, intends to give an indication this week that Ministers might side with the citizen rather than business after all.

What the insurance industry really wants is access to our entire health and DNA profiles to provide an insight into likely life expectancy and the chance of claiming for care in old age. They can then load premiums to their advantage. No other insurance industry in the European Union is permitted to collect such information, thus allowing it to cherry-pick its clientele and create a genetic underclass.

There is no reason why Britain should be the exception. In any case, the number of 'simple' genes allowing straightforward predictions about conditions such as Huntington's disease is tiny - and the trivial number of cases has almost no measurable impact on insurers' actuarial calculations.

Neither the state nor private companies should have access to our DNA to further their interests. The presumption must be that such information is private. In its forthcoming report, the Government's Human Genetics Commission should call at least for a two-year moratorium on disclosing DNA information until we understand the likely implications. Mr Milburn says he will accept its recommendation. We hope he is as good as his word.

webTitle: Observer review: Just Capital by Adair Turner

fields.headline: Goodbye stakeholders, hello social democrats
fields.standfirst: Peter Mandelson prescribes a good dose of modern social democracy to supplement Adair Turner's Just Capital
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson prescribes a good dose of modern social democracy to supplement Adair Turner's Just Capital
fields.body:
Just Capital
Adair Turner
Macmillan £20, pp406
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Adair Turner has produced a gem of liberal political economy worthy of Meade, Keynes and Hobhouse. Just Capital should become a New Labour 'must read'. He is for the free market, but without the slavish obsession of the true believer. With fact and logic, he destroys the ideologues of Anglo-Saxon Euroscepticism who take for granted the automatic superiority of the American model over the European. He rejects the argument of the Right that globalisation makes governments powerless to provide decent public services. He believes that markets, left to themselves, will not solve all the world's problems such as financial instability or environmental change.

At the same time, competitive markets are the best route to higher productivity and living standards. I agree with him that the British Left has historically failed to appreciate markets and that market mechanisms can play a useful role in solving a variety of social and economic problems. Nevertheless, as a social democrat who believes that we are in politics principally to advance and equalise individual opportunity, I am not completely convinced by Turner's arguments. Where would I add grit to this appealing oyster of social liberalism?

Like me, he believes in full employment. The key is to guarantee 'positive' labour-market flexibility. 'Flexibility' is not, however, a matter of employees fitting in with what management requires. Rather, it is firms setting working hours in accordance with the needs of markets and consumers, agreeing wages freely, and workers moving easily from one job or skill to the next, with minimum employment standards that do not discourage employers from creating jobs.

It is Turner's view that society should minimise involuntary unemployment. It is legitimate for the individual to choose voluntary unemployment and to receive benefits instead of work. This is a liberal view of the relationship between individual liberty and the state. In contrast, social democrats would demand and expect more for people. There is a moral duty attached to work. A society where everyone who can work does work not only minimises waste and maximises prosperity, it offers the best conditions for genuine equality of opportunity.

The challenge, however, is to provide a wider definition of what employment means. Social democrats have traditionally equated participation with the paid labour market. Yet there is non-paid work that should be considered legitimate. Caring, informal education and volunteering all enhance individual wellbeing and are good for society. An active welfare state designed to encourage people into work should recognise this. In its second term, New Labour has to broaden the scope of its 'welfare to work' policies.

Turner is also too dismissive of the state's role in promoting national competitiveness. Just Capital accepts the traditional, neo-liberal view that the state should do nothing to influence where industries, sectors or firms choose to locate. If we examine what works in public policy, as Turner commends, a more balanced picture emerges. For example, would he have rejected the EU's decision to invest in Airbus, transforming the company into a world leader? Or investment to keep the Japanese car manufacturer Nissan located in the North-East of England?

Governments exercise an important influence in promoting sectors or assisting business clusters, distinct from the policies of the 1960s and 1970s. Trying to pick winners or even reconstructing groups of companies to conform to a bureaucratic view of what makes commercial sense was conspicuously unsuccessful. It diminishes the efficiency of national economies. But this should not prevent investment in research and its commercial application that, in the long term, makes a country the world leader, especially in the knowledge economy, where sustained scientific research is necessary.

Perhaps the most difficult aspect of Just Capital for social democrats is his dismissal of stakeholding. He argues that the Anglo-Saxon model of shareholder capitalism is probably better suited to the current period of rapid technological change. Stakeholding was the fashionable philosophy of the mid-1990s. Will Hutton's The State We're In offered an attractive deconstruction of free-market economics after the excesses of the 1980s. However, I now doubt the viability of stakeholding as a guide to policy. I accept the view that in a world where stocks are openly traded on the financial markets, firms are led to maximise shareholder value.

Companies perform best where they work in social partnership with employees. But even if we tried to legislate for stakeholding, it is difficult to imagine how governments could alter corporate behaviour without drastic and unwieldy intervention. Yet if shareholder capitalism has triumphed in an era of global financial markets, this has major implications for those who actually live and work in the modern economy. It affects wage levels, the employment rights to which workers are entitled, working conditions, training, and how the work-life balance is managed. This raises some crucial questions.

Turner's response is twofold. First, individuals are fundamentally self-interested, and ultimately, in his view, this is the best way to maximise economic efficiency and wealth creation.

Second, those who want to build a responsible society should trust the state to redistribute income, and provide core public services. There is no contradiction between individuals who vote altruistically, yet behave self-interestedly in the marketplace.

If Turner is right, as he may be, then the book is strangely neglectful of the role modern trade unionism could play in his liberal economy. He does acknowledge that if the Wilson government had succeeded with 'In Place of Strife' in 1969, British trade unions could have modernised and assumed a more constructive role. It was certainly a missed opportunity of historic proportions, but to argue that it has now gone forever is simply too pessimistic.

Whether it is policies to promote full employment, creating the conditions in which enterprise can thrive in the knowledge economy or developing a role for modern trade unionism, we need a good dose of modern social democracy to help our country succeed.

fields.headline: Racists created the Noble Savage
fields.standfirst: Author claims term was the work of bigots, not Rousseau
fields.trailText: Author claims term was the work of bigots, not Rousseau.
fields.body:
The Noble Savage, long assumed to be the invention of the eighteenth-century philosopher Jean-Jacques Rousseau, was, in fact, a racist propaganda device of British anthropologists to create a climate where slavery and genocide could be mooted.

The claim that Rousseau created the myth was made by one of the nineteenth century's most notorious racists to give weight to his belief in the notion of 'inferior' races, according to a new book, The Myth of the Noble Savage .

Ter Ellingson, associate professor of anthropology at the University of Washington, believes the manipulation of the myth was part of a successful attempt by a faction of racist anthropologists to take over the anti-racist Ethnological Society in London in the late 1850s.

'Rousseau did not promote the idea of the Noble Savage nor did he ever mention it. The idea he did is one of the most widespread misbeliefs of all time,' said Ellingson.

The term 'noble savage' was mentioned a handful of times before Rousseau, most notably by the poet and playwright John Dryden, but Ellingson maintains it had fallen out of use until reinvoked by the racist anthropologist John Crawfurd in 1859.

By attributing the myth to Rousseau, Crawfurd gave the notion intellectual weight.

'The myth and the attribution of it to Rousseau was reintroduced by a racist faction in the Ethnological Society of London as part of a coup which aimed to divert the society from its anti-racist, pro-human rights roots,' said Ellingson.

Ellingson maintains that the myth was a vital tool which enabled racist anthropologists such as Crawfurd to promote the centrality of race as a scientific ideology while advocating violently racist modes of ordering society.

An unbroken three-month run of racist presentations followed the 1859 coup of the society's board and it was in the first of these lectures that Crawfurd demolished the illusion of savage nobility and denied any non-white race any right to equality. 'Crawfurd's inaugural address was an announcement of the overthrow of the old ways and the ascendancy of a new anthropological racism and a new supporting mythology,' said Ellingson.

In his speech, Crawfurd recited lines from a Dryden play mentioning the noble savage and damned such people as 'miserable beings'. 'I cannot set much value on [his] freedom of the being [and] nor can I conceive anything noble in the poor naked, crouching creature, trembling with cold and starving from hunger,' he said.

'Such savages are the men whose condition was envied by a very eloquent but very eccentric philosopher of the last century; but I imagine a week's residence, even a night's lodging, with the Fuegians would have brought Jean-Jacques Rousseau to a saner conclusion.'.

Ellingson believes Crawfurd was so convincing that the original Noble Savage myth was forgotten. 'The mere repetition of the words Noble Savage sufficed to serve as a devastating weapon against any opposition to the racist agenda. The myth of the Noble Savage became a weapon in the Ethnological Society's scientific-racist project of helping to naturalise a genocidal stance towards the "inferior" races.'

fields.headline: Alchemy eyes Cammell bid
fields.trailText: Venture capital firm Alchemy has emerged as a bidder for shipbuilder Cammell Laird, which went into receivership last Wednesday.
fields.body:
Venture capital firm Alchemy has emerged as a bidder for shipbuilder Cammell Laird, which went into receivership last Wednesday.

Sources close to the company said Alchemy had made an initial approach before the Merseyside-based group appointed investment bank Close Brothers on 20 March to carry out a restructuring.

The news comes as Cammell directors consider a management buyout of the UK business, which employs 1,800 workers at its Merseyside and Tyneside operations. Chairman Juan Kelly is keen for an MBO to succeed and held discussions last week with Edward Klempka, one of four receivers from accountant PricewaterhouseCoopers.

Klempka, who said he was optimistic about selling the company as a going concern, told The Observer: 'Cammell Laird has a recent history of profitability and has an international following. I welcome the interest that has been shown from possible buyers or from an MBO.'

Cammell has had problems since a contract to extend a liner for Italian firm Costa Crociere was terminated after it had spent £40m. Its difficulties were heightened when it failed to clinch a contract to build two cruise ships worth $500m for operator Luxus.

Kelly said: 'The market is there, the facilities are good, the workforce is good, as is the core of the management - an MBO would be a natural next step.'

He is willing to take a role in a buyout, and other directors, including group managing director John Schofield, and Tyneside managing director David Skentelbery, are considering this option. Alchemy is a possible partner, although four venture capital firms are said to have made approaches.

Left to sink in sea of debt

webTitle: Classic Stories of the Old and New Testament read by Martin Jarvis and Rosalind Ayres

fields.headline: Classic Stories of the Old and New Testament read by Martin Jarvis and Rosalind Ayres
fields.standfirst:
Classic Stories of the Old Testament
Classic Stories of the New Testament Running time 3hrs each
CSA Telltapes £9.99, or both for £13.99 from www.csatelltapes.demon.co.uk
Hear an extract
You will need RealPlayer to listen to this clip. You can download it here free
fields.trailText: The narration of these stories from the Bible maintains their dignity while creating a startling immediacy.
fields.body:
In the incomparable language of the King James version, Ruth gleans an 'ephah' of barley; David puts smooth stones from the brook to slay Goliath into his 'scrip'; and God in Revelation will give 'unto him that is athirst of the fountain of life'.

The narration of these stories from the Bible maintains their dignity while creating a startling immediacy. Martin Jarvis's voice as he reads David's lament for Jonathan and Saul prickles the skin. They 'were lovely and pleasant in their lives, and in their death they were not divided'.

When Mary Magdalene realises she is addressing not the gardener but the risen Christ by the empty sepulchre, she cries out, 'Rabboni'. In that single word, Jarvis succeeds in conveying both Mary's surprise and the depth of her love.

The readers clarify the message through nuance, as when Peter talks of the apostles who were filled with the Holy Ghost and speaking in tongues. 'For these are not drunken,' he says, 'this is that which was spoken by the prophet.' To these words - to the mockers who suspected the effects of the new wine - Jarvis gives a quiet but unshakeable confidence.

The selection of stories is excellent, producing a tremendous narrative drive. Whether believer or non-believer, the listener cannot fail to be entranced.
