fields.headline: Wine, woman and song
fields.standfirst: Berry Brothers, one of the country's oldest wine merchants, is hoping a duet with Delia Smith will provide a recipe for future success
fields.trailText: Berry Brothers, one of the country's oldest wine merchants, is hoping a duet with Delia Smith will provide a recipe for future success.
fields.body:
Berry Brothers & Rudd of 3 St James's Street, London SW1, a wine business that supplies the Queen as well as her tree-hugging son, has just clambered into bed with Delia Smith. Cyberspace throws up some strange alliances, but this one seems very strange indeed. What does one of the country's oldest and most patrician wine merchants have in common with a down-to-earth, Norwich City-supporting cook with a penchant for cranberries? Not much on the face of it. But the more you look at the deal, the more it makes sense. Berry Brothers is going to recommend a wine to match Delia's recipe of the day on deliaonline.com. Despite appearances to the contrary - the shop makes Berry Brothers look like a business with its heart in the 18th century - it's the sort of step that has made it one of the most dynamic wine merchants in the country.

Simon Berry, a seventh-generation wine merchant, says the shop is a misleading façade for the business. 'It worries me that people think we're too stuffy to buy from. But what can we do? We can't knock it down, paint it pink or put up neon lights. English Heritage would have a fit.' And so, you suspect would Berry. 'The fascinating thing about any business is deciding what you keep and what you throw away.'

Berry Brothers has managed the trick with considerable skill. In 1994, Berry and six other family members set out to restructure the business. Berry Brothers had always been cushioned from the realities of the modern wine market by the success of its Cutty Sark Whisky, but it was time to move into the late-20th century. Since then, it's opened a shop at Heathrow Terminal Three, set up a website, opened sites in Dublin and Hong Kong and created a wine school in the cellars at St James's.

If Berry Brothers chose bad wines, all this would be irrelevant. But they don't. The list runs to more than 2,500 lines, ranging from fine wines to everyday bottles. 'We'll sell anything as long as it's good to drink,' says Berry. Indeed, this has always been the case. Berry was reading a wine list from 1900 last week and came across five Australian wines - revolutionary stuff at the time.

Needless to say, you won't find a £2.99 plonk here. 'Our customers,' according to Berry, 'are people who realise that by paying a little more, you get more back in terms of taste and interest. Wine is a mysterious subject in many ways, but it's also very simple. In the final analysis, it's just fermented grape juice.' Delia Smith, who once spent a large chunk of a television programme 'teaching' people how to boil an egg, couldn't have put it better herself.

1998 Côtes du Rhne Villages, Séguret, Domaine La Montagne d'Or (£6.95). Produced in one of the most beautiful villages in what locals like to call 'la Provence intelligente', this is yet another wonderful southern Rhne 1998. Soft, juicy and peppery.

1998 Saxenburg Private Collection Shiraz, Stellenbosch (£9.95). Saxenburg is among the most exciting estates in South Africa. This top-notch Shiraz is as good as anything from Australia at this price.

1999 Pinot Grigio, Alvaro Pecorari, Friuli (£10.95). Italian Pinot Grigio can be a huge disappointment, but when it's good it's excellent. This example from the heart of the Friuli district is an intense, almost voluptuous white with flavours of pear and orange zest.

1996 Chablis Premier Cru, Vaillons, Daniel Defaix (£16.95). Monsieur Defaix has a reputation for producing Chablis that develops complexity with age. This Premier Cru Chardonnay is nutty, rich and full-bodied.

1996 Château Labégorce-Zédé, Margaux (£20). This is essence of Margaux, produced in a very good left bank vintage, with elegant aromas.

 All the above wines are available from Berry Brothers (0870 900 4300; or orders@bbr.com). Delivery is free on orders over £100; otherwise £7.50 per UK address

fields.headline: Angel delights
fields.standfirst: The short-trouser brigade won't be short-changed when it comes to party food. Here's how to keep things sweet
fields.trailText: The short-trouser brigade won't be short-changed when it comes to party food. Here's how to keep things sweet.
fields.body:
What we feed our children has changed dramatically over the past few decades - indeed, it is evolving day by day. As we go to press, the word is: organic vegetables, no red meat, no peanuts - but all that will probably change by the end of the week. While parents understandably chop and change about what is or isn't good for their kids, one thing remains constant: the sort of food young children ask for at their birthday party.

When I asked a group of children what they wanted for their birthday tea - and allowing them total adult-free abandon - they chose food virtually identical to the stuff served up at every birthday party I went to 30 years ago. It seems that no matter how much children tolerate our latest thoughts and concerns for their dietary wellbeing, what is truly embedded in their collective soul is the thought of chocolate rice-crispy cakes, jelly, ice cream and birthday cake. Of course, there are one or two things that pop up for a year or two then deflate as fast as a knifed Teletubby, but there is a constant, unshakable core which one must respect. To do anything else on this special day would be to break some unwritten rule passed down throughout history. While we can swap the phony orange colouring for freshly squeezed juice and sneak real milk chocolate into the cakes instead of chocolate-flavour covering, some things are written in stone, and we change them at our peril.

Fair enough, I do as I am told, even by someone in short trousers. Whatever good intentions we may have for the rest of the year, I don't honestly think we should even attempt to inject our usual healthy-eating principles into these proceedings. This is a party - their party - and if they want to eat shocking-pink Barbie cake with tooth-rotting icing and six different E numbers, then we shouldn't try to talk them out of it. It is only one day a year, and it just won't be a party if we start clucking away about brown rice and organic carrots.

One of the things I regret most about my childhood was the amount of sugar I was allowed to consume. Buckets of the stuff. I am now paying the price for years of marshmallows and fizzy pop. But as I said, it's a party, and sweet, sweet cake is always at the top of the list. A big cake, yes, but even fairy cakes, complete with camp icing and sugar flowers, are a constant, and when all is said and done, absurdly charming. Adults, no matter what they pretend, find them irresistible. It must say something that if ever I get deeply depressed, the sushi, noodles and fresh fruit juice go out the window to be replaced by a box of Mr Kipling iced fancies eaten in my dressing gown.

The peak of any party was, and still is, reached with the blowing out of the candles. If anybody remembers to dim the lights, then so much the better. I can still feel the butterflies in my tummy as I breathed in, the humiliation of not blowing them out all at once being too much to bear. There was, I seem to remember, an adult strategically situated over my shoulder to make sure they were, by hook or by crook, extinguished in one puff.

There is something special about having your own individual iced cake, but nothing can beat the sheer spectacle of a vast layer cake studded with candles. The best idea I have come across in this respect is Konditor & Cook's (020 7407 5100) tiny iced squares - complete with icing messages or flowers - that can be handed out individually or pushed together to form one huge cake. So the kids get a fabulous, multicoloured birthday cake that can be speared with candles, and then, as if by magic, it splits into 20 tiny cakes. They can tuck in then and there or take their individual sticky square home to squash into the carpet in the back of the car.

While there are a number of rather good books encouraging children to cook, most of those on cooking for children seem to me to be somewhat patronising and out of touch. No parent I have ever met can explain the phenomenal book sales of one particular bestselling author. According to most parents I have spoken to, there is still a huge gap in the market for a book on cooking for children. But one book that gets nearer than most, and was loved by everyone I spoke to, is Eat Up by ex-Ivy head chef Mark Hix (£16.99, Fourth Estate). While the plethora of photographs of cutesy children holding free-range eggs will send even the most adoring parents reaching for the sickbag, the recipes themselves are cracking stuff. Salmon and pea casserole, Corn fritters, fishcakes with herb sauce and Crispy pig's tails put this book head and shoulders above the competition. Here at last are recipes that kids - at least the ones I know - really want to eat. And yes, there is chocolate rice-crispy birthday cake, too. As if anyone would dare.

Mark Hix's Thai summer rolls

Children often prefer raw vegetables to cooked ones. They also like messing about in the kitchen. I see every reason to mercifully exploit this. How you could approach it is by letting them wrap up their own Thai summer rolls. Follow the recipe below, but instead of wrapping the rolls yourself, give each child a piece or two of rice paper, and pile the vegetables in dishes in the middle of the table. The kids then grab whatever they want, heap it up on their rice paper, then roll it up and eat it. Huge fun. I wish my parents had thought if this instead of sandwiches made of egg and cress and white sliced. Makes 8-12.

2 spring onions, finely shredded
10-12 mangetouts, finely shredded
2 large carrots, peeled and finely shredded
1 chicken breast, cooked and finely shredded
1-2 tsp sesame oil
1-2 tsp soy sauce
1 tbsp chopped coriander
8-12 small rice-paper sheets (from Chinese grocers and major supermarkets)

Mix together all the ingredients except the rice paper and season lightly with salt and pepper, if necessary.

Take a shallow bowl large enough to hold the rice paper and half fill it with warm water. Put two or three pieces of rice paper at a time into the water to soften - this normally takes 2-3 minutes. Remove from the water and drain on kitchen paper. Put some of the chicken and vegetable mixture down the centre of each piece of paper and roll up as tightly as possible, then store, seam-side down, on a tray covered with clingfilm until required.

Mark Hix's elderflower jelly

It isn't a party without jelly. Remember not to double up on gelatine if you make more than the amount below. Makes 6 small jellies.

800ml water
juice of 1 lemon
400g caster sugar
40g gelatine
100ml elderflower cordial
200g mixed berries (strawberries, raspberries, blueberries, blackberries)

Bring the water and lemon juice to the boil, add the sugar and stir until dissolved, then remove from the heat, Soak the gelatine leaves in cold water for a minute or so until soft. Gently squeeze out the water, add the gelatine to the sugar syrup and stir until dissolved. Add the elderflower cordial, then leave the jelly to cool but do not let it set.

Put the berries into a 1.5 litre jelly mould or 4-6 individual moulds, then pour in the jelly. Put in the fridge for an hour or so until set.

Blueberry muffins

Blueberries are perfect for throwing into fairy cakes and muffins because most kids seem to like them and, unknown to them, they are little powerhouses of vitamins. Also, if you squash them between your thumb and finger as you add them to the cake mixture, you will find they bleed, sending beautiful purple blue ripples throughout the finished cakes. Makes 12.

250g plain flour
1 level tsp baking powder
4 tbsp caster sugar
1 medium egg
grated zest of 1 small orange
225ml buttermilk or milk
50g butter, melted
225g blueberries

Preheat the oven to 200 C/gas mark 6. Sift the flour and baking powder into a large bowl, then stir in the caster sugar and tsp of salt.

In a separate bowl, beat the egg and add the orange zest and the buttermilk or milk. Stir in the melted butter, then pour the mixture into the flour. Stir for half a dozen strokes, then stop. The mixture will be lumpy, but this does not matter. Divide half the mixture between 12 buttered muffin tins, then drop about four blueberries into each one and cover with the remaining mixture.

Bake the muffins the centre of the preheated oven for about 20 minutes till risen and golden. Serve warm.

 Overleaf, Jim Ainsworth on where to find fun-filled ingredients for a children's party.

Address: The Great House, Lavenham, Suffolk.
Lunch for two, including wine and service, around £60.

My friend Jocelyn lives near Newmarket where he is a pimp for horses. He would not put it this way. In the world of serious racehorse breeding, they are both wary of the vernacular and addicted to euphemism. Still, as his job is to market afternoons of carnal pleasure with some of the world's greatest stallions (yours - or should I say your mare's - for a six-figure sum) it does seem a reasonable description.

It also explains his desire to know where the asparagus at the Great House in the Suffolk village of Lavenham came from. The horse-breeding business is all about provenance and origin, and the obsession can easily tumble into the rest of life. He desperately needed to know which piece of land had sired his lunch.

The response from the waitress was as deliciously French as is the whole establishment, an old wood-lined country inn which would sit as comfortably in, say, Beaune as it does here on Britain's soft eastern shoulder. She gave a bored Gallic shrug and said simply, in richly accented English, 'I don't know. England, maybe.' She disappeared off to find out and we were left to consider the menus.

At lunchtime, worryingly, it is titled 'menu touristique', which is one of those dead phrases the adventurous eater dreads.

There is also something mournful about the word 'tourist' discovered lurking in Britain's rural heartlands right now. Foot and mouth had not, at the time of eating, reached Suffolk, but the fear remains that the contagion will infect both the land and then the tourist trade that the Great House needs to sustain its menu touristique.

Let's hope the disease stays away and the tourists keep coming, for that menu, whatever it is called, is good value at £15.95 for three courses. We were joined for lunch by Jocelyn's partner, Judy, which gave us the opportunity to try most of the starters and main courses. The menu, like the dining room and staff, is classically French: words and phrases like 'gratinées' and 'à la provençal' are scattered hither and yon. Somehow it makes it all read rather heavily, as though the dishes have been dragged from the dusty pages of Larousse and shocked into life with a defibrillator.

Certainly, where the starters are concerned, they taste and look far better than they read. Jocelyn's starter - 'your Spanish asparagus, monsieur' as he was told, with careful emphasis - was listed as coming with smoked salmon and a hollandaise sauce, beneath a 'pastry cage'. It was a clever piece of work, the warmth of the asparagus and the cool chill of the smoked salmon giving a lovely contrast. The pastry cage was more of a bonnet, and the better for it, being light and crisp. Judy's ravioli stuffed with soft, herbed cheese was made with a fine pasta and came with a cracking sorrel sauce. I ordered moules gratinées à la provençal - mussels in the shell with garlic and parsley butter - one of those dishes which it is easy to ruin: too much garlic and it becomes astringent, too long under the grill and the molluscs shrivel up. These got it right on all counts. As Jocelyn pointed out we had used up two baskets of bread to mop up our various sauces, which had to be a good sign.

The main courses were less spectacular, but still accomplished enough, though Jocelyn and I disagreed over his choice, tuna en daube à la provençal. It's a classic dish which really is in Larousse : tuna, stewed with tomatoes, onions and anchovies. I don't think fresh tuna stands up well in a stew and nothing about this particular version convinced me otherwise. The flavour is too subtle to hold its own. This, though, is personal taste. Jocelyn was happy. Judy's chicken breast with tarragon came crisp skinned and the fresh herbs gave what is usually a bland piece of the bird a solid lift. My lamb shank in a red-wine sauce was good, professional stuff, but it could have done without the slick of what tasted like melted parmesan.

Two of us made the appropriate 'mmming' sound over a pistachio crème brlée in which the custard came studded with a generous handful of crushed nuts (not a phrase to mention around a man who deals with stallions at stud). Jocelyn chose the French bread-and-butter pudding with apple and a butterscotch sauce. It was, he said, not exactly what he was expecting. There was something rather neat and tidy about what is usually a chuck-it-all-together sort of pudding, but somehow he found the will to clean the plate. There's a wide-ranging wine list at modest prices - many under £20 - with an admirable number of the wines by the glass and half bottle. We chose a sharp fresh Sancerre.

Over coffee, Jocelyn described in enthusiastic detail and at quite some volume the exact practicalities involved in getting large horses to have sex with each other. In turn a number of the other clientele - mainly local county folk, starting their weekend at Friday lunchtime - made like the asparagus and blanched. I'd explain it all for you now but I think you'd lose your appetite and that's not what a restaurant column is meant to do.

Contact Jay Rayner on jay.rayner@observer.co.uk.

webTitle: Monty Don: The weekend starts here

fields.headline: The weekend starts here
fields.standfirst: It's the biggest weekend of the year, when even the most reluctant gardener gets out the potting compost and puts down roots for the growing season. Here is Monty's step-by-step guide to laying good groundwork
fields.trailText: It's the biggest weekend of the year, when even the most reluctant gardener gets out the potting compost and puts down roots for the growing season. Here is Monty's step-by-step guide to laying good groundwork.
fields.body:
Easter arrives in the garden like a combination of a spring tide and a five-year-old's Christmas. It is the tangible measure of the season, regardless of date, weather or winter's legacy. Easter lets the garden know that spring is here, in your back yard, and we have the longest officially sanctioned break of the year to do something about it.

I try to take Easter as a gardening holiday. This is more than just an extended weekend at home. I book it in, accept no daylight invitations, and plan four days of work. This usually means either one big job or, more often - as will be the case this year - a systematic reclamation of the garden after winter.

Some of this depends when Easter falls. Looking back through my garden diaries of the past few years, Easter weather has varied enormously. Sometimes it is back-blisteringly hot, but the global-warmed trend does seem to be towards wet springs. In 1998, Easter was a few days earlier than this year, and the vegetables were deep under flood water. For Good Friday, 10 April, I wrote: 'Worst floods in Midlands in recorded time. The Arrow (the river just 100 yards from our back door) burst banks, killing man.' Then, the next day: 'Icy north wind all day, some snow, practically coldest day of winter.' In 1999, Easter was a week earlier still, and there was a respite in that it was merely muggy and mild. We put up the fruit-cage, sowed squashes and pumpkins, and all the plum and damson blossom were in full bloom. There is not a sign of it today, exactly two years later. Then last year, Easter was a week later than this year, and it was wet and flooded. 'Heard on the radio that it's already wettest April on record. Water in veg garden. No flushing loo, bath, washing up, etc. Afternoon sunny. Thousands of flies on box and - oddly - foxgloves. Tulips fab. Mowed all grass save where under water.'

Whatever the weather, Easter is a time to get to grips with the garden. For garden centres it is the peak of their selling year, and everyone is inclined to get outside and do something, whether it's wet or not. The truth is that there is invariably more to do at this time of year than can possibly be achieved during the break. This can lead to the state of affairs that I often get into when I have been away a lot, where you rush outside, full of good intentions, but are overwhelmed by the enormity of horticultural neglect in the full glare of the April sunshine. The result is inconsequential pottering and an exhaustion incommensurate with the dribble of energy expended. This is why I have outlined the following plan of Easter attack, where there are four different projects for the four days of the holiday. Experienced gardeners will be too busy outside to be reading this, so no apologies for covering the basics.

Gone to seed

1 Seed and potting compost. This is not the same as garden compost - although, as we shall see, there is a potential overlap. Compost for sale in garden centres tends to be labelled as potting compost or general-purpose compost. Neither is the best thing for seeds sown in containers. You can buy seed compost, which is normally John Innes No 1. This not a brand but a formula. I personally do not use it, as I find it a bit plasticy.

Most multipurpose composts use peat as the main component. This works well and is cheap but is brutally destructive to the wetlands from where it is extracted. There is no justification in ruining a balanced natural environment that has taken thousands of years to evolve just for the sake of cheap compost. So do not buy anything that has peat in it.

There are now a number of commercial alternatives based on crushed bark, coir, commercially made compost and even, from Thames water, recycled waste. You can also easily make your own from topsoil, garden compost and sharp sand, all dried and sieved. A coir-based compost or finely crushed bark is likely to be most successful. The secret is not to use it neat. Seeds need very little nourishment to grow successfully, but they do need good drainage and an easy passage for the new roots to grow into, so mix it up 50:50 in a bucket with sharp sand (not builders' sand), perlite or vermiculite. Sharp sand is cheapest.

2 Even if you do not have a greenhouse (and you should - they add a dimension to any garden, however small), grow seeds on a windowsill or a table by a window or in a sunny porch. Avoid south-facing windows, otherwise the seeds will be scorched. West is best. A warm room is important, but if there is a radiator below the seeds, turn it down to a very gentle background heat. If the new seedlings have long stems and lean towards the window, that is a sure sign that they are starved of light. Light levels drop astonishingly quickly as you get further away from the window, so keep them near the glass.

3 Seeds germinate best in a gently warm, moist atmosphere. The moisture bit can be tricky to get right. On the whole, it is better to keep them too dry rather than too wet, but just right is best. Too much wet drowns them and the seedlings can easily 'dampen-off' - which means that they get a fungal disease and die. Too little water and they starve, droop and often never fully recover. A good tip is to soak the container in a few inches of water before you sow, so the roots go into gentle damp soil. Water the container lightly after sowing. If you have heat underneath them, you must watch that they are not drying out at the roots while remaining wet at the surface. Use your eye to judge how healthy they look.

4 What do you sow in? To start with, the soil outside is surprisingly good. Make a seedbed by clearing a square yard or two of good soil in a sunny, sheltered spot. Work it so that the soil is completely malleable ('a fine tilth'). On my soil, this means adding plenty of sharp sand. You will not need any extra goodness, although leaf mould or very well-rotted compost will help the soil structure. Make very short drills in the soil and sow seeds directly into them. These can be much closer together than seeds sown where they are to mature - just a few inches apart. If you have a cloche, so much the better. When the seeds have developed into healthy seedlings, you will carefully dig them up (with a lump of soil around the roots of each plant) and transplant them to their final site. The advantages of this system are that the growing plants develop in the soil in which they are to grow, and this helps transplantation enormously. They are also much hardier than plants grown indoors.

If you grow seeds indoors - as I do with nearly all mine - then consider sowing in pots rather than seed trays. The roots will be bigger and they are easier to handle and prick out (the moving of seedlings to a bigger container as soon as they are big enough to handle). The sooner that seedlings are pricked out, the better and quicker they grow on.

5 Label everything. I have a rule that every container and row is labelled with the name of the plant, the variety and date sown. This is tedious but essential. The biggest mistake is to label just one pot in a batch because it is certain that pots - and therefore varieties - that look identical at seedling stage will be mixed up. I use cheap white labels and a graphite pencil.

Border patrol

1 If we get a warm spell - have faith, we will - herbaceous plants start to grow inches every day at this time of year. All the energy of the roots is put into creating new top growth, whereas later in the summer they will mainly service and supply it. Thus it is an excellent time to move them around. You can judge from the new growth the extent of the area that they will cover, and the trauma of being dug up and handled will quickly be forgotten in the warm soil.

The easiest way to create a new herbaceous plant from an existing one is to simply chop a piece off with a spade. If the plant is relatively small, this will mean cutting it into two while it is in the soil and digging up one of the halves. If it is larger, dig up the whole thing, place it on the surface of the soil and cut pieces either in segments like a cake or as if you were cutting down a circle to make a square. The important point is to leave behind the core or centre and use the outside for the new plant. Throw away (on the compost heap) the remaining core, as all the vigour and flowering energy will be on the outside. Water the new pieces in well, and they will grow as though nothing had happened.

2 It is really important to stake all herbaceous plants before they need it. The new growth is soft and sappy and prone to being battered by wind and rain, let alone falling all over the place under their top-heavy weight. Traditionally, pea-sticks or brushwood were used, and they are still the best - they can be manipulated to support most shapes and sizes of plant and blend in well, unlike canes and string, which look a bit stark until the plants grow over them. We use thick homemade wire supports, rather like flat-topped croquet hoops, pushed into the ground. They work well, are stronger than wood, last forever and are cheap and easy to make. But whatever you use, do it well before it is remotely necessary to the plant - otherwise it will be too late.

3 Mulching. Once the borders get into their stride, it is difficult to weed without damaging seedlings and young annuals you have planted. Now is the time to weed through and then mulch every piece of bare soil. In a border, this wants to be well-rotted organic material, both for nutritional and aesthetic reasons, although for weed-suppression, anything, from newspaper to black polythene, would do the trick. We use only well-rotted mushroom compost or spent cocoa shells on our borders. The latter we buy in sacks and the former in as large a quantity as we can get delivered, as it is the perfect soil-improver for our heavy, slightly acid soil. Cocoa shells are very light, easy to handle, fill the garden with the aroma of chocolate for weeks, and lighten the soil very effectively. They work in an unusual way. You put them on dry, pouring them round the plants. Then it rains and they form a slimy skin which, when dry, turns into a crust. This seals moisture in and stops weeds growing through. If it is reasonably dry, it also deters slugs, although if it is warm and wet it encourages them, so only use it in early spring. Mushroom compost has to be shovelled on but has the great advantage over garden compost or cattle manure of being sterile. You bring no weeds in with it. Put any mulch on at least 2in thick. Better to do half the garden properly than all of it too thinly.

4 Weeds. If you have a perennial weed growing through the middle of a herbaceous plant - couch grass is growing through one big clump of my daylilies ( Hemerocallis ) - there is only one course of action. Be completely ruthless. Dig up the entire clump and wash the roots thoroughly under a tap or strong hose until every scrap of weed root has been washed off. I would then pot it up for a month to make sure that no weed is left in before replanting it. Hand-weed the area around the affected plant with obsessive care.

5 If you are starting a new border based on herbaceous perennials (does anyone have a truly herbaceous border nowadays?), it will repay you fivefold to prepare the site properly. Such fast growers are voracious feeders, and the better and richer your soil is, the better the display. Note that I say 'soil'. I do not suggest that you feed your plants unless they are sickly. This only leads to unnaturally lush growth that is prone to attack by pests and disease. Always feed the soil, not the plant. Having said that, dig the site over thoroughly, taking out every hint of perennial weed. Add plenty of organic compost or manure. Make the border bigger than you think you need or want - it is astonishing how quickly the space gets filled after the first year. Resist the temptation to whizz out, buy some plants and stick them in half-prepared ground. Any time spent on preparation is never wasted.

Where the grass is greener

It is that lawn time of year again. We all know that lawns are a luxury and look awful for most of the year. We all know that paved areas are much better for sitting, walking, pushing wheelbarrows and just about any other garden activity. But nevertheless, we all want a lawn. So here is a five-step plan to making the perfect patch of grass.

1 Prepare the ground well. Actually this ought to be steps 1, 2 and 3 because a lawn is only as good as the soil beneath the green stuff. If you already have a horribly scruffy area of grass and want it better, or if you are moving to a virgin site, the same applies. Dig over the whole area, removing all perennial weeds, then fork or rotovate it. If it is heavy clay, add lots of sharp sand and rotovate this in. What is lots? You cannot add too much. If your soil is light, add some organic compost and mix it in to give it some beef. Rake it reasonably level and ideally leave it for a few weeks.

2 The reason you leave it is to let the annual weeds grow. Hoe them off and rake the site again, this time trying hard to get it as smooth and level as possible. Then, when it is all but perfect, trample all over it, using your heels in a waddle. This will compact the ground to find out any dips and hollows that would appear anyway sooner or later. Rake it again.

3 Seed. If you are not in a hurry, it is undoubtedly the best option. It is easy and cheap and allows you to be specific about the type of grass you want. Choose a seed mix that suits your usage. Ryegrass brings toughness, bents and fescues a finer finish. The average family lawn is a mixture of about 60 per cent ryegrass, with bents and fescues making up the rest. Spread the seed by hand evenly. Sow it first walking in one direction and then again walking at 90 , resisting the temptation to sow it too thickly. Think of each seed as a plant that will grow strongly without much competition. Rake it over twice, reversing the order of the 90 variation. Net it or put black cotton across it to stop birds - and worse - cats. Water thoroughly. Easy peasy.

4 Turf has the great advantage of looking good from day one, but this is almost the only advantage over seed. It is essential to prepare the ground for turf in exactly the same way as for seed. Make sure that the turf is delivered either the night before laying or early on the same day, because it is important to get it spread out as soon as possible. You will need some boards (scaffolding planks are ideal) to kneel and walk on. Start at one end and lay the turfs in courses like a horizontal brick wall. Butt the edges up really tightly and keep any shorter lengths in the middle of a course, not at the edge. Move the planks over the laid turf as you progress, never stepping directly on to them once they are down. The weight of the boards also acts as a leveller. When you have finished, fence it off from children and animals and give it a really good soak. Never let the turf dry out for at least a fortnight. This is vital. If you see any of the turfs curling up at the edges, soak them immediately and go on soaking them until they are saturated.

5 Newly laid turf or grass seed should be allowed to grow longer than a conventional lawn in its first year. The length of a football pitch is more appropriate, giving the roots a chance to be fed and establish. Mow it lightly after about a month. For the rest of the summer, cut it no more than once a week, collecting up the cuttings each time. Do not expect your perfect lawn until a year after it is made.

Paving the way

One of the first things I try to do around Easter is to have a meal outside and to eat and drink outside as much as possible thereafter. But to enjoy this properly, it is essential to have a place that is dedicated to this.

1 Choose your site. Make it big enough. Even if you live alone, ideally you want to be able to fit a table, four chairs and - vitally - lots of pots. The first thing to think about is when you'll use it. If having breakfast outside is important to you, then the site must get morning sun, which comes in low from the east. If you are likely to use it at lunchtime, then it must have shade, because even in this country, lunchtime sun can be uncomfortably hot. If you are to use it mainly for sipping your gin and tonic after work, then it must have a clear line of sunshine to the west.

2 Choose your materials. No one can decide the aesthetics of this but you - but here are some practical considerations. York stone adds instant weathered substance, which is what we Brits tend to like. But it is expensive, heavy and can be hard to get a good supply. Brick can be patterned in lots of ways and is easy to handle and readily available. But it is not cheap, and old bricks crumble in frost and can be very slippery. Artificial paving slabs look best when overtly modern, are cheap, easy to lay and very durable. Concrete is not to be sniffed at and can be a very good cheap surface, especially if brushed over or polished, depending on the desired effect. Whatever you choose, avoid a rough, bumpy surface. Chairs and tables want to sit level.

3 Dig the site out and use pegs to establish a level, leaving enough room for plenty of hardcore. Bind this with sand using the pegtops for your level. Always lay stones, pavings and bricks directly on to sand without any cement. Assuming that it is a rectangular shape - and there is no reason why it should be - start at one corner and work across establishing a course, adding and subtracting sand as necessary. It is essential that each item, be it a small brick paver or a huge stone slab, is absolutely level with itself and its neighbours before you lay another. Let 1mm discrepancy get established and it will be a foot-tripping 10mm by the end of the row. Because I do not use cement, I do not build in a fall as the water drains between the materials. If you want a non-draining surface, then you must create a gentle fall away from any building.

4 When it is finished (and if you have odd bits to fill, remember that a table is likely to cover some sins in the middle and pots can deal with the corners), brush over the joins with more sand. You can add some potting compost to the mix if you want plants to grow in the cracks, although weeds will inevitably join them, too. Water this sand in or leave it for a week and then go over it again after it has been washed in. That's it.

5 Pots. Lots and lots of pots. Patios and terraces are the best place for growing scented plants in pots. I suggest herbs, especially Mediterranean ones such as rosemary, thyme, lavender, artemisia and sage (which can all be given the really sharp drainage they need), scented-leafed geraniums and pelargoniums, bay, sweet peas, lilies, tobacco plants - use pots to create a sweetly scented and beautiful background to your al fresco life. And finally, you will want some shelter from the sun and perhaps, just perhaps, from the rain.

Happy Easter.

There are now a number of commercial alternatives based on crushed bark, coir, commercially made compost and even, from Thames water, recycled waste. You can also easily make your own from topsoil, garden compost and sharp sand, all dried and sieved. A coir-based compost or finely crushed bark is likely to be most successful. The secret is not to use it neat. Seeds need very little nourishment to grow successfully, but they do need good drainage and an easy passage for the new roots to grow into, so mix it up 50:50 in a bucket with sharp sand (not builders' sand), perlite or vermiculite. Sharp sand is cheapest. 2 Even if you do not have a greenhouse (and you should - they add a dimension to any garden, however small), grow seeds on a windowsill or a table by a window or in a sunny porch. Avoid south-facing windows, otherwise the seeds will be scorched. West is best. A warm room is important, but if there is a radiator below the seeds, turn it down to a very gentle background heat. If the new seedlings have long stems and lean towards the window, that is a sure sign that they are starved of light. Light levels drop astonishingly quickly as you get further away from the window, so keep them near the glass. 3 Seeds germinate best in a gently warm, moist atmosphere. The moisture bit can be tricky to get right. On the whole, it is better to keep them too dry rather than too wet, but just right is best. Too much wet drowns them and the seedlings can easily 'dampen-off' - which means that they get a fungal disease and die. Too little water and they starve, droop and often never fully recover. A good tip is to soak the container in a few inches of water before you sow, so the roots go into gentle damp soil. Water the container lightly after sowing. If you have heat underneath them, you must watch that they are not drying out at the roots while remaining wet at the surface. Use your eye to judge how healthy they look. 4 What do you sow in? To start with, the soil outside is surprisingly good. Make a seedbed by clearing a square yard or two of good soil in a sunny, sheltered spot. Work it so that the soil is completely malleable ('a fine tilth'). On my soil, this means adding plenty of sharp sand. You will not need any extra goodness, although leaf mould or very well-rotted compost will help the soil structure. Make very short drills in the soil and sow seeds directly into them. These can be much closer together than seeds sown where they are to mature - just a few inches apart. If you have a cloche, so much the better. When the seeds have developed into healthy seedlings, you will carefully dig them up (with a lump of soil around the roots of each plant) and transplant them to their final site. The advantages of this system are that the growing plants develop in the soil in which they are to grow, and this helps transplantation enormously. They are also much hardier than plants grown indoors. If you grow seeds indoors - as I do with nearly all mine - then consider sowing in pots rather than seed trays. The roots will be bigger and they are easier to handle and prick out (the moving of seedlings to a bigger container as soon as they are big enough to handle). The sooner that seedlings are pricked out, the better and quicker they grow on. 5 Label everything. I have a rule that every container and row is labelled with the name of the plant, the variety and date sown. This is tedious but essential. The biggest mistake is to label just one pot in a batch because it is certain that pots - and therefore varieties - that look identical at seedling stage will be mixed up. I use cheap white labels and a graphite pencil. Border patrol 1 If we get a warm spell - have faith, we will - herbaceous plants start to grow inches every day at this time of year. All the energy of the roots is put into creating new top growth, whereas later in the summer they will mainly service and supply it. Thus it is an excellent time to move them around. You can judge from the new growth the extent of the area that they will cover, and the trauma of being dug up and handled will quickly be forgotten in the warm soil. The easiest way to create a new herbaceous plant from an existing one is to simply chop a piece off with a spade. If the plant is relatively small, this will mean cutting it into two while it is in the soil and digging up one of the halves. If it is larger, dig up the whole thing, place it on the surface of the soil and cut pieces either in segments like a cake or as if you were cutting down a circle to make a square. The important point is to leave behind the core or centre and use the outside for the new plant. Throw away (on the compost heap) the remaining core, as all the vigour and flowering energy will be on the outside. Water the new pieces in well, and they will grow as though nothing had happened. 2 It is really important to stake all herbaceous plants before they need it. The new growth is soft and sappy and prone to being battered by wind and rain, let alone falling all over the place under their top-heavy weight. Traditionally, pea-sticks or brushwood were used, and they are still the best - they can be manipulated to support most shapes and sizes of plant and blend in well, unlike canes and string, which look a bit stark until the plants grow over them. We use thick homemade wire supports, rather like flat-topped croquet hoops, pushed into the ground. They work well, are stronger than wood, last forever and are cheap and easy to make. But whatever you use, do it well before it is remotely necessary to the plant - otherwise it will be too late. 3 Mulching. Once the borders get into their stride, it is difficult to weed without damaging seedlings and young annuals you have planted. Now is the time to weed through and then mulch every piece of bare soil. In a border, this wants to be well-rotted organic material, both for nutritional and aesthetic reasons, although for weed-suppression, anything, from newspaper to black polythene, would do the trick. We use only well-rotted mushroom compost or spent cocoa shells on our borders. The latter we buy in sacks and the former in as large a quantity as we can get delivered, as it is the perfect soil-improver for our heavy, slightly acid soil. Cocoa shells are very light, easy to handle, fill the garden with the aroma of chocolate for weeks, and lighten the soil very effectively. They work in an unusual way. You put them on dry, pouring them round the plants. Then it rains and they form a slimy skin which, when dry, turns into a crust. This seals moisture in and stops weeds growing through. If it is reasonably dry, it also deters slugs, although if it is warm and wet it encourages them, so only use it in early spring. Mushroom compost has to be shovelled on but has the great advantage over garden compost or cattle manure of being sterile. You bring no weeds in with it. Put any mulch on at least 2in thick. Better to do half the garden properly than all of it too thinly. 4 Weeds. If you have a perennial weed growing through the middle of a herbaceous plant - couch grass is growing through one big clump of my daylilies ( Hemerocallis ) - there is only one course of action. Be completely ruthless. Dig up the entire clump and wash the roots thoroughly under a tap or strong hose until every scrap of weed root has been washed off. I would then pot it up for a month to make sure that no weed is left in before replanting it. Hand-weed the area around the affected plant with obsessive care. 5 If you are starting a new border based on herbaceous perennials (does anyone have a truly herbaceous border nowadays?), it will repay you fivefold to prepare the site properly. Such fast growers are voracious feeders, and the better and richer your soil is, the better the display. Note that I say 'soil'. I do not suggest that you feed your plants unless they are sickly. This only leads to unnaturally lush growth that is prone to attack by pests and disease. Always feed the soil, not the plant. Having said that, dig the site over thoroughly, taking out every hint of perennial weed. Add plenty of organic compost or manure. Make the border bigger than you think you need or want - it is astonishing how quickly the space gets filled after the first year. Resist the temptation to whizz out, buy some plants and stick them in half-prepared ground. Any time spent on preparation is never wasted. Where the grass is greener It is that lawn time of year again. We all know that lawns are a luxury and look awful for most of the year. We all know that paved areas are much better for sitting, walking, pushing wheelbarrows and just about any other garden activity. But nevertheless, we all want a lawn. So here is a five-step plan to making the perfect patch of grass. 1 Prepare the ground well. Actually this ought to be steps 1, 2 and 3 because a lawn is only as good as the soil beneath the green stuff. If you already have a horribly scruffy area of grass and want it better, or if you are moving to a virgin site, the same applies. Dig over the whole area, removing all perennial weeds, then fork or rotovate it. If it is heavy clay, add lots of sharp sand and rotovate this in. What is lots? You cannot add too much. If your soil is light, add some organic compost and mix it in to give it some beef. Rake it reasonably level and ideally leave it for a few weeks. 2 The reason you leave it is to let the annual weeds grow. Hoe them off and rake the site again, this time trying hard to get it as smooth and level as possible. Then, when it is all but perfect, trample all over it, using your heels in a waddle. This will compact the ground to find out any dips and hollows that would appear anyway sooner or later. Rake it again. 3 Seed. If you are not in a hurry, it is undoubtedly the best option. It is easy and cheap and allows you to be specific about the type of grass you want. Choose a seed mix that suits your usage. Ryegrass brings toughness, bents and fescues a finer finish. The average family lawn is a mixture of about 60 per cent ryegrass, with bents and fescues making up the rest. Spread the seed by hand evenly. Sow it first walking in one direction and then again walking at 90 , resisting the temptation to sow it too thickly. Think of each seed as a plant that will grow strongly without much competition. Rake it over twice, reversing the order of the 90 variation. Net it or put black cotton across it to stop birds - and worse - cats. Water thoroughly. Easy peasy. 4 Turf has the great advantage of looking good from day one, but this is almost the only advantage over seed. It is essential to prepare the ground for turf in exactly the same way as for seed. Make sure that the turf is delivered either the night before laying or early on the same day, because it is important to get it spread out as soon as possible. You will need some boards (scaffolding planks are ideal) to kneel and walk on. Start at one end and lay the turfs in courses like a horizontal brick wall. Butt the edges up really tightly and keep any shorter lengths in the middle of a course, not at the edge. Move the planks over the laid turf as you progress, never stepping directly on to them once they are down. The weight of the boards also acts as a leveller. When you have finished, fence it off from children and animals and give it a really good soak. Never let the turf dry out for at least a fortnight. This is vital. If you see any of the turfs curling up at the edges, soak them immediately and go on soaking them until they are saturated. 5 Newly laid turf or grass seed should be allowed to grow longer than a conventional lawn in its first year. The length of a football pitch is more appropriate, giving the roots a chance to be fed and establish. Mow it lightly after about a month. For the rest of the summer, cut it no more than once a week, collecting up the cuttings each time. Do not expect your perfect lawn until a year after it is made. Paving the way One of the first things I try to do around Easter is to have a meal outside and to eat and drink outside as much as possible thereafter. But to enjoy this properly, it is essential to have a place that is dedicated to this. 1 Choose your site. Make it big enough. Even if you live alone, ideally you want to be able to fit a table, four chairs and - vitally - lots of pots. The first thing to think about is when you'll use it. If having breakfast outside is important to you, then the site must get morning sun, which comes in low from the east. If you are likely to use it at lunchtime, then it must have shade, because even in this country, lunchtime sun can be uncomfortably hot. If you are to use it mainly for sipping your gin and tonic after work, then it must have a clear line of sunshine to the west. 2 Choose your materials. No one can decide the aesthetics of this but you - but here are some practical considerations. York stone adds instant weathered substance, which is what we Brits tend to like. But it is expensive, heavy and can be hard to get a good supply. Brick can be patterned in lots of ways and is easy to handle and readily available. But it is not cheap, and old bricks crumble in frost and can be very slippery. Artificial paving slabs look best when overtly modern, are cheap, easy to lay and very durable. Concrete is not to be sniffed at and can be a very good cheap surface, especially if brushed over or polished, depending on the desired effect. Whatever you choose, avoid a rough, bumpy surface. Chairs and tables want to sit level. 3 Dig the site out and use pegs to establish a level, leaving enough room for plenty of hardcore. Bind this with sand using the pegtops for your level. Always lay stones, pavings and bricks directly on to sand without any cement. Assuming that it is a rectangular shape - and there is no reason why it should be - start at one corner and work across establishing a course, adding and subtracting sand as necessary. It is essential that each item, be it a small brick paver or a huge stone slab, is absolutely level with itself and its neighbours before you lay another. Let 1mm discrepancy get established and it will be a foot-tripping 10mm by the end of the row. Because I do not use cement, I do not build in a fall as the water drains between the materials. If you want a non-draining surface, then you must create a gentle fall away from any building. 4 When it is finished (and if you have odd bits to fill, remember that a table is likely to cover some sins in the middle and pots can deal with the corners), brush over the joins with more sand. You can add some potting compost to the mix if you want plants to grow in the cracks, although weeds will inevitably join them, too. Water this sand in or leave it for a week and then go over it again after it has been washed in. That's it. 5 Pots. Lots and lots of pots. Patios and terraces are the best place for growing scented plants in pots. I suggest herbs, especially Mediterranean ones such as rosemary, thyme, lavender, artemisia and sage (which can all be given the really sharp drainage they need), scented-leafed geraniums and pelargoniums, bay, sweet peas, lilies, tobacco plants - use pots to create a sweetly scented and beautiful background to your al fresco life. And finally, you will want some shelter from the sun and perhaps, just perhaps, from the rain. Happy Easter.

fields.headline: Clampdown on genetic tests
fields.trailText: The exploitation of genetic testing by insurers is set to be outlawed by the government amid fears of creating an uninsurable 'genetic underclass'.
fields.body:
The exploitation of genetic testing by insurers is set to be outlawed by the government amid fears of creating an uninsurable 'genetic underclass'.

Health Secretary Alan Milburn will signal this week that the use of so-called genetic profiling tests, which could predict who will die prematurely or suffer chronic disease, to deny people essentials such as mortgage cover should be banned. He is still awaiting final recommendations from the ethical watchdog, the Human Genetics Commission, next month before taking a final decision, but is known to favour at least a partial moratorium. One option considered by the commission is to regulate against 'genetic discrimination' by insurers in the same way as racial prejudice.

Milburn will also pledge legislation to ban human reproductive cloning - likely to be highlighted in Labour's manifesto - to allay public fears about scientists playing God. The practice is already outlawed by watchdog, the Human Fertility and Embryology Authority, but he wants to ensure that this ban could not be reversed in future.

Milburn will use a speech on Thursday to highlight potential benefits of genetic testing, such as new screening programmes for those found to have inherited a risk of serious treatable disease, and promise NHS funding for developing accurate tests. But he will warn discoveries must not be used to divide patients into a 'genetic underclass' likely to become ill and a healthy 'genetic superclass'.

'The NHS over the next decade and beyond can put Britain at the leading edge of this new frontier, not just in advances on genetic testing but to develop for Britain modern genetic health services unrivalled anywhere in the world,' he will tell his audience at the International Centre for Life in Newcastle. Milburn will stop short of announcing an outright ban on insurers using any genetic test results, pending commission reports. But the commission is understood to favour a moratorium of at least two years - and has not ruled out a ban, backed by 78 per cent of the public in Mori polls.

Ministers may make a regulatory distinction between 'essentials' such as life insurance needed for mortgage cover, where genetic discrimination could have disastrous consequences, and 'luxuries' such as extensive private health insurance, where patients could rely on the NHS instead.

Milburn knows discussing such a sensitive issue close to an election is risky. But he fears that unless patients are sure test results will not be used against them, scientific progress will be hampered as they refuse to take tests.

'There are huge potential health gains to be had from genetic advances, but until we address these public concerns we can't create the necessary space,' said one source close to Milburn. 'We want to make sure these advances are to the benefit of all, not the cost of a few.'

The Department of Health has approved only one genetic test, for the rare and fatal Huntington's chorea, as reliable. Others are in the pipeline for approval, but already being used by insurers. So far the industry has handled fewer than 100 cases involving genetic testing. But numbers will soar over the next decade as researchers develop susceptibility tests for more common illnesses such as cancers, Alzheimer's or heart disease. Britain is well placed to lead research because of its role in the Human Genome Project, which mapped l the genes in DNA.

Insurers argue using genetic testing to calculate premiums is little different from asking about family medical histories and helps spread risk. They agreed not to use results in applications for life insurance linked to mortgages of under £100,000, but a recent survey found this widely flouted.

The Commons science and technology committee has condemned the voluntary code as 'inadequate' and warned insurers were placing a significance on tests 'that cannot at present be justified'.

But the committee said an outright ban could disadvantage those with a family history of disease whose own tests were negative.

fields.headline: Sir must be his own master
fields.standfirst:
Until teachers learn to organise themselves professionally, they are always going to be the government's whipping boys

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Until teachers learn to organise themselves professionally, they are always going to be the government's whipping boys.
fields.body:
Occasionally, the Government serves a reminder that it does have ambitions to improve the lot of ordinary people. The commitments to reduce child poverty and raise health spending were just such unexpected moments. Last Thursday, when Mr Blair said he wanted state schools to have as good 'facilities and investment' as private schools, was another.

If you look more closely, it's not the ringing assault on private-sector advantage that it first seems. It is not a commitment to ensure that staff-pupil ratios in state schools match those in private schools or to raise teachers' pay. Rather, it is a commitment to raise spending on state school laboratories, playing fields and language facilities so they match those in private schools.

In other words, it's a politically clever way of legitimising the Government's plans to build 1,500 specialist schools by 2006 and break up the comprehensive system. But despite that caveat, it remains the first time any British government has said it wants the state system to reach even partial parity with private schools. It's an important moment.

More extraordinarily still, it was said at a teachers conference, the first time a serving Prime Minister has ever addressed a conference of classroom teachers. He told the delegates that his aim was to raise education spending in real terms every year to raise standards for Britain's neglected 80 per cent of children. It was hardly earth-shattering stuff, but it is a remarkable commentary on the British education debate that not one of Mr Blair's predecessors has made the same remarks.

The Government wants to establish a big-tent consensus on education and brick by solid brick the fundamentals are being laid that are becoming increasingly difficult to contest: high standards for all; diverse, specialist schools rather than 'one size fits all' comprehensives; teachers who are professionalised and paid performance-related pay; more investment. And so on.

The Tories are hopelessly outflanked; they have never taken state education seriously and constructed the funding system that entrenches inequality. But more unfairly, the same fate awaits the teaching unions. They are right to warn that specialist schools with higher funding sitting side by side with less well funded comprehensives will mean a two-tier education system. Nobody listens.

Here the teachers are their own worst enemy. The National Union of Teachers, the largest of the 11 teaching unions, has long seen that until teachers have the same professional status as doctors, lawyers and accountants, they are not going to be paid decently and, as importantly, will not have the same voice in shaping how their profession is structured. The British Medical Association, the Law Society and the Institute of Chartered Accountants are not merely the guardians of professional status; no government can easily pass legislation if any of these professional bodies objects. Teachers need to be in the same position.

But they are not and the more they use the language of industrial action, the more the goal of professional standing will elude them. The fragmented unions need to merge, get themselves into a position of market power and then talk the language of professionals. They may even want to recast themselves as an association, society or institute, one of whose prime purposes is the policing of standards and regulation of those who don't meet the grade.

Once in this position, their criticisms of the Government's education reforms will not seem self-serving. Instead, they will be a unified, powerful profession speaking for the interests of all children, one the Government dare not cross.

The difficulty is that the Government has got there before them. The General Teaching Council (GTC) has only been fully operational for six weeks as the regulator of teacher standards, but this is to be the new, government-inspired guardian of teachers' ambitions to achieve professional status. The GTC is the putative rival to the General Medical Council and the Law Society. If the teaching unions want to establish their seniority, rather as the BMA has done with the GMC in medicine, they had better act quickly.

The signs are that they understand the imperative. The unions have worked more closely than ever before in trying to get the Government to adopt Scotland's increase in teacher pay and accompanying 35-hour week in England and Wales, and the Government has now conceded that it will review their working conditions. Despite calling off immediate industrial action, the threat of co-ordinated action in the autumn to achieve a 35-hour week remains, with Education Secretary David Blunkett using the counter-argument that no other professional group accepts a limit to the working week.

Mr Blunkett is both right and wrong. If the teachers had professional status, they would not be threatening industrial action over a 35-hour week; they wouldn't need to because there would be an inbuilt flexibility over their working hours and their salaries would be higher. But that's not where they actually are, nor where the Government really wants them to be. It suits the Government for teachers to be oppositional, because it delegitimises their argument.

Yet the Government's education plans are fraught with hazards. Despite the barrage of propaganda, comprehensive schools began to work during the 1990s; the proportion of A-C passes at GCSE and A-level passes were up. If the investment in comprehensives matched the private sector and their teachers were a fully professionalised, highly-paid force then they could make further advances .

The difficulty with the diverse, specialist schools the Government advocates is that they will quickly become the preserve of the socially ambitious and the middle class and that the benefits of higher education spending will not percolate very far down the income scale.

The teachers should call the Government's bluff and try to be the unified professional grouping the Government says it wants and therefore argue from a position of strength. Because the chances of that are so low, the outcome of the argument is preordained. The teachers will lose and so, despite New Labour's avowed intentions, will a truly universal education system.

fields.headline: Waiting for 'God' to go...
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Overheard at the Granita restaurant, Islington, one evening last week:
fields.body:
Overheard at the Granita restaurant, Islington, one evening last week:

Gordon Brown: It's the last time, Tony, I warn you.

Tony Blair: What? Do you want to give up being Chancellor, Gordon?

Brown: No, it's the last time we come to this restaurant. It brings back terrible memories.

Blair: Oh, I rather like replaying those memories. I think we did the decent thing.

Brown: I did the decent thing, you mean - not standing against you for the leadership.

Blair: Yes but under our secret deal I promised to let you run the Government, so that I could be presidential. For all the backbiting it hasn't worked out too badly.

Brown: Huh. When are you planning to hand over?

Blair: Waitress, could I just have a little extra parmesan on my sun-dried tomatoes? Come on Gordon, let's relax like the old days. What are you reading over Easter?

Brown: The Road to Victory

Blair: Is it about me? I'm reading Tony Blair, Prime Minister by John Rentoul.

Brown: The Road to Victory is not about you Tony. It's Martin Gilbert on Churchill, 1941 to 1945.

Blair: Interesting?

Brown: The only thing that would interest you is that there is a famous postponement.

Blair: What famous postponement? The second world war didn't come up in my Law Studies.

Brown: Operation Overlord, or D-Day to you. It was postponed from the beginning of May to the beginning of June - like something else I could mention.

Blair: Go on Gordon, tell me more. This sounds like a good omen. What were the dates?

Brown: It was postponed from 1 May to 6 June 1944.

Blair: Why, that's amazing, Gordon. So close to postponing the election from 3 May to 7 June. D-Day, Britain's finest hour!

Brown: Somehow, I don't see 7 June 2001 as B-Day, Blair's finest hour. Frankly we've been bloody lucky.

Blair: Not just lucky, Gordon. Why, our economic policies have been wonderful.

Brown: And we've stolen the Opposition's clothes. And Ken Clarke isn't even on the opposition front bench. Frankly it's been painfully easy.

Blair: Oh, by the way. That reminds me. I've heard a rumour that after my - I mean our - landslide victory, Portillo's going to take over with K. Clarke as his deputy.

Brown: Stranger things have happened. Clarke teamed up with Redwood last time. But, come on Tony, what about all these rumours that you want to step down and earn some money?

Blair: I say, waitress, can we have another bottle of mineral water please?

Brown: You can't keep me waiting forever, Tony.

Blair: Well, Gordon, if I may say so, it takes two to play that game.

Brown: What do you mean?

Blair: How long are you going to keep me waiting?

Brown: I don't know what you are talking about.

Blair: Oh yes you do. Europe. You stole control of our European policy from me and, frankly, I'm in your hands.

Brown: You mean the famous five tests and all that?

Blair: I certainly do. When can you deliver me a favourable verdict?

Brown: Well, Mervyn King of the Bank said it would take 200 years to be really sure.

Blair: I'm not hanging around that long. Waitress, I think we need another bottle of New World chardonnay.

Brown: Oh Lord, anything but chardonnay.

Blair: Seriously though. What's our policy?

Brown: We'll make the assessment in two years. It will be rigorous and fair.

Blair: Oh dear. Does that mean...

Brown: It means it will be on the one hand and on the other hand. How can it possibly be conclusive?

Blair: Couldn't we announce the day after the election that we are in favour of joining the euro in principle?

Brown: We've already done that. We're always doing that. But at the moment we are doing a lot better than our continental neighbours, and that European Cental Bank of theirs is crazy.

Blair: Things may change.

Brown: Speaking purely from the economic side, I don't see the hurry. If we carry on doing well, and the investment keeps coming in...

Blair: But how long will that go on? And isn't it stopping already? Why, the other day I felt just like an Old Labour Harold Wilson, telephoning the American headquarters of Motorola and pleading with them not to cut back in Scotland.

Brown: Don't worry, Tony. Thanks to my - our - policies, we're well placed to ride the cycle.

Blair: I thought we said we'd abolished the economic cycle?

Brown: No, Tony, recent events have forced us to redefine that boast. We're well placed to ride the cycle. We're well placed to ride the cycle. Got it?

Blair: OK, OK.

Brown: So do you want to do a deal?

Blair: What sort of deal?

Brown: I make sure that, although the five tests are stringent, fair, objective, on the one hand and on the other, nevertheless the Treasury comes down in favour, and I fight to the hilt for you during the referendum campaign.

Blair: This is wonderful, Gordon. Fancy a euro-friendly Calvados?

Brown: No, I'll have a John Smith's Glenlivet if you don't mind.

Blair: And I'm the British Prime Minister who goes down in history as taking us into Europe.

Brown: No, Tony, Ted Heath's already done that. You go down as keeping us in Europe.

Blair: And you, Gordon? What can I do for you in return?

Brown: Step down in my favour immediately after the referendum.

Blair: Er, hang on: surely you can allow me a year or so to savour the delights?

Brown: Well, maybe a week or so.

Blair: A week or so? Could be a long time in politics, Gordon.

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Nils chance
fields.body:
Nils chance

Interesting mutterings coming out of Wapping. Sunday Times editor John Witherow has been casting around for a new business editor to fill the gap left by John Jay who has teamed up with his old pal John Duffield. One name keeps cropping up at the top of Witherow's hit list. But Diary does not believe Nils Pratley will be keen to accept the Murdoch shilling so soon after becoming grand fromage at Sunday Business.

Scents of failure

Diary is full of existential angst with the news that the mighty New York Times is axing jobs. We also hear on the sly that News International has shut its advertising production department. But what really stuns Diary is the news that DigiScents, the firm that for two years has been bravely developing a device to deliver smells over the internet, is closing its HQ in California. Despite raising more than $20 million, for some reason demand for a twenty-first century scratch'n'sniff card has been sadly lacking. A recession is definitely on the way.

Short of ideas

Diary is resorting to blatant plagiarism to shore up its readership. Following the news that the Daily Telegraph is to shorten the size of its pages so they are, to quote Hollinger boss Dan Colson, more user-friendly to women, 'whose arms aren't as long', Diary is to start downsizing. By the end of the year the plan is for it to be reduced to two clues of the Azed crossword.

Evan's gate

This week, in a Telegraph-sized 'not nearly so bonkers as normal story corner', we predict that Newsnight 's Evan Davis is set to become BBC economics editor. Current incumbent, Cap'n Bob bag carrier Peter Jay, above, will 'disappear' until Christmas, when he will stand down. Source credibility rating 6/10.

Hits and misses

Diary is in the middle of negotiations with its favourite government department, Maff, with a view to securing a presence on its brilliant website. Due to the equally brilliant way Maff has handled foot and mouth, an astonishing 226,000 people visited its website in March to find out what is going on. The potential for banner ads must be huge. We insist Maff do the right thing and carry free ads for B&Bs in Devon and Cumbria.

Balls, my liege

This week in 'Sexpress and the city', Diary's new soap devoted to the activities of a diminishing number of media folk, we observe a heart-warming exchange between chief villain Tricky Dicky Desmond, and a lackey. Dicky to female production person designing a page: 'Nah! that's crap. Do this, do that.' The page is duly changed. Dicky: 'There you are. Isn't that the dog's bollocks?' Lackey, after a pause, 'No, Mr Desmond, just bollocks.'

Respect yourself

Good to see ex-Mail on Sunday ed Jonathan Holborow, below, on Newsnight. 'The Press Complaints Council is not a body I or many journalists respect now,' Holborow thundered. Many hacks would argue that the grandly titled Editorial Panel set up to protect (sic) the Sexpress is not a body many hacks respect either. But not our Johnny, who sits on it.

Look in mirror

Congrats to the Mirror for taking the high ground. In preparation for an advertising campaign emphasising its hard-hitting news credentials (slogan: 'The guts not the gutter'), The Mirror devoted 12 pages of its Wednesday edition to its Pride of Britain awards. But such action looks ill-judged considering the campaign also boasts the Mirror isn't shy of 'putting a front-page story on the front page'.

The same cannot be said for its sister Sunday, which prefers to bury its biggest stories deep inside. Diary's rough sums suggest the £40m wiped off Trinity Mirror's share price by the Leeds trial débcle works out at around £20,000 a word. Not even Littlejohn is on that. Yet.
