webTitle: OFT inquiry set to cast cloud over Sky's future

fields.headline: OFT inquiry set to cast cloud over Sky's future
fields.standfirst:
The report is postponed - but analysts believe it could be good news for beleaguered rivals, writes Jamie Doward

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The report is postponed - but analysts believe it could be good news for beleaguered rivals, writes Jamie Doward
fields.body:
Somewhere in the bowels of Fleetbank House, London, EC4, there is a time bomb with a very long fuse. And some would like it to explode right under BSkyB, the satellite broadcaster which, with more than 5 million digital subscribers, dominates the media landscape. Should the device fail to go off, the chances are Sky's competitors will end up on the casualty list instead.

The bomb in question is an Office of Fair Trading inquiry so far four months in the making. The OFT launched the investigation just before Christmas, predicting that it would emerge in around six months' time. But none of the OFT's mandarins banked on how contaminated pigswill would end up impacting on the world of media regulation.

Now that the election has been postponed because of the foot and mouth crisis, OFT sources suggest that the potentially incendiary report won't be published until the end of June at the earliest.

It is clearly received wisdom in the corridors of Fleetbank House that it's not a good idea to annoy Rupert Murdoch - whose News International effectively controls Sky through its 37.5 per cent stake - the month before an election. Especially given that Sky could end up facing a £100 million fine (10 per cent of its earnings) as a result of the investigation.

At the heart of the inquiry lies the question of whether Sky has abused a dominant market position in broadcasting. Rivals, chiefly ONdigital, the terrestrial digital television service jointly owned by Carlton and Granada, say the wholesale price it pays to carry Sky's premium channels (sports and films), is almost as high as that it charges its own subscribers.

As such ONdigital faces an unpleasant choice: either it raises the prices it charges for the channels, or it takes a hit and subsidises the service. The former is practically a no brainer - consumers will simply opt to take Sky. And the latter is now unthinkable, given that ONdigital is predicted to shell out £1.2 billion by 2003 in a desperate bid to subsidise the cost of its set-top boxes - four times what it had originally predicted.

A clearly frustrated Stuart Prebble, chief executive of ONdigital, summed up his company's position: 'It seems there are only two possible relationships with Sky: one is hostile; the other is servile.'

For ONdigital - Sky's biggest customer, with a million subscribers - such a pricing policy means it loses money if subscribers take just one or two channels. It breaks even if they take three, moves to profit if they take four.

When it launched, ONdigital had no idea that Sky would be so hard-nosed. 'They just didn't envisage that Sky would be so aggressive,' one industry source said. 'Sky ate them alive.'

ONdigital also cries foul over the way Sky cross-promotes its channels. Viewers watching Sky Sports are regularly reminded they can check out the Player Cam on Sky Sports Extra - a service not available on ONdigital. And, while Sky Premier might show the latest movies for satellite viewers, it doesn't always offer the same service for terrestrial viewers. Sky's subscribers saw the blockbuster Men In Black two years before their ONdigital counterparts, for example.

Then there are the exclusion clauses Sky has signed with a number of channels, blocking their availability to other broadcasters. Taking 50 per cent stakes in the likes of the History Channel, Nickelodeon and National Geographic, not to mention owning Fox Kids outright, has helped it clinch such deals.

Now Adam Singer, chief executive of cable firm Telewest, has predicted that ONdigital will have to either fold or merge with another media company if it is to survive. But help can be found in strange quarters.

The big pub chains are none too happy with Sky's pricing policy, either. Only a few months ago the biggest bars were paying £380 a month for their Sky fix. Now they have to pay £880 if they want to put the super into Sunday. Industry sources say more than 20 different firms - including Bass and Whitbread, Channel 4, cable companies NTL and Telewest and telecom firm Kingston - have given evidence to the OFT. City sources say that, despite appearances, Sky, which isn't expected to turn a profit until 2003, is scared about the inquiry's possible outcome.

Observers say Sky has done a 'brilliant' job in suppressing interest in the inquiry. Sky supporters have chanted the mantra that OFT inquiries are nothing new. In addition, media sources highlight the fact that the OFT recently released Sky from two regulatory commitments - chiefly to do with the way it provides accounts - as evidence that things may be looking up for the company.

And Sky also points out that the media landscape has changed dramatically in recent months. Rivals are now launching their own channels. ONdigital will have its own premium sports channel later this year, for example. Telewest, meanwhile, produces hundreds of hours of its own content through Flextech, the company with which it merged two years ago.

New technologies such as ADSL - phone lines carrying video signals - are now on the market. Consolidation of the cable industry from 40 players to two means Sky faces powerful rivals. So, the argument runs, why regulate the price it charges for content?

But, significantly, the inquiry is the first launched under new OFT boss John Vickers. Media observers say Vickers would not have contemplated such a high-profile investigation unless he was sure there was a case to be answered. And, while OFT inquiries into Sky may be nothing new, this is the first to be launched under the new Competition Act, which gives investigators far greater powers than they wielded under the old Fair Trading Act.

As well as a fine and the possible imposition of a new pricing structure, the inquiry could ultimately force Sky to adopt a Microsoft style break- up, separating its distribution and content divisions. This option does not look likely, however. 'I don't think anybody believes the OFT will make them divide into two parts. It would be so complicated,' one media source said

Nevertheless, the City is worrying as the inquiry draws to a close. Analysts at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter said in a note this month that the inquiry 'could weigh on stock'.

But bad news for Sky would be good news for competitors. MSDW's media team stated: 'We feel reduced rates in wholesale could benefit the entire pay-TV industry and, to a lesser degree, BSkyB as higher volume and greater penetration would lead to higher incremental revenues.'

Vickers will now be considering such a move. But not before an election, obviously.

webTitle: Fourth estate at sixes and sevens

fields.headline: Fourth estate at sixes and sevens
fields.standfirst:
It was the week when newspapers became the story. Their role in a series of high-profile scandals ignited a fierce debate about the role of the press in Britain. Peter Preston on the feuding behind the fallout

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: It was the week when newspapers became the story. Their role in a series of high-profile scandals ignited a fierce debate about the role of the press in Britain. Peter Preston on the feuding behind the fallout.
fields.body:
It was one of those weeks when journalists turn up their coat collars and flee the eyes of baleful neighbours. A pariah week: the week of the News of the World 's Sophie sting, the week an £8 million trial in Hull suddenly ended and the editor of the Sunday Mirror, just as suddenly, lost his job.

But the crescendo of vituperation, this time round, was subtly different. It came not from the politicians, who grow circumspect when there's an election to fight, nor even from a Buckingham Palace press machine which had blunderingly made a bad scene much worse. No, the charge against Rebekah Wade of the NoW and the Mirror 's hapless Colin Myler was led by other papers as dog savaged dog.

Call the Independent : 'The News of the World 's public interest defence of its entrapment is utterly feeble; the newspaper deserves the strongest censure from the PCC. The tittle-tattle exposed by this sting cannot possibly justify the use of deception.'

Call the Telegraph , denouncing Sophie's humiliation as 'brutality and cowardice mingled'. What, it inquired, 'is happening to the tabloid press? There is a role for rough-and-ready journalism that exposes scandals of real public interest. Instead the Sunday Mirror , like the News of the World , seems intent on reversing declining circulation by desperate measures.'

The Guardian thought the Sunday Mirror had been 'idiotic' over its contempt of court and observed bleakly that 'the greater the [ NoW ] intrusion, the bigger the sales'.

Dominic Lawson in the Sunday Telegraph railed against 'the treachery of a disaffected ex-employee' (the whistleblower who shopped the Countess of Wessex). The Sun skipped for joy over its front page headline - 'What a Sunday Mirror Cock-up'.

Now some of this, of course, was pretty self-serving. The editors of the Sun and the Mirror (that 'cocky chancer' Piers Morgan, according to David Yelland of the Sun ) manifestly loathe each other. Rival groups will always put the boot in come what may. (The Daily Express's conclusion that the Myler debacle came because he was 'faced with declining circulation' was, in context, as ripe as they come).

But beyond it you could see the canyon that divides national newspapers. Call David Aaronovitch in the Indie: 'These horrible rags are ruining people's lives.'

There was no instant edge of fear to the reaction - because the politicians were otherwise engaged. Neither Tony Blair nor William Hague is going to threaten fresh legal retribution for the press. Both are much too busy trying to get elected. There are looming problems from a judiciary seemingly bent on writing its own ad hoc privacy laws after the incorporation of the European Convention into British law, but these are as yet inchoate. For once, journalists and editors felt free to say what they thought for themselves - as citizens, neighbours, human beings.

Call Simon Jenkins in the Times : 'A profession has a code of practice, rules of fairness and confidentiality,' he wrote. 'But the business of newspapers is so overwhelmed by market competition that most constraint has gone by the board.'

Though Jenkins doubled back to find some good in this anarchy, he nevertheless still wants legal sanctions on press freedom, just as he did when he sat a decade ago on the Calcutt committee.

The debate about whether journalism is a profession or a rough trade has now moved to centre stage. It is what Aaronovitch means when he concludes that 'most of the industry is ethics-free'.

Whatever success Lord Wakeham of the PCC claims for his efforts, the greatest sceptics are the ones emerging from inside the industry he serves. And, without doubt, they reflect the public opinion they know most intimately. They sit on public bodies which grimace over intrusion; they get asked to Palace parties; they may find themselves sitting next to Anna Ford at dinner in Kew.

Out in the regions, moreover, hundreds of editors who want to be part of their local communities feel the same pressures in their golf and Rotary clubs. Why should they be casually tossed into the same trash can as Rebekah Wade?

Slowly, inexorably, journalism seems to be splitting between the gentlemen and the players. That was the divide the PCC was invented to bridge. But for how long?

At which point, amid the hubbub, it seems right to enter a couple of pleas for the defence. Was the News of the World justified in setting a phoney sheikh to catch a countess? The PCC code of practice says that: 'Subterfuge can only be justified in the public interest and only when material cannot be obtained by other means.' Part of the definition of public interest allows 'exposing crime or a serious misdemeanour'.

Here the man who Dominic Lawson calls a treacherous ex-employee had been injuncted into silence. If his story was to be pursued, there were no other means. And what is a crime or serious misdemeanour?

Sophie has resigned; Murray Harkin has resigned; new, stricter guidelines are being promulgated. It's hard to say that something modestly 'serious' wasn't wrong here, unless you take the remarkably indulgent Telegraph view that 'given the circumstances - a businesswoman trying to impress a prospective client - it is easy to imagine how she might have gone much further'.

Equally the law of contempt remains much as the last great report on it (in 1965) concluded: a fount of 'uncertainty'. We have no means of knowing what will or won't happen to the Sunday Mirror (with or without its editor) but we do know, from a Mirror Group statement, that the usual assemblage of lawyers sat over the offending article for hours last Saturday afternoon and passed it for publication.

If there was a 'serious error of editorial judgment' then a largely uninvolved Myler has paid a very heavy price.

As ever, perhaps, it's not the splashiest cases that make the mood. Instead they may merely crystallise it. Mazher Mahmood, the NoW 's 'investigations editor', has been togging himself out as a sheikh for years and sniffing 'coketales' round every corner. The image of tabloids out of control is a continuum, not a sudden development.

Is there the supposed desperation of falling circulation here? That's much harder to sustain. Of course, Colin Myler wasn't the only editor to resign last week: Janet Street-Porter walked the plank at a becalmed Independent on Sunday . Circulation does matter (and has surely helped a beleaguered Morgan of the Mirror ). Rupert Murdoch, for one, isn't keen on privacy laws which would knock the stuffing out of the Sun . But an inside page spread (pages 8 and 9) of the Sunday Mirror is hardly a panzer thrust for sales - and Wade havered embarrassingly for a week before printing the Sophie tapes.

The more difficult question is the one posed, along the way, by the Telegraph 's leader writer. If there is a 'role for rough-and-ready journalism', what is it? Chris Blackhurst, lately deputy editor of Richard Desmond's very rough-and-ready Express , gave his answer in the Independent . Remember the Sun pursuing Bruce Grobbelaar, or Sunday Times stingers trawling Parliament with cash for questions? 'Those stories give entrapment a good name,' he wrote. 'Without them we would continue to believe in our own sweet, naive way that sports stars always try their hardest and that our politicians are only interested in working for us.'

The problem for journalists now - half rough trade, half profession - is deciding who they are. Lofty columnists can columnise, editors hobnob with royalty: but where is the raw edge of news to come from? Is all life to be a genteel averting of eyes over something nasty at the end of the Telegraph's garden?

There are always new influences in play. When the Sunday Mirror fell into contempt, Trinity Mirror's share price plunged with it. But expect no miraculous consensus on last week's form. Was Myler a bungler getting his cards or a pleasant professional defeated by the system? Was Rebekah Wade a wild woman rampaging again, or a nervous Nellie covering her back?

While journalists themselves can't agree, there will always be trouble - and another lousy week with the neighbours.
